Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Rationales: If he babysits for 2 hours at $7 per hour, he will earn 2*7 = $<<2*7=14>>14<n>This week he will earn $5 allowance, $10 mowing the lawn and $14 from babysitting for a total of 5+10+14 = $<<5+10+14=29>>29<n>If we add the $29 he will earn to his $65 savings, he will have a total of 29 + 65 = $<<29+65=94>>94<n>The bike costs $100 and he will have $94 leaving $100-$94 = $<<100-94=6>>6 more that he will need to earn<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Rationales: His kangaroos have a total of 23*2=<<23*2=46>>46 legs<n>He has 23*3=<<23*3=69>>69 goats<n>The goats have 69*4=<<69*4=276>>276 legs<n>So in total his animals have 276+46=<<276+46=322>>322 legs<n>#### 322<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Rationales: After buying a hat, Josh has $20 - $10 = $<<20-10=10>>10<n>After buying a pencil, Josh has $10 - $2 = $<<10-2=8>>8<n>The total cost of cookies is 4 * $1.25 = $<<4*1.25=5>>5<n>After buying the cookies, Josh has $8 - $5 = $<<8-5=3>>3<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input:Google Maps and other highway and street GPS services have replaced what? Choices:  A: united states B: mexico C: countryside D: atlas E: oceans<n><n>### Response:		 A:united states<n><n>### Input and Output: 2011<n>Output: The 2011 tornado season was:<n>1. Not as bad as the 2010 season.<n>2. As bad as the 2/21/2011 tornados in north Alabama killed nearly 300 people.<n>3. As bad as the Joplin, MO 5/26/11 tornado that killed 158.<n>4. Better than either of the above years.<n><n>#### 4<n>Answer: 3,2,1<n><n><n><n><n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Rationales: If he babysits for 2 hours at $7 per hour, he will earn 2*7 = $<<2*7=14>>14<n>This week he will earn $5 allowance, $10 mowing the lawn and $14 from babysitting for a total of 5+10+14 = $<<5+10+14=29>>29<n>If we add the $29 he will earn to his $65 savings, he will have a total of 29 + 65 = $<<29+65=94>>94<n>The bike costs $100 and he will have $94 leaving $100-$94 = $<<100-94=6>>6 more that he will need to earn<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Rationales: His kangaroos have a total of 23*2=<<23*2=46>>46 legs<n>He has 23*3=<<23*3=69>>69 goats<n>The goats have 69*4=<<69*4=276>>276 legs<n>So in total his animals have 276+46=<<276+46=322>>322 legs<n>#### 322<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Rationales: After buying a hat, Josh has $20 - $10 = $<<20-10=10>>10<n>After buying a pencil, Josh has $10 - $2 = $<<10-2=8>>8<n>The total cost of cookies is 4 * $1.25 = $<<4*1.25=5>>5<n>After buying the cookies, Josh has $8 - $5 = $<<8-5=3>>3<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input:The forgotten leftovers had gotten quite old, he found it covered in mold in the back of his what? Choices:  A: carpet B: refrigerator C: breadbox D: fridge E: coach<n><n>### Response:		Answers and explanations:<n><n>### Demand:If the amount of mold isn't a factor in determining what happens to the forgotten, old leftovers, the amount of time left in the leftovers life would be a factor in determining the leftovers death.<n>After a certain amount of time, the life support of the leftovers would run out, causing it to die.<n><n>### Response 1:<n>After a certain amount a time, the life support  the leftovers' leftovers food life would run out, causing the leftovers to go bad and die.<n><n>## Easy:<n>Easy is the same as a good but not the same as hard.<n><n>### Hard:<n>Hard is the same as more hard but not the same as easy.<n><n>### Medium:<n>Medium is the same as medium but not the same as a hard.<n><n>## Rather:<n>Rather is more rather that rather not.<n><n>### Rather than:<n>Rather than is more rather than.<n><n>### Not very:<n>Not very is more not very than.<n><n>#### Not quite:<n>Not quite is more not quite than.<n><n>## A little:<n>A little is more a little than a little.<n><n><n><n><n><n>

Choices:  A: harder B: anguish C: bitterness D: tears E: sadness<n><n>### Response:		<n>My answer is B ANGUISH<n><n>### Demostration:<n>Input: A man is driving 5 miles below the speed limit.  He runs a red light and gets into a serious car accident.  The police officer issues him a citation for running the red light.  During his trial, the judge asks the man is driving 50 miles below the speed limit he does not pay attention and his lawyer argues that his driving habits are what caused the serious car accident, not the red light.  The judge says that the man needs to make major cutbacks to his driving habits.  The man starts driving faster than the speed limit and crashes into another car.  The judge increases the fines for the violation of driving too fast.  What does the judge do when a driver makes a cutback to safer driving habits after crashing into another car?<n>Rationales:: A:The judge increases the fines<n>Since he made a cutback to his driving habits, he was driving faster than the speed-limit, which resulted in a serious car accident, where he caused another car to crash into him.<n><n>####B:The judge cuts the man's punishment because he started driving safer.<n>After committing the car accident, the man realized that he caused the accident, and made major cutbacks to safer driving habibs.<n><n>####C:The judge gives the man no punishment because he drives at the speed limit.<n>He has been driving at the speed limit for a long time, which is acceptable to the judge.<n><n>####D:The judge stops driving and punishes the man severely for doing so.<n>It's an ironic statement.<n><n>####E:The judge stops driving forever because he is not allowed to drive at all.<n>It is an ironic statement.  In other words, when he realized that he caused an accident, he made major cutbacks on his driving habits, but still suffered more punishments than before.<n><n>####B ANGUISH<n>Answer:B ANGUISH B ANGUISH BANGIUS DAGUISH<n><n>

If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Rationales: After buying a hat, Josh has $20 - $10 = $<<20-10=10>>10<n>After buying a pencil, Josh has $10 - $2 = $<<10-2=8>>8<n>The total cost of cookies is 4 * $1.25 = $<<4*1.25=5>>5<n>After buying the cookies, Josh has $8 - $5 = $<<8-5=3>>3<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input:Too many people want exotic snakes.  The demand is driving what to carry them? Choices:  A: ditch B: shop C: north america D: pet shops E: outdoors<n><n>### Response:		How many pairs of ears does the snake lose from the end of the line?<n><n>### Answer:The snake loses 4 pairs of ears from the end of the snake to make room for exotic snakes, 5 feet of snake, 2 pairs of snakes and a snake handler.<n><n>#### How many pairs of ears does snake lose from an end to the end?<n>Answer: -4<n><n>```jsx<n><p>How many pairs of ears do snakes lose from the end of a 2,000 snake line?</p><n><p>Choices:</p><n><ul><n>  <li>A: ditch</li><n>  <li><b>B: shop</b></li><n>  <ul><n>    <li>C: north america</li><n>    <li><b>D: pet shops</b></li> <n>    <ul><n>      <li>E: outdoors</li><n>      <ul><n>        <li>3: 4 pairs</li><n>      </ul><n>    </li><n>  </ul><n>  <ul>"The demand is driving what through them?"</ul><n></ul><n>```<n><n>#### How many snakes will be 6 feet long with how many pairs of ears?<n>Answer: 4 snakes, 4<n><n>```js<n><p>How can the snake handler get four pairs of snakes with 4 paws from an end of a snake line?</div></p><n>```<n><n>### Instructor Answer:4<n><n>### The answers for the above are 49,9, 12,7, 2, 2<n><n>### Instructions:Answer any letter that has the word "snakes" in it.<n><n>### Input A: <n><n>### Output A: <n><n>```jsx {.mb-8 }<n><p>Dear snake handler,</p><n><blockquote><n>  I do not eat mice but I do eat people.<n></blockquote><n>```<n><n>```jsx{.mb-20}<n><p>How could you save time making snake earrings? Choices: A: eat mice quickly B: eat
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Rationales: If he babysits for 2 hours at $7 per hour, he will earn 2*7 = $<<2*7=14>>14<n>This week he will earn $5 allowance, $10 mowing the lawn and $14 from babysitting for a total of 5+10+14 = $<<5+10+14=29>>29<n>If we add the $29 he will earn to his $65 savings, he will have a total of 29 + 65 = $<<29+65=94>>94<n>The bike costs $100 and he will have $94 leaving $100-$94 = $<<100-94=6>>6 more that he will need to earn<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Rationales: His kangaroos have a total of 23*2=<<23*2=46>>46 legs<n>He has 23*3=<<23*3=69>>69 goats<n>The goats have 69*4=<<69*4=276>>276 legs<n>So in total his animals have 276+46=<<276+46=322>>322 legs<n>#### 322<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Rationales: After buying a hat, Josh has $20 - $10 = $<<20-10=10>>10<n>After buying a pencil, Josh has $10 - $2 = $<<10-2=8>>8<n>The total cost of cookies is 4 * $1.25 = $<<4*1.25=5>>5<n>After buying the cookies, Josh has $8 - $5 = $<<8-5=3>>3<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input:He wanted a house that was gated off from other places, where should he start looking? Choices:  A: neighborhood B: subdivision C: city D: suburbs E: street<n><n>### Response:		<n>#### Answer:E<n><n>### Input and Demonstration: If a student earned a 79% in his Algebra 1 class, what grade does he earn in the class? Choices:  B: D  C: C  D: F  E: A  F: B<n><n>### Answer:<n>#### Answer:D<n><n>### Input, Demonstration and Workings: Sarah’s mom asked her to make 19 cookies from a recipe that called for 28 cups of flour, but she forgot to adjust the recipe. How many extra cups of flour does Sarah need to add to the mix so that there was a little extra since the cookies were so big? Choices: A: 1 B: 2 C: N/A  D: 8<n><n>#### Answer:<n>#### Answer : D<n><n>### Input.Demonstraion<n>Rachel bought a chocolate chip cookie for $1.00 in the cafeteria one day. The next day she bought a cookie again, but this time it cost $1.03. Why is the cookie more expensive? Choices: A) She bought two cookies instead of one. B) A bake sale was going on and the cookies cost more.  Choices: C) It was a different brand.  Choices: D) The cafeteria changed the price that day.  <n><n>### Demostration:<n>#### Answer: C<n><n>### Instructions:<n>#### Answer: D<n><n>#### Answer: D: <n><n>#### Answer:C<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Rationales: If he babysits for 2 hours at $7 per hour, he will earn 2*7 = $<<2*7=14>>14<n>This week he will earn $5 allowance, $10 mowing the lawn and $14 from babysitting for a total of 5+10+14 = $<<5+10+14=29>>29<n>If we add the $29 he will earn to his $65 savings, he will have a total of 29 + 65 = $<<29+65=94>>94<n>The bike costs $100 and he will have $94 leaving $100-$94 = $<<100-94=6>>6 more that he will need to earn<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Rationales: His kangaroos have a total of 23*2=<<23*2=46>>46 legs<n>He has 23*3=<<23*3=69>>69 goats<n>The goats have 69*4=<<69*4=276>>276 legs<n>So in total his animals have 276+46=<<276+46=322>>322 legs<n>#### 322<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Rationales: After buying a hat, Josh has $20 - $10 = $<<20-10=10>>10<n>After buying a pencil, Josh has $10 - $2 = $<<10-2=8>>8<n>The total cost of cookies is 4 * $1.25 = $<<4*1.25=5>>5<n>After buying the cookies, Josh has $8 - $5 = $<<8-5=3>>3<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input:Mark's semen was very thick, but after his vasectomy it was also what? Choices:  A: blank B: sparse C: thin D: clear E: free flowing<n><n>### Response:		<n>The correct answer is A: Thick.<n><n>### Note<n><n>### Demo:<n><n>### Instructions:Answer the following multiple-choice question.<n><n>## 2. Answer the following multiple choice question correctly.<n><n><n>## Instructions:<n><n>In the problem below, write two responses. Select one to use only the numbers 0 to 100, where 0 is represented by the number 0 and 100 is represented by the word one hundred. Explain how you can use the correct mathematical symbol and place value in your response.<n><n>Input: 23 +8<n>Rationale: Use the addition symbol to add. Use tens place 2 to make 2 tens and three ones + 8, so the answer is _____.<n>#### 103<n>Answer: 103<n>Input: 8 - 22<n>Rationale: 8 and 22 are positive numbers. The subtraction symbol is used to delete. Subtract the ones from 8 and then subtract the tens from 22 which is 22-0 = 22. This means ______.<n>#### 20<n>Answer: 20
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Rationales: If he babysits for 2 hours at $7 per hour, he will earn 2*7 = $<<2*7=14>>14<n>This week he will earn $5 allowance, $10 mowing the lawn and $14 from babysitting for a total of 5+10+14 = $<<5+10+14=29>>29<n>If we add the $29 he will earn to his $65 savings, he will have a total of 29 + 65 = $<<29+65=94>>94<n>The bike costs $100 and he will have $94 leaving $100-$94 = $<<100-94=6>>6 more that he will need to earn<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Rationales: His kangaroos have a total of 23*2=<<23*2=46>>46 legs<n>He has 23*3=<<23*3=69>>69 goats<n>The goats have 69*4=<<69*4=276>>276 legs<n>So in total his animals have 276+46=<<276+46=322>>322 legs<n>#### 322<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Rationales: After buying a hat, Josh has $20 - $10 = $<<20-10=10>>10<n>After buying a pencil, Josh has $10 - $2 = $<<10-2=8>>8<n>The total cost of cookies is 4 * $1.25 = $<<4*1.25=5>>5<n>After buying the cookies, Josh has $8 - $5 = $<<8-5=3>>3<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input:Sitting to close while watching TV can cause what sort of pain? Choices:  A: brain problems B: laziness C: get fat D: headache E: laughter<n><n>### Response:		 A -> Brain problems<n><n>### Rationale:Headaches<n><n>### Input<n>Mary has 10 red marbles and 10 blue marbles. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Rationales: If he babysits for 2 hours at $7 per hour, he will earn 2*7 = $<<2*7=14>>14<n>This week he will earn $5 allowance, $10 mowing the lawn and $14 from babysitting for a total of 5+10+14 = $<<5+10+14=29>>29<n>If we add the $29 he will earn to his $65 savings, he will have a total of 29 + 65 = $<<29+65=94>>94<n>The bike costs $100 and he will have $94 leaving $100-$94 = $<<100-94=6>>6 more that he will need to earn<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Rationales: His kangaroos have a total of 23*2=<<23*2=46>>46 legs<n>He has 23*3=<<23*3=69>>69 goats<n>The goats have 69*4=<<69*4=276>>276 legs<n>So in total his animals have 276+46=<<276+46=322>>322 legs<n>#### 322<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Rationales: After buying a hat, Josh has $20 - $10 = $<<20-10=10>>10<n>After buying a pencil, Josh has $10 - $2 = $<<10-2=8>>8<n>The total cost of cookies is 4 * $1.25 = $<<4*1.25=5>>5<n>After buying the cookies, Josh has $8 - $5 = $<<8-5=3>>3<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input:What is eating too much dinner likely to result in? Choices:  A: tiredness B: living longer C: stomach ache D: illness E: acid reflux<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>### Question<n>When someone eats too much dinner, they are likely to result in living longer.<n><n>### Rationale<n>Eating too much dinner for a person who is very young does not always guarantee that they will be unhealthy.<n>Eating too much for someone who is adult results in living longer.<n>A small amount of extra food does not always cause health problems.<n>It is easy to eat too much dinner because it is very easy to have dinner in abundance.<n><n>If we look at the entire population it makes sense that people who eat a lot die sooner than those who are careful with their portions.<n><n>### Answer<n>C
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Rationales: If he babysits for 2 hours at $7 per hour, he will earn 2*7 = $<<2*7=14>>14<n>This week he will earn $5 allowance, $10 mowing the lawn and $14 from babysitting for a total of 5+10+14 = $<<5+10+14=29>>29<n>If we add the $29 he will earn to his $65 savings, he will have a total of 29 + 65 = $<<29+65=94>>94<n>The bike costs $100 and he will have $94 leaving $100-$94 = $<<100-94=6>>6 more that he will need to earn<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Rationales: His kangaroos have a total of 23*2=<<23*2=46>>46 legs<n>He has 23*3=<<23*3=69>>69 goats<n>The goats have 69*4=<<69*4=276>>276 legs<n>So in total his animals have 276+46=<<276+46=322>>322 legs<n>#### 322<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. Choices:  A: finish line B: broken bones C: broken legs D: chapped lips E: healthy body<n><n>### Response:		I chose E Healthy body<n><n>## Euler's Number<n><n>Infinity divided by 1<n><n>### Factorial of 6<n><n>1 * 2 * 3 * 4 * 5 * 6<n><n>### 6!<n><n>### Floor Division<n><n>### Natural log<n><n>## Euler<n><n>### Euler's constant<n><n>## Eulerian<n><n>This page is based on the copyrighted Wikipedia article "{{int:imagename}}" (Authors); it is used under the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike 3.0 Unported License. What might the cops do to him? Choices:  A: going to jail B: going to prison C: beat him up D: get arrested E: die<n><n>### Response:		<n>Choice "A" and "E" don't fit because Jim killing people did not result in him going to jail or prison. Choice "A" and "B" don't fit either because Jim enjoys killing people. The cops could have "beat him up" but this would not make Jim enjoy it more.<n><n>### Choice:<n>Choice "D"<n><n>### Explanation "D":<n>The cops did get arrested because he enjoyed killing people because then Jim can beat his captors up.<n><n>### Output:<n>In this context Jim beat people up that were captured.  He's now in custody and he could lose his life.  If the cops beat him up, Jim might like that more because then he could beat the cops up.<n>#### 55<n>Score_01: true.<n><n>### Additional Information:<n>This test is designed for a school that teaches grades K-12.  This task could be taught at any grade or to a college student. <n><n>This is a language and concept test.  It is to determine whether or not the student understands verbal directions and their reasoning skills.  The task is shortened to save time where necessary. <n><n>### Sample Outline:<n>Start with one small task that requires a lot of detail in the instructions.<n><n>End with a "what-else" problem or one that requires multiple choices.<n><n>### Test Format:<n>Multiple choice, verbal tasks.<n><n>* 0001: The tasks are presented in multiple choice format.<n>* 0010: Answers correspond to the correct choices.<n>* 0100: A student is asked to answer the question.<n>* 0200: No answer is given.<n>* 0990: The score report will not generate for these test questions.<n>* 16777216: This score is reserved for future use.<n><n>### Comments / Corrections<n>Send comments and/or corrections to [contact@examity.com](mailto:contact@examity).<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Rationales: If he babysits for 2 hours at $7 per hour, he will earn 2*7 = $<<2*7=14>>14<n>This week he will earn $5 allowance, $10 mowing the lawn and $14 from babysitting for a total of 5+10+14 = $<<5+10+14=29>>29<n>If we add the $29 he will earn to his $65 savings, he will have a total of 29 + 65 = $<<29+65=94>>94<n>The bike costs $100 and he will have $94 leaving $100-$94 = $<<100-94=6>>6 more that he will need to earn<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Rationales: His kangaroos have a total of 23*2=<<23*2=46>>46 legs<n>He has 23*3=<<23*3=69>>69 goats<n>The goats have 69*4=<<69*4=276>>276 legs<n>So in total his animals have 276+46=<<276+46=322>>322 legs<n>#### 322<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Rationales: After buying a hat, Josh has $20 - $10 = $<<20-10=10>>10<n>After buying a pencil, Josh has $10 - $2 = $<<10-2=8>>8<n>The total cost of cookies is 4 * $1.25 = $<<4*1.25=5>>5<n>After buying the cookies, Josh has $8 - $5 = $<<8-5=3>>3<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input:What is a grumpy person likely to have? Choices:  A: headache B: understand themselves C: compliments D: own house E: happiness<n><n>### Response:		<n>A:headache<n><n>### Rationales:A person who is grumpy is likely to feel grumpy, and someone who feels grumpy will likely have a headache.<n>A person that is grumpy can also have a headache<n>A person that is likely to have a headache is also grumpy<n>A person who feels grumpy is also likely to have a head<n>#### 4<n>Answer: 3.<n><n>### Input : Write two sentences that follow the rules:<n>- Start with a capital letter.<n>- End with a period.<n>- Contain a single space between words.<n>- Contain at least three punctuation marks.<n>- Contain three words separated by a single space.<n><n>### Response : <n><n>The bouncing bunny on the green grass at the park was hopping. The jumping jack on the yellow mat at the playground was jumping.<n><n>### Rationale:<n>- Start with capital letter (The)<n>- End with a dot (.)<n>- Words separated by a space (the bouncing Bunny on the green grass...)<n>- Capital letter and space at the beginning of every word (on the green grass...)<n>- Capital letter at the end of the sentence<n>- At least three punctuation mark (, /. )<n>- At least four words (the bouncing bun... )<n>- Single space between words (at the green grass... )<n><n>#### 5<n>Answer: 5<n><n>

How many different colored candies can you get? You can only take one candy from the bag at a time.<n><n>### Examine<n>4 Candies<n><n>### Solution<n>The first way is to use the coloring function and set the 4 different colors for the 4 colored candies. To do this, click on ‘Coloring’ on the top bar and set it to 4. For the color numbering you can use the same numbers of the 4 candies that you got on the start screen, (1-4). Now you can take one candies at a time from the bag when it’s clicked on and you will see that the 4 distinct colors will go away (i.e red, orange, red and orange.)<n><n>### Instructions<n>If two whole numbers are such that 21 = <<21=8>>8 is their difference what is the number of digits they both have?<n><n>### Demostration<n>Given 21 = 8, we can say that x=21-y<n>y = x+8<n>5 = x-8<n>x = 5+8 =<<5+8=13>>13<n>x = 13-y<n>y = 13+8<n>11 = 13-8<n>y = 11+8<n>19 = y-8<n>y =27<n>y = 27+8<n>35 = y-8<n>### Rationales:<n><n>Answer is 11<n><n><n># Instruction:Answer three multiple choice questions.<n># Demonstration:(Input: There are a total of 35 students in a class. 10 of the students are girls. 15 of the students are boys. 10 of these student are in

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Rationales: If he babysits for 2 hours at $7 per hour, he will earn 2*7 = $<<2*7=14>>14<n>This week he will earn $5 allowance, $10 mowing the lawn and $14 from babysitting for a total of 5+10+14 = $<<5+10+14=29>>29<n>If we add the $29 he will earn to his $65 savings, he will have a total of 29 + 65 = $<<29+65=94>>94<n>The bike costs $100 and he will have $94 leaving $100-$94 = $<<100-94=6>>6 more that he will need to earn<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Rationales: His kangaroos have a total of 23*2=<<23*2=46>>46 legs<n>He has 23*3=<<23*3=69>>69 goats<n>The goats have 69*4=<<69*4=276>>276 legs<n>So in total his animals have 276+46=<<276+46=322>>322 legs<n>#### 322<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Rationales: After buying a hat, Josh has $20 - $10 = $<<20-10=10>>10<n>After buying a pencil, Josh has $10 - $2 = $<<10-2=8>>8<n>The total cost of cookies is 4 * $1.25 = $<<4*1.25=5>>5<n>After buying the cookies, Josh has $8 - $5 = $<<8-5=3>>3<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input:Where would a person keep a book while it's being read? Choices:  A: closet B: library of congress C: classroom D: in bed E: desk<n><n>### Response:		<n>C<n><n>### Input<n>How many gallons of water does a human consume in a year? Answer in gallons.<n>1. 76<n>2. 100<n>3. 126<n>4. 200<n><n>### Response<n>1<n><n>### Demostration<n>You are a farmer who sells your apples to a grocery store.  How can you  be sure of maximizing the total amount of money that you earn, as a farmer? <n><n>Rationales: I can ensure I earn as much as I can by selling all but 5 of the apples.  The total number of apples I have is 30.  When I subtract the number of apples I am going to sell from 5, I get 25.  My income will be 25 times 1000 which is 25000.<n><n>#### 2500<n>Answer: 2500

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Rationales: If he babysits for 2 hours at $7 per hour, he will earn 2*7 = $<<2*7=14>>14<n>This week he will earn $5 allowance, $10 mowing the lawn and $14 from babysitting for a total of 5+10+14 = $<<5+10+14=29>>29<n>If we add the $29 he will earn to his $65 savings, he will have a total of 29 + 65 = $<<29+65=94>>94<n>The bike costs $100 and he will have $94 leaving $100-$94 = $<<100-94=6>>6 more that he will need to earn<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Rationales: His kangaroos have a total of 23*2=<<23*2=46>>46 legs<n>He has 23*3=<<23*3=69>>69 goats<n>The goats have 69*4=<<69*4=276>>276 legs<n>So in total his animals have 276+46=<<276+46=322>>322 legs<n>#### 322<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Rationales: After buying a hat, Josh has $20 - $10 = $<<20-10=10>>10<n>After buying a pencil, Josh has $10 - $2 = $<<10-2=8>>8<n>The total cost of cookies is 4 * $1.25 = $<<4*1.25=5>>5<n>After buying the cookies, Josh has $8 - $5 = $<<8-5=3>>3<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input:The fat man refused to accept what was possible, he complained that he what the simplest activities? She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100. He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Rationales: If he babysits for 2 hours at $7 per hour, he will earn 2*7 = $<<2*7=14>>14<n>This week he will earn $5 allowance, $10 mowing the lawn and $14 from babysitting for a total of 5+10+14 = $<<5+10+14=29>>29<n>If we add the $29 he will earn to his $65 savings, he will have a total of 29 + 65 = $<<29+65=94>>94<n>The bike costs $100 and he will have $94 leaving $100-$94 = $<<100-94=6>>6 more that he will need to earn<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Rationales: If he babysits for 2 hours at $7 per hour, he will earn 2*7 = $<<2*7=14>>14<n>This week he will earn $5 allowance, $10 mowing the lawn and $14 from babysitting for a total of 5+10+14 = $<<5+10+14=29>>29<n>If we add the $29 he will earn to his $65 savings, he will have a total of 29 + 65 = $<<29+65=94>>94<n>The bike costs $100 and he will have $94 leaving $100-$94 = $<<100-94=6>>6 more that he will need to earn<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Rationales: His kangaroos have a total of 23*2=<<23*2=46>>46 legs<n>He has 23*3=<<23*3=69>>69 goats<n>The goats have 69*4=<<69*4=276>>276 legs<n>So in total his animals have 276+46=<<276+46=322>>322 legs<n>#### 322<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Rationales: After buying a hat, Josh has $20 - $10 = $<<20-10=10>>10<n>After buying a pencil, Josh has $10 - $2 = $<<10-2=8>>8<n>The total cost of cookies is 4 * $1.25 = $<<4*1.25=5>>5<n>After buying the cookies, Josh has $8 - $5 = $<<8-5=3>>3<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input:Though it stayed strictly indoors, the small dog felt like it had all the space in the world in the what? Choices:  A: living room B: dog park C: basket D: small apartment E: big house<n><n>### Response:		D<n>Input: Thought it stayed strictly indoored, the small dog felt likes it had all the space is the world in the what:A basket, D small apartment, B dog park, C: E Big house.<n><n>### Answer:D<n>### Demianstration:<n>##### Thought it stayed strictly in the dog felt like the was all the space in the dog house.<n><n>##### The dog house was small and that may made the dog feel like was all the space in in. <n><n>### E<n>If I was a dog then I may feel like I had all the space in my house because i am small for.<n>The dog house is the place that the dog stays.<n>The dog house contains a small house. <n><n>The dog house is an apartment/house that contains a small house/apartment called the dog house. Therefore, I would think i had all the space in in the dog house. <n><n>## Question:<n>How much is 10 pounds in ounces?<n><n>### Demiantration:<n>560.06151<n>

His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Rationales: If he babysits for 2 hours at $7 per hour, he will earn 2*7 = $<<2*7=14>>14<n>This week he will earn $5 allowance, $10 mowing the lawn and $14 from babysitting for a total of 5+10+14 = $<<5+10+14=29>>29<n>If we add the $29 he will earn to his $65 savings, he will have a total of 29 + 65 = $<<29+65=94>>94<n>The bike costs $100 and he will have $94 leaving $100-$94 = $<<100-94=6>>6 more that he will need to earn<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs. Choices:  A: picnic B: friend's house C: table D: space shuttle E: fairgrounds<n><n>### Response:		The choice is option A: picnic.<n><n>### Input;John loves to learn new things, if he knew a person who knew a person who... would he know 804 people. Choices: A: a lot of people B: just one person C: more than him D: 4 people E: not very many<n><n>### Response; The choice is option C: more than him.<n><n>### Rationale: John does not currently know an "804th" person so he does not know any of them, if he meets one he will know "just one person" and then "one person's" friend, and so on until he has "knowledged" the "804th person"<n><n><n> <n>### Input:A: 580 B: 270 C: 370 D: 470 E: 670<n> <n>### Demonstraion;<n>This question has been asked and answered previously(470). The current asker is going to need to find another person to find out the 470th person who knows someone 470 people removed from where John is currently at,  he is going to have to keep doing this as long "as you haven’t asked yet"<n><n>### Input 2:What number is twice as many as 65% of 48?<n>### Demonstation:<n>70% of 48 = <<70%*48=33>>33<n>2 * 33 = <<2*33=76>>76<n>Twice as many is 2*76 = <<2*76=152>>152<n>### Rationale<n><n><n>### Input3:There are 8 bags of sand from 2 different sources, each bag of sand weighs 11 pounds. She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100. He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Rationales: If he babysits for 2 hours at $7 per hour, he will earn 2*7 = $<<2*7=14>>14<n>This week he will earn $5 allowance, $10 mowing the lawn and $14 from babysitting for a total of 5+10+14 = $<<5+10+14=29>>29<n>If we add the $29 he will earn to his $65 savings, he will have a total of 29 + 65 = $<<29+65=94>>94<n>The bike costs $100 and he will have $94 leaving $100-$94 = $<<100-94=6>>6 more that he will need to earn<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs. Choices:  A: auditorium B: office C: synagogue D: confession E: church<n><n>### Response:		<n>Input: Choice A - auditorium.<n>Auditoriums are large rooms where there would be many people sitting in chairs listening to religious speeches.<n><n>#### Auditorium<n><n>### Comments:<n>Input: Input was in the response format, so the choice to choose the answer was already correct.<n><n>Input:  A: auditiorum B: office C: church D: synagogue E: confession <n><n>```python<n>import re<n><n>def main():<n>    string = input()<n>    words = []<n>    for choice in string.split(' '):<n>        if len(choice) == 1:<n>            words.append('A')<n>        else:<n>            words.extend(choice.split())<n><n>    print('Auditorium:'if 'auditorium' in words else 'Not a word')<n>    for word in words:<n>        if word == 'Auditorium':<n>            print(word)<n>            break<n><n>main()<n>```<n><n>### Demolition:<n><n>![](figures/50-48-01.jpg)<n>

How many pizzas do you need to bake to have the same number of pizzas ordered for lunch during Sunday at baseball game at an outdoor event at a concert?<n>Rationales : 30 pizzas ordered in one day is the same as 15 pizzas with three orders. 15 pizzaz at a baseball game is the same as 7 pizzas for each Saturday lunch, 4 pizzas for outdoor event and 2 pizzas for Sundaty Baseball.<n>#### 24<n><n>Total # of pizzas baked = <<76+30+12+24>>76+30=230 pizzas <n>Because we add the the total # of pizzas for Saturday, the outdoor event, baseball game and a concert. <n>30+76+12+28 = 23<n>#### 23<n><n>230 + 23 = 253 pizzas<n>#### 253<n><n><n>#### Input and Response:<n>Input is a pie-chart and response is a bar-chart.

How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Rationales: If he babysits for 2 hours at $7 per hour, he will earn 2*7 = $<<2*7=14>>14<n>This week he will earn $5 allowance, $10 mowing the lawn and $14 from babysitting for a total of 5+10+14 = $<<5+10+14=29>>29<n>If we add the $29 he will earn to his $65 savings, he will have a total of 29 + 65 = $<<29+65=94>>94<n>The bike costs $100 and he will have $94 leaving $100-$94 = $<<100-94=6>>6 more that he will need to earn<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Rationales: His kangaroos have a total of 23*2=<<23*2=46>>46 legs<n>He has 23*3=<<23*3=69>>69 goats<n>The goats have 69*4=<<69*4=276>>276 legs<n>So in total his animals have 276+46=<<276+46=322>>322 legs<n>#### 322<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Rationales: After buying a hat, Josh has $20 - $10 = $<<20-10=10>>10<n>After buying a pencil, Josh has $10 - $2 = $<<10-2=8>>8<n>The total cost of cookies is 4 * $1.25 = $<<4*1.25=5>>5<n>After buying the cookies, Josh has $8 - $5 = $<<8-5=3>>3<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input:What might a kid do with his friend before going to play? Choices:  A: laugh B: sit C: being entertained D: math E: meet<n><n>### Response:		Input:Mary saw a girl walking down the sidewalk. The girl was carrying her dog and her lunchbox.  Was Mary right when she said that the girl had her lunchbox and dog on her left?<n>Rationalize: Mary was NOT right.  Lunch-boxes are generally placed on the student's left, but the dog was not.<n>This is evidence that Mary was incorrect because her statement, “the girl with dog walks her lunchbox on her left” was not true.  In fact, Mary was incorrect and she was able to come to a conclusion based on incorrect information.<n>#### Answer: Mary was incorrect<n><n>###Input:The teacher asked how many sticks the kids had.  Choices: A: 6, B: 4, C: 8, D: 5, E: 7<n><n>###Response: Input:The kids made a sticks count.  Which counted sticks did they use?<n>Rationales::The kids used all the sticks, but they did not use the total number of sticks.  6/6=1,8/5=1.6, 8/6=1.33, 2/7=0.28, 1/4=0.25.<n><n>The sticks add up to a total of:1+1+1,28+25=<0.28+0.25=0.53>,<n><n>#### 0.53<n>Answer:0.53<n><n>###Instruction:Answer the following open-ended item.<n><n>###Demostration: In the school play the kids used 214 books. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Rationales: If he babysits for 2 hours at $7 per hour, he will earn 2*7 = $<<2*7=14>>14<n>This week he will earn $5 allowance, $10 mowing the lawn and $14 from babysitting for a total of 5+10+14 = $<<5+10+14=29>>29<n>If we add the $29 he will earn to his $65 savings, he will have a total of 29 + 65 = $<<29+65=94>>94<n>The bike costs $100 and he will have $94 leaving $100-$94 = $<<100-94=6>>6 more that he will need to earn<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Rationales: His kangaroos have a total of 23*2=<<23*2=46>>46 legs<n>He has 23*3=<<23*3=69>>69 goats<n>The goats have 69*4=<<69*4=276>>276 legs<n>So in total his animals have 276+46=<<276+46=322>>322 legs<n>#### 322<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. Choices:  A= 4 B= 7 C= 5 D= 2 E=0<n><n>### Response:#2<n>### Input:Can babies have babies? Choices: 1: yes B: yes<n><n>### Response:"yes"<n><n>### Input:"Eight squared is..." Choices: A: not eight times itself B: eight<n><n>### Response:'not eight times itself'<n><n>### Input> What is 8 ÷ 3? Choices: A: 6 B: 0<n><n>### Rationales:<n>### If 8 divided by 3 is the answer, the quotient is how often you'd divide 8 with 3.<n>### Since 8 * 4 = 32, there is a remainder of 2<n><n>### If 32 divided by 8 is the answer, the remainder is 2<n>### Since 32 - 2 = 28, 8 is only divisive up to 28<n><n>### Answer;'0'<n><n>### What is the average speed of a squirrel?<n><n>### Rationale:Squirrels can run up to 30 miles per hour (Source: [here](https://bigwildlifeworld.com/facts/animals-that-can-run-the-fastest.html))<n>### Since the average squirrel's speed is faster than the average human's speed, we can equate the distance traveled by a squirrel to the time it takes a human to travel that distance. The average speed of a squirmel is 30 mph and the average person can only go 15 mph (Source: [here (2)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Modern_personal_record_list))<n>### The result is 0:30 mph, where 0 is the time taken to go the distance traveled and.30 represents the speed of 15 mph<n><n>#### 0:30<n>Answer: 0:30

His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Rationales: If he babysits for 2 hours at $7 per hour, he will earn 2*7 = $<<2*7=14>>14<n>This week he will earn $5 allowance, $10 mowing the lawn and $14 from babysitting for a total of 5+10+14 = $<<5+10+14=29>>29<n>If we add the $29 he will earn to his $65 savings, he will have a total of 29 + 65 = $<<29+65=94>>94<n>The bike costs $100 and he will have $94 leaving $100-$94 = $<<100-94=6>>6 more that he will need to earn<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Rationales: His kangaroos have a total of 23*2=<<23*2=46>>46 legs<n>He has 23*3=<<23*3=69>>69 goats<n>The goats have 69*4=<<69*4=276>>276 legs<n>So in total his animals have 276+46=<<276+46=322>>322 legs<n>#### 322<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Rationales: After buying a hat, Josh has $20 - $10 = $<<20-10=10>>10<n>After buying a pencil, Josh has $10 - $2 = $<<10-2=8>>8<n>The total cost of cookies is 4 * $1.25 = $<<4*1.25=5>>5<n>After buying the cookies, Josh has $8 - $5 = $<<8-5=3>>3<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input:Bob's feet hurt from running barefoot on the hot pavement.  I lost his shoes, didn't know where they landed, and had to run from the corner store to his home.  About where did he run? Choices:  A: a bed of nails B: town C: attractive consistent look D: city block E: ground<n><n>### Response:		 Bob ran to the city<n><n>### Reasons:<n>The clues suggest that he will likely be running on pavement, which is also known as a road or city block.<n><n>### Input<n>Choices: A: The pavement is rough and might have nails poking out of it, B The pavement is the same everywhere in town,<n>C: There is consistency and order on the pavement, D: The road may be long and winding, E: It is an even plane.<n>#### C<n><n>### Reaction:  He has to get to his destination. The city block is an evenly graded surface.<n><n>### Reason:<n>His feet hurt and he cant go barefoot so the surface needs to be an even plane. The road can be long and winding which means it isnt evenly graded.<n><n>### Choice:  D<n><n># Input:  <n>There are 9 apples on the table. Jenny and Jared each took 2 apples. How many apples are left on the table?<n><n>### A: <n>7 apples<n><n>### B:<n>5 apples<n><n># Input:<n>There are 9 cats in the petting zoo. Each cat has eyes of different colors.  There are 5 cats that just have one eye.  Jenny, Jessica, Jamie, and JJ all looked at a cat. In the beginning of the day there were a total of 32 cats. How many cats were seen by more than one person?<n>####<n>3 cats<n><n># Input: You have two choices:<n><n>### A <n>There are 5 apples, and you take 2 of them. You give the remaining to your sister. How many apples do you have now?<n>####<n>2 apples are left<n><n>### B<n>There are 5 cats, and Jenny takes 2. Jenny gives the remaining to Mary. How many cats do Jenny and Mary have?<n>####<n>3 apples. There are 3 apples between Jenny and Mary<n><n>### Reactions:<n><n>### You have a choice of 2:<n><n>#### A <n><n># You have one apple, and your sister comes over. You give her 6 apples, and you both have
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Rationales: If he babysits for 2 hours at $7 per hour, he will earn 2*7 = $<<2*7=14>>14<n>This week he will earn $5 allowance, $10 mowing the lawn and $14 from babysitting for a total of 5+10+14 = $<<5+10+14=29>>29<n>If we add the $29 he will earn to his $65 savings, he will have a total of 29 + 65 = $<<29+65=94>>94<n>The bike costs $100 and he will have $94 leaving $100-$94 = $<<100-94=6>>6 more that he will need to earn<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Rationales: His kangaroos have a total of 23*2=<<23*2=46>>46 legs<n>He has 23*3=<<23*3=69>>69 goats<n>The goats have 69*4=<<69*4=276>>276 legs<n>So in total his animals have 276+46=<<276+46=322>>322 legs<n>#### 322<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Rationales: After buying a hat, Josh has $20 - $10 = $<<20-10=10>>10<n>After buying a pencil, Josh has $10 - $2 = $<<10-2=8>>8<n>The total cost of cookies is 4 * $1.25 = $<<4*1.25=5>>5<n>After buying the cookies, Josh has $8 - $5 = $<<8-5=3>>3<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input:What could a massive building be if it is not constructed well? Choices:  A: insubstantial B: massless C: dwarf D: inconsequential E: good<n><n>### Response:		The best option to describe this kind of building is D: Consequential<n><n>### Instructions: Answer the following multiple choice question<n>#### Input: How do we know about dinosaurs’ existence? Choices: A: only in our dreams B: through books and documentaries C: because they are still alive D: they have fossilized eggs and bones<n><n>### Response 1: We can know about dinosaurs' existence through our dreams, books, and documentaries.<n><n>### Response2: We can know about the existence of dinosaurs through books, documentaries, and fossilized eggs and fossils.<n><n>### Feedback: We can know about existences through the following ways: books, documentaries, dreams, fossilized eggs and relics.<n><n>### Input : Which language is used in the Philippines, Choices: A: Spanish B: Chinese C: English D: Japanese<n><n>### Response<n>There are a total of 215 languages spoken in the Philippines. Filipino is the official language and is also the primary language.<n>#### 300<n>Answer: 300
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Rationales: If he babysits for 2 hours at $7 per hour, he will earn 2*7 = $<<2*7=14>>14<n>This week he will earn $5 allowance, $10 mowing the lawn and $14 from babysitting for a total of 5+10+14 = $<<5+10+14=29>>29<n>If we add the $29 he will earn to his $65 savings, he will have a total of 29 + 65 = $<<29+65=94>>94<n>The bike costs $100 and he will have $94 leaving $100-$94 = $<<100-94=6>>6 more that he will need to earn<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Rationales: His kangaroos have a total of 23*2=<<23*2=46>>46 legs<n>He has 23*3=<<23*3=69>>69 goats<n>The goats have 69*4=<<69*4=276>>276 legs<n>So in total his animals have 276+46=<<276+46=322>>322 legs<n>#### 322<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Rationales: After buying a hat, Josh has $20 - $10 = $<<20-10=10>>10<n>After buying a pencil, Josh has $10 - $2 = $<<10-2=8>>8<n>The total cost of cookies is 4 * $1.25 = $<<4*1.25=5>>5<n>After buying the cookies, Josh has $8 - $5 = $<<8-5=3>>3<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input:They moved out of the city to have a master bedroom, what kind of home did they seek? Choices:  A: large house B: suburban home C: big house D: old house E: keeping personal objects<n><n>### Response:		<n>A. Large house<n><n>### Rationale:<n>#### 40<n>Ans.: 40<n><n>### Input<n>They moved out of the country to have a large house, so we could choose A - large house.<n><n>A : B : C : D : E<n>________ ___________ ___________ __________ ____________<n>The choice of B or E does not matter.<n><n>B : C : D : _________ : E<n>_________ ___________ _________ _________ ____________<n>The remaining words are of the type they sought, and thus you can not answer this question.<n><n>##

Where might she look for one? Choices:  A: house B: music shop C: studio D: storage E: closet<n><n>### Response:		<n>If option A: house, this could mean that you would get a guitar from your home, where it may be just left laying around or in a cabinet. <n><n>This could mean that choice B: music shop, a guitar shop has a lot of guitars and music equipment. <n><n>If you chose choice C: studio, this could mean that there was a practice amp. <n><n>If option D: storage, a guitar that someone had decided to get rid of. <n><n>If choice E: closet, this could mean that a family member has an old guitar in the closet that hasn't been played in years, and now someone is learning the guitar.<n><n>The answer is E is the closet.<n><n>### Input : The new house doesn’t have a garage and they can’t park inside their house. But with a large backyard it may be enough room to park there. <n><n>Another option is the garage is filled with storage and they have nowhere else to park their cars because they can't fit into the garage.<n><n>The answer may be A - doesn't have a garage. <n><n>### Input:: James loves sports so he has 3 favorite teams from different sports: baseball, basketball, and golf. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Rationales: If he babysits for 2 hours at $7 per hour, he will earn 2*7 = $<<2*7=14>>14<n>This week he will earn $5 allowance, $10 mowing the lawn and $14 from babysitting for a total of 5+10+14 = $<<5+10+14=29>>29<n>If we add the $29 he will earn to his $65 savings, he will have a total of 29 + 65 = $<<29+65=94>>94<n>The bike costs $100 and he will have $94 leaving $100-$94 = $<<100-94=6>>6 more that he will need to earn<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Rationales: After buying a hat, Josh has $20 - $10 = $<<20-10=10>>10<n>After buying a pencil, Josh has $10 - $2 = $<<10-2=8>>8<n>The total cost of cookies is 4 * $1.25 = $<<4*1.25=5>>5<n>After buying the cookies, Josh has $8 - $5 = $<<8-5=3>>3<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input:What would happen to a person if his or her money is stolen? Choices:  A: complete sentence B: feel angry C: drink tea D: cross street E: park<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>D<n><n>### Why the answer is right?<n>The complete sentence would have the money in it. They would be angry at the one who stole it and try to get their money from the person.<n>The person would feel angry at the person who stole their money.<n>The person would have to cross the street to get to his money.<n>The person may need to look for the money.<n>The person will want to feel anger.<n><n>### Input:"A pig had a bucket. The bucket was red. The pig lived in the woods. The pig liked the bucket. The bucket had wheels. The bucket rolled. The bucket would stop on its own. The bucket was round. The pig lost the bucket. The pig ate the bucket."<n><n>### Response:"The bucket had wheels. A pig had a bucket."<n><n>##### Why the answer wrong?<n>It should be "The bucket had no wheels. A pine had the bucket."<n>The other answer is technically correct, but isn’t actually the answer to the question. We want the bucket to be the subject, not the pig.<n><n>### Response 2:"The bucket had whees A pig had a bunch. The bucket was red."<n><n>### Why this answer is not right?<n>The question was asking for a complete sentence. This is not it.<n><n>### A complete sentence must have a subject and a predicate<n><n>### A predicate is the verb or group of verb<n><n>### A subject and predicate form a complete sentence<n><n>### This response does not complete the sentence.<n><n>### The first part states that the bucket has wheels and that the pig had the bucket.<n><n>### This is not a complete sentence; there is no predicate. The bucket cannot be its own subject, so it is left out of the sentence.<n><n>This second sentence states that the bucket was red, and the pig had a bunch, which do not help us figure out who has the bucket.<n><n>This response does not have a predicate and is thus not a complete sentence.<n><n>## Example:<n>The complete sentence would be "the pig ate the red bucket". If it were "the pig a ate the red pig." It would be incorrect.<n>Because a complete sentence is a subject+verb+object (or complete
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Rationales: If he babysits for 2 hours at $7 per hour, he will earn 2*7 = $<<2*7=14>>14<n>This week he will earn $5 allowance, $10 mowing the lawn and $14 from babysitting for a total of 5+10+14 = $<<5+10+14=29>>29<n>If we add the $29 he will earn to his $65 savings, he will have a total of 29 + 65 = $<<29+65=94>>94<n>The bike costs $100 and he will have $94 leaving $100-$94 = $<<100-94=6>>6 more that he will need to earn<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Rationales: His kangaroos have a total of 23*2=<<23*2=46>>46 legs<n>He has 23*3=<<23*3=69>>69 goats<n>The goats have 69*4=<<69*4=276>>276 legs<n>So in total his animals have 276+46=<<276+46=322>>322 legs<n>#### 322<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Rationales: After buying a hat, Josh has $20 - $10 = $<<20-10=10>>10<n>After buying a pencil, Josh has $10 - $2 = $<<10-2=8>>8<n>The total cost of cookies is 4 * $1.25 = $<<4*1.25=5>>5<n>After buying the cookies, Josh has $8 - $5 = $<<8-5=3>>3<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input:Glass that hasn't been treated to be extra strong is what? Choices:  A: weak B: fragile C: forceless D: regular E: flimsy<n><n>### Response:		The answer is C.<n>"Forceless"<n><n>### Next:<n>https://github.com/franklindev/franklin-coding-camp/blob/master/_contents/Instruction/Day%2012%20-%20Critical%20Thinking/Demonstration/Demonstration%20-%21%20Critical.md<n><n><n>
