She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Rationales: If he babysits for 2 hours at $7 per hour, he will earn 2*7 = $<<2*7=14>>14<n>This week he will earn $5 allowance, $10 mowing the lawn and $14 from babysitting for a total of 5+10+14 = $<<5+10+14=29>>29<n>If we add the $29 he will earn to his $65 savings, he will have a total of 29 + 65 = $<<29+65=94>>94<n>The bike costs $100 and he will have $94 leaving $100-$94 = $<<100-94=6>>6 more that he will need to earn<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Rationales: His kangaroos have a total of 23*2=<<23*2=46>>46 legs<n>He has 23*3=<<23*3=69>>69 goats<n>The goats have 69*4=<<69*4=276>>276 legs<n>So in total his animals have 276+46=<<276+46=322>>322 legs<n>#### 322<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Rationales: After buying a hat, Josh has $20 - $10 = $<<20-10=10>>10<n>After buying a pencil, Josh has $10 - $2 = $<<10-2=8>>8<n>The total cost of cookies is 4 * $1.25 = $<<4*1.25=5>>5<n>After buying the cookies, Josh has $8 - $5 = $<<8-5=3>>3<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input:What is an area with no grass where I can get things to sell at a roadside stand? Choices:  A: surface of earth B: rest area C: supermarket D: state park E: garden<n><n>### Response:		C<n><n>### Explanation:<n>The term "a roadside stand" means this location is an area that is typically next to a road and has no cars driving by.<n>A roadside stand is located next to a road and cars will typically not drive by.  A supermarket will be located down a road and is always located next to a road.<n>A garden is located on a small plot of land that people take care of.<n><n>Answer:C<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Rationales: If he babysits for 2 hours at $7 per hour, he will earn 2*7 = $<<2*7=14>>14<n>This week he will earn $5 allowance, $10 mowing the lawn and $14 from babysitting for a total of 5+10+14 = $<<5+10+14=29>>29<n>If we add the $29 he will earn to his $65 savings, he will have a total of 29 + 65 = $<<29+65=94>>94<n>The bike costs $100 and he will have $94 leaving $100-$94 = $<<100-94=6>>6 more that he will need to earn<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Rationales: His kangaroos have a total of 23*2=<<23*2=46>>46 legs<n>He has 23*3=<<23*3=69>>69 goats<n>The goats have 69*4=<<69*4=276>>276 legs<n>So in total his animals have 276+46=<<276+46=322>>322 legs<n>#### 322<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Rationales: After buying a hat, Josh has $20 - $10 = $<<20-10=10>>10<n>After buying a pencil, Josh has $10 - $2 = $<<10-2=8>>8<n>The total cost of cookies is 4 * $1.25 = $<<4*1.25=5>>5<n>After buying the cookies, Josh has $8 - $5 = $<<8-5=3>>3<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input:They checked the weather one more time during the flight, they were on their way to paradise and wanted it to what? Choices:  A: look beautiful B: be happy C: change quickly D: occur here E: surprise us<n><n>### Response:		D -  Weather can either occur naturally or be brought on at a certain time, it can't be changed or surprised so C can be ruled out. If we use A, that makes happy to be a synonym. We can't say that to be here is the same as to change here or to surprise here. So the only ways that B or E can't be used is if to be happy means to be at paradise, which we don't know, and when to change happens. A, B, and E are eliminated.  Now D or E could both be used as synonyms for occurring. Only one would be right. For D, the synonym would be brought on because it can't be synonymous with happened. For E, a synonym would be to surprise because it hasn't been eliminated as part of B. D and E can only be synonymous if they are all different, so we can cross those out, as well.  We can rule out the synonym of brought on of changed because they aren't synonyms and we can still cross out the synonym of surprise for happy because only one can be correct. A can be ruled out because it doesn't make sense.  B is the answer because it is the only one left since happiness occurs and weather can be brought on if they knew that it would be at paradise. <n>####  E<n>Answer:  E -  Surprise<n><n>### Instructions:Analyze the passage below.<n><n>###  Analysis:I really liked the book that my friend made. I read the whole thing at night and I read lots more every night. That book wasn't the only thing I liked about my friend, my friend gave me the book. I had asked my friend if I could have something to read besides the dictionary and his biography. We were at this boring party that night and I couldn't talk to anyone because I didn't know anyone. When I wanted to go home, My friend, whose name was Steve, said he was staying. I said I am not interested at the moment, and I'd rather go home. He insisted on staying, and then he said he was a good story teller. When it was our turn to tell stories, I asked him to tell me a story, and he said he didn't have anything original or interesting to tell, but
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Rationales: If he babysits for 2 hours at $7 per hour, he will earn 2*7 = $<<2*7=14>>14<n>This week he will earn $5 allowance, $10 mowing the lawn and $14 from babysitting for a total of 5+10+14 = $<<5+10+14=29>>29<n>If we add the $29 he will earn to his $65 savings, he will have a total of 29 + 65 = $<<29+65=94>>94<n>The bike costs $100 and he will have $94 leaving $100-$94 = $<<100-94=6>>6 more that he will need to earn<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Rationales: His kangaroos have a total of 23*2=<<23*2=46>>46 legs<n>He has 23*3=<<23*3=69>>69 goats<n>The goats have 69*4=<<69*4=276>>276 legs<n>So in total his animals have 276+46=<<276+46=322>>322 legs<n>#### 322<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Rationales: After buying a hat, Josh has $20 - $10 = $<<20-10=10>>10<n>After buying a pencil, Josh has $10 - $2 = $<<10-2=8>>8<n>The total cost of cookies is 4 * $1.25 = $<<4*1.25=5>>5<n>After buying the cookies, Josh has $8 - $5 = $<<8-5=3>>3<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input:What has a master of their craft done about that craft? Choices:  A: drill B: committed murder most vile C: bargemaster D: learn E: understand<n><n>### Response:		<n>#### A<n>B<n>Answer: C<n><n>### Input What kind of work do they do? Choices: A: fishing B: writing C: singing D: construction E: running<n><n>### Response A<n>B<n>Answer B<n><n>### Input Where are they called? Choices: A : a street B: a ship C D:a village E: another town<n><n>### Response B<n>A<n>Answer: B<n><n>### Instructions:Answer the following fill in the blank question.<n><n>## Input:<n>Ricky has $3 in his wallet.  He bought a ____________ for $2.  If he had 25 pennies in his pocket he has 28 pennies in total. How much money left in his wallet if he had exactly 60 pennies before buying the candy bar?<n>Rationales<n>Input:  $3<n>Candy Bar: $2<n>Input: Pennies: 25<n>Input: total pennies(total input): 28<n>Input: after buying candy - ($3 - $2)<n>Input: after buys candy - = $1<n><n>#### 1<n>Answer: $1<n><n>### Instructor:Answer the following true or false question.<n><n>## Instructions:<n>Write a response that appropriately determines if the statement is true or false.<n><n>### Input (statement): The cactus has green thorns ________.<n>### Rationales:<n>Statement: The cactus has ____ thorns.  The cactus also has green thorns.<n>Thus, we know that the statement is true.<n><n>### True<n>### False<n>Answer: True<n><n>### Instinct:Complete the instruction below with a single word.<n><n>### Rationals:<n><n>Instructions: <n><n>Input: <n>Write a word that completes the following statement: One-fifth of the children in the neighborhood are ______. <n><n>### A. boring B. interesting C. good D. bad<n>Answer: A. boring<n><n>### Instuction:Complete the instruction below<n><n>### Rationale<n>Input: A gourmet chef uses a ________ to cook food.<n>Input: Culinary
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Rationales: If he babysits for 2 hours at $7 per hour, he will earn 2*7 = $<<2*7=14>>14<n>This week he will earn $5 allowance, $10 mowing the lawn and $14 from babysitting for a total of 5+10+14 = $<<5+10+14=29>>29<n>If we add the $29 he will earn to his $65 savings, he will have a total of 29 + 65 = $<<29+65=94>>94<n>The bike costs $100 and he will have $94 leaving $100-$94 = $<<100-94=6>>6 more that he will need to earn<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Rationales: His kangaroos have a total of 23*2=<<23*2=46>>46 legs<n>He has 23*3=<<23*3=69>>69 goats<n>The goats have 69*4=<<69*4=276>>276 legs<n>So in total his animals have 276+46=<<276+46=322>>322 legs<n>#### 322<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Rationales: After buying a hat, Josh has $20 - $10 = $<<20-10=10>>10<n>After buying a pencil, Josh has $10 - $2 = $<<10-2=8>>8<n>The total cost of cookies is 4 * $1.25 = $<<4*1.25=5>>5<n>After buying the cookies, Josh has $8 - $5 = $<<8-5=3>>3<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input:He was a very sharp engineer, but when it came to the details his calculations could were often what? Choices:  A: complimentary B: inelegant C: ocean D: dull E: inaccurate<n><n>### Response:		C, E<n><n>### Input:-2|3|<<-2|3|>>8<n><n>### Response:-2|3|8<n>Rationales: *-2* is negated by +2.<n>*-3* is negated by (+3) and then multiplied *<<3* is negated and then multiplied. This means that there are 4 negated numbers in total, with the only non-negated value being 8.<n><n>#### 2<n><n>### Input:[4*2]<n>### Response:8<n><n>### Instructions:Answer the following multiple-choice question.<n><n>## Output:<n>In 6, which multiplication sign is missing:<n><n>A. / B. × C. * D. %<n>#### D<n>Answer: D<n><n>### Rationales: 6 * 2 = 12, 6 + 2 = 8<n><n>#### 4<n>### Input:[1|2]<n>### Rationals: 1 * 2 = 2 and 1 + 2 = 3<n><n>#### 5<n>### Input:[8%0|10]<n>### Response:[0,2,10]<n><n>### Input:--2=<<--2=>>-1<n><n>### Response:--2=<<--1=>>0<n><n>### Input:@$5;20;150<n>### Rational:5; 20; 100; 50; 25; 12.5; 6.25<n><n>### Input:{1|23|4}<n>### Rational:-1, 23, 4<n><n>### Input:#4+#2;#4-#3<n>### Rational:{4,2}, {4,-1}; {4,2}; {4,4}; {4,4}<n><n>### Input:=3*2-4<n>### Rational:=6-6<n><n>### Input?:3+2*-<<2*-3>>9<n>### Rational?:2*-3=<-7>9<n><n>### Input:%&%<n>### Rational:%&%<n><n>### Input%8^2%<n>### Ration: %8^2%<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Rationales: If he babysits for 2 hours at $7 per hour, he will earn 2*7 = $<<2*7=14>>14<n>This week he will earn $5 allowance, $10 mowing the lawn and $14 from babysitting for a total of 5+10+14 = $<<5+10+14=29>>29<n>If we add the $29 he will earn to his $65 savings, he will have a total of 29 + 65 = $<<29+65=94>>94<n>The bike costs $100 and he will have $94 leaving $100-$94 = $<<100-94=6>>6 more that he will need to earn<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Rationales: His kangaroos have a total of 23*2=<<23*2=46>>46 legs<n>He has 23*3=<<23*3=69>>69 goats<n>The goats have 69*4=<<69*4=276>>276 legs<n>So in total his animals have 276+46=<<276+46=322>>322 legs<n>#### 322<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. Name this item? Choices:  A: electric locomotive B: electric typewriter C: multi-coloured walrus D: electric refrigerator E: electric drill<n><n>### Response:		<n>Input: It is an electric refrigerator.<n><n>### Explaination:<n>The electric motor powered by electricity was one of the most useful inventions of the 1920s. Electricity was widely distributed across the United States.  They could be used in any way.  An example of an item that was electric is an electric refridgerator. The word walrus was misspelled and the word drill had its plural changed. There was only one choice left.<n><n>### Input and Explanation:<n>Input: The electric motor powered many  of almost every house.  Choices:  A) electric locomotive B) electric typewriter C) multi-coloured walruses D) electric refrigerator<n><n>Explanation: The only correct answer is E.) Electric refrigerator.  Each of the above answers are incorrect in one way or another.  For example, electric locomotive refers  to a train driven by a magnet or engine which is electric.  An electric typewriter uses a computer keyboard and computer program  to transfer letters typed into typewriter.  A multi-colored walrus is a walrus that has multiple colors, not a walrus that is multi colored.  An electric drill is an electric tool used for  drilling.
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100. He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Rationales: If he babysits for 2 hours at $7 per hour, he will earn 2*7 = $<<2*7=14>>14<n>This week he will earn $5 allowance, $10 mowing the lawn and $14 from babysitting for a total of 5+10+14 = $<<5+10+14=29>>29<n>If we add the $29 he will earn to his $65 savings, he will have a total of 29 + 65 = $<<29+65=94>>94<n>The bike costs $100 and he will have $94 leaving $100-$94 = $<<100-94=6>>6 more that he will need to earn<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Rationales: His kangaroos have a total of 23*2=<<23*2=46>>46 legs<n>He has 23*3=<<23*3=69>>69 goats<n>The goats have 69*4=<<69*4=276>>276 legs<n>So in total his animals have 276+46=<<276+46=322>>322 legs<n>#### 322<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Rationales: After buying a hat, Josh has $20 - $10 = $<<20-10=10>>10<n>After buying a pencil, Josh has $10 - $2 = $<<10-2=8>>8<n>The total cost of cookies is 4 * $1.25 = $<<4*1.25=5>>5<n>After buying the cookies, Josh has $8 - $5 = $<<8-5=3>>3<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input:If I am a person, I have a unique ability to do what? Choices:  A: cross street B: stand upright C: speak spanish D: speak chinese E: further education<n><n>### Response:		Answer in the textbox provided that a person can stand upright.<n><n>#### Answer:E<n>#### Answer:E
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Rationales: If he babysits for 2 hours at $7 per hour, he will earn 2*7 = $<<2*7=14>>14<n>This week he will earn $5 allowance, $10 mowing the lawn and $14 from babysitting for a total of 5+10+14 = $<<5+10+14=29>>29<n>If we add the $29 he will earn to his $65 savings, he will have a total of 29 + 65 = $<<29+65=94>>94<n>The bike costs $100 and he will have $94 leaving $100-$94 = $<<100-94=6>>6 more that he will need to earn<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs. Choices:  A: russia B: at home C: hole D: field E: heaven<n><n>### Response:		Choices:  D & B is a match.<n><n>### Rationale:The lemurs are in a zoo or if they stay at home they would eat their mice.<n><n>### Input if a zoo. <n>### Rationale for A if a zoo and B at home.<n><n>### Choices:  B & E is a match. <n>### Answer:  D&B<n><n>### Demostration of D&B answer.<n>### Demonstation of  D&B<n>### If a zoo the the lemurs would stay in the zoo but if they stayed home they would eat the mice.<n>### If the zoo they would eat the mush.<n><n>### If they stayed at home they would eat the mouse.<n>### If they stay at home they will eat there mice at home.<n><n>#### A<n>Answer:  A<n><n>#### B<n>Answer:  B<n><n>#### C<n>Answer:  C<n><n>#### D<n>Answer:  D<n><n>#### E<n>Answer:  E<n><n>### Input If a zoo and you went to the zoo what would you see? Choices: A: pigeons, B: monkeys, C: penguins and D: beasts.<n><n>### Answer:B&E a match if the zoo.<n><n>### Demo if zoo.<n>### Demo if the zoo they must be monkeys, pigeons, beasts and penguins.<n><n>### A is a monkey<n><n>### C is a beast not in a zoo but in the wild bears and tigars<n><n>### Demo of B & E match.<n><n>## Demonstration of D and E match<n><n>### Rules of Demonstration.<n>1: if one can say monkey you can say zoo.<n><n>2: If one can say pigeons zoo you can say pigeons wild.<n><n>###  A is a monkey in a zoo.<n>###  B is a monkey in the wild.<n>### C is any animal in the wild.<n><n>## Output<n><n>### Choice E:<n>Answer: E<n><n>### Choicce D:<n>Answer: D
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Rationales: If he babysits for 2 hours at $7 per hour, he will earn 2*7 = $<<2*7=14>>14<n>This week he will earn $5 allowance, $10 mowing the lawn and $14 from babysitting for a total of 5+10+14 = $<<5+10+14=29>>29<n>If we add the $29 he will earn to his $65 savings, he will have a total of 29 + 65 = $<<29+65=94>>94<n>The bike costs $100 and he will have $94 leaving $100-$94 = $<<100-94=6>>6 more that he will need to earn<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Rationales: His kangaroos have a total of 23*2=<<23*2=46>>46 legs<n>He has 23*3=<<23*3=69>>69 goats<n>The goats have 69*4=<<69*4=276>>276 legs<n>So in total his animals have 276+46=<<276+46=322>>322 legs<n>#### 322<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Rationales: After buying a hat, Josh has $20 - $10 = $<<20-10=10>>10<n>After buying a pencil, Josh has $10 - $2 = $<<10-2=8>>8<n>The total cost of cookies is 4 * $1.25 = $<<4*1.25=5>>5<n>After buying the cookies, Josh has $8 - $5 = $<<8-5=3>>3<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input:He waited for his friend at the squash court, but he was worried his friend thought he meant the at the other end of the public what? Choices:  A: country club B: rich person's house C: pool D: park E: fitness center<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>Choices:  A: county club  B: rich persons house  C: pool  D: park  E: fitness center  The answer is A: county club, since at the end of the public what he meant was country club. The question asks to the reader to figure out where his friend meant to meet him and his options are a) the pool, b) the park, c) the fitness center, d) a) the squash court - but the squash court in this case was where his friend thought he was wanting to meet.<n><n>#### <n>Answer: D<n><n>### Input<n>This is a set of instructions. The total number of sheets with 20 stickers on each paper will equal 30 * 20 = 600<n><n>The total number of stickers after the papers are assemble = <<600>>600 - 100 = 500<n><n>### Bonus Answer: 500<n>

His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Rationales: If he babysits for 2 hours at $7 per hour, he will earn 2*7 = $<<2*7=14>>14<n>This week he will earn $5 allowance, $10 mowing the lawn and $14 from babysitting for a total of 5+10+14 = $<<5+10+14=29>>29<n>If we add the $29 he will earn to his $65 savings, he will have a total of 29 + 65 = $<<29+65=94>>94<n>The bike costs $100 and he will have $94 leaving $100-$94 = $<<100-94=6>>6 more that he will need to earn<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Rationales: His kangaroos have a total of 23*2=<<23*2=46>>46 legs<n>He has 23*3=<<23*3=69>>69 goats<n>The goats have 69*4=<<69*4=276>>276 legs<n>So in total his animals have 276+46=<<276+46=322>>322 legs<n>#### 322<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Rationales: After buying a hat, Josh has $20 - $10 = $<<20-10=10>>10<n>After buying a pencil, Josh has $10 - $2 = $<<10-2=8>>8<n>The total cost of cookies is 4 * $1.25 = $<<4*1.25=5>>5<n>After buying the cookies, Josh has $8 - $5 = $<<8-5=3>>3<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input:The person put on lotion, what did they want? Choices:  A: fresh smell B: good credit C: smooth skin D: fresh produce E: headache<n><n>### Response:		E<n>Rationales: The answer is letter E.<n>#### E<n>Answer: E<n><n>### Input and Response:The boy found $50 and $2.  What is the percent of what the boy found? Choices: A. 10% of his $20 allowance B. 20% of his allowance C. 33.3% of his allowance D. 50% of his allowanc E. 1% of his allowance<n><n>### Response and Answer:D<n>Rationales: Choice D, 50% of an allowance<n>#### 50<n>Answer: D<n><n>### Input  Answer:<n><img src="https://edx.math.wmich.edu/media/user_files/a_q-5.jpg" width="1000" height="1000"><n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Rationales: If he babysits for 2 hours at $7 per hour, he will earn 2*7 = $<<2*7=14>>14<n>This week he will earn $5 allowance, $10 mowing the lawn and $14 from babysitting for a total of 5+10+14 = $<<5+10+14=29>>29<n>If we add the $29 he will earn to his $65 savings, he will have a total of 29 + 65 = $<<29+65=94>>94<n>The bike costs $100 and he will have $94 leaving $100-$94 = $<<100-94=6>>6 more that he will need to earn<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Rationales: His kangaroos have a total of 23*2=<<23*2=46>>46 legs<n>He has 23*3=<<23*3=69>>69 goats<n>The goats have 69*4=<<69*4=276>>276 legs<n>So in total his animals have 276+46=<<276+46=322>>322 legs<n>#### 322<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Rationales: After buying a hat, Josh has $20 - $10 = $<<20-10=10>>10<n>After buying a pencil, Josh has $10 - $2 = $<<10-2=8>>8<n>The total cost of cookies is 4 * $1.25 = $<<4*1.25=5>>5<n>After buying the cookies, Josh has $8 - $5 = $<<8-5=3>>3<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input:Mom is tidying a house, where would she put the loose dictionary? Choices:  A: shelf B: library C: classroom D: table E: desk<n><n>### Response:		C<n><n>### Input:"I have 7 pencils, 8 m&ms and 9 socks." How many different ways can 4 of these items be split into 2 groups?<n><n>### Rationales:The first item (7 m&ms) can then be paired with one of the other 3 remaining items (1 pencil, 8 socks or 9 m&ms).  There are 3 different ways to combine 7 m&ms with one of the remaining items (not including repetition).  Then one of the remaining 3 items (1 pencils, 9 socks or 8 m&ms) are paired with the remaining items and there are 3 ways to choose this item (not including repetition) (since the remaining 4 items are also the remaining 4 items).  Since the amount of choices are 3 choose 4, there are 3^4=36 ways that the 4 items could be split<n><n>### Answer: 36<n>### Input: A group of scientist is studying the ocean. How many seals can 360 scientists count in one year if they can count 17 seals for one hour each?<n><n>### Answer 480<n>### Input: 17<n><n>### Instructions:Input: What is 0.7 x 8?<n><n>### Demostration:  0.7 x 0.7 x.08 =.000468<n>#### 0.00046<n>Answer: 000046 (46 thousandths)<n><n>### Input  : Input: How many ounces are in 125 pounds?<n><n>### Response : 320, since 125 /2 = 62.5;6,8 = 62 and 0.8, 320 ounces<n><n>### Input : Input: How much does a gallon of paint weigh?<n><n>### Demo: An empty gallon of paint has a weight of 5.3 pounds<n><n>### Answer : 1.15<n><n>### Input<n><n>### Demos<n>Input: How much does a 50 lb. bag of feed weigh?<n><n>Demos:Answer

In this experiment, 0.6837, the probability that the ball is on the blue box is:<n><n>0.68393750.421747x0.6 = 0.421<n><n><n>### Example:<n>#### Sample and Population<n>Sample population is the set of all numbers<n><n>Population sample is the set of all integers<n><n>#### Sample space<n>If we chose a number between 0 and 9, the sample space is the set of all possibilities. Choices:  A: liquidated B: own resources C: branch out D: commit crime E: game over<n><n>### Response:		E: Game over.<n><n>### Rationales:E: Game over<n>![sorry](screenshots/sorry.jpg)<n><n>### Input-B: <n>#### Response: B: bankrupt.<n><n>### Input C-<n>#### Response: C: branch out.<n><n>### <n>### Input- <n>#### Response:<n>D: commit crime <n><n><n>### Rationale:-<n>![defeat](screenshots/%2320.jpg)<n>### The word bankruptcy means failure by debt.  This can happen to a company, a person, their investments and even their government.<n>### <n>When a company runs out of money or if they are not making enough money, then they say they are **BANKRUPT**.  A company can only go bankrupt if they have not enough money to pay their **debts** and other expenses or **liabilities**.<n>Companies that are not able to pay their debts will be  put into a bankruptcy court, so they can be **sold** or otherwise turned over to the creditors.  And with that, usually the business is closed and people are fired.  The only way a business can avoid bankruptcy is to stay in business by running a more efficient business, cutting costs, and finding ways to make more money.<n><n>#### 2 <n>### I want to know whether you are a loyal person or not so that you can be given the loyalty award.<n><n>### Your response:<n><n>### Rations: <n>![27](screenshots//27.gif)<n>Loyalty award: 1/4<n><n>### If Loyalty award: 3/4<n>### Input-<n><n>### Ration: <n><n>![132](../../../screenshots//132.jpg)<n><n>![418](../../../screenshot/418.jpg)<n>

Choices:  I: 122 J: 88 k: 22 l: 33<n><n>### Response:"I"<n><n>### Justifications"I" can be found in the middle between 80 and max of 220 seconds<n><n>### Input"My father has $1,251.  He wants to be debt free, so he needs to spend less than $125 per month to achieve that.   What is the least he can spend this month?<n><n>### Response"A"<n><n>### Rationales: $1,250 < $125<n><n>### Input "If it takes you 30 minutes to get ready in the morning, how many hours would it take you to get ready if you tripled the amount of time?"<n><n>### Response "2"<n><n>### What does "100" + "3" mean as a mathematical expression?<n><n>### Rationale: 100+3 is the same as 103 (read as "hundred three")<n><n>### Input  "My favorite number is 36.  If I wanted to double it, how much would I have to add to it?"<n><n>### What number should you add?<n><n>### Answer "60"<n><n>### How can you double a number like 38 by combining it with a number of the same type? Remember -- you can't use only addition!<n><n>### If you have 30 seconds to add 5 and 7, what method can you use?<n><n>### Addition -- 5+7=12<n><n>### If I asked you to subtract 47 from 75, what's the first thing you think to do?<n><n>### Choosing the answer key you'll need to subtract 47. This is important to note because it's critical that you know what to do before you decide on the answer and try a calculation!<n><n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Rationales: If he babysits for 2 hours at $7 per hour, he will earn 2*7 = $<<2*7=14>>14<n>This week he will earn $5 allowance, $10 mowing the lawn and $14 from babysitting for a total of 5+10+14 = $<<5+10+14=29>>29<n>If we add the $29 he will earn to his $65 savings, he will have a total of 29 + 65 = $<<29+65=94>>94<n>The bike costs $100 and he will have $94 leaving $100-$94 = $<<100-94=6>>6 more that he will need to earn<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Rationales: His kangaroos have a total of 23*2=<<23*2=46>>46 legs<n>He has 23*3=<<23*3=69>>69 goats<n>The goats have 69*4=<<69*4=276>>276 legs<n>So in total his animals have 276+46=<<276+46=322>>322 legs<n>#### 322<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Rationales: After buying a hat, Josh has $20 - $10 = $<<20-10=10>>10<n>After buying a pencil, Josh has $10 - $2 = $<<10-2=8>>8<n>The total cost of cookies is 4 * $1.25 = $<<4*1.25=5>>5<n>After buying the cookies, Josh has $8 - $5 = $<<8-5=3>>3<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input:I am looking to buy honey right from an apiary, where should I go? Choices:  A: jar B: stick to fingers C: beehive D: stick to fingers E: farmer's market<n><n>### Response:		E<n><n>### Instructions:Please answer the question.<n><n>## Instructions:Write a complete sentence for each question shown. <n><n>## A<n>Isn’t it a lot of fun?<n><n>## A<n>No, I’d like to do that, too.<n><n>## A<n>It is really very useful.<n><n>## B<n>I’m a ______<n><n>## B<n>It’s so much more fun.<n><n>## B.<n>Yes, I really enjoy it.<n><n>## B <n>That’s not fun.<n><n>## C<n>He is a ________  or he is a ________.<n><n>## C<n>This is easy, she is very _______ .<n><n>## D<n>My car is a __ or My car is a __.<n><n>## D <n>The store is open ___ or it is open__________. (Fill in the blank.)<n><n>## D<n>She is very late.  It is ______ or _______<n><n>## E <n>He will arrive  around ______ (early/late).<n><n>## E<n>The class will meet at ________ o clock (early/late)  on ________ (first/second).<n><n>## F <n>He will arrive around _____  (early/late.)<n><n>## F<n>His plane will depart __ or _____.<n><n>## G <n>She will arrive around ______ (time).<n><n><n>## G<n>The plane will arrive _______ (early/late)..<n><n>## F  or G <n>Please choose answer G or H: <n><n>## F<n>The store will open at _____ or it will close at ________.<n><n>## F<n>It was _______ (late/early) when I came back.<n><n><n>## G  or H<n>Please choose answer G  or  H: <n><n><n><n>

She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Rationales: If he babysits for 2 hours at $7 per hour, he will earn 2*7 = $<<2*7=14>>14<n>This week he will earn $5 allowance, $10 mowing the lawn and $14 from babysitting for a total of 5+10+14 = $<<5+10+14=29>>29<n>If we add the $29 he will earn to his $65 savings, he will have a total of 29 + 65 = $<<29+65=94>>94<n>The bike costs $100 and he will have $94 leaving $100-$94 = $<<100-94=6>>6 more that he will need to earn<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Rationales: After buying a hat, Josh has $20 - $10 = $<<20-10=10>>10<n>After buying a pencil, Josh has $10 - $2 = $<<10-2=8>>8<n>The total cost of cookies is 4 * $1.25 = $<<4*1.25=5>>5<n>After buying the cookies, Josh has $8 - $5 = $<<8-5=3>>3<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input:Jimmy wanted a beer but his wife was an alcoholic on probation. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100. He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn. Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs. It does not specify much enough detail to give much more than a hint of what note may be indicated.<n><n>### Input : Which of the following is true?<n><n>The temperature can increase without increasing the entropy of the universe.<n>The speed of sound can increase without the entropy of the universe increasing.<n>Entropy increases as the temperature increases.<n>All of the preceding answers are false.<n><n><n>### Response : The entropy of a physical system cannot decrease.<n><n>### I am in the middle of the forest and it is starting to get dark.I realize<n><n>### that I have to be more careful about where I put my feet.Why is it important<n><n>### for me to pay more attention to the ground beneath my feet in the dark of the night? <n><n>### The answer is A.  It is important to pay attention to the ground so you do not stumble and fall <n><n>### and hurt yourself.<n><n>### How many squares of chocolate would you need to make 32 squares of 1 inch chocolatey treats?<n><n>### The number of squares of chocolate you would need would have to be two times as much as the number of 1 inch squares, so two times 32 = 64.<n><n>### The question asks how many squares of CHOCOLATE.  So you'll need to multiply the 32 by TWO.<n><n>### NOT, how many squares of choclatey treats.<n><n>### You'll need 64 squares of chocolate to make 64 squares of 1 in choclatey treat.<n><n>

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Rationales: If he babysits for 2 hours at $7 per hour, he will earn 2*7 = $<<2*7=14>>14<n>This week he will earn $5 allowance, $10 mowing the lawn and $14 from babysitting for a total of 5+10+14 = $<<5+10+14=29>>29<n>If we add the $29 he will earn to his $65 savings, he will have a total of 29 + 65 = $<<29+65=94>>94<n>The bike costs $100 and he will have $94 leaving $100-$94 = $<<100-94=6>>6 more that he will need to earn<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Rationales: His kangaroos have a total of 23*2=<<23*2=46>>46 legs<n>He has 23*3=<<23*3=69>>69 goats<n>The goats have 69*4=<<69*4=276>>276 legs<n>So in total his animals have 276+46=<<276+46=322>>322 legs<n>#### 322<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Rationales: After buying a hat, Josh has $20 - $10 = $<<20-10=10>>10<n>After buying a pencil, Josh has $10 - $2 = $<<10-2=8>>8<n>The total cost of cookies is 4 * $1.25 = $<<4*1.25=5>>5<n>After buying the cookies, Josh has $8 - $5 = $<<8-5=3>>3<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input:Where would you go if you didn't feel like baking a cake yourself? Choices:  A: theater B: refrigerator C: bakery D: grocery store E: oven<n><n>### Response:		My mom would bake the cake if we don't want to bake a cake on any special occasions.<n><n>#### Answers:C<n>#### E<n>#### F<n>#### A<n>#### B
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Rationales: If he babysits for 2 hours at $7 per hour, he will earn 2*7 = $<<2*7=14>>14<n>This week he will earn $5 allowance, $10 mowing the lawn and $14 from babysitting for a total of 5+10+14 = $<<5+10+14=29>>29<n>If we add the $29 he will earn to his $65 savings, he will have a total of 29 + 65 = $<<29+65=94>>94<n>The bike costs $100 and he will have $94 leaving $100-$94 = $<<100-94=6>>6 more that he will need to earn<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Rationales: His kangaroos have a total of 23*2=<<23*2=46>>46 legs<n>He has 23*3=<<23*3=69>>69 goats<n>The goats have 69*4=<<69*4=276>>276 legs<n>So in total his animals have 276+46=<<276+46=322>>322 legs<n>#### 322<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Rationales: After buying a hat, Josh has $20 - $10 = $<<20-10=10>>10<n>After buying a pencil, Josh has $10 - $2 = $<<10-2=8>>8<n>The total cost of cookies is 4 * $1.25 = $<<4*1.25=5>>5<n>After buying the cookies, Josh has $8 - $5 = $<<8-5=3>>3<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input:What do you need to be to learn hard concepts? Choices:  A: copy B: intelligent C: improved performance D: empowering E: have more knowledge<n><n>### Response:		Answer the following question to complete the instruction below.<n><n>### Rationales:<n>Answer: A<n><n>### Input 2<n><n>### Response 2<n><n>## Task Input 3: The question reads below.<n><n>## Task Input Answer 3:

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100. How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Rationales: If he babysits for 2 hours at $7 per hour, he will earn 2*7 = $<<2*7=14>>14<n>This week he will earn $5 allowance, $10 mowing the lawn and $14 from babysitting for a total of 5+10+14 = $<<5+10+14=29>>29<n>If we add the $29 he will earn to his $65 savings, he will have a total of 29 + 65 = $<<29+65=94>>94<n>The bike costs $100 and he will have $94 leaving $100-$94 = $<<100-94=6>>6 more that he will need to earn<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Rationales: His kangaroos have a total of 23*2=<<23*2=46>>46 legs<n>He has 23*3=<<23*3=69>>69 goats<n>The goats have 69*4=<<69*4=276>>276 legs<n>So in total his animals have 276+46=<<276+46=322>>322 legs<n>#### 322<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Rationales: After buying a hat, Josh has $20 - $10 = $<<20-10=10>>10<n>After buying a pencil, Josh has $10 - $2 = $<<10-2=8>>8<n>The total cost of cookies is 4 * $1.25 = $<<4*1.25=5>>5<n>After buying the cookies, Josh has $8 - $5 = $<<8-5=3>>3<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input:People want to explore space, so what should they use to do it? Choices:  A: public place B: roadblock C: space shuttle D: hoverboard E: supermarket<n><n>### Response:		A and E<n><n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Rationales: If he babysits for 2 hours at $7 per hour, he will earn 2*7 = $<<2*7=14>>14<n>This week he will earn $5 allowance, $10 mowing the lawn and $14 from babysitting for a total of 5+10+14 = $<<5+10+14=29>>29<n>If we add the $29 he will earn to his $65 savings, he will have a total of 29 + 65 = $<<29+65=94>>94<n>The bike costs $100 and he will have $94 leaving $100-$94 = $<<100-94=6>>6 more that he will need to earn<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Rationales: His kangaroos have a total of 23*2=<<23*2=46>>46 legs<n>He has 23*3=<<23*3=69>>69 goats<n>The goats have 69*4=<<69*4=276>>276 legs<n>So in total his animals have 276+46=<<276+46=322>>322 legs<n>#### 322<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Rationales: After buying a hat, Josh has $20 - $10 = $<<20-10=10>>10<n>After buying a pencil, Josh has $10 - $2 = $<<10-2=8>>8<n>The total cost of cookies is 4 * $1.25 = $<<4*1.25=5>>5<n>After buying the cookies, Josh has $8 - $5 = $<<8-5=3>>3<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input:When he touched the exposed wire he shouldn't have found it surprising that he got what? Choices:  A: see work B: shocked C: humor D: startled E: funny<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>### Instructions:Answer the following multiple choose answer.<n><n>Demonstration:<n>Input:`When he touched the exposed wires he should have found it surprising.`<n><n>#### `A: see work`<n><n>#### `B: shocked`<n><n>#### `C: humor`<n><n>#### `D: startled`<n><n>#### `E: funny`<n><n><n><n>### Multiple-choice Rounding/Estimation<n>Instruction:Round 50 to two decimal places.<n><n>The rational is :<n><div align="center"> <img width="20%" align="left" height="20%" src="RoundingUpTo1-2Decimals.png"></div><n><n><div align="left"> <n>If any of the above rational is wrong,  You can always correct me through this link<n>[Coral_Vell_1](Corrie_Vell_1) <n></div><n><n><n>---<n>Copyright©2020, Corrie_Vell_6, All rights reserved.<n><n><n># Project 1: The Great Bake-Off<n>In this project you will participate in a virtual bake-off, by completing the following items in this project assignment.<n><n>### Name:<n><n>### Instructor:<n><n>### Submission Title:<n><n>### Summary:<n><n>In this Project 1: The Bake-Off assignment, you will complete the following in this project assignment. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Rationales: If he babysits for 2 hours at $7 per hour, he will earn 2*7 = $<<2*7=14>>14<n>This week he will earn $5 allowance, $10 mowing the lawn and $14 from babysitting for a total of 5+10+14 = $<<5+10+14=29>>29<n>If we add the $29 he will earn to his $65 savings, he will have a total of 29 + 65 = $<<29+65=94>>94<n>The bike costs $100 and he will have $94 leaving $100-$94 = $<<100-94=6>>6 more that he will need to earn<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Rationales: His kangaroos have a total of 23*2=<<23*2=46>>46 legs<n>He has 23*3=<<23*3=69>>69 goats<n>The goats have 69*4=<<69*4=276>>276 legs<n>So in total his animals have 276+46=<<276+46=322>>322 legs<n>#### 322<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Rationales: After buying a hat, Josh has $20 - $10 = $<<20-10=10>>10<n>After buying a pencil, Josh has $10 - $2 = $<<10-2=8>>8<n>The total cost of cookies is 4 * $1.25 = $<<4*1.25=5>>5<n>After buying the cookies, Josh has $8 - $5 = $<<8-5=3>>3<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input:The cow would come outside even after the storm had passed, it wouldn't leave the what? Choices:  A: meat grinder B: stable C: red barn D: gate E: green field<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>#### A<n>Answer: C<n><n>#### B<n>Answer: C<n>Rationales:<n><n>### Input<n>What do the blue square, star and diamond indicate on the following grid?<n>[9828057428737897437538](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/98280_%2B_05742_%2B_80574_%2B_97437_%2B_53873_%2B_78974_%22%3B_0578_%2B_37897_%2B05780_%2897_%3B_08797%29_%2B_13798_%2B57805_%3B_43780_%3B_57804_%2B78005_%2B70809_57812_%2B7387057_%2B79870576)<n><n>#### A<n>Choice: C<n><n>#### D<n>Choice: D<n><n>#### A<n><n>[7709043712837284387853](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/1-5-8-7-9-3-2-5-38785-785-37128-8372-78438-71283-70437-04371-78097-30583)(A=the blue square ,B= the star,C= the diamond ,D= the purple hexagon ,E=the red octagon  ,F=the blue triangles ,G= the green triangle  ,H the golden rectangle  )<n><n>#### D<n><n>Choice:  A<n><n>Rationales<n>

Do you have any ideas of how I can use these amounts to get closer to buying my phone?<n><n>### Response:#  I have some ideas for you. So, your total budget is $10 - $35 = $<<10-$35=25>>25<n>Your grandmother will give you $10 and you have $25 saved from your own money.<n><n>####<n>Answer:#<n><n>### Input|1:Mary's family went to the movies on Friday. Her mom paid the tickets for $15. Then she found a coupon which gave them a free popcorn. Mary went to a fast food restaurant that night and bought a chicken burger with some fries for $20. She also wanted to order desert. The desert was half off if it was bought with a meal. What was the lowest amount of money Mary needed?|<n><n>### Rationales|The family needed $15 to watch the movies + the free pop corns + extra money for the desert = $15+$0 = $<<15+$0=$15>>15<n>After buying chicken burger and fries Mary had $10 left.<n>The desert cost $5 so she needed $0+$5=$<<0+$5=$5>>5<n>So in total she need $15+$5=$<<15+$5=$20>>20<n>####<n>Answer:#

Choices:  A: large city B: strip mall C: building D: shopping mall E: aquarium<n><n>### Response:		<n>There is one option that meets all the conditions. This was given in the instructions.<n>![](./Images/InstructionFig.png)<n>![](./Images1_70_72/Image11.png)<n>We will store our items in the shopping mall.<n><n>### 2,2<n><n>### Instructions: Answer the following multiple choice question<n><n>### Demostration:<n>Input: Eight friends made a penguin snowfort. Their names were A, B, C, D, E, F, G, and H. A, B, C were in the first room. D, E, F were in the next room. G, H were in the last room. A-D stayed in their room throughout the course of the party. H arrived at 1:37 p.m. The party ended at 6:05 p.m. When the party started, J was the first person to arrive. He is the only one that was the first person to enter every room of the snowfort. The party started and ended between J and I. T, K, L, and M were in the party room. How many rooms of the snowfort were not entered by any of the guests?<n>Rationales<n>  Since we know that there were 8 friends and J was the first guest to enter each room and J was the last guest to enter, then  J was the only guest who entered 15 of the 16 rooms of the fort.<n>  There were 16 rooms, except for all the rooms J entered he entered them twice, but there is 1 less room with every guest, except for J. So each room must have been entered 3 times.<n>  There were a total of 8 guests that did not enter at least 16 of the rooms.<n>  The 16 rooms and the guests that entered each room are:  [15, 15, 14, 14,...1 13, 12, 11, 10, 8, 8, 6, 4, 5] [J, I, M, L, K, T, C, H, F, E, G]<n>  By using our information and the information in the image, we can clearly see that H stayed in the last room the whole time<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Rationales: If he babysits for 2 hours at $7 per hour, he will earn 2*7 = $<<2*7=14>>14<n>This week he will earn $5 allowance, $10 mowing the lawn and $14 from babysitting for a total of 5+10+14 = $<<5+10+14=29>>29<n>If we add the $29 he will earn to his $65 savings, he will have a total of 29 + 65 = $<<29+65=94>>94<n>The bike costs $100 and he will have $94 leaving $100-$94 = $<<100-94=6>>6 more that he will need to earn<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Rationales: His kangaroos have a total of 23*2=<<23*2=46>>46 legs<n>He has 23*3=<<23*3=69>>69 goats<n>The goats have 69*4=<<69*4=276>>276 legs<n>So in total his animals have 276+46=<<276+46=322>>322 legs<n>#### 322<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Rationales: After buying a hat, Josh has $20 - $10 = $<<20-10=10>>10<n>After buying a pencil, Josh has $10 - $2 = $<<10-2=8>>8<n>The total cost of cookies is 4 * $1.25 = $<<4*1.25=5>>5<n>After buying the cookies, Josh has $8 - $5 = $<<8-5=3>>3<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input:What would release energy, but not mainly in your muscles? Choices:  A: vent B: think C: shouting D: work off E: exercise<n><n>### Response:		Think<n><n>### Instructions:Answer the following multiple-choice question.<n><n>## Rationales: Choices:  A and C<n><n>###  A<n><n>- Input:José has three coins.  One is from Mexico, one is from the United States, and one is from Canada.  If the Mexico coin is worth $0.18, the United States coin is worth $0,10, and the Canadian coin is worth $02. What is the total value of the three coins?<n>- Explanation: In total the three coins have 3*0.18 + 3*0.09 + 3*02 = <<3*0.14+5*0.03+9*0.02=3*0.17=<<5.6>>5.6  cents<n>#### 5.6<n>Answer: 5.6<n><n>## Rational: Choice: Option D<n><n>###  D<n><n>- Input:Campus security is considering whether they should use 3 guards or 1 guard.  A 1 guards work for 8 hours.  2 guards work for 6 hours.  3 guards work for 4 hours. Which is cheaper?<n>- Explanations: A guards work for 36 hours at $20/8=<<20/8=2.5>>2.5 per hour/day<n>If we add 2 guards at 2.5/6=<<2.5/6=.4167>>.4167 it still equal to 6+8=<<6+8=14>>1.4167 so we can say that 3 guards are cheaper<n>#### 1.41666666...<n>Answer: 1.41<n><n>## Rational C: Choice:Option E<n><n>### E<n><n>- Input:Ten animals cost $150.  Three times as many animals cost $210.  How many times more expensive is $210 than $150?<n>- Explanatory Rationale: Ten times cheaper<n>- Three times as many means, there are 3*10 animals.<n>- So it means we multiply 3*10 by

How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100. He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn. You are the editor for the review.<n><n>### Passage A:This article is about the world's leading businessman, Bill Gates.<n>The article says that the richest man in the world is a billionaire from America who was born in Washington DC on the 28th of October 1955. By the time he reaches the age of 18 years old, Bill Gates had already developed his first software program and was already earning money. 5 years later, Mr. Gates had formed Microsoft Corporation with his friend Paul Allen. Microsoft now runs the Windows operating systems and the software that runs on them. Microsoft also makes computers for all kinds of people around the world.<n><n>### 💬 Writing<n>### Summary:<n>What is the passage about?<n>In this passage, a writer named John describes a news story. The title is "Bill Gates : The World's Leading Businessman". The writer gives us a brief outline of Bill Gates' life. The writer talks about his start-up at age 18. The article mainly describes how hard of a worker the man is, the founder of the company Microsoft which today is one of the most successful companies in the world, and the founder of the Gates foundation which does a lot of charity work.<n><n>### Opinion<n>What is your opinion of this passage?<n>I have always heard of this legendary man. I didn't realize that he is the founder of Microsoft, one of the three companies that we have. Bill Gates is like a hero to me because he is a billionaire and he gives half of it away to charity.<n><n>### Answer:C<n><n>### <n>

" not "How many times is three times 5?<n>*In the answer choice 75, the expression 3 times 5 is being repeated six times in a row while the question asks how many times it is being repeated in general.<n>*The solution is to just say 6 times in general. <n>#### 3<n>*answer 5<n><n>### Output<n>

Choices:  A: alert B: deep sleep C: drink coffee D: open eyes E: conscious<n><n>### Response:		D<n><n>### Explain what the answer is:<n>Since we don't know what person it is, we can't really answer this question. We do know though that this person is awake. Because they are awake, they are at least partially conscious or at least awake enough to know what's currently happening.<n><n>### Input:"Jenny and Steve played with a dollhouse in the park and Jenny drew a picture of the house today. Steve drew a picture of a tree." Which of the following could follow these statements?  A:  Steve plays with the dollhouse in the park.  B:  Jenny drew a  picture of the house in the park.  C:  The park has a dollhouse in it.  D:  Both Jenny and Steve drew pictures of the house.<n><n>### A<n><n>### Expand:<n>Steve made a drawing of a tree. Since the park is not the tree, the house is not the tree. So Steve could not draw a picture of the house. Since Jenny drew a picture, she is the one who drew a picture. So, Steve did not draw a picture. The picture of the house was made by Jenny.<n><n>### Explained:<n>Steve plays in the park. However, a house is not present. Jenny drew a picture because she knows what is going on. She draws a picture of the house because she knows what it looks like from memory.<n><n>### The park has no doll house in it because that is Steve and Jenny's house. It is their house.<n><n>## What You Have Learned<n>- This is an instruction.<n><n>- This is a demonstration.<n><n>- The only way to answer this type of question is to answer each part carefully and provide an answer that fits the problem.<n><n>## You may skip the questions, but be sure to complete the instruction first before you can continue.<n><n>- This question is a demonstration.  It asks me to complete the request. Because there is only one way to answer, I can answer by following the steps in the instructions. <n><n>- In this question, we don't want to skip the instructions.<n><n>- This answer is the same answer as 40.<n><n>- The answer in this question is 43.<n><n>## How did this help you complete this task?
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Rationales: If he babysits for 2 hours at $7 per hour, he will earn 2*7 = $<<2*7=14>>14<n>This week he will earn $5 allowance, $10 mowing the lawn and $14 from babysitting for a total of 5+10+14 = $<<5+10+14=29>>29<n>If we add the $29 he will earn to his $65 savings, he will have a total of 29 + 65 = $<<29+65=94>>94<n>The bike costs $100 and he will have $94 leaving $100-$94 = $<<100-94=6>>6 more that he will need to earn<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Rationales: His kangaroos have a total of 23*2=<<23*2=46>>46 legs<n>He has 23*3=<<23*3=69>>69 goats<n>The goats have 69*4=<<69*4=276>>276 legs<n>So in total his animals have 276+46=<<276+46=322>>322 legs<n>#### 322<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Rationales: After buying a hat, Josh has $20 - $10 = $<<20-10=10>>10<n>After buying a pencil, Josh has $10 - $2 = $<<10-2=8>>8<n>The total cost of cookies is 4 * $1.25 = $<<4*1.25=5>>5<n>After buying the cookies, Josh has $8 - $5 = $<<8-5=3>>3<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input:What do humans do when in a race? Choices:  A: lay eggs B: eat fruit C: wrestle D: compete with each other E: draw pictures<n><n>### Response:		<n>When humans are in a race, they eat fruit because they all are runners and when runners are on a run they often eat food to boost their energy. They also take breaks periodically and sometimes have to stop and eat.<n><n>##### <n><n>### The Answer:<n>![The answer to 369](/assets/images/369_Answer.png)<n>###### 85<n>Answer: 85<n><n>### Input Choices:<n>* 05<n>* 55<n>* 75<n>* 35<n>* 15 * 15<n>* 20<n>* 15<n>* -15<n>* 10<n>* 00 * 00<n>* -20<n>* 5.24<n>* 12.55<n>* 24.69<n>* 36.93<n>* 0.369<n>* 85<n>* 85.21<n>* 95.11<n>* 856<n>* 755<n>* 65<n>* 125<n>* 115<n><n>#### 85<n>Answer 85, The Answer to 369<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Rationales: If he babysits for 2 hours at $7 per hour, he will earn 2*7 = $<<2*7=14>>14<n>This week he will earn $5 allowance, $10 mowing the lawn and $14 from babysitting for a total of 5+10+14 = $<<5+10+14=29>>29<n>If we add the $29 he will earn to his $65 savings, he will have a total of 29 + 65 = $<<29+65=94>>94<n>The bike costs $100 and he will have $94 leaving $100-$94 = $<<100-94=6>>6 more that he will need to earn<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Rationales: His kangaroos have a total of 23*2=<<23*2=46>>46 legs<n>He has 23*3=<<23*3=69>>69 goats<n>The goats have 69*4=<<69*4=276>>276 legs<n>So in total his animals have 276+46=<<276+46=322>>322 legs<n>#### 322<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Rationales: After buying a hat, Josh has $20 - $10 = $<<20-10=10>>10<n>After buying a pencil, Josh has $10 - $2 = $<<10-2=8>>8<n>The total cost of cookies is 4 * $1.25 = $<<4*1.25=5>>5<n>After buying the cookies, Josh has $8 - $5 = $<<8-5=3>>3<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input:What happens to people playing games? Choices:  A: winning B: entertainment C: happiness D: cheating E: relaxation<n><n>### Response:		The correct answer is B. People playing games are playing to be entertained and are not cheating. A person may win a game but not have fun playing it.<n>

They were all paid $15.00 per hour for the number of hours they worked.<n><n>Three workers were assigned to rake leaves. Six of the eight each worked three hours. For working 6 hours each, the workers were paid $9 each for making street repairs.<n><n>No one knew how many hours the remaining two workers worked. The city manager said they did not work on the mows since they did the leaves or street repairs. <n><n>How much was the total payments owed the workers for the eight workers that made street repairs?<n><n>### Incorrect response<n>300<n>### Correct response<n>476<n><n>### Input3:<n>Jill was born on February 1st. She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.
