If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Rationales: After buying a hat, Josh has $20 - $10 = $<<20-10=10>>10<n>After buying a pencil, Josh has $10 - $2 = $<<10-2=8>>8<n>The total cost of cookies is 4 * $1.25 = $<<4*1.25=5>>5<n>After buying the cookies, Josh has $8 - $5 = $<<8-5=3>>3<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input:Sam was against Allison's decision.  Joe was the opposite.  What was Joe, regarding that decision? Choices:  A: being for B: away from C: combined D: for or E: conjunction<n><n>### Response:		<n>Choices:<n>1.<n>2.<n>3.<n>4.<n><n>### InputA goose follows the letter J. A sheep follows the letter E. In pairs they go around and around. The goose moves towards and never away from any letter being on that letter. The sheep follows the letter around and never goes into any of the letters.  What letter does the sheep end up on?<n><n>Rationales:<n>The goose moves towards and towards only the letter ‘J’ because it does not move away from the letter ‘J’, like a sheep, which moves away from any letter.<n>The sheep moves away from the letter ‘E’ since the sheep follows the letter ‘E’ around which is like moving away from the letter ‘A’ because the goose follows the letter ‘J’ which is the goose’s destination. <n>The goose comes and goes around the other letters except ‘E’ and ‘J’.<n>If the goose comes to the letter ‘J’ and goes to the letter ‘J, the only letters left in the row are the E and the J. The goose moves from the letter ‘E, to the letter ‘J and the sheep moves from the letter E to the letter ‘J.<n>So the last letter the goose is on is the letter J and the sheep will be on the letter ‘E.<n>![](https://github.com/bharriss/homework/blob/master/HW-9161s/HW/HW10/9161sHW/Screen%2BBitmoji.png?raw=true)<n><n>#### Answer:<n>The sheep will be on the last letter the go does not move away from J<n>Answer: J
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Rationales: If he babysits for 2 hours at $7 per hour, he will earn 2*7 = $<<2*7=14>>14<n>This week he will earn $5 allowance, $10 mowing the lawn and $14 from babysitting for a total of 5+10+14 = $<<5+10+14=29>>29<n>If we add the $29 he will earn to his $65 savings, he will have a total of 29 + 65 = $<<29+65=94>>94<n>The bike costs $100 and he will have $94 leaving $100-$94 = $<<100-94=6>>6 more that he will need to earn<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Rationales: His kangaroos have a total of 23*2=<<23*2=46>>46 legs<n>He has 23*3=<<23*3=69>>69 goats<n>The goats have 69*4=<<69*4=276>>276 legs<n>So in total his animals have 276+46=<<276+46=322>>322 legs<n>#### 322<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Rationales: After buying a hat, Josh has $20 - $10 = $<<20-10=10>>10<n>After buying a pencil, Josh has $10 - $2 = $<<10-2=8>>8<n>The total cost of cookies is 4 * $1.25 = $<<4*1.25=5>>5<n>After buying the cookies, Josh has $8 - $5 = $<<8-5=3>>3<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input:Where could you find a bookstore? Choices:  A: town B: carpeting C: city D: phone book E: magazines<n><n>### Response:		<n>C<n><n>### Rationale:  Books are a product sold by bookstores.  Magazines can be found in magazine stores, but books can be found in bookstores as well.<n><n><n><n>### Question 1:<n><n>### Demand: What does 'demand' mean?<n><n>### Rationales: Answer: A. B. C. D.  E.<n><n><n><n><n>## Question 2:<n><n>### Where could you find a phone book? Choices: <n><n>### Roles: <n><n>## Rationales:<n><n>### Response<n><n><n>### Where can you find a phone book<n><n>### Rationals<n>C<n><n><n><n>## Below is a sentence with an underlined word or phrase.<n><n>Edit that sentence by replacing the underlined term with one option, or by putting it in parentheses.<n><n>Input:  A dog is sleeping under a tree.<n><n>Rationales:  Dog is an animal. dog is a verb that means he's moving under the tree.. animal is a category..sleeping means resting but he's not sleeping there<n><n>Answer:  A dog sleeps (is resting under the tree)<n>#### A dog sleeps under a tree<n><n><n>### Write a response to this sentence<n><n><n>When George was very little he thought a cat was a dog.<n><n>Input: When George was very little he ____ a cat was a dog<n><n>Answer:  When George was very little (he thought) a cat was a dog

How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100. He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Rationales: If he babysits for 2 hours at $7 per hour, he will earn 2*7 = $<<2*7=14>>14<n>This week he will earn $5 allowance, $10 mowing the lawn and $14 from babysitting for a total of 5+10+14 = $<<5+10+14=29>>29<n>If we add the $29 he will earn to his $65 savings, he will have a total of 29 + 65 = $<<29+65=94>>94<n>The bike costs $100 and he will have $94 leaving $100-$94 = $<<100-94=6>>6 more that he will need to earn<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Rationales: After buying a hat, Josh has $20 - $10 = $<<20-10=10>>10<n>After buying a pencil, Josh has $10 - $2 = $<<10-2=8>>8<n>The total cost of cookies is 4 * $1.25 = $<<4*1.25=5>>5<n>After buying the cookies, Josh has $8 - $5 = $<<8-5=3>>3<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input:Which effect of stress could cause death if not treated immediately? Choices:  A: age grieving person B: heart attacks C: depression D: hair loss E: headache<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>```py<n>def stressEffectAndDeath():<n>    if (stress == 'death'):<n>        die('death')<n>    elif Stress == 'hair loss':<n>        lose('hair')<n>    elif (stress == 'heart attacks':<n>        die('heart attack')<n>    elif stress == 'age grieving person':<n>        die('age')<n>def die(option):<n>    if str(age.year) < 18:<n>        death(option,'Adults')<n>    elif (Age >= 18):<n>        die(option,'TeenAge')<n>    else:<n>        die(option, 'Infant')<n>def die(choice,Type):<n>    if (Type == 'Infant'):<n>        InfantDeath('adults')<n>    else:if (Type == 'TeenAge'):<n>        TeenDeath('adult')<n>def InfantDeath(stress):<n>    if (Gender == male):<n>        print(stress+' is the second death')<n>    elif (Gender == female):<n>        print(sress+' is the first death')<n>def TeenDeath(stressy):<n>    if (str(age.year) >= 18): Gender=='Male'<n>        else: Gender='female'<n>        print(str(stress+Gender))<n>    else: print(str(str+Gender))<n>```<n><n>### Rationale:<n><n>*stress=='death': will cause death*<n>*stress== 'Age Griving Person':will cause death*<n>*Stress=='heart attack': will cause cause death *<n>*stress==''hair loss'': will have you bald
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Rationales: If he babysits for 2 hours at $7 per hour, he will earn 2*7 = $<<2*7=14>>14<n>This week he will earn $5 allowance, $10 mowing the lawn and $14 from babysitting for a total of 5+10+14 = $<<5+10+14=29>>29<n>If we add the $29 he will earn to his $65 savings, he will have a total of 29 + 65 = $<<29+65=94>>94<n>The bike costs $100 and he will have $94 leaving $100-$94 = $<<100-94=6>>6 more that he will need to earn<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Rationales: His kangaroos have a total of 23*2=<<23*2=46>>46 legs<n>He has 23*3=<<23*3=69>>69 goats<n>The goats have 69*4=<<69*4=276>>276 legs<n>So in total his animals have 276+46=<<276+46=322>>322 legs<n>#### 322<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Rationales: After buying a hat, Josh has $20 - $10 = $<<20-10=10>>10<n>After buying a pencil, Josh has $10 - $2 = $<<10-2=8>>8<n>The total cost of cookies is 4 * $1.25 = $<<4*1.25=5>>5<n>After buying the cookies, Josh has $8 - $5 = $<<8-5=3>>3<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input:Where might you have cake with your ice cream? Choices:  A: earth B: movie C: party D: served cold E: freezer<n><n>### Response:		<n>A. earth<n><n>### Input:"Today it was 95 degrees.  Is tomorrow going to be hotter?" Answer:Yes\strong{or}No<n><n>### Reponse:<n>Yes<n>

Choices:  A: theater B: computer C: opera D: television E: concert<n><n>### Response:		<n>In order to find the answer, we start looking at the letters A - E for clues on how we could differentiate.<n><n>#### A for theater, B for computer, C for opera, D for television, E for concert<n><n>Each response has only 1 occurrence of each letter.<n><n>When taking "a program", A and C are the same because it is a paper "program".<n><n>After going through and eliminating the "non-matches", I'm left with two choices -- "B" or "D".<n><n>I go to dictionary.com to look for "program":<n><n>> [Definition of "program", The Free Dictionary](https://www.thefreedictionary.com/program)<n><n>#### -noun \ˈprä- gram\<n><n>: a series of events; also : the schedule of events for a theatrical or other production<n><n>So in the end, I would say that the best answer is "B" because "B" matches both theater and computer.<n><n>#### B<n><n><n>### Next Instruction:<n>Write a response using the request "List three or four things that are 3 feet each".<n><n>### Next Demonstration: <n>Write a response that appropriately list 3 or 4 things that are each 3 feet.<n><n>### Next Response:<n><n>Things that are 3 feet:<n><n>1. Choices:  A: drinking B: intimacy C: dancing D: happiness E: enjoyment<n><n>### Response:		A: drinking<n><n>### Rationale:It says "If" they were celebrating the "occasion" and "occasion" refers to birthday. So, if they were celebrating a birthday they could be drinking with cake.<n>#### <n><n>### Input<n>Input: If the number of students to attend a meeting are 12%, 10 students are going to attend the meeting. How many students are in the meeting?<n><n>### Response<n>So there are 12% students who are going to attend the conference and there will be 10 students overall in this conference.<n><n>\$<n>12\\10=1\\112-10<n>\$<n><n>That will be 1.05<n><n>#### 1.05 students<n><n>### Rationales<n>To be more specific to the students, their proportion has already been given in the question and according to the information, the total number of students is 1.05.<n><n>### Input 2<n>Input: In an office a person is paid either $10 and hour, $13 and hour, or $15 and hour. If they are paid $13 and hour.  If overtime pay is $2 per hour on all of their hours. How much should the employee be paid?<n><n>### Rerponse 2<n><n>So the first part that is given is that the person is paid $13, and there are two possibilities of this happening; for $15 or for $10. <n>If they are paid at $13 then they will make $13 per hour.  If over time at $2 per hour: 1+1=$2<n>But each hour that they work they have already been paid for $13 hours and now they get $2 for every 13 hours they work, so they will get extra paid of $13*(number of hours worked) (13-1)=12*(number of hours worked). <n><n>#### 12*$2=$24<n><n>### Rationel<n>You already paid a base rate for time of $13.  For every hour that they work you get paid $2 for every hour you work.  All hours in work will be multiplied by 13 and then you multiply that by 2. This will give you the final payment
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Rationales: If he babysits for 2 hours at $7 per hour, he will earn 2*7 = $<<2*7=14>>14<n>This week he will earn $5 allowance, $10 mowing the lawn and $14 from babysitting for a total of 5+10+14 = $<<5+10+14=29>>29<n>If we add the $29 he will earn to his $65 savings, he will have a total of 29 + 65 = $<<29+65=94>>94<n>The bike costs $100 and he will have $94 leaving $100-$94 = $<<100-94=6>>6 more that he will need to earn<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Rationales: His kangaroos have a total of 23*2=<<23*2=46>>46 legs<n>He has 23*3=<<23*3=69>>69 goats<n>The goats have 69*4=<<69*4=276>>276 legs<n>So in total his animals have 276+46=<<276+46=322>>322 legs<n>#### 322<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Rationales: After buying a hat, Josh has $20 - $10 = $<<20-10=10>>10<n>After buying a pencil, Josh has $10 - $2 = $<<10-2=8>>8<n>The total cost of cookies is 4 * $1.25 = $<<4*1.25=5>>5<n>After buying the cookies, Josh has $8 - $5 = $<<8-5=3>>3<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input:Where could you find some large pieces of paper that are not for sale? Choices:  A: cabinet B: computer printer C: suitcase D: office supply store E: artist's studio<n><n>### Response:		Artist's Studio<n><n>### Input<n>Why did the student who ate all the candy get a bad grade? <n>### Response<n>Because he ate all the candies.<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Rationales: If he babysits for 2 hours at $7 per hour, he will earn 2*7 = $<<2*7=14>>14<n>This week he will earn $5 allowance, $10 mowing the lawn and $14 from babysitting for a total of 5+10+14 = $<<5+10+14=29>>29<n>If we add the $29 he will earn to his $65 savings, he will have a total of 29 + 65 = $<<29+65=94>>94<n>The bike costs $100 and he will have $94 leaving $100-$94 = $<<100-94=6>>6 more that he will need to earn<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Rationales: His kangaroos have a total of 23*2=<<23*2=46>>46 legs<n>He has 23*3=<<23*3=69>>69 goats<n>The goats have 69*4=<<69*4=276>>276 legs<n>So in total his animals have 276+46=<<276+46=322>>322 legs<n>#### 322<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Rationales: After buying a hat, Josh has $20 - $10 = $<<20-10=10>>10<n>After buying a pencil, Josh has $10 - $2 = $<<10-2=8>>8<n>The total cost of cookies is 4 * $1.25 = $<<4*1.25=5>>5<n>After buying the cookies, Josh has $8 - $5 = $<<8-5=3>>3<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input:Why would professionals playing sports not be able to compete? Choices:  A: pain B: mudslide C: sweating D: injuries E: rain<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>### Rationales:<n>Pain is a cause for a professional sports competitor not being able to play in the game.<n><n>### ##<n>Answer: A<n><n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100. How many times have you ever read a book? If you don't know off the top of your head, you can estimate.<n><n>### Partial Rationale: This choice is incorrect. The rationale includes answers to choices other than what is shown.<n><n>### Rationale: This answer doesn’t need a rational since I don’t know the answer to it.<n><n>### Note: This question can also be thought of as, “How many times have you ever watched a movie in a theatre?”<n><n>### Input Answers:<n>I’ve never read a book.<n><n>### Answer: I don’t know how many times I’ve watched a movie in a theater.<n><n>### Choice:I’d be interested in learning more about how to learn and make things.<n><n>### Proposed Rationale: This choice was incorrect even though it provided a partial rationale (that other parts were correct.)<n><n>### Part of Rationale: I’d be interested in reading books. I’d be interested to learn more about math. I’d also be […].<n><n>### Proposal Rationale: Books are one of those ways. Math in any of its forms (such as reading, taking a class etc.,) would be another. There is tons of information and tutorials available online to learn a variety of things which could take up most of my free time if I wanted.<n><n>### Other Examples<n>I was going to ask you to fix it for me because I don’t know (answer)<n>I’d like to answer you (I think that is what was intended)<n>So my question (if that is what you mean) is,<n>I need to figure out (answer) and would like some help.<n>I would like your comments on (something) and any suggestions to (something).<n>I have (something) and I’m concerned about<n><n>I have (something and would like your opinion on it.

Choices:  A: surrender B: defence C: retreat D: cease fire E: defend<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>### Answer:A<n><n>### Input : I have 7 friends in my class.  In order to win I need to be one of the people that is chosen to play.  I will win if there are fewer than 2 people with the same number of votes and I am one of the winners.  If there are 5 people with the same number votes, I will not win because I have the same number of votes as only one winner. If I am chosen to play, I will need 15 votes.<n>Rationales: In order to win, there must be fewer than 2 people.  If it were to be 3 or more, the person voted on would only need 7 to win in order to be a winner.<n>If there would then be the winner who would then have 10 votes then I would have 15 votes.  I only need 15 votes to win if there are only 2 winners.  There is no way that me playing would cause me not to win.<n>#### 2<n>Answer: 2<n><n>### Input::In the 14th and final round, a two-minute break will be given. After the break, each team will get three opportunities to score a field goal. They will score three points for a successful kick.<n>Rationales<n>In 14th round, 2*3 = <<2*3=6>>6<n><n>#### 6<n><n>Answer: 6

How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Rationales: If he babysits for 2 hours at $7 per hour, he will earn 2*7 = $<<2*7=14>>14<n>This week he will earn $5 allowance, $10 mowing the lawn and $14 from babysitting for a total of 5+10+14 = $<<5+10+14=29>>29<n>If we add the $29 he will earn to his $65 savings, he will have a total of 29 + 65 = $<<29+65=94>>94<n>The bike costs $100 and he will have $94 leaving $100-$94 = $<<100-94=6>>6 more that he will need to earn<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Rationales: His kangaroos have a total of 23*2=<<23*2=46>>46 legs<n>He has 23*3=<<23*3=69>>69 goats<n>The goats have 69*4=<<69*4=276>>276 legs<n>So in total his animals have 276+46=<<276+46=322>>322 legs<n>#### 322<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Rationales: After buying a hat, Josh has $20 - $10 = $<<20-10=10>>10<n>After buying a pencil, Josh has $10 - $2 = $<<10-2=8>>8<n>The total cost of cookies is 4 * $1.25 = $<<4*1.25=5>>5<n>After buying the cookies, Josh has $8 - $5 = $<<8-5=3>>3<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input:The shore was now a tourist attraction with nearby little shops, but at one time this what was home to a bustling fishing industry? Choices:  A: seaside town B: resort C: ocean D: california E: beach<n><n>### Response:		D
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Rationales: If he babysits for 2 hours at $7 per hour, he will earn 2*7 = $<<2*7=14>>14<n>This week he will earn $5 allowance, $10 mowing the lawn and $14 from babysitting for a total of 5+10+14 = $<<5+10+14=29>>29<n>If we add the $29 he will earn to his $65 savings, he will have a total of 29 + 65 = $<<29+65=94>>94<n>The bike costs $100 and he will have $94 leaving $100-$94 = $<<100-94=6>>6 more that he will need to earn<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Rationales: His kangaroos have a total of 23*2=<<23*2=46>>46 legs<n>He has 23*3=<<23*3=69>>69 goats<n>The goats have 69*4=<<69*4=276>>276 legs<n>So in total his animals have 276+46=<<276+46=322>>322 legs<n>#### 322<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Rationales: After buying a hat, Josh has $20 - $10 = $<<20-10=10>>10<n>After buying a pencil, Josh has $10 - $2 = $<<10-2=8>>8<n>The total cost of cookies is 4 * $1.25 = $<<4*1.25=5>>5<n>After buying the cookies, Josh has $8 - $5 = $<<8-5=3>>3<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input:When someone falls from a mountain it will lead them to? Choices:  A: too much B: act dead C: die D: rush E: explode<n><n>### Response:		A)Too much<n><n>### Input A: Mary had 80 toys and wanted to pick 4 toys from each category. She picked 4 dinosaurs, 4 stuffed animals, and 2 cars. Then she picked 4 dragons, 4 jacks, 4 baby dolls, and 2 trucks. How many of each category did Mary collect?<n><n>### Response Choices:  <n>A) 0 cars, 0 dinosaurs, 2 of each of the rest of the categories  \(\frac{0}{0}+\frac{4}{0}+\frac{2}{2} = \frac{4}{2}\)\nB) 2 cars, 0 dinosauers, \(\frac{2}{0}\)\n\( +\frac{4}{0} \)  = \((4/2)\)\n\( +\)\((4/2)\)=\)\(\frac{0}{2}\)\nC) 0 of each  \(\frac{4}{4}+\frac{0}{0} + \frac{2}{2}+\frac{0}{2} =\frac{6}{2}\)\nD) 4 cars, 2 dinosaurs, 0 stuffed animals, 0 jacks, 0 baby dolls, and \(\frac{4.2}{2}\)\nE) 2 dinosaurs and then picked random \((4/2) + \frac{2.2}{2}\)<n>\]\( = \frac{6.2}{2}\), \(\frac{6.2/2}{1}\)<n><n>\]\( =(3.1)\)\nF) 4 dinosaurs and one thing else<n>\]\( =\frac{4/2 +1.000 \)\(=\)\(\frac{4.1 \)\(-\) 0}{2}\)<n>\(=\frac{4.1}{2}\)\n\n<n><n>### Input B: Write an expression that shows the total amount that she left with after adding the cost of the hats.<n>\]\( = 80 - 25 + the cost of the hatches\) = 80 - \((2.5) \times 4\) = \((77)\)\n\n<n>Categories:\n<n>Dinosaurs
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Rationales: If he babysits for 2 hours at $7 per hour, he will earn 2*7 = $<<2*7=14>>14<n>This week he will earn $5 allowance, $10 mowing the lawn and $14 from babysitting for a total of 5+10+14 = $<<5+10+14=29>>29<n>If we add the $29 he will earn to his $65 savings, he will have a total of 29 + 65 = $<<29+65=94>>94<n>The bike costs $100 and he will have $94 leaving $100-$94 = $<<100-94=6>>6 more that he will need to earn<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Rationales: His kangaroos have a total of 23*2=<<23*2=46>>46 legs<n>He has 23*3=<<23*3=69>>69 goats<n>The goats have 69*4=<<69*4=276>>276 legs<n>So in total his animals have 276+46=<<276+46=322>>322 legs<n>#### 322<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Rationales: After buying a hat, Josh has $20 - $10 = $<<20-10=10>>10<n>After buying a pencil, Josh has $10 - $2 = $<<10-2=8>>8<n>The total cost of cookies is 4 * $1.25 = $<<4*1.25=5>>5<n>After buying the cookies, Josh has $8 - $5 = $<<8-5=3>>3<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input:There was a saucepan used only for marinara, where was it kept? If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Rationales: After buying a hat, Josh has $20 - $10 = $<<20-10=10>>10<n>After buying a pencil, Josh has $10 - $2 = $<<10-2=8>>8<n>The total cost of cookies is 4 * $1.25 = $<<4*1.25=5>>5<n>After buying the cookies, Josh has $8 - $5 = $<<8-5=3>>3<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input:What is someone watching a person who is playing guitar doing? Choices:  A: auditioning B: hear sounds C: listening to music D: making music E: arthritis<n><n>### Response:		Inspector<n>### Comments: The person isn't making music but rather listening to music. Someone who is doing that is listening, not making.<n>The guitar player is doing music which is making music.<n><n>### InputA: How many apples are in the box?  Choices: A: 6 apples B: 7 apples C: 8 apples D: 9 apples E: 10 apples<n><n>### ResponseA: A<n>### CommentsA: 6-7-8-9-10<n><n>### InputB: How many minutes to the next train?  Choices: B: 10 minutes C: 21 minutes D: 9 minutes E: 4 minutes<n><n>### ResponseB: E<n>### CommentsB: 4-10-21-9<n><n>### InputC: How many feet long is your room? Choices: C: 1ft 6in D: 3ft E: 1ft F: 2ft<n><n>### ResponseC: B<n>### CommentsC: 1ft-2ft-3ft-4ft-5ft-6ft 6ft-5ft-4ft-3ft-2ft-1ft  16ft<n><n>### InputD: How tall is the tabletop?  Choices: D: 12" E: 24" F: 20" G: 26" H: 19"<n><n>### ResponseD: G<n>### CommentsD: 24"-12"-20"-26"-22"-28"  23"<n><n>### InputE: How many minutes is the next train? Choices: E: no train F: 100 years G: 11 minutes H: 9 minutes. I: 42 minutes <n><n>### ResponseE:C<n>### CommentsE: 9-11-42-11-100 years-<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Rationales: If he babysits for 2 hours at $7 per hour, he will earn 2*7 = $<<2*7=14>>14<n>This week he will earn $5 allowance, $10 mowing the lawn and $14 from babysitting for a total of 5+10+14 = $<<5+10+14=29>>29<n>If we add the $29 he will earn to his $65 savings, he will have a total of 29 + 65 = $<<29+65=94>>94<n>The bike costs $100 and he will have $94 leaving $100-$94 = $<<100-94=6>>6 more that he will need to earn<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Rationales: His kangaroos have a total of 23*2=<<23*2=46>>46 legs<n>He has 23*3=<<23*3=69>>69 goats<n>The goats have 69*4=<<69*4=276>>276 legs<n>So in total his animals have 276+46=<<276+46=322>>322 legs<n>#### 322<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Rationales: After buying a hat, Josh has $20 - $10 = $<<20-10=10>>10<n>After buying a pencil, Josh has $10 - $2 = $<<10-2=8>>8<n>The total cost of cookies is 4 * $1.25 = $<<4*1.25=5>>5<n>After buying the cookies, Josh has $8 - $5 = $<<8-5=3>>3<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input:James thought that giving the AI a secular upbringing would be the better choice.  He felt that the alternative might have results that were too what? Choices:  A: eternal B: religious C: unpredictable D: holy E: monastic<n><n>### Response:		<n>What Is It:<n>A<n><n>### Response Explanation:<n>James thought that giving the ai an eternal life cycle would result in a too eternal AI.<n><n>### Response justification / Explanation:<n><n>#### A<n><n>Answer: <n>A<n><n>## Discussion<n><n>You can ask for help! You can also send a message to a tutor.<n><n>A tutor might not immediately answer your message but don't worry! How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100. You want to write code for program that asks the user what he wants from choices A,B,C,D,E  If (option chosen=E) the program will print E is correct if (Option chosen=A)... print A is incorrect and so on for all option<n>#### 0: E is the correct answer<n>#### 1: A is incorrect<n>#### 2: B is incorrect<n>#### 3: C is incorrect<n>#### 4: D is incorrect<n>#### 5: None of the above is incorrect

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Rationales: If he babysits for 2 hours at $7 per hour, he will earn 2*7 = $<<2*7=14>>14<n>This week he will earn $5 allowance, $10 mowing the lawn and $14 from babysitting for a total of 5+10+14 = $<<5+10+14=29>>29<n>If we add the $29 he will earn to his $65 savings, he will have a total of 29 + 65 = $<<29+65=94>>94<n>The bike costs $100 and he will have $94 leaving $100-$94 = $<<100-94=6>>6 more that he will need to earn<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Rationales: His kangaroos have a total of 23*2=<<23*2=46>>46 legs<n>He has 23*3=<<23*3=69>>69 goats<n>The goats have 69*4=<<69*4=276>>276 legs<n>So in total his animals have 276+46=<<276+46=322>>322 legs<n>#### 322<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Rationales: After buying a hat, Josh has $20 - $10 = $<<20-10=10>>10<n>After buying a pencil, Josh has $10 - $2 = $<<10-2=8>>8<n>The total cost of cookies is 4 * $1.25 = $<<4*1.25=5>>5<n>After buying the cookies, Josh has $8 - $5 = $<<8-5=3>>3<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input:The man was playfully wrestling with a woman he was enamored with, what was the physiological result? Choices:  A: competition B: blood C: wins D: medals E: erections<n><n>### Response:		The physiological result is a: competition<n><n>### Demostration:<n><n>The man was playfully *wrestling* with a woman he was *enamored* with. In order to properly compete, they would've had to be wrestling in a *blood* match.<n>While in a *combat* situation, their *victory* *came* in the form of *honorable mention*. In a medical *setting*, wrestling could lead to *medical* problems.<n>A man suffering *edema* and *hemorrhage* may appear to be suffering a *boner* due to an *erection*.  <n>But since we just don't know about the circumstances, we can't know for certain. <n><n>### Input : What is the main function of a hematoma? Choices: 1. to increase oxygen blood concentration 2.to decrease oxygen blood concentration 3.to help wounds heal 4.to help transport nutrients throughout the body 5.to help transport waste products throughout the body<n><n><n>### Demonsstration<n>Hematomas are not functions, they are results of a disease.<n>The main function of a **blood clot**, or an **emicost*, is to prevent bleeding from occurring; thus to help in the **process** of wound **healing**.<n><n>When a clot is formed, one of two things happens, the clot dissolves or expands, but we are interested in **the first instance**.<n><n>**Edema** *a swelling caused by the accumulation of fluid in the tissues of the body. Edema is most often the result of other disorders rather than a disease in and of itself*, is one result from hematomas.<n><n>*A hemorrhage (also called bleeding) is a pathological shedding of blood from a part of the body. *There is usually no obvious cause for a hemorrhage and they are known as "bleeds in the clear".<n><n>### Input a choice: What is a phlebotomy? Choices:  a) the act of drawing blood b) the act of removing an embolism c) the act to remove an emiymatic blood clot d) the act of a hemorrh
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Rationales: If he babysits for 2 hours at $7 per hour, he will earn 2*7 = $<<2*7=14>>14<n>This week he will earn $5 allowance, $10 mowing the lawn and $14 from babysitting for a total of 5+10+14 = $<<5+10+14=29>>29<n>If we add the $29 he will earn to his $65 savings, he will have a total of 29 + 65 = $<<29+65=94>>94<n>The bike costs $100 and he will have $94 leaving $100-$94 = $<<100-94=6>>6 more that he will need to earn<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Rationales: His kangaroos have a total of 23*2=<<23*2=46>>46 legs<n>He has 23*3=<<23*3=69>>69 goats<n>The goats have 69*4=<<69*4=276>>276 legs<n>So in total his animals have 276+46=<<276+46=322>>322 legs<n>#### 322<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Rationales: After buying a hat, Josh has $20 - $10 = $<<20-10=10>>10<n>After buying a pencil, Josh has $10 - $2 = $<<10-2=8>>8<n>The total cost of cookies is 4 * $1.25 = $<<4*1.25=5>>5<n>After buying the cookies, Josh has $8 - $5 = $<<8-5=3>>3<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input:The small cabin was not available, so they were upgraded to what? Choices:  A: villa B: spacecraft C: hall D: palace E: hotel<n><n>### Response:		D.<n><n><n>

You pick two marbles, put them back in the box how many marbles of the same color come out? Choices: 1: 2 white2: 1 white and 1 black 3: 2 black4: 3 white5: 3 black<n><n>## Response:2 white<n><n>## Rationales:<n>There are several ways to do this problem, but the most efficient and logical way is to set up a ratio. Here is how we do it:<n><n>\$\dfrac{6}{6} \implies 1\$\<n><n>\$\dfrac {4}{6} \implies \dfrac 46\$<n><n>\$\dfrac{\text {White}}{\text {Total}} \implies \dfrac 1{1+\dfrac{4}{6}}\\\implies \dfrac{0.1666667}{1.0333333} \implies 0.1667 : 0.0333\$<n><n>So, to find the total amount of marbles pulled, we simply add 0.03 + 0.16 = $\frac{0.16}{0.16}$ = 1.<n><n>In this case, we're pulling 1 white and 3 black marbles, so our answer is C.<n><n>#### 2 white<n><n>##Input:John counted the number of apples in each box. How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Rationales: If he babysits for 2 hours at $7 per hour, he will earn 2*7 = $<<2*7=14>>14<n>This week he will earn $5 allowance, $10 mowing the lawn and $14 from babysitting for a total of 5+10+14 = $<<5+10+14=29>>29<n>If we add the $29 he will earn to his $65 savings, he will have a total of 29 + 65 = $<<29+65=94>>94<n>The bike costs $100 and he will have $94 leaving $100-$94 = $<<100-94=6>>6 more that he will need to earn<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats. If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Rationales: His kangaroos have a total of 23*2=<<23*2=46>>46 legs<n>He has 23*3=<<23*3=69>>69 goats<n>The goats have 69*4=<<69*4=276>>276 legs<n>So in total his animals have 276+46=<<276+46=322>>322 legs<n>#### 322<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Rationales: After buying a hat, Josh has $20 - $10 = $<<20-10=10>>10<n>After buying a pencil, Josh has $10 - $2 = $<<10-2=8>>8<n>The total cost of cookies is 4 * $1.25 = $<<4*1.25=5>>5<n>After buying the cookies, Josh has $8 - $5 = $<<8-5=3>>3<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input:What is illegal to do when you play cards at a casino? Choices:  A: remember B: help C: count D: winning E: dealing<n><n>### Response:		C<n><n>### Rationale: The casino does not allow it's visitors to count the cards they have remaining while playing.<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Rationales: If he babysits for 2 hours at $7 per hour, he will earn 2*7 = $<<2*7=14>>14<n>This week he will earn $5 allowance, $10 mowing the lawn and $14 from babysitting for a total of 5+10+14 = $<<5+10+14=29>>29<n>If we add the $29 he will earn to his $65 savings, he will have a total of 29 + 65 = $<<29+65=94>>94<n>The bike costs $100 and he will have $94 leaving $100-$94 = $<<100-94=6>>6 more that he will need to earn<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats. Choices: A: a box B: a ball C: a stick D: a rubber ball E: a rubber<n>### Response<n><n>An rubber ball<n><n>### Input - Demonstraion - Answer<n><n>Maleko was singing in a rock band and his band was playing music with a lot of bass. Maleko could hear it vibrating evenly in the wood floor and the walls of his house. Even though this happened the drums did not hit the floor and the walls made vibrations, what does this describe? HINT: Think about how a stringed instrument creates sound.<n>If a musician plucks a string on an instrument, it's vibrating will cause a sound to reverberate. Similarly, if a band is playing, and the sounds traveling through the air to your ears reach a solid surface (like the floor), they will bounce back to your ear. What we're describing is called reflective sound.<n><n>### Rationales Answer:If a musician plunks a string on an instrument it's vibrations will cause a sound to travel. Just as sound from a musician travels in air and can then hit an object and bounce back to your ears.<n><n>#### 1<n>Answer: 1<n><n>### Input : Choices: 		What is it when you cannot tell if something is in your own point of view? Choices:  A: let down B: respect C: illness D: satisfaction E: gratitude<n><n>### Response:		D<n><n>### Instructions:A person has 15 apples, 12 oranges, and 10 lemons. She eats 5 apples, 6 oranges, and 8 lemons. How many apples, oranges, and lemons does she have left?<n><n>Rationales:I'm going to write out the problem in a more visual way:<n>She would end up with 3*5+2*6+3*8=<<3*5+2*{6+8}={3+10}>=43<n>3*10=<<3*10=30>>30<n>So she has 3*10-3+43=<<3*{10-3+30}={10-3+27}>=27<n>If you look at it in it's entirety, 3*10=27<n>5*6+2*8=4+14 =18<n>2*14-2+2*8 =4+14 =22<n>so whats left is 27-4-22=<<27-4-{22}>=8
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Rationales: If he babysits for 2 hours at $7 per hour, he will earn 2*7 = $<<2*7=14>>14<n>This week he will earn $5 allowance, $10 mowing the lawn and $14 from babysitting for a total of 5+10+14 = $<<5+10+14=29>>29<n>If we add the $29 he will earn to his $65 savings, he will have a total of 29 + 65 = $<<29+65=94>>94<n>The bike costs $100 and he will have $94 leaving $100-$94 = $<<100-94=6>>6 more that he will need to earn<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Rationales: His kangaroos have a total of 23*2=<<23*2=46>>46 legs<n>He has 23*3=<<23*3=69>>69 goats<n>The goats have 69*4=<<69*4=276>>276 legs<n>So in total his animals have 276+46=<<276+46=322>>322 legs<n>#### 322<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Rationales: After buying a hat, Josh has $20 - $10 = $<<20-10=10>>10<n>After buying a pencil, Josh has $10 - $2 = $<<10-2=8>>8<n>The total cost of cookies is 4 * $1.25 = $<<4*1.25=5>>5<n>After buying the cookies, Josh has $8 - $5 = $<<8-5=3>>3<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input:What did the business require of everyone walking into their store? She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100. He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Rationales: If he babysits for 2 hours at $7 per hour, he will earn 2*7 = $<<2*7=14>>14<n>This week he will earn $5 allowance, $10 mowing the lawn and $14 from babysitting for a total of 5+10+14 = $<<5+10+14=29>>29<n>If we add the $29 he will earn to his $65 savings, he will have a total of 29 + 65 = $<<29+65=94>>94<n>The bike costs $100 and he will have $94 leaving $100-$94 = $<<100-94=6>>6 more that he will need to earn<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats. She makes $5 per hour serving food to customers.  On Friday, she is planning on working at her father’s restaurant until closing.  Customers come in throughout the day and if they order appetizers or pasta they pay 10 cents per appetizer or pasta item. Customers who order a full meal pay $10.45 for their meal.  Rachel wants to earn enough money to buy new ingredients like a bottle of basil for new pest for her restaurant.  By Friday, how much money does Rachel need to earn before she can buy the bottle of basil?<n><n>### Solution<n><n>Rachel earns $5 per hour working. She works for 8 hours on Friday which is 8hr*5=40$, this is her earning for 1 day. The total earning is $325+$40=$365, after purchasing 1 bottle of basil costs $3.5 for it so she need to pay $365-$8=$357.<n><n>### Input Rachel was at the mall during the weekend and she bought one doll and two books at the mall.  If each book costs $25.50 and each doll costs $23, how much money did Rachel spend to buy her products?<n><n>### Solituion<n><n>Rachel bought one book and two dolls in the weekend. The total price of dolls is 23*2=$46, for books, 25.50*1=$11.15. So totally $46+11.15=$57.15.<n><n>###Input<n>Blaire is saving for a bicycle.  The bicycle costs $30. James says, “If I had driven 9 miles north and then 12 miles due west, then I would be standing where you are now.”  How far north is James?<n><n>### Demisturation:<n>James is looking at the map, 9 miles north means he moves 0 miles to north, then he moves 12 miles west from the north.<n>so the distance James moves to make the northwest is 21 miles.<n>since the friend Bob is currently standing where James is, the distance Bob is from him is the distance of moving northwest-16 miles=<<21-16=5>>5<n>#### 5<n>Answer: 5<n>

Choices:  A: say thank B: smile C: looking for D: get more E: show appreciation<n><n>### Response:		Smile<n><n>### Rationale<n>Looking for something is not a correct option because <n>we get something and we don't go somewhere and look for something.<n>Appreciation and show appreciation mean that we are showing appreciation by saying "we are thankful for getting this"<n><n>### Choice E<n><n>### Input:(00008:003539) [heap corruption]<n><n>### Rationales:<n>After reading the instruction and the response in the answer choice, the computer would produce the following output.<n>### Input:In 2018, Markus bought a used car. It cost $4,491. He also paid $42 in sales tax and $64 in registration fees. In all, Markus paid 15 percent of the price of the car to register it. What was the total amount that Markus paid for the car?<n>### Choice A<n>### Choice B<n>### Choice C<n>### Choice D<n>### Choice: 1622<n><n>### Racionales: B has been selected.<n><n>### Choices:(11148):[heap corruption] (11619):[heap coruction ] (13694):[heap corruciton] (15858):[heapcoruction]<n>### Racional E: [heap corruption error] the answer given the problem for the last part is B so since B is the answer for the question, if a person selects the correct B, then the program will create the error "heap corruption error". This error is caused by not having the computer recognize the response as being correct.<n><n><n><n>### Chooses:(10728):[heap collision] (10970):[heap collision error]<n><n>### Choose D: 17 * 27 = [249]<n>### Rationale D: The answer has been selected.<n>### Since computer only read part of the question, it cannot tell that the last part is an integer that was divided by two.<n><n>### Tests:<n>### Choices: 0, 21, 41, 17, 21,
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Rationales: If he babysits for 2 hours at $7 per hour, he will earn 2*7 = $<<2*7=14>>14<n>This week he will earn $5 allowance, $10 mowing the lawn and $14 from babysitting for a total of 5+10+14 = $<<5+10+14=29>>29<n>If we add the $29 he will earn to his $65 savings, he will have a total of 29 + 65 = $<<29+65=94>>94<n>The bike costs $100 and he will have $94 leaving $100-$94 = $<<100-94=6>>6 more that he will need to earn<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Rationales: His kangaroos have a total of 23*2=<<23*2=46>>46 legs<n>He has 23*3=<<23*3=69>>69 goats<n>The goats have 69*4=<<69*4=276>>276 legs<n>So in total his animals have 276+46=<<276+46=322>>322 legs<n>#### 322<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Rationales: After buying a hat, Josh has $20 - $10 = $<<20-10=10>>10<n>After buying a pencil, Josh has $10 - $2 = $<<10-2=8>>8<n>The total cost of cookies is 4 * $1.25 = $<<4*1.25=5>>5<n>After buying the cookies, Josh has $8 - $5 = $<<8-5=3>>3<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input:Some might say that if you want to do something that results in changing society then you need to start from within, to do this what would you be doing? What statement applies to all four?<n><n>1. A: 5 - 2 = 1<n>2. B: 8 - 3 = 5<n>3. C: 7 - 4 = 3<n>4. D: 10 ÷3 = 3<n><n>## answer:1. If we are given a number N, and another number we will ask how many 3’s there are between two consecutive numbers.  In this case that the given numbers are going from 199 to 251.  From 199 to the next number (which is 200) then we just skip this number.

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Rationales: If he babysits for 2 hours at $7 per hour, he will earn 2*7 = $<<2*7=14>>14<n>This week he will earn $5 allowance, $10 mowing the lawn and $14 from babysitting for a total of 5+10+14 = $<<5+10+14=29>>29<n>If we add the $29 he will earn to his $65 savings, he will have a total of 29 + 65 = $<<29+65=94>>94<n>The bike costs $100 and he will have $94 leaving $100-$94 = $<<100-94=6>>6 more that he will need to earn<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Rationales: His kangaroos have a total of 23*2=<<23*2=46>>46 legs<n>He has 23*3=<<23*3=69>>69 goats<n>The goats have 69*4=<<69*4=276>>276 legs<n>So in total his animals have 276+46=<<276+46=322>>322 legs<n>#### 322<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Rationales: After buying a hat, Josh has $20 - $10 = $<<20-10=10>>10<n>After buying a pencil, Josh has $10 - $2 = $<<10-2=8>>8<n>The total cost of cookies is 4 * $1.25 = $<<4*1.25=5>>5<n>After buying the cookies, Josh has $8 - $5 = $<<8-5=3>>3<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input:A yard is made up of what? Choices:  A: city B: michigan C: three feet D: subdivision E: three arm span<n><n>### Response:		Answer the question that appears on the top of this screen.<n><n>### Answer Option 1<n>### Answer Option: The answer to a question like this is always three of the options at the bottom.<n>![img](https://github.com/codingchef/codingchef.github.io/blob/master/pages/images/chef3.png)<n>### Answer Option(a)<n>The answer to a question like Question 1 is always three of the answers on the bottom. This is because the answer consists of either one thing, two things, or three things - so that's the question we're answering.<n><n>### Response<n>The correct response is A.<n><n>### Justification:<n>The answer to this question is always three of the items on the bottom. A yard is a space between different places in a city, and a subdivision is a space of land with different areas. Therefore, it is a space between different areas, and the answer is that a yard is not a subdivision.<n><n>### Explanation:<n>A yard is made up by three things, but a yard is not a space. It is a three point space in the middle where two other spaces meet. So the answer is a space between different spaces. That is a subdivision, and not a yard.<n><n>### Rationale:<n>As long as you recognize that the options are always three of the options on the bottom, and you take note of the space/thing distinction, you are guaranteed to complete the questions correctly.<n><n>```python<n>if (choice == 3):<n>    chef = [choice]<n>else:<n>    chef = [choices]<n>print(chef)<n>```<n>```<n>Output:<n>['A', 'M', 'M']<n><n>```<n><n>### Input<n><n>### Demonsration<n><n>### Answer<n><n>### Justitfication:<n>

His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Rationales: If he babysits for 2 hours at $7 per hour, he will earn 2*7 = $<<2*7=14>>14<n>This week he will earn $5 allowance, $10 mowing the lawn and $14 from babysitting for a total of 5+10+14 = $<<5+10+14=29>>29<n>If we add the $29 he will earn to his $65 savings, he will have a total of 29 + 65 = $<<29+65=94>>94<n>The bike costs $100 and he will have $94 leaving $100-$94 = $<<100-94=6>>6 more that he will need to earn<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Rationales: His kangaroos have a total of 23*2=<<23*2=46>>46 legs<n>He has 23*3=<<23*3=69>>69 goats<n>The goats have 69*4=<<69*4=276>>276 legs<n>So in total his animals have 276+46=<<276+46=322>>322 legs<n>#### 322<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Rationales: After buying a hat, Josh has $20 - $10 = $<<20-10=10>>10<n>After buying a pencil, Josh has $10 - $2 = $<<10-2=8>>8<n>The total cost of cookies is 4 * $1.25 = $<<4*1.25=5>>5<n>After buying the cookies, Josh has $8 - $5 = $<<8-5=3>>3<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input:If children get confused walking home where may they go? Choices:  A: play chess B: sun themselves C: wrong house D: set table E: gettable<n><n>### Response:		Answer the following multiple question.Choices: A) both A and B B) none of the above C) both B and C D) A and D<n>#### D<n>Answer: D<n><n>### Input :Greg is painting a picture with blue, green, purple, red, and yellow.  How many different ways are there to put his colors together to make 5 different colored pictures?<n><n>### Response :Answer the following multiple question<n><n>Choices : A) no way B) 5 ways C) 8 ways D) 10 ways<n>#### B<n>Answer : B<n><n>### Input If there are exactly 1034 people in an office, how many different ways can a group of 2 people greet 1034 different people every morning?<n><n>### Demostration Each morning exactly 1033 people greet 1 person.<n>The first person greets 1032 people.<n>A new person joins the office.<n>Now 1033/2 is the number of way in which exactly two persons can greet 102 people.<n><n><n>### Response Answer the following multiple question<n>#### D<n>Answer : D<n><n>### Instructions:For the number line below, draw and label a number line.<n><n>### Response Write a response in which you complete the table below.Choices: A: less than 5/8ths B: equal to 1/2 C: between 1/3 and 2/9 D: between -1 and 1<n><n>#### D<n>Answer D<n><n>### Demorastion:You can create a fractions table from 3 to 1<n>Draw and label it below.<n>####<n>2  1  0<n>Answer: <n><n>### Input 15, 13, 14, 10, 20, 18<n><n>### Input Which fraction has an addition of 3?<n><n>### Input Select the two fractions that add up to 6 and then add them.
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Rationales: If he babysits for 2 hours at $7 per hour, he will earn 2*7 = $<<2*7=14>>14<n>This week he will earn $5 allowance, $10 mowing the lawn and $14 from babysitting for a total of 5+10+14 = $<<5+10+14=29>>29<n>If we add the $29 he will earn to his $65 savings, he will have a total of 29 + 65 = $<<29+65=94>>94<n>The bike costs $100 and he will have $94 leaving $100-$94 = $<<100-94=6>>6 more that he will need to earn<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Rationales: His kangaroos have a total of 23*2=<<23*2=46>>46 legs<n>He has 23*3=<<23*3=69>>69 goats<n>The goats have 69*4=<<69*4=276>>276 legs<n>So in total his animals have 276+46=<<276+46=322>>322 legs<n>#### 322<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Rationales: After buying a hat, Josh has $20 - $10 = $<<20-10=10>>10<n>After buying a pencil, Josh has $10 - $2 = $<<10-2=8>>8<n>The total cost of cookies is 4 * $1.25 = $<<4*1.25=5>>5<n>After buying the cookies, Josh has $8 - $5 = $<<8-5=3>>3<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input:The graveyard was important to build, where should it be built? Choices:  A: arlington B: church property C: out back D: every town E: cemetery<n><n>### Response:		<n>E<n>#### E<n>Answer: E<n><n>### Instructions: Choose the best answer for the following question.<n><n>Rationales: The answer is given as <<C>> and the options are <<A>>, <<B>>, <<D>>, and <<E>>. We can determine the right answer from the options given from the following:<n><n>Answer: B<n><n>### Answer:B<n><n>### 2:<n>### A<n>### B<n>### C<n>### D<n>### E<n><n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Rationales: If he babysits for 2 hours at $7 per hour, he will earn 2*7 = $<<2*7=14>>14<n>This week he will earn $5 allowance, $10 mowing the lawn and $14 from babysitting for a total of 5+10+14 = $<<5+10+14=29>>29<n>If we add the $29 he will earn to his $65 savings, he will have a total of 29 + 65 = $<<29+65=94>>94<n>The bike costs $100 and he will have $94 leaving $100-$94 = $<<100-94=6>>6 more that he will need to earn<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Rationales: His kangaroos have a total of 23*2=<<23*2=46>>46 legs<n>He has 23*3=<<23*3=69>>69 goats<n>The goats have 69*4=<<69*4=276>>276 legs<n>So in total his animals have 276+46=<<276+46=322>>322 legs<n>#### 322<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Rationales: After buying a hat, Josh has $20 - $10 = $<<20-10=10>>10<n>After buying a pencil, Josh has $10 - $2 = $<<10-2=8>>8<n>The total cost of cookies is 4 * $1.25 = $<<4*1.25=5>>5<n>After buying the cookies, Josh has $8 - $5 = $<<8-5=3>>3<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input:What is the opposite of hosting a crowd? Choices:  A: few people B: pay debts C: individual D: single person E: small group<n><n>### Response:		The correct answer is that an individual host would be A: few people <n><n>

Choices:  A: problems B: not noticeable C: deflation D: economic instability E: eat cake<n><n>### Response:		C<n><n>### Rationale:<n>Problems- When the government tries to reduce demand, supply and inflation by increasing taxes, there are consequences.<n><n>- Supply will automatically decrease because there is less demand for products.<n>- Businesses will lower prices of products. However, business owners won't lower the price of everything. They will only lower the price of products that they produce more than they do.<n>- Taxes increase the price of the products that consumers need the most causing inflation. Taxes decrease the demand of a country's products, which causes consumers to buy more imports from other countries.(https://sites.google.com/view/finance-journal-11/economics/fighting-inflation)<n><n><n>

Choices:  A: wild ride B: need for rest C: a massive bear D: playing marbles E: constructing<n><n>### Response:		A: wild ride<n><n>### Difficulty & Rugularity: Medium<n><n>### Instructions: Answer the following multiple choice question:<n><n>### Demographics: All users.<n><n>### Context:<n><n>### Delivery:<n><n>### Constraints: A minimum of 150 words.<n><n>### Rationale: A: Since the phrase “all day” is vague by itself, we’ll use it with the word “kids” and with the “had been” to refer to a continuous, sequenced, progressive, or repetitive situation without a clear point on starting.<n><n>We first need more context. This question requires more context for us to decide if the kids were having fun all day. Was this for a few hours, for a few days, or for a few weeks? This leads to a few more questions:<n><n>How many kids did they see? Do they have different ages? Did they just see the same 3-6 kids? How big was the area where they were playing?<n>The context needs to tell us these things in order to properly place this question in the time continuum. This will allow us to decide if the wild ride was before or after the fun, or if it’s an ongoing problematic situation.<n><n>If each kid saw a fun wild ride, but some had a fun wild ride more often than others, then the wild ride could occur after the fun.<n><n>If one or two of the kids had a fun wild ride and the others saw no fun wild ride at all, we would infer the first kids saw a fun wild ride before the rest.<n><n>### Input<n>The kids had been playing all day and a massive bear appeared and attacked them. <n><n>### Rationales:  <n><n>### D: The context of the question does not provide enough information, and therefore, we cannot accurately answer. All we know is that there were four girls and they were playing with something. We do not know what the “something was” or it’s dimensions. That is, we do not know if this “something” was small, medium, or large? We also do not know how much time they played.<n><n>The answer of choice D is that they played marbles.  <n>However, there were six  marbles and no balls. Since the context did not

What is the 5th letter of the alphabet?<n><n>### Response Option: <n><n>### Justication: 5th letter of alphabet<n>-P for Q, so 5th letter of Alphabet will be R<n>```<n>Q-R = -1, so X is 5th letter of alphbat<n>```<n><n><n>#### X<n>Answer :X<n>
