Choices:  A: chicken coop B: supermarket C: box D: egg carton E: henhouse<n><n>### Response:		<n>The correct answer is D the egg carton.<n><n>\section{Source:<a href="https://github.com/TensorFlow/lite#quickstart-android" class="external_link"> TensorFlow.org </a>}<n><n>### Instructions:<n>Write a response that appropriately replies to the request.<n><n>Rationales:<n><n>The TensorFlow Mobile Lite library is a TensorFlow library optimized for mobile devices and has all the functionality of TensorFlow Lite, the CPU execution model. Mobile Lite supports CPU, GPU and DSP, which include CPUs such as the Qualcomm Snapdragon line, NVIDIA on Tegra, as well as Intel processors, ARM Cortex, and Mali GPUs running at 1800x1800 or higher.<n><n>To use Mobile Lite on an Android device, select the "Enable TensorFlow Mobile LITe" check box when configuring your application in the Android Manifest file. To run inference on the TensorFlow model, you must add the following two lines to your Android manifest file. There is no need to define TENSORFLOW_LITE_DEVICES in the Java code as it is done at configuration time.<n><n>```xml<n><uses-library android:name="org.tensorflow.lite" /><n><uses-feature android:name="android.hardware.camera2" android:required="false" /><n>```<n><n>After adding the Android manifest file, open the SDK Manager and install the C++ and System libraries. Click on the AVD Manager and create a device configuration with a Qualcomm Hexagon DSP.<n><n>To integrate the TensorFlow Lite library into an Android or an Android Studio project, add Android Support to the project. You must use the CMake command before compiling the program for Android:<n><n>```bash<n>cmake \<n>  -BBuild \<n>  -DCMAKE_TOOLCHAIN_FILE=CMakeToolchain.cmake \<n> ...<n>```<n><n>In this section, you will take the model from the first application and make it run faster on a mobile device in order to reduce the burden on resources like RAM, CPU and battery. <n><n>#### Input: Which of the following is the first step in building a model on Android?

If every 60 minutes are 60 seconds each, how many minutes does 26 hours and minutes equal?<n><n>### Response<n><n>#### 1259<n>Input:We know that for every 60 minutes it is equal to 60 seconds. 26 hours and ____ minutes = <<26*60=1680>>1680 minutes<n>Since 1680/60 = <<1680/30=56>>56<n>When 26/56 =<<26/56=47>>47<n>Minutes:<n>47*60 = <<47*60=2720>>2720<n><n>#### 2720<n>Answer: '2720'

If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Rationales: His kangaroos have a total of 23*2=<<23*2=46>>46 legs<n>He has 23*3=<<23*3=69>>69 goats<n>The goats have 69*4=<<69*4=276>>276 legs<n>So in total his animals have 276+46=<<276+46=322>>322 legs<n>#### 322<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Rationales: After buying a hat, Josh has $20 - $10 = $<<20-10=10>>10<n>After buying a pencil, Josh has $10 - $2 = $<<10-2=8>>8<n>The total cost of cookies is 4 * $1.25 = $<<4*1.25=5>>5<n>After buying the cookies, Josh has $8 - $5 = $<<8-5=3>>3<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input:The band enjoyed their success and fans, they loved to what at the start of every concert? Choices:  A: hear crowd go mad B: working hard C: clap D: reproduce E: celebrate<n><n>### Response:		<n>They started with the crowd goes mad for them.<n><n>### Answer: A: hear crowd goe mad<n><n>### Input<n>Betty has six books in her box which she wants to keep in alphabetical order. What is the minimum number of times that she can go through the box so that the books stay in order?<n><n>### Response<n>She can do her job by going through the book twice.<n><n>### Choices:  ANSWER: 2  B: three  C: four  D: two  E: five<n><n>### Instructions<n><n>#### Task 1:<n><n>#### Task 2:<n><n>#### Task3:<n><n>[Previous](026.md) | Page 109/111 | [Next](028.md)<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Rationales: If he babysits for 2 hours at $7 per hour, he will earn 2*7 = $<<2*7=14>>14<n>This week he will earn $5 allowance, $10 mowing the lawn and $14 from babysitting for a total of 5+10+14 = $<<5+10+14=29>>29<n>If we add the $29 he will earn to his $65 savings, he will have a total of 29 + 65 = $<<29+65=94>>94<n>The bike costs $100 and he will have $94 leaving $100-$94 = $<<100-94=6>>6 more that he will need to earn<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Rationales: His kangaroos have a total of 23*2=<<23*2=46>>46 legs<n>He has 23*3=<<23*3=69>>69 goats<n>The goats have 69*4=<<69*4=276>>276 legs<n>So in total his animals have 276+46=<<276+46=322>>322 legs<n>#### 322<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Rationales: After buying a hat, Josh has $20 - $10 = $<<20-10=10>>10<n>After buying a pencil, Josh has $10 - $2 = $<<10-2=8>>8<n>The total cost of cookies is 4 * $1.25 = $<<4*1.25=5>>5<n>After buying the cookies, Josh has $8 - $5 = $<<8-5=3>>3<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input:We want to try some new barbecue sauces, where should we buy some? Choices:  A: detroit B: australia C: michigan park D: cafe E: retail store<n><n>### Response:		Choice A, B, C, D, E<n><n>

Has 24% more e. has200% more of c<n>Therefore the bigger choice is one of : (a) or (d) or (e) The correct answer to the questions, is one of: 1. Choice(a) 2. Choice(d) or 3. She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100. Choices:  A: music shop B: music store C: jug band D: united states E: among nice people<n><n>### Response:		<n>```<n>A. music shop<n>```<n><n>### Rationale:The banjo is known as a musical instrument from the United States but originated in the Caribbean.<n><n>### Input :<n>12 students at Jensen High School took the test for physics today. There were five more boys than girls who took the test. All the students passed in at least 1 hour on average. Five of the girls who passed in late were late because they forgot to put their test in their backpacks but otherwise passed on time. If one boy passed 30 minutes late, how late on average did all the boys fail to leave the classroom?<n>Rationales :<n><n><n>If you look at the two subproblems of this question, and the data for subproblem A, the information given gives us 12 students taking the test with 5 more boy than girls. Then 5 girls late due to absent, and one boy that is late on average 30 Min.<n>You subtract the two subproblems together to get an answer of 12-5=7 boy late (2 more than the 2 girls late)<n><n>You then add your 30 Min time of your boy that was late, and multiply by the number of boys late with that information. Then you subtract it from your original answer.<n><n>In conclusion, the average time for boys to leave classroom was about 31.2 Minutes late for everyone as a whole.<n><n>### Answer:128 Minutes<n><n>

How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Rationales: If he babysits for 2 hours at $7 per hour, he will earn 2*7 = $<<2*7=14>>14<n>This week he will earn $5 allowance, $10 mowing the lawn and $14 from babysitting for a total of 5+10+14 = $<<5+10+14=29>>29<n>If we add the $29 he will earn to his $65 savings, he will have a total of 29 + 65 = $<<29+65=94>>94<n>The bike costs $100 and he will have $94 leaving $100-$94 = $<<100-94=6>>6 more that he will need to earn<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Rationales: His kangaroos have a total of 23*2=<<23*2=46>>46 legs<n>He has 23*3=<<23*3=69>>69 goats<n>The goats have 69*4=<<69*4=276>>276 legs<n>So in total his animals have 276+46=<<276+46=322>>322 legs<n>#### 322<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Rationales: After buying a hat, Josh has $20 - $10 = $<<20-10=10>>10<n>After buying a pencil, Josh has $10 - $2 = $<<10-2=8>>8<n>The total cost of cookies is 4 * $1.25 = $<<4*1.25=5>>5<n>After buying the cookies, Josh has $8 - $5 = $<<8-5=3>>3<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input:The person turned the oven on and put a pizza in, what happened one hour later? Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Rationales: If he babysits for 2 hours at $7 per hour, he will earn 2*7 = $<<2*7=14>>14<n>This week he will earn $5 allowance, $10 mowing the lawn and $14 from babysitting for a total of 5+10+14 = $<<5+10+14=29>>29<n>If we add the $29 he will earn to his $65 savings, he will have a total of 29 + 65 = $<<29+65=94>>94<n>The bike costs $100 and he will have $94 leaving $100-$94 = $<<100-94=6>>6 more that he will need to earn<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Rationales: His kangaroos have a total of 23*2=<<23*2=46>>46 legs<n>He has 23*3=<<23*3=69>>69 goats<n>The goats have 69*4=<<69*4=276>>276 legs<n>So in total his animals have 276+46=<<276+46=322>>322 legs<n>#### 322<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Rationales: After buying a hat, Josh has $20 - $10 = $<<20-10=10>>10<n>After buying a pencil, Josh has $10 - $2 = $<<10-2=8>>8<n>The total cost of cookies is 4 * $1.25 = $<<4*1.25=5>>5<n>After buying the cookies, Josh has $8 - $5 = $<<8-5=3>>3<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input:What could happen to you after you see some beautiful clouds above you? A:  If you see the clouds in the answer above?<n><n>Answer: Your feelings will change.<n>Rationales: Your feelings are going to change.<n>#### C<n>Answer: C<n><n><n>### Input<n>Instruction:  Use mathematical reasoning to answer each of the following. Then write your answer.<n><n>### Rationales<n>You know that if we multiply the second number in a multiplication sentence by anything, it doesn't change anything.  For example: 4*7 =7*4.<n>You can multiply each side of an equation by the same number to eliminate that number if the equation is equal.<n><n>First, let's simplify the equation: -2*(-2)+5=?<n>10<n>-2*-2=-4<n>+5=-4<n>-4+5=10<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input 2:<n>You know that if you multiply the second number in multiplication sentence by anything it doesn't change the value. For example:  1*3!=1*3!=3<n>Simplify 8*-2=-16<n>8*-2=-8*2<n>-16 =-8*2<n>You can multiply each sides of an equation to eliminate a number if the equation is an equals.<n><n><n>#### -16<n>Answer: -16<n><n>### Rationale<n>Your first instinct is to multiply each side by -3 to change both sides into negatives. You are close! However, to cancel, we need to use the Distributive Property:  A*B+C = A*(B+C)<n>-8*2 -8 (the number in the top of the brackets is what will cancel, in this case 8) = -8*(3+2)<n>-8*3 -24= -8*(-3)<n>8=(8*(-3))/=8(-3)<n>8/(-3)=8/3=-2<n>So, multiply each side by -2<n>#### -8*(-2)<n>Answer: -8=-8*(-2)

Beth bought 2 shirts for herself and her friends at the rock concert.  Each shirt costs $39.50.  How much money do the tickets and the shirts cost?<n>Rationale: The tickets cost 53.25, not including the money to the shirts.  Because this was from her mother’s credit this money must have been deducted for the tickets also.  We can find the tickets cost by subtracting the money on the credit card from the total cost.  We can then subtract each shirts cost from Beth’s remaining money to find the total cost.<n><n>#### 12<n>Answer: $12<n><n>### InputZach and his brother Sam like to play

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Rationales: If he babysits for 2 hours at $7 per hour, he will earn 2*7 = $<<2*7=14>>14<n>This week he will earn $5 allowance, $10 mowing the lawn and $14 from babysitting for a total of 5+10+14 = $<<5+10+14=29>>29<n>If we add the $29 he will earn to his $65 savings, he will have a total of 29 + 65 = $<<29+65=94>>94<n>The bike costs $100 and he will have $94 leaving $100-$94 = $<<100-94=6>>6 more that he will need to earn<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Rationales: His kangaroos have a total of 23*2=<<23*2=46>>46 legs<n>He has 23*3=<<23*3=69>>69 goats<n>The goats have 69*4=<<69*4=276>>276 legs<n>So in total his animals have 276+46=<<276+46=322>>322 legs<n>#### 322<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Rationales: After buying a hat, Josh has $20 - $10 = $<<20-10=10>>10<n>After buying a pencil, Josh has $10 - $2 = $<<10-2=8>>8<n>The total cost of cookies is 4 * $1.25 = $<<4*1.25=5>>5<n>After buying the cookies, Josh has $8 - $5 = $<<8-5=3>>3<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input:The only baggage the woman checked was a drawstring bag, where was she heading with it? Choices:  A: garbage can B: military C: jewelry store D: safe E: airport<n><n>### Response:		<n>### Demontration:E=airport<n><n>### RationalesA:Not enough infoB:Not applicableC:Not applicableD:Not applicableE:Checking in for flight<n><n><n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Rationales: If he babysits for 2 hours at $7 per hour, he will earn 2*7 = $<<2*7=14>>14<n>This week he will earn $5 allowance, $10 mowing the lawn and $14 from babysitting for a total of 5+10+14 = $<<5+10+14=29>>29<n>If we add the $29 he will earn to his $65 savings, he will have a total of 29 + 65 = $<<29+65=94>>94<n>The bike costs $100 and he will have $94 leaving $100-$94 = $<<100-94=6>>6 more that he will need to earn<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Rationales: His kangaroos have a total of 23*2=<<23*2=46>>46 legs<n>He has 23*3=<<23*3=69>>69 goats<n>The goats have 69*4=<<69*4=276>>276 legs<n>So in total his animals have 276+46=<<276+46=322>>322 legs<n>#### 322<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Rationales: After buying a hat, Josh has $20 - $10 = $<<20-10=10>>10<n>After buying a pencil, Josh has $10 - $2 = $<<10-2=8>>8<n>The total cost of cookies is 4 * $1.25 = $<<4*1.25=5>>5<n>After buying the cookies, Josh has $8 - $5 = $<<8-5=3>>3<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input:Where do you put your grapes just before checking out? Choices:  A: mouth B: grocery cart C: super market D: fruit basket E: fruit market<n><n>### Response:		<n>Grape<n>  <n><br><n><n>### Revision:<n><n>#### Instruction:Complete the sentence.<n>I am currently practicing adding 3 digit numbers.<n>#### Rationale:<n>I have already practicked adding 2 digit numbers.<n>#### Answer:<n>I have currently practiced adding 3 digit numbers.\<n><n>### Instructions:Complete the sentence. She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100. He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn. Choices:  A: write an essay B: organize thoughts C: speak information D: summarize main points E: have information<n><n>### Response:		<n>Write an essay.<n><n>### Input1:  It is important for a student to do her or his own homework and to never work with your classmates or anyone else to help them. If you share your homework paper with your classmate or anyone else (or ask to share it), you are doing homework together.  Do you think this is a good rule to obey?<n><n>### Demstration1:<n>If I ask you, "Is the sky blue?" You reply "No, it is pink and fuzzy". If this is an appropriate response, I can tell you that I won't believe you.  If it is an inappropriate response, I can tell that you have been influenced by your environment and do not understand the question clearly.<n><n>#### 👎<n><n>Answer: 👎👎<n>```<n>It is a good rule to never share homework papers with your classmates because that is wrong.<n><n>```<n>Homework papers are to teach us how to write an essay for a specific topic. When I give students information about a topic to write about, I want to make sure that the essay paper that I receive from students is a reflection of their understanding of what I want. If I can’t determine that my student understands the prompt, I will fail them.<n>A student should do homework for only his or her own gain. If this happens, the student will be able to express himself/herself in writing.<n>```<n><n>### Input2: I was talking to my neighbor about my math class. I was learning to solve an equation.   X - =  - <n>The answer to X had to be negative or zero.<n>How did my neighbor respond? Was it a good response? If it was a good response, why? If it wasn’t a<n>good response, why not?<n><n>### Response1:<n>My neighbor said that X will always be greater than or equal to 0. My neighbor said this without knowing what I had just learned with my group in math class.<n>#### 💯<n><n>Answer:<n>```<n>My neighbor doesn't know anything about my math class because he never attend it.<n>If my neighbor's response was a good response, it should be because of this.<n>```<n><n>🙅‍♀️<n>

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Rationales: If he babysits for 2 hours at $7 per hour, he will earn 2*7 = $<<2*7=14>>14<n>This week he will earn $5 allowance, $10 mowing the lawn and $14 from babysitting for a total of 5+10+14 = $<<5+10+14=29>>29<n>If we add the $29 he will earn to his $65 savings, he will have a total of 29 + 65 = $<<29+65=94>>94<n>The bike costs $100 and he will have $94 leaving $100-$94 = $<<100-94=6>>6 more that he will need to earn<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Rationales: His kangaroos have a total of 23*2=<<23*2=46>>46 legs<n>He has 23*3=<<23*3=69>>69 goats<n>The goats have 69*4=<<69*4=276>>276 legs<n>So in total his animals have 276+46=<<276+46=322>>322 legs<n>#### 322<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Rationales: After buying a hat, Josh has $20 - $10 = $<<20-10=10>>10<n>After buying a pencil, Josh has $10 - $2 = $<<10-2=8>>8<n>The total cost of cookies is 4 * $1.25 = $<<4*1.25=5>>5<n>After buying the cookies, Josh has $8 - $5 = $<<8-5=3>>3<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input:What could happen to a paper if you leave it outside even if it does not move? Choices:  A: one material often recycled B: ripped C: saturated with water D: one dimensional E: crumpled<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>### Input : A dog is 15 years old.  It can be either a bichon or a dogue de Bordeaux.  A bichon’s life expectancy is 12 years.  A dogue de Bordeau’s life expectancy if 10.  The probability of a bichon being a dogue is 10%.  What is the probability of the dog living at least 13 years?<n><n>### Response : A<n>

He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Rationales: If he babysits for 2 hours at $7 per hour, he will earn 2*7 = $<<2*7=14>>14<n>This week he will earn $5 allowance, $10 mowing the lawn and $14 from babysitting for a total of 5+10+14 = $<<5+10+14=29>>29<n>If we add the $29 he will earn to his $65 savings, he will have a total of 29 + 65 = $<<29+65=94>>94<n>The bike costs $100 and he will have $94 leaving $100-$94 = $<<100-94=6>>6 more that he will need to earn<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. Choices:  A: walmart B: white house C: country D: corporation E: government<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>### Extension:<n>#### A<n>[White House](https://wikipedia.org/wiki/White_House)<n>**A:** The White House is President Donald Trump’s house. It also used to be President Barack Obama’s house.<n>**B:**  Walmart is the worlds largest company.  It has over 2.2 million employees and sells all kinds of products.<n>**C:**  Country is a geographic territory.  It is used to categorize places where different languages speak different dialects and have different religions.<n>**D:**  The federal government is a form of centralized government.  Some famous countries are [North Korea](https://wikipedia.or/wiki/North_Korea) and [South Korea](https://wikipedia-org/wiki/South_Korea)<n>**E:**  Government is a set of systems.  It is used in the U.S. for political decisions.<n>#### The U.S. government<n>The [white house](https://wikipedia-ORG/wiki/White_house) is not a government.<n><n>**White House**<n>    * Is the residence of the President and Vice President of the United States<n>                 |<n>            | |     * Is a major tourist site<n><n>### Response 2:D<n>#### 2<n>[Walmart](https://wikipedia-Org/wiki/Walmart)<n>Walmart is a company that specializes in retail. This means they sell food as well as clothing and various other items to people who visit their stores and on their e-commerce website. Walmart is the largest company in the United States with over 2.2 Million employees. They are found all across the country in thousands of locations. Walmart was not even close when it came to profits between 1970 and 2019. The [government](https://wikipedia-com/wiki/Government) was $35,696 BILLION with Walmart trailing behind at $400 BILLION in profits.  Walmart is the largest private employer worldwide. Walmart is not an international country. They are a single company based in the United States, the largest single country by population and square mileage. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Rationales: If he babysits for 2 hours at $7 per hour, he will earn 2*7 = $<<2*7=14>>14<n>This week he will earn $5 allowance, $10 mowing the lawn and $14 from babysitting for a total of 5+10+14 = $<<5+10+14=29>>29<n>If we add the $29 he will earn to his $65 savings, he will have a total of 29 + 65 = $<<29+65=94>>94<n>The bike costs $100 and he will have $94 leaving $100-$94 = $<<100-94=6>>6 more that he will need to earn<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Rationales: His kangaroos have a total of 23*2=<<23*2=46>>46 legs<n>He has 23*3=<<23*3=69>>69 goats<n>The goats have 69*4=<<69*4=276>>276 legs<n>So in total his animals have 276+46=<<276+46=322>>322 legs<n>#### 322<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Rationales: After buying a hat, Josh has $20 - $10 = $<<20-10=10>>10<n>After buying a pencil, Josh has $10 - $2 = $<<10-2=8>>8<n>The total cost of cookies is 4 * $1.25 = $<<4*1.25=5>>5<n>After buying the cookies, Josh has $8 - $5 = $<<8-5=3>>3<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input:What kind of driving leads to accidents? Choices:  A: stressful B: dangerous C: fun D: illegal E: deadly<n><n>### Response:		 B<n><n>### Input:'My little brother goes to bed at 7 pm. Is that enough?'<n><n>### Rules:You have enough time if time equals less than or equal to the event ends.  There are 140 minutes in 2 hours and 10 minutes. 2:10 = <<2:10=76>>76 is less than 140 but it is not < 140.So we have enough time.<n><n>### Answer:'Yes.'<n><n>### Instructions:Amy needs 300 pennies.  Annie has 238 pennies.  How many pennies (whole pennies)more does Amy need?<n>Rationales:'Amy needs 3 times as many pennies as Annie, which is a ratio of 3:1, or 3 : <<3:1=3>>3 to 1.<n><n>If Annie has 2x3 = <<2x3=6>>6 pennies extra, Amy needs 3-6 = <<3-6=3>>3 pennies(penny means a whole penny).<n><n>#### 3<n><n>Answer: 3

She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Rationales: If he babysits for 2 hours at $7 per hour, he will earn 2*7 = $<<2*7=14>>14<n>This week he will earn $5 allowance, $10 mowing the lawn and $14 from babysitting for a total of 5+10+14 = $<<5+10+14=29>>29<n>If we add the $29 he will earn to his $65 savings, he will have a total of 29 + 65 = $<<29+65=94>>94<n>The bike costs $100 and he will have $94 leaving $100-$94 = $<<100-94=6>>6 more that he will need to earn<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Rationales: His kangaroos have a total of 23*2=<<23*2=46>>46 legs<n>He has 23*3=<<23*3=69>>69 goats<n>The goats have 69*4=<<69*4=276>>276 legs<n>So in total his animals have 276+46=<<276+46=322>>322 legs<n>#### 322<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Rationales: After buying a hat, Josh has $20 - $10 = $<<20-10=10>>10<n>After buying a pencil, Josh has $10 - $2 = $<<10-2=8>>8<n>The total cost of cookies is 4 * $1.25 = $<<4*1.25=5>>5<n>After buying the cookies, Josh has $8 - $5 = $<<8-5=3>>3<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input:A fox was thirsty searching for water during the drought, where was he? Even in a full immersion environment you're likely to make mistakes, mistakes will cause misinterpretation, which will be uncomfortable, which will cause what?, Choices:  A: better communication B: overthinking C: frustration D: misunderstandings E: headaches<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>#### A&B&C&D&E<n>Answer: A&B&C+D&E<n><n>### Instructions:<n>There are 4 different task shown in the following code block.  Your task is to write a response to each of the tasks using the same method (multiple choice question) from the above questions.<n><n><n>### Input 01:<n>Rachel asked the clerk if her cellular was out of date. The clerk thought Rachel asked if her telephone was out of date,<n>and Rachel took offence with the answer.<n><n>####  True<n>False<n>A false or right option.  Rachel said "cell phone" and the clerk said "telephone", but in fact Rachel meant what she intended, which was "cell phone".<n>####  False<n>True<n>Rachel's mistake was that she asked the clerk a question, but the clerk answered as if Rachel had asked another question, that is they spoke at cross purposes.<n><n>####  D<n>D = Rachel's message was clear and the clerk's message was clear. Rachel said cell phone, but the clerk heard telephone, therefore they were at cross purposes.<n>####  F<n>F = Rachel's cell phone was out of date, but the clerk's telephone wasn't out of date.<n>####  C<n>C = A different message was conveyed. Rachel asked if the cellular was out of data, the clerk thought Rachel was asking about her telephone.<n><n>### Input<n>#### G<n>G = False<n>Rachel meant that her cell phone was out of data, but the clerk thought she meant to ask about her telephone. This shows there was a mix up at 2 levels of communication.<n><n>#### J<n>J = J = True<n>Rachel said "cell phone", the Clerk heard "telephone" and the message from both never reached each other. However, the clerk did not say that Rachel's cellular phone was now out of date.<n><n>#### B<n>B = True<n>Rachael tried to ask a question, but the Clerk's response gave the impression that the cellular wasn't working.<n><n>#### A<n>A = False<n>Both the Clerk and Rachel were uncomfortable

If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Rationales: His kangaroos have a total of 23*2=<<23*2=46>>46 legs<n>He has 23*3=<<23*3=69>>69 goats<n>The goats have 69*4=<<69*4=276>>276 legs<n>So in total his animals have 276+46=<<276+46=322>>322 legs<n>#### 322<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Rationales: After buying a hat, Josh has $20 - $10 = $<<20-10=10>>10<n>After buying a pencil, Josh has $10 - $2 = $<<10-2=8>>8<n>The total cost of cookies is 4 * $1.25 = $<<4*1.25=5>>5<n>After buying the cookies, Josh has $8 - $5 = $<<8-5=3>>3<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input:What would you do if you want to be able to earn money? Choices:  A: apply for job B: stand in line C: take care of proposals D: pass course E: play the lottery<n><n>### Response:		<n>```mark the options below that best complete the request.<n>```<n>Answer:<n>```option c```<n><n>### Instructions:<n>  Answer the following multiple choice question<n>  The following problems are based on the diagram above. You must follow the rules to complete the diagram.<n><n>  Input: The number of 5" pieces is 12, which is twice as many as 6" pieces. How many sticks of each type do you have?<n><n>  Input:<n>  Solution:<n>  85% of 37 students are passing the class.  How many students are failing?<n><n>### Answer:<n>  Solution: ( 5/6*18)<n><n>### Instructor:<n>  You have 5 minutes to create a 15 minute lesson plan that goes along with the demonstration. Make a copy of this question and write one paragraph explaining the problem. Add questions on your problem and write answers with your reasoning.
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Rationales: If he babysits for 2 hours at $7 per hour, he will earn 2*7 = $<<2*7=14>>14<n>This week he will earn $5 allowance, $10 mowing the lawn and $14 from babysitting for a total of 5+10+14 = $<<5+10+14=29>>29<n>If we add the $29 he will earn to his $65 savings, he will have a total of 29 + 65 = $<<29+65=94>>94<n>The bike costs $100 and he will have $94 leaving $100-$94 = $<<100-94=6>>6 more that he will need to earn<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Rationales: His kangaroos have a total of 23*2=<<23*2=46>>46 legs<n>He has 23*3=<<23*3=69>>69 goats<n>The goats have 69*4=<<69*4=276>>276 legs<n>So in total his animals have 276+46=<<276+46=322>>322 legs<n>#### 322<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Rationales: After buying a hat, Josh has $20 - $10 = $<<20-10=10>>10<n>After buying a pencil, Josh has $10 - $2 = $<<10-2=8>>8<n>The total cost of cookies is 4 * $1.25 = $<<4*1.25=5>>5<n>After buying the cookies, Josh has $8 - $5 = $<<8-5=3>>3<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input:They decided to hash things out over drinks, after enough booze they were able to get close on a few things and what? Choices:  A: reach tentative agreement B: suicide C: examine thing D: commit murder E: stay in bed<n><n>### Response:		<n>#### A and C<n>Answer: A and C<n><n>### Input:-<n>In the 2017 National Spelling Bee, a word that was misspelled by six contestants was "marocain." What is a marocain?<n><n>#### NEGATIVE RESULT<n><n>#### 1<n>False<n><n>##### Rationale: Marocain is a type of woven fabric<n><n>### Input<n>Answer the following fill-in-the-blank question.<n>A wisp of________ is so thin that it appears to be made from an extremely delicate and lightweight material such as a thin wire.<n><n>#### NEG ATIVE RESULT<n>#### 1<n><n>#### False<n><n>##### Rationales: The answer is fine thread<n>##### CORRECT  EXPLANATION:<n><n><n>### Task:Input: A man named Bill is 3 4/7 times as old as his son is. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Rationales: If he babysits for 2 hours at $7 per hour, he will earn 2*7 = $<<2*7=14>>14<n>This week he will earn $5 allowance, $10 mowing the lawn and $14 from babysitting for a total of 5+10+14 = $<<5+10+14=29>>29<n>If we add the $29 he will earn to his $65 savings, he will have a total of 29 + 65 = $<<29+65=94>>94<n>The bike costs $100 and he will have $94 leaving $100-$94 = $<<100-94=6>>6 more that he will need to earn<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Rationales: His kangaroos have a total of 23*2=<<23*2=46>>46 legs<n>He has 23*3=<<23*3=69>>69 goats<n>The goats have 69*4=<<69*4=276>>276 legs<n>So in total his animals have 276+46=<<276+46=322>>322 legs<n>#### 322<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Rationales: After buying a hat, Josh has $20 - $10 = $<<20-10=10>>10<n>After buying a pencil, Josh has $10 - $2 = $<<10-2=8>>8<n>The total cost of cookies is 4 * $1.25 = $<<4*1.25=5>>5<n>After buying the cookies, Josh has $8 - $5 = $<<8-5=3>>3<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input:Though she made the cut years ago, its figurative scars would never what? Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Rationales: If he babysits for 2 hours at $7 per hour, he will earn 2*7 = $<<2*7=14>>14<n>This week he will earn $5 allowance, $10 mowing the lawn and $14 from babysitting for a total of 5+10+14 = $<<5+10+14=29>>29<n>If we add the $29 he will earn to his $65 savings, he will have a total of 29 + 65 = $<<29+65=94>>94<n>The bike costs $100 and he will have $94 leaving $100-$94 = $<<100-94=6>>6 more that he will need to earn<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats. The answer is "death" because "he didn't want this" means he didn't want to die and he was losing consciousness.<n><n>```python<n>answer = input("What is the answer? ")<n>if answer == "A":<n>	print("Correct")<n>elif answer == "B":<n>	print("Incorrect")<n>elif answer == 'C':<n>	print("InsCORRECT")<n>elif answer =="D":<n>	print("INCORRECT")<n>else:<n>	print("INEXISTENT")<n>```<n>answer = input(" ")<n><n>Input: Scoot and Emma each received 3 gold medals in the triathlon.  Scoot got 1 gold more than Emma. How many medals did Scoot and Emma receive?<n>Rationales<n><n>Scoot got 3+1 =<<3+1=4>>4<n>Emma got 3-1 =<<3-1=2>>2<n><n><n>input = " "<n>

If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Rationales: His kangaroos have a total of 23*2=<<23*2=46>>46 legs<n>He has 23*3=<<23*3=69>>69 goats<n>The goats have 69*4=<<69*4=276>>276 legs<n>So in total his animals have 276+46=<<276+46=322>>322 legs<n>#### 322<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Rationales: After buying a hat, Josh has $20 - $10 = $<<20-10=10>>10<n>After buying a pencil, Josh has $10 - $2 = $<<10-2=8>>8<n>The total cost of cookies is 4 * $1.25 = $<<4*1.25=5>>5<n>After buying the cookies, Josh has $8 - $5 = $<<8-5=3>>3<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input:How does getting paid feel? Choices:  A: income tax B: satisfaction C: sorrow D: ocean E: bill collectors to happy<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>### Input 2: Choices:  A. She has a lot of work to do this weekend. B. She's going to the library today for homework. C. She'll be playing video games all night. D. She has some studying to do.<n><n>### Response 2: B<n><n>### Input x: How many cars are parked in your neighborhood every day?<n><n>### Response x: 231<n><n>### Input y: How many days do you workout a week?<n><n>### Reponse y: 1<n><n>### If 5/9 of bicycles are boy’s bikes, how many are girls’ bikes?<n><n>### If you are walking and you travel 1.8 miles in a hour and walk 15 minutes, how far have you traveled?<n><n>### Your dog likes to play in 3 feet of water, how many different combinations of toys can your dog play with in that water amount?<n><n>### How many times have you jumped in the pool today?<n><n>### There are 25 students at your school. 5 of them always play sports. 3 like science. 3 like math. 3 like to read. 3 are in the music club. 2 play video games. 4 write their own stories. 2 eat lunch with you. 6 make artwork. 1 goes to the dance classes. 6 eat pizza. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Rationales: If he babysits for 2 hours at $7 per hour, he will earn 2*7 = $<<2*7=14>>14<n>This week he will earn $5 allowance, $10 mowing the lawn and $14 from babysitting for a total of 5+10+14 = $<<5+10+14=29>>29<n>If we add the $29 he will earn to his $65 savings, he will have a total of 29 + 65 = $<<29+65=94>>94<n>The bike costs $100 and he will have $94 leaving $100-$94 = $<<100-94=6>>6 more that he will need to earn<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Rationales: His kangaroos have a total of 23*2=<<23*2=46>>46 legs<n>He has 23*3=<<23*3=69>>69 goats<n>The goats have 69*4=<<69*4=276>>276 legs<n>So in total his animals have 276+46=<<276+46=322>>322 legs<n>#### 322<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Rationales: After buying a hat, Josh has $20 - $10 = $<<20-10=10>>10<n>After buying a pencil, Josh has $10 - $2 = $<<10-2=8>>8<n>The total cost of cookies is 4 * $1.25 = $<<4*1.25=5>>5<n>After buying the cookies, Josh has $8 - $5 = $<<8-5=3>>3<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input:Where do bees congregate with red flowerS? She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Rationales: After buying a hat, Josh has $20 - $10 = $<<20-10=10>>10<n>After buying a pencil, Josh has $10 - $2 = $<<10-2=8>>8<n>The total cost of cookies is 4 * $1.25 = $<<4*1.25=5>>5<n>After buying the cookies, Josh has $8 - $5 = $<<8-5=3>>3<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input:Where would a lizard surprise a person? Choices:  A: new mexico B: forrest C: dessert D: garden E: creek<n><n>### Response:		E<n><n>### Input A: If a penguin is wearing a shirt, what does it cost? Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Rationales: If he babysits for 2 hours at $7 per hour, he will earn 2*7 = $<<2*7=14>>14<n>This week he will earn $5 allowance, $10 mowing the lawn and $14 from babysitting for a total of 5+10+14 = $<<5+10+14=29>>29<n>If we add the $29 he will earn to his $65 savings, he will have a total of 29 + 65 = $<<29+65=94>>94<n>The bike costs $100 and he will have $94 leaving $100-$94 = $<<100-94=6>>6 more that he will need to earn<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Rationales: His kangaroos have a total of 23*2=<<23*2=46>>46 legs<n>He has 23*3=<<23*3=69>>69 goats<n>The goats have 69*4=<<69*4=276>>276 legs<n>So in total his animals have 276+46=<<276+46=322>>322 legs<n>#### 322<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100. The cost per box is $3 and $3.60 and each box takes up one gallon (4 quarts) of space in a warehouse.<n><n>If there are 2978 boxes in all, how many boxes of each kind are there? <n><n><n>### Response<n><n>Since there are 2987 boxes in all, there must be 2987-2977 = 10  boxes with handles.  If there are 10 boxes with handles and 4871 other boxes, the cost to fill warehouses with 4881 boxes using these boxes would be $3*10 + $3.60*4871 = $1172.60. It is, therefore, cheaper to fill the warehouses with the handle boxes only.<n><n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Instructions<n>Input: A small box of juice costs $1.20. If another small bottle of juice costs 20% more, what is the name of the different juices so their prices are in multiples of the original cost?<n>Rationales : If there were a "large" box of juice that costs $10, the percent of the increase of the bottles is $20/$4.50 = 452%=45%. Therefore the name of the juice is $1.20*145% = $1.79<n><n>#### 1.79<n>Answer: 1.79

A train station is a place that trains usually leave from to travel somewhere else.  Tickets are sold for trains and trains leave from a train station.<n><n>B: The ticket booth can’t be at a cathedral.  A church is not a place you buy train tickets.  People may go to church, but a church is not usually somewhere you buy train tickets like ticket booths are.<n><n>C: A metro station could be the location to buy some tickets, but not all of them.  Most metros need at least $2 to ride on the subway.  The train is on the same track as the subway.  So a metro station is a good idea, but not for all tickets.<n><n>D: A ticket booth is not at a fairgrounds.  This is where rides and food and games are bought.  It is not a good place to sell tickets.  Tickets to train rides are bought at a train station.<n>E: A ticket booth would not be by a amusement park.  There are usually a lot of rides in an amusement park and they are not by train stations.<n><n>#### F<n>Answer: F<n><n>### Input :The first game Josh was to play. His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Rationales: If he babysits for 2 hours at $7 per hour, he will earn 2*7 = $<<2*7=14>>14<n>This week he will earn $5 allowance, $10 mowing the lawn and $14 from babysitting for a total of 5+10+14 = $<<5+10+14=29>>29<n>If we add the $29 he will earn to his $65 savings, he will have a total of 29 + 65 = $<<29+65=94>>94<n>The bike costs $100 and he will have $94 leaving $100-$94 = $<<100-94=6>>6 more that he will need to earn<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Rationales: His kangaroos have a total of 23*2=<<23*2=46>>46 legs<n>He has 23*3=<<23*3=69>>69 goats<n>The goats have 69*4=<<69*4=276>>276 legs<n>So in total his animals have 276+46=<<276+46=322>>322 legs<n>#### 322<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Rationales: After buying a hat, Josh has $20 - $10 = $<<20-10=10>>10<n>After buying a pencil, Josh has $10 - $2 = $<<10-2=8>>8<n>The total cost of cookies is 4 * $1.25 = $<<4*1.25=5>>5<n>After buying the cookies, Josh has $8 - $5 = $<<8-5=3>>3<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input:If somebody likes temperatures cool, they might have more than one electric fan where? Choices:  A: home B: hardware store C: home D: hot room E: office<n><n>### Response:		Home<n><n>### Input:(A) Which of these are ways a person could say the word "girl" in Spanish?Choices:  A: the child next door B: mi chica C: tu hija D: la monstrutrAnswers: Home A C D<n>-Rationales:Answer:Home<n><n>## Exer 3<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Rationales: If he babysits for 2 hours at $7 per hour, he will earn 2*7 = $<<2*7=14>>14<n>This week he will earn $5 allowance, $10 mowing the lawn and $14 from babysitting for a total of 5+10+14 = $<<5+10+14=29>>29<n>If we add the $29 he will earn to his $65 savings, he will have a total of 29 + 65 = $<<29+65=94>>94<n>The bike costs $100 and he will have $94 leaving $100-$94 = $<<100-94=6>>6 more that he will need to earn<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Rationales: His kangaroos have a total of 23*2=<<23*2=46>>46 legs<n>He has 23*3=<<23*3=69>>69 goats<n>The goats have 69*4=<<69*4=276>>276 legs<n>So in total his animals have 276+46=<<276+46=322>>322 legs<n>#### 322<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Rationales: After buying a hat, Josh has $20 - $10 = $<<20-10=10>>10<n>After buying a pencil, Josh has $10 - $2 = $<<10-2=8>>8<n>The total cost of cookies is 4 * $1.25 = $<<4*1.25=5>>5<n>After buying the cookies, Josh has $8 - $5 = $<<8-5=3>>3<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input:He had done a great job with the scary decorations, they were completely what? Choices:  A: terrible B: little C: halloween D: small E: horrible<n><n>### Response:		Answer options: A,B,C,D,E<n><n>## Questions from Test and Practice<n><n>### Test Questions<n><n>### Practice Questions<n>

She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Rationales: If he babysits for 2 hours at $7 per hour, he will earn 2*7 = $<<2*7=14>>14<n>This week he will earn $5 allowance, $10 mowing the lawn and $14 from babysitting for a total of 5+10+14 = $<<5+10+14=29>>29<n>If we add the $29 he will earn to his $65 savings, he will have a total of 29 + 65 = $<<29+65=94>>94<n>The bike costs $100 and he will have $94 leaving $100-$94 = $<<100-94=6>>6 more that he will need to earn<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Rationales: His kangaroos have a total of 23*2=<<23*2=46>>46 legs<n>He has 23*3=<<23*3=69>>69 goats<n>The goats have 69*4=<<69*4=276>>276 legs<n>So in total his animals have 276+46=<<276+46=322>>322 legs<n>#### 322<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Rationales: After buying a hat, Josh has $20 - $10 = $<<20-10=10>>10<n>After buying a pencil, Josh has $10 - $2 = $<<10-2=8>>8<n>The total cost of cookies is 4 * $1.25 = $<<4*1.25=5>>5<n>After buying the cookies, Josh has $8 - $5 = $<<8-5=3>>3<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input:What is done to wood to attach something to it? Choices:  A: nailed B: carved C: polished D: eat cake E: petrify<n><n>### Response:		<n>I would choose the letter 'B'.  What is done to wood to "attach something" to it.. I think it depends on what type of wood you use, however wood is typically "carved".<n><n>### Response<n>I would choose the 'E' option because wood cannot be eaten, because you cannot eat wood, only eat the items that are made from wood.<n><n>### Input<n>In one classroom, there are no more than two tables. How many tables may be in this classroom?<n><n>### Response 1:<n>I would pick B because you can pick A, B or C to answer this question and you cannot pick neither or both<n><n>### Response2:<n>I would pick C because there are only two variables and you are choosing and option which is either a,b,or c.<n><n>### Response3:<n>I would pick A because there is an option that is "two or more tables" and you can not have only one table in the classroom, so there is 3+ choices if you choose the letter A<n><n>### Response4:<n>I would pick D because if they where to pick the letter E, theres would only be 1 classroom because theres is a choice that is "one choice" and thats only if you pick the letter A.<n><n>### Request:<n>##### I ask the above question and get these answers:<n>A<n><n>B<n><n>C<n><n>E<n><n>Neither<n><n>Both (A and E both)<n><n>How do I respond to the above responses? What would you respond here? Be careful, because some responses are correct and some are not. <n><n>Answer: In this case it is good to explain to your group that their answers are incorrect, especially if there is only one answer, then it is correct.<n><n>If you were at the question that they put down the last response that was incorrect, I think you would respond with what I chose because the students would then know that all they needed to do was pick one answer for them to be correct and they probably are not gonna pick none or both.<n><n>I would still respond to none because the answer is "either no one or two or more tables" and both is incorrect because there is only one choice.<n><n>### The above questions may be asked by a third-grade class, but you are a teacher.  As a teacher,
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Rationales: If he babysits for 2 hours at $7 per hour, he will earn 2*7 = $<<2*7=14>>14<n>This week he will earn $5 allowance, $10 mowing the lawn and $14 from babysitting for a total of 5+10+14 = $<<5+10+14=29>>29<n>If we add the $29 he will earn to his $65 savings, he will have a total of 29 + 65 = $<<29+65=94>>94<n>The bike costs $100 and he will have $94 leaving $100-$94 = $<<100-94=6>>6 more that he will need to earn<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Rationales: His kangaroos have a total of 23*2=<<23*2=46>>46 legs<n>He has 23*3=<<23*3=69>>69 goats<n>The goats have 69*4=<<69*4=276>>276 legs<n>So in total his animals have 276+46=<<276+46=322>>322 legs<n>#### 322<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Rationales: After buying a hat, Josh has $20 - $10 = $<<20-10=10>>10<n>After buying a pencil, Josh has $10 - $2 = $<<10-2=8>>8<n>The total cost of cookies is 4 * $1.25 = $<<4*1.25=5>>5<n>After buying the cookies, Josh has $8 - $5 = $<<8-5=3>>3<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input:What is likely to have more than one level in a city? Choices:  A: carpenter's shop B: video game C: garage D: total number E: building<n><n>### Response:		<n>C<n><n>### Instructions:Answer the following multiple-choice question.<n><n>## Instructions:<n>Write responses to questions 1–3.<n><n>### Question 1<n>In this context, what is the base and what is the height?<n>* Base is the first number<n>* Height is the number of times we multiply the base to get to the last number.<n><n>#### 10<n><n>### Question #2<n>What is the next number?<n><n>#### 43<n><n>### Questions 3–7: You will find four tables with two problems each.<n><n>#### Table 1<n>Problem 1<n><n>**Example:** 2 * __ + 4 = __<n><n>**Solution:** You find the value of the __ in the following equation:<n>```<n> 2 * __ + __ = __<n>```<n>Subtract the two values from __ to get __.<n><n>**Clarification:** 2 * the blank + the blank = 18<n>```<n>__ * __ + __ = 18<n>___ = 18 - __<n>___ = 10<n>```<n>So, __ equals 10.<n><n>#### Table #2<n>Solve these equations using the method described in Table 1.<n><n>Problem 1<n>```<n>__ + __ = __<n>___ + __ = ____<n>```<n><n>Problem 2<n>```<n>__ * 2 = __<n>___ * 2 = __ <n>```<n><n>#### #Table 3<n><n>## Problem #7<n>Choose the expression that shows the answer to each of the following questions. In the blank, fill in the missing number:<n><n>Problem #1<n>```<n>19 – ___<n>19 - __<n>```<n><n>Problem #2<n>```<n>28 – ___<n>28 - __ <n>```<n>

She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Rationales: If he babysits for 2 hours at $7 per hour, he will earn 2*7 = $<<2*7=14>>14<n>This week he will earn $5 allowance, $10 mowing the lawn and $14 from babysitting for a total of 5+10+14 = $<<5+10+14=29>>29<n>If we add the $29 he will earn to his $65 savings, he will have a total of 29 + 65 = $<<29+65=94>>94<n>The bike costs $100 and he will have $94 leaving $100-$94 = $<<100-94=6>>6 more that he will need to earn<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Rationales: If he babysits for 2 hours at $7 per hour, he will earn 2*7 = $<<2*7=14>>14<n>This week he will earn $5 allowance, $10 mowing the lawn and $14 from babysitting for a total of 5+10+14 = $<<5+10+14=29>>29<n>If we add the $29 he will earn to his $65 savings, he will have a total of 29 + 65 = $<<29+65=94>>94<n>The bike costs $100 and he will have $94 leaving $100-$94 = $<<100-94=6>>6 more that he will need to earn<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Rationales: After buying a hat, Josh has $20 - $10 = $<<20-10=10>>10<n>After buying a pencil, Josh has $10 - $2 = $<<10-2=8>>8<n>The total cost of cookies is 4 * $1.25 = $<<4*1.25=5>>5<n>After buying the cookies, Josh has $8 - $5 = $<<8-5=3>>3<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input:What do you get for not moving your car during the required time? Choices:  A: towed B: accidents C: driving D: getting tired E: ticket<n><n>### Response:		<n>- If you move or park your vehicle during the time that is restricted you may get ticket.<n>- If you park or leave your vehicle on the restricted street or area, your vehicle might be towed.<n>- If you get a parking ticket, it can be a fine.<n>- There is a big chance to get in a car accident.<n>- If you move your car back and forth, you could lose your health due to the stress.<n><n>### Input<n>### I would like to help clean up your yard. What time is the start of the work?<n>- The time of start varies from job to job.<n>- The start time depends on the customer preferences.<n>- I am here for only the evening work.<n>- If no one is there I will just wait for any of you to return.<n>- I am starting from the morning and continue until the afternoon.<n><n>### Response<n>- You are welcome to join me.<n>- Sure. The earlier the arrival the better the job.<n>- I am expecting your help.<n><n>### I already completed my morning. Would you like to meet in the afternoon?<n>- Your arrival time is good. I will be around until at least 6 pm.<n>- Sure. I finish around 6 pm<n>- I will be finished much sooner than that.<n>- I am available for the rest of the day.<n>- I will come back to see what I have missed.<n>- I will do that. Thank you very much.<n>- Would you want me to stay around until 7?<n><n>### I plan to work this entire day.  Would your work allow you to work all day?<n>- If this is a normal work day then yes.<n>- I can work as long as you need.<n>- I cannot work longer than this.<n><n>### Thank you.<n>- You are welcome.<n>- You are really kind.<n>- I am so blessed to have people like you.
