If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Rationales: His kangaroos have a total of 23*2=<<23*2=46>>46 legs<n>He has 23*3=<<23*3=69>>69 goats<n>The goats have 69*4=<<69*4=276>>276 legs<n>So in total his animals have 276+46=<<276+46=322>>322 legs<n>#### 322<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Rationales: After buying a hat, Josh has $20 - $10 = $<<20-10=10>>10<n>After buying a pencil, Josh has $10 - $2 = $<<10-2=8>>8<n>The total cost of cookies is 4 * $1.25 = $<<4*1.25=5>>5<n>After buying the cookies, Josh has $8 - $5 = $<<8-5=3>>3<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input:John came to see Sam and Sam kicked him out.  Sam didn't like company.  He prefered what? Choices:  A: you B: abbreviation C: solitude D: loneliness E: alone<n><n>### Response:		B<n><n>### Rationales<n><n>Input:Ray's dad gave him $50 for lunch.  He paid $12 for pizza and $8 for his soda at the stand and had $30 leftover.  When he added $6.50 for a slice of cake on top of everything what changed was? A. He had no money to buy the cake. B. He had a whole 25% more money left over. C. He had less money than he had before. D. He had twice as much money to spend on the cake as he did on his lunch.<n><n>#### Answer B<n>\$20\$50 - \$12\$12 - \$8\$8 - \$6.50\$6.50 = \$6\$50 - $$6.50$6.50 - \$6.5\$50 = \$18\$6<n>answer: 12
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Rationales: If he babysits for 2 hours at $7 per hour, he will earn 2*7 = $<<2*7=14>>14<n>This week he will earn $5 allowance, $10 mowing the lawn and $14 from babysitting for a total of 5+10+14 = $<<5+10+14=29>>29<n>If we add the $29 he will earn to his $65 savings, he will have a total of 29 + 65 = $<<29+65=94>>94<n>The bike costs $100 and he will have $94 leaving $100-$94 = $<<100-94=6>>6 more that he will need to earn<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Rationales: His kangaroos have a total of 23*2=<<23*2=46>>46 legs<n>He has 23*3=<<23*3=69>>69 goats<n>The goats have 69*4=<<69*4=276>>276 legs<n>So in total his animals have 276+46=<<276+46=322>>322 legs<n>#### 322<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Rationales: After buying a hat, Josh has $20 - $10 = $<<20-10=10>>10<n>After buying a pencil, Josh has $10 - $2 = $<<10-2=8>>8<n>The total cost of cookies is 4 * $1.25 = $<<4*1.25=5>>5<n>After buying the cookies, Josh has $8 - $5 = $<<8-5=3>>3<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input:What's it called when you have seen something through an eyepiece? Choices:  A: sights B: optical illusion C: optical telescope D: light microscope E: binocular<n><n>### Response:		<n>#### 1<n>Answer: A<n><n>### Input"You can take a ______ home as an experiment to perform on your project." <n>### Response:<n>#### 1<n>1.A.<n>#### 2<n>1.B.<n>#### 3<n>1.C.<n>#### 4<n>1.D.<n>#### 5<n>1.E.<n>#### 6<n>1. F.<n><n>***<n><n>### Instructions : Answer the following questions in complete sentences.<n><n>### Q1<n><n>### What is the purpose of a glossary?<n><n>### Q2<n><n>### What does a glossary include?<n><n>### What are the four components of a glossary entry?<n><n>### Format of a word or phrase used in the dictionary: <n><n>### The definition<n>### Example use<n><n>### The pronunciation <n><n>### Notes: (add additional explanatory text if applicable)<n><n>#### 1<n>A glossary is an alphabetical list of all important technical vocabulary within a scientific text. <n><n>#### 2<n>A glossary includes the definitions, pronunciation, example use of words, and notes.<n><n>#### 3<n>A word or phrase in the dictionary can be arranged in four categories. <n><n>#### Definition  : The specific meaning or the precise use of a particular word or phrase.<n><n>#### Example use:  A sample sentence containing the word. <n><n>#### Pronunciation:  Pronunciation is the manner in which an individual speaks a particular word or phrase in a native language, foreign language, or dialect.<n><n>#### Notes: (this is a place for clarification or questions or more details, if necessary.) <n><n>#### 4<n>In the science experiment, one can find many words they were unfamiliar with.<n><n>#### 5<n>The first thing I would like to know is...<n><n>#### 6<n>If possible, I would like to find out, the meaning or the procedure as well.<n><n>#### 7<n>However, if we want to have an answer, it would be better to find the first thing in the process in experimentation.<n><n>#### 8<n>I feel like it is hard to find the procedure on how you do the experiment exactly.<n><n>#### 9
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Rationales: If he babysits for 2 hours at $7 per hour, he will earn 2*7 = $<<2*7=14>>14<n>This week he will earn $5 allowance, $10 mowing the lawn and $14 from babysitting for a total of 5+10+14 = $<<5+10+14=29>>29<n>If we add the $29 he will earn to his $65 savings, he will have a total of 29 + 65 = $<<29+65=94>>94<n>The bike costs $100 and he will have $94 leaving $100-$94 = $<<100-94=6>>6 more that he will need to earn<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Rationales: His kangaroos have a total of 23*2=<<23*2=46>>46 legs<n>He has 23*3=<<23*3=69>>69 goats<n>The goats have 69*4=<<69*4=276>>276 legs<n>So in total his animals have 276+46=<<276+46=322>>322 legs<n>#### 322<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Rationales: After buying a hat, Josh has $20 - $10 = $<<20-10=10>>10<n>After buying a pencil, Josh has $10 - $2 = $<<10-2=8>>8<n>The total cost of cookies is 4 * $1.25 = $<<4*1.25=5>>5<n>After buying the cookies, Josh has $8 - $5 = $<<8-5=3>>3<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input:What is a good result of jogging? Choices:  A: insect repellent B: heart attacks C: improved health D: shin splints E: being tired<n><n>### Response:		Exercise is good for your health, but it is bad for your shin splints.<n><n>

He liked being about to divide people into what categories? Choices:  A: winners and losers B: perform better C: might win D: losses E: enemies<n><n>### Response:		A:winners and losers<n><n>#### Instructional Strategy:Ask the student to review a task (like step 21 in this assignment) and decide what to do next.<n><n>### Response Strategy:Ask them first how many things were there in a set and how many they put in a different set.  If you know this student is strong in this, then give more specific questions like, "You have 7 cookies from a set of 5 and you can only bring 2 cookies from home to the office.  How many cookies do you take with you?"<n><n>### Demotivation<n>Demotivation:When a student cannot even figure out one of the simple math questions, they often get very frustrated with the task. This is one of those situations.<n>I encourage you to make sure the student works on some fun math practice. You get a score on the practice that you can compare.  I have found that often these students do better on an adaptive math practice and a different subject<n><n>### Strategies for Response:<n>Make sure you break down each question so a student doesn't get frustrated that the answer is too long for him to answer. Use strategies listed below and have a student explain how he came about the answer.  For example, if the student gives 10 and you are sure that answer is wrong, just ask him how he came up with 10 and how many others did he think?<n><n>### Response<n><n>Input: John loved competing because he could easily divide people into what categories: Choices: A: winners and loers B: perfom better C: might win<n><n>Answer:D<n><n>####Instructional Strategy:<n>Ask the student to list out all the choices he thinks and then ask him how he decides which ones are correct.  <n><n>####Response Strategy:<n>A few strategies I use is when one answers is obvious to me and I am sure it is incorrect - I tell the student - hey John, this one I know is not correct, so I will be thinking of the correct choice.  I will take away the other choices until there are only left two choices left.  <n><n>I let student decide which choice he thinks and then I take all the choices except one, so at this point there is only two choices.  I repeat myself for a few times

He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Rationales: After buying a hat, Josh has $20 - $10 = $<<20-10=10>>10<n>After buying a pencil, Josh has $10 - $2 = $<<10-2=8>>8<n>The total cost of cookies is 4 * $1.25 = $<<4*1.25=5>>5<n>After buying the cookies, Josh has $8 - $5 = $<<8-5=3>>3<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input:What could prevent someone from buying chistmas presents? Choices:  A: happiness B: lack of money C: stress D: relief E: exhiliration<n><n>### Response:		<n>Happiness, lack of money, stress, or exciliation wouldn't prevent someone from buying Christmas presents. <n>A person could buy Christmas gifts while happy, in great debt, under stress, or relieved of stress.<n><n><n>### RATIONALES<n>Happiness<n>If a person is happy, he or she might consider buying Christmas gifts.<n><n>Lack of money<n>If a person lacks the money to buy Christmas gifts, he or she would not be buying them.
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Rationales: If he babysits for 2 hours at $7 per hour, he will earn 2*7 = $<<2*7=14>>14<n>This week he will earn $5 allowance, $10 mowing the lawn and $14 from babysitting for a total of 5+10+14 = $<<5+10+14=29>>29<n>If we add the $29 he will earn to his $65 savings, he will have a total of 29 + 65 = $<<29+65=94>>94<n>The bike costs $100 and he will have $94 leaving $100-$94 = $<<100-94=6>>6 more that he will need to earn<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Rationales: His kangaroos have a total of 23*2=<<23*2=46>>46 legs<n>He has 23*3=<<23*3=69>>69 goats<n>The goats have 69*4=<<69*4=276>>276 legs<n>So in total his animals have 276+46=<<276+46=322>>322 legs<n>#### 322<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Rationales: After buying a hat, Josh has $20 - $10 = $<<20-10=10>>10<n>After buying a pencil, Josh has $10 - $2 = $<<10-2=8>>8<n>The total cost of cookies is 4 * $1.25 = $<<4*1.25=5>>5<n>After buying the cookies, Josh has $8 - $5 = $<<8-5=3>>3<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input:Joe bought a ficus.  He thought it would look good in what part of his home? Choices:  A: family room B: tropical forest C: flower garden D: movie theater E: hair salon<n><n>### Response:		<n>Write a response that appropriately answers the question above.<n><n>### Outcome:<n>You should write your response here. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Rationales: If he babysits for 2 hours at $7 per hour, he will earn 2*7 = $<<2*7=14>>14<n>This week he will earn $5 allowance, $10 mowing the lawn and $14 from babysitting for a total of 5+10+14 = $<<5+10+14=29>>29<n>If we add the $29 he will earn to his $65 savings, he will have a total of 29 + 65 = $<<29+65=94>>94<n>The bike costs $100 and he will have $94 leaving $100-$94 = $<<100-94=6>>6 more that he will need to earn<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Rationales: His kangaroos have a total of 23*2=<<23*2=46>>46 legs<n>He has 23*3=<<23*3=69>>69 goats<n>The goats have 69*4=<<69*4=276>>276 legs<n>So in total his animals have 276+46=<<276+46=322>>322 legs<n>#### 322<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Rationales: After buying a hat, Josh has $20 - $10 = $<<20-10=10>>10<n>After buying a pencil, Josh has $10 - $2 = $<<10-2=8>>8<n>The total cost of cookies is 4 * $1.25 = $<<4*1.25=5>>5<n>After buying the cookies, Josh has $8 - $5 = $<<8-5=3>>3<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input:Traveling underwater has many dangers, such as low visibility causing what? Choices:  A: disorientation B: due to C: meeting new people D: getting somewhere E: relocation<n><n>### Response:		<n>```python<n>if input==A:<n> print("Disorientation")<n>elif input==B:<n> print("Low visibility")<n>elif input==C:<n> print("Meeting new people")<n>elif input==D:<n> print("Getting somewhere")<n>elif input==E:<n> print("Relocation")<n>```<n>

How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Rationales: If he babysits for 2 hours at $7 per hour, he will earn 2*7 = $<<2*7=14>>14<n>This week he will earn $5 allowance, $10 mowing the lawn and $14 from babysitting for a total of 5+10+14 = $<<5+10+14=29>>29<n>If we add the $29 he will earn to his $65 savings, he will have a total of 29 + 65 = $<<29+65=94>>94<n>The bike costs $100 and he will have $94 leaving $100-$94 = $<<100-94=6>>6 more that he will need to earn<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Rationales: His kangaroos have a total of 23*2=<<23*2=46>>46 legs<n>He has 23*3=<<23*3=69>>69 goats<n>The goats have 69*4=<<69*4=276>>276 legs<n>So in total his animals have 276+46=<<276+46=322>>322 legs<n>#### 322<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Rationales: After buying a hat, Josh has $20 - $10 = $<<20-10=10>>10<n>After buying a pencil, Josh has $10 - $2 = $<<10-2=8>>8<n>The total cost of cookies is 4 * $1.25 = $<<4*1.25=5>>5<n>After buying the cookies, Josh has $8 - $5 = $<<8-5=3>>3<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input:Where are there more telephone booths? Choices:  A: gas stations B: city C: london D: train station E: airport<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>    -----<n>    C<n>    ----<n><n>### Rationale: Choice E is the highest amount of number of telephone booths.<n><n>### Rationales:  C has the maximum number of telephone boots.<n><n>### Additional Question: What are all real life applications for this question.<n><n>## Instuction:<n><n>Given a number ________, find all possible positive and negative values that the square root of the number may equal.<n><n>## Answer<n><n>* <n><n>    squareRoot<n><n>## Solution<n><n>Using the function squareRoot in the range of 1 - 100. The square root is equal to its number.<n><n>## References<n><n>1. https://www.sage.com/about/blog/mathematical-tales/exercise-2-square-root-and-integer-part<n><n>## Implementation<n><n>```python<n>num = int(input())<n><n>number_of_answer=0<n>for n in range(1, num):<n>    n = n + 2<n>    if n**2 == num:<n>        number_of_answer+=1<n><n>print('Ans:',number_of_answer)<n><n><n>```<n>

Given the options of A, B, C and D, only option C will work in this case.  For that, the mother cow would end up having 40+40+40 offspring!<n>

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Rationales: If he babysits for 2 hours at $7 per hour, he will earn 2*7 = $<<2*7=14>>14<n>This week he will earn $5 allowance, $10 mowing the lawn and $14 from babysitting for a total of 5+10+14 = $<<5+10+14=29>>29<n>If we add the $29 he will earn to his $65 savings, he will have a total of 29 + 65 = $<<29+65=94>>94<n>The bike costs $100 and he will have $94 leaving $100-$94 = $<<100-94=6>>6 more that he will need to earn<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Rationales: His kangaroos have a total of 23*2=<<23*2=46>>46 legs<n>He has 23*3=<<23*3=69>>69 goats<n>The goats have 69*4=<<69*4=276>>276 legs<n>So in total his animals have 276+46=<<276+46=322>>322 legs<n>#### 322<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Rationales: After buying a hat, Josh has $20 - $10 = $<<20-10=10>>10<n>After buying a pencil, Josh has $10 - $2 = $<<10-2=8>>8<n>The total cost of cookies is 4 * $1.25 = $<<4*1.25=5>>5<n>After buying the cookies, Josh has $8 - $5 = $<<8-5=3>>3<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input:What place of work might you find a hairpin? Choices:  A: hair salon B: hair of woman C: barber shop D: pincushion E: woman's hair<n><n>### Response:		<n><n><n><n>![](./images/A_C.png) A and C<n>![](./images2A.png) C and E<n><n>Answer:<n><n><n>![](images/C.png) C<n><n>```<n><n>### Input<n><n>Johnny was doing his math homework. He had 44 cents in nickels, dimes, and quarters. How many nickels and dimes does Johnny have if 44 divided by 8=<<44/8=6>>6?<n><n>### Demostration<n><n>Input: John has a total of 44 cents<n><n>This means he has 44 * 1=<<44*1=44>>43 cents<n><n>We need to find out how many nickels and dime/quarter combination of 43 cents total us 6<n><n>The combination that total us 6 is 6 cents x 6 Nickels and 6 more Quarter<n><n>We can create this combination by putting 6 nickels and 6 Quarters<n><n>$ 43 cents 6*12=$$ 6*0.12=$$6*1=$$ 6 dimes<n><n>$43 0.25 = <<43*0.25= 10.8=>11 quarters $ 43 11=<<43*11=156=>156 1=156<n><n>We need 17 cents left so we do not have $ 156+17= <<156+16=172>>172<n><n>So we need 172 - 156 = $<<172-156=16>>16 cents<n><n>#### 16<n>Answer: 16<n><n>### Input2<n>In the year 2176, an American, named George Washington, invented a machine that could make cheesecakes.  Three hundred years later, Americans can make about two bazillion million cheesecakes. I need to select a correct response, i.e. to answer choice “B“ the right answer is “HOME.“  If you have a question about the task, please post it below!<n><n>### Input (Task 1):How many inches in 3 feet?<n><n>### Response (Task 1): 12<n><n>### Explain (Task 1):Inches are one of two metrics for measuring length.  A foot in the decimal form is expressed as .33333 feet.  We can multiply.3333 by 3 to get 12.0000 inches.  We add a decimal point between the two numbers to get 12 inches.<n><n>### Inputs (Task 2):You have 27 books.  You have 23 books shelf.  How many books do you have left?<n><n>### Explian (Task 2):We can count and list the number of shelves.  Each shelf can hold 23 books.  We want to count how many books are left out.  The answer is 4.<n><n>### Explication (Home):A few years back I had a very difficult time with these types of math problems.  I had to struggle to understand exactly what I was suppose to do, and it was because I had to come up with a way to organize the problem, understand the problem, and then organize the answer.  I don't know your exact challenges but I would invite you to try to use a different method.  There are many different types.  There is one we call the 2-column method.  I've never seen anyone do one in exactly the same way.  I have seen many different methods, and the basic one is usually to create a second column of how much we need.  This is much like the first method we looked at where we did:  What is the answer minus the solution.  If you write it out long hand you can see it.<n><n>### The second method is more like algebra.  Instead of getting the number difference you multiply the difference by the same number.  Now the

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Rationales: If he babysits for 2 hours at $7 per hour, he will earn 2*7 = $<<2*7=14>>14<n>This week he will earn $5 allowance, $10 mowing the lawn and $14 from babysitting for a total of 5+10+14 = $<<5+10+14=29>>29<n>If we add the $29 he will earn to his $65 savings, he will have a total of 29 + 65 = $<<29+65=94>>94<n>The bike costs $100 and he will have $94 leaving $100-$94 = $<<100-94=6>>6 more that he will need to earn<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Rationales: His kangaroos have a total of 23*2=<<23*2=46>>46 legs<n>He has 23*3=<<23*3=69>>69 goats<n>The goats have 69*4=<<69*4=276>>276 legs<n>So in total his animals have 276+46=<<276+46=322>>322 legs<n>#### 322<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. Choices:  A: high school gymnasium B: city C: park D: use E: los angeles<n><n>### Response:		B: city<n><n>### Response explanation:Answer A can be ruled out because basketball courts are indoors. Basketball gyms are not outdoors, unless they are outdoors. Also, basketball courts are not found outside only in Los Angeles. Only the city has basketball courts.<n><n>### Response B: B: city<n>The city has an outdoor basketball court. Basketball Courts are typically made of asphalt which is not indoors but outside in the Park. This choice can be further supported by the fact that basketball are also used in the park, so it does not make sense to put the park to a park. Only Los Angeles contains all the answers of A and B, 1 and 2.<n><n>### Answer A: basketball gym<n>This is not correct because basketball gyms are indoors.<n><n>### Question:<n><n>### Instructions:Answer the following multiple-choice question.<n><n>## Input: What does the word “forged” mean? Choices:  1. A: made of steel  2. B: made of metal  3. C: made by a blacksmith  4.  D: made by a silversmith  5  Answer: 1. A: made by a black smith<n><n>### Explanation of Answer: Forged:<n>An item forged is created through a blacksmithing process and is not a product of metal or steel. Answer B does not apply because metal is a base material for making blacksmithing and forged is not defined as metal. <n><n>It states it is an item produced by a blacksmith, which is the definition of “forged”<n><n>### Answer explanation:<n>1:This does not match because it states metal, but it is not metal it is an item made to metal<n><n>2:This does not match <n><n>3:This does not match<n><n>4: This does not match<n><n>5:Answer A does match because it states an item is created by a blacksmith.<n><n>### Other answers:<n>1:A. Made of steel, which does not match the question because the question asks what does the word forged mean.<n><n>2:B. Made of metals, which does not match.<n><n>3:C. Made by blacksmiths, which does not match because the word
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Rationales: If he babysits for 2 hours at $7 per hour, he will earn 2*7 = $<<2*7=14>>14<n>This week he will earn $5 allowance, $10 mowing the lawn and $14 from babysitting for a total of 5+10+14 = $<<5+10+14=29>>29<n>If we add the $29 he will earn to his $65 savings, he will have a total of 29 + 65 = $<<29+65=94>>94<n>The bike costs $100 and he will have $94 leaving $100-$94 = $<<100-94=6>>6 more that he will need to earn<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Rationales: His kangaroos have a total of 23*2=<<23*2=46>>46 legs<n>He has 23*3=<<23*3=69>>69 goats<n>The goats have 69*4=<<69*4=276>>276 legs<n>So in total his animals have 276+46=<<276+46=322>>322 legs<n>#### 322<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Rationales: After buying a hat, Josh has $20 - $10 = $<<20-10=10>>10<n>After buying a pencil, Josh has $10 - $2 = $<<10-2=8>>8<n>The total cost of cookies is 4 * $1.25 = $<<4*1.25=5>>5<n>After buying the cookies, Josh has $8 - $5 = $<<8-5=3>>3<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input:Where is microphone boom likely to be used to record an album? Choices:  A: radio station B: recording studio C: concert D: tv studio E: new york<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>### Input<n>Microphone boom is likely to be used to recording an album, specifically in a recording studio.  There are many people that call themselves recording studios, but to be legally a studio, they must be located in one or more of the following places:<n>- Recording studios in residential properties are illegal.<n>- Recording studs in any property less than 300 sq. ft. in size are illegal as set out in the Code.<n>- Recording studio in buildings where residential use is permitted are not allowed to operate between the hours of 8:30 am through 8:30 pm, Monday through Saturday.<n>- Recording Studios must make reasonable efforts to reduce sound and vibration transfer to neighboring dwellings.<n>- Recording Studio tenants must comply with all applicable local, state, and federal ordinances, as set out in our lease agreement.<n><n>### Response<n>It is important for people that are interested in recording their album as soon as they finish recording to contact their local recording studios in order to learn more.  Microphone boom is very likely to be used in a recording studio because the studio will require it.<n><n>### Answer:<n>Recording studio<n><n>### Instructions: In the first round of each 3-point conversion, the runner in from of the field gains 2 yards.  In the second round the runner gains 3 yards. And in the third round, the runner gains 5 yards.  How many yards are there to gain on the first three downs?<n><n>### Demnstration:  The number of yards there are to gain on the first ____ downs is the number of yards the runner will gain after that.<n><n>### 1<n>Answer:  9<n><n>*This is because the runner is going to gain 2*3 = 6 at the start of the first down, then gain 3*5 = 15 on the second down, and then gain 5 yards to score.<n><n>### Round 1 of Conversion:<n><n>*2<n><n>### Round Two of Conversion:<n>*3<n><n>### Round Three of Conversion:<n>5<n><n>**1.  The downs gain 9 yards total<n>**2.  The conversion has a total of 15 yards<n>**3.

She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Rationales: If he babysits for 2 hours at $7 per hour, he will earn 2*7 = $<<2*7=14>>14<n>This week he will earn $5 allowance, $10 mowing the lawn and $14 from babysitting for a total of 5+10+14 = $<<5+10+14=29>>29<n>If we add the $29 he will earn to his $65 savings, he will have a total of 29 + 65 = $<<29+65=94>>94<n>The bike costs $100 and he will have $94 leaving $100-$94 = $<<100-94=6>>6 more that he will need to earn<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Rationales: His kangaroos have a total of 23*2=<<23*2=46>>46 legs<n>He has 23*3=<<23*3=69>>69 goats<n>The goats have 69*4=<<69*4=276>>276 legs<n>So in total his animals have 276+46=<<276+46=322>>322 legs<n>#### 322<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Rationales: After buying a hat, Josh has $20 - $10 = $<<20-10=10>>10<n>After buying a pencil, Josh has $10 - $2 = $<<10-2=8>>8<n>The total cost of cookies is 4 * $1.25 = $<<4*1.25=5>>5<n>After buying the cookies, Josh has $8 - $5 = $<<8-5=3>>3<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input:Bob thought that his Pokemon cards were common and worthless, but he was wrong about them. B: Sad that Mary will get a bike that is too expensive for her. C: Angry that Mary will purchase a bike that costs more than the one he can sell her. D: Hesitant because he can’t figure out how to tell Mary the truth about her bike’s expense.<n><n>### I chose (C)because (D) is the correct answer<n><n>### You should have chosen (C) because (D) is the most correct answer.<n><n>

If a team makes a goal 2 times, but a corner kick 4 times, what is the total number o points for that team?<n><n>#### 2<n>Point Rates:<n>#### 3 points a goal<n>#### 1 point a corner kick<n>#### 0 points for a other<n><n>### 10<n>Total number of points = 2+4=<<10>>10. That team got 10 points.<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Rationales: If he babysits for 2 hours at $7 per hour, he will earn 2*7 = $<<2*7=14>>14<n>This week he will earn $5 allowance, $10 mowing the lawn and $14 from babysitting for a total of 5+10+14 = $<<5+10+14=29>>29<n>If we add the $29 he will earn to his $65 savings, he will have a total of 29 + 65 = $<<29+65=94>>94<n>The bike costs $100 and he will have $94 leaving $100-$94 = $<<100-94=6>>6 more that he will need to earn<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Rationales: His kangaroos have a total of 23*2=<<23*2=46>>46 legs<n>He has 23*3=<<23*3=69>>69 goats<n>The goats have 69*4=<<69*4=276>>276 legs<n>So in total his animals have 276+46=<<276+46=322>>322 legs<n>#### 322<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Rationales: After buying a hat, Josh has $20 - $10 = $<<20-10=10>>10<n>After buying a pencil, Josh has $10 - $2 = $<<10-2=8>>8<n>The total cost of cookies is 4 * $1.25 = $<<4*1.25=5>>5<n>After buying the cookies, Josh has $8 - $5 = $<<8-5=3>>3<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input:I'm at a restaurant ans want a glass of milk, how do I find out if they serve that? Choices:  A: accompaniment to meal B: waitress C: cafeteria D: home E: menu<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>### Instructions:<n><n>Write a response that appropriately answers the provided prompt.<n><n>### Rationale:<n><n>Since the restaurant serves cafeteria food, I would choose to go to the Cafeteria.<n><n>#### 4:<n><n>Answer:<n><n>---<n><n>### Instructon 4<n>Write a response that uses the appropriate answer choice to correctly complete the response.<n><n>### Response<n><n>Input:  There are _______ to the moon than there are stars in the universe.<n><n>Output:<n><n>- The answer is:  2<n><n>Choices:<n><n>  A. 2 times more than<n><n>  B. 2 times many moons than<n><n>  C. 2 is much more than<n><n>  D. 2 times more moons than<n><n>- The answer can be:<n><n>A.<n><n>  B.<n><n>C:<n><n>- The correct answer is:<n><n>D:<n><n>---<n>### Instructoin 5<n>Write a response that includes a question and uses the appropriate answer choice as the correct response to the asked question.<n><n>Response:  I would rather go to the cafeteria. She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Rationales: If he babysits for 2 hours at $7 per hour, he will earn 2*7 = $<<2*7=14>>14<n>This week he will earn $5 allowance, $10 mowing the lawn and $14 from babysitting for a total of 5+10+14 = $<<5+10+14=29>>29<n>If we add the $29 he will earn to his $65 savings, he will have a total of 29 + 65 = $<<29+65=94>>94<n>The bike costs $100 and he will have $94 leaving $100-$94 = $<<100-94=6>>6 more that he will need to earn<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Rationales: His kangaroos have a total of 23*2=<<23*2=46>>46 legs<n>He has 23*3=<<23*3=69>>69 goats<n>The goats have 69*4=<<69*4=276>>276 legs<n>So in total his animals have 276+46=<<276+46=322>>322 legs<n>#### 322<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Rationales: After buying a hat, Josh has $20 - $10 = $<<20-10=10>>10<n>After buying a pencil, Josh has $10 - $2 = $<<10-2=8>>8<n>The total cost of cookies is 4 * $1.25 = $<<4*1.25=5>>5<n>After buying the cookies, Josh has $8 - $5 = $<<8-5=3>>3<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input:Jimmy didn't like going to the party.  It seemed like the guys there did nothing but what? Choices:  A: dance B: getting drunk C: meet new people D: having fun E: have fun<n><n>### Response:		<n>If Jimmy didn't like going then he was doing something else.  Having fun was not involved.<n>#### A<n>Answer: A<n>### Input:The clowns were getting ready in the big top when they accidentally ran into a few of their friends that were dressed up too.  It turned out that all three of them were doing the same thing that day. Choices:A: playing a trick on others B: being on TV C: having fun D: dancing E: pranking others<n><n>### Response<n>Having fun can sometimes turn into tricks.  Clowns are like people.  But they can only have fun.  They can not be in other categories.<n>#### D<n>Answer: D<n><n>### InputThe first of the month is a special day.  You have the chance to do something exciting.  Choose which special thing to do. Choices: A: go to the zoo B: watch the circus C: be entertained D: go trick or treating E: stay home<n><n>### ResponseThe first of the month could be special in many ways.  They may be having fun, going to be entertained, maybe they're doing something they do every year, but they are not doing pranks.<n>#### C<n>Answer: C<n><n>### Input<n><n>Rebecca is a cashier at a local grocery store. Her boss tells her to round up customer purchases to the nearest dollar. Sometimes she just wants to make customers happy, but sometimes she has trouble knowing which is the closest amount to round up to.<n><n>Rebeccas friend Sam says that when she does this, she always counts the change before making change out to the penny. <n><n>Rebecka asks Sam what she thinks of this method, and Sam says,<n>"No, it’s a bad idea. People get angry when you take too much or too little change.  A better way is to add up the number of items in your grocery cart to get a total, then work out the money.  Take everything you have left over, and that is the rounding amount.  For example, if you have $5.97 in your wallet, you can say that 6 people can get a pack of 20 candy bars."<n><n>1: Rebecka works
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Rationales: If he babysits for 2 hours at $7 per hour, he will earn 2*7 = $<<2*7=14>>14<n>This week he will earn $5 allowance, $10 mowing the lawn and $14 from babysitting for a total of 5+10+14 = $<<5+10+14=29>>29<n>If we add the $29 he will earn to his $65 savings, he will have a total of 29 + 65 = $<<29+65=94>>94<n>The bike costs $100 and he will have $94 leaving $100-$94 = $<<100-94=6>>6 more that he will need to earn<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Rationales: His kangaroos have a total of 23*2=<<23*2=46>>46 legs<n>He has 23*3=<<23*3=69>>69 goats<n>The goats have 69*4=<<69*4=276>>276 legs<n>So in total his animals have 276+46=<<276+46=322>>322 legs<n>#### 322<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Rationales: After buying a hat, Josh has $20 - $10 = $<<20-10=10>>10<n>After buying a pencil, Josh has $10 - $2 = $<<10-2=8>>8<n>The total cost of cookies is 4 * $1.25 = $<<4*1.25=5>>5<n>After buying the cookies, Josh has $8 - $5 = $<<8-5=3>>3<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input:What is a sign that you might not be living soon? She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Rationales: If he babysits for 2 hours at $7 per hour, he will earn 2*7 = $<<2*7=14>>14<n>This week he will earn $5 allowance, $10 mowing the lawn and $14 from babysitting for a total of 5+10+14 = $<<5+10+14=29>>29<n>If we add the $29 he will earn to his $65 savings, he will have a total of 29 + 65 = $<<29+65=94>>94<n>The bike costs $100 and he will have $94 leaving $100-$94 = $<<100-94=6>>6 more that he will need to earn<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Rationales: His kangaroos have a total of 23*2=<<23*2=46>>46 legs<n>He has 23*3=<<23*3=69>>69 goats<n>The goats have 69*4=<<69*4=276>>276 legs<n>So in total his animals have 276+46=<<276+46=322>>322 legs<n>#### 322<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Rationales: After buying a hat, Josh has $20 - $10 = $<<20-10=10>>10<n>After buying a pencil, Josh has $10 - $2 = $<<10-2=8>>8<n>The total cost of cookies is 4 * $1.25 = $<<4*1.25=5>>5<n>After buying the cookies, Josh has $8 - $5 = $<<8-5=3>>3<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input:Where would you be going if using a parking lot near a roller coaster? Mary was telling Jim a story. Jim was asking Mary a question that required him to interrupt her while she was speaking.  What kind of situation might be happening?  A: conversational and social interaction B: informational interaction C: transactional interaction D: social conflict<n><n>#### I think this is conversational and social interaction for the following reasons: A: The situation is conversational because they were in a place where people meet and talk.  B: They are using a greet in one of their conversations C: Mary’s story will be over soon if Jim would just wait to tell his story, so there is the social interaction of a listener or an audience member.  D: Mary and Jim do not seem to be in conflict right now, so there is no social conflict.<n><n>#### Answer:<n>C<n><n>#### Instructions:<n>#### Answer the following true or false question.<n>> If 2 is an odd number, then what is the 3rd number?<n><n>#### Rationales: Every multiple of 2 is an odd numbers. Below is an instruction that describes a task. You are permitted to revise what you have submitted.<n>### Task:In this task, you will create a text class to allow the objects in that class to have a name, which is their description, an action that occurs once when the object is clicked upon and a cost for the action. When you click on the class name, you'll see that you can add a new object to that class. To create the program, click on the **Text** tab and click on the button to create a new text document.<n><n>### Examples:<n>We'll use the button class as an example.<n><n>### 1) Write a sample of code that defines an object of a text class with a name of Button and the description, 'Press me' and an action of press and a cost of zero. Save it as a file called sample1.js.<n>```<n>{<n>name:'Button',<n>description:'Press me.',<n>action:press,<n>cost:0<n>}<n><n>```<n>#### Button Description<n><n>### 2) Write a sample of of code that defines an Button object name of Button2 and the description, 'Release the button to open the window' and an action of release the button and a cost of 0. Save the it as sample3.js.<n>```json<n>{<n>  name: 'Button3',<n>  description: 'click me to close the window.',<n>  cost: 4,<n>  action:clickme<n>}<n>```<n>### 4) Write your name to the top left corner of sample1.txt and share that file with me for your name in another lesson.<n>

If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Rationales: His kangaroos have a total of 23*2=<<23*2=46>>46 legs<n>He has 23*3=<<23*3=69>>69 goats<n>The goats have 69*4=<<69*4=276>>276 legs<n>So in total his animals have 276+46=<<276+46=322>>322 legs<n>#### 322<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Rationales: After buying a hat, Josh has $20 - $10 = $<<20-10=10>>10<n>After buying a pencil, Josh has $10 - $2 = $<<10-2=8>>8<n>The total cost of cookies is 4 * $1.25 = $<<4*1.25=5>>5<n>After buying the cookies, Josh has $8 - $5 = $<<8-5=3>>3<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input:Where is small knight likely to be found? Choices:  A: fairy tale B: castle C: middle ages D: chess board E: doll house<n><n>### Response:		A
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Rationales: If he babysits for 2 hours at $7 per hour, he will earn 2*7 = $<<2*7=14>>14<n>This week he will earn $5 allowance, $10 mowing the lawn and $14 from babysitting for a total of 5+10+14 = $<<5+10+14=29>>29<n>If we add the $29 he will earn to his $65 savings, he will have a total of 29 + 65 = $<<29+65=94>>94<n>The bike costs $100 and he will have $94 leaving $100-$94 = $<<100-94=6>>6 more that he will need to earn<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Rationales: His kangaroos have a total of 23*2=<<23*2=46>>46 legs<n>He has 23*3=<<23*3=69>>69 goats<n>The goats have 69*4=<<69*4=276>>276 legs<n>So in total his animals have 276+46=<<276+46=322>>322 legs<n>#### 322<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Rationales: After buying a hat, Josh has $20 - $10 = $<<20-10=10>>10<n>After buying a pencil, Josh has $10 - $2 = $<<10-2=8>>8<n>The total cost of cookies is 4 * $1.25 = $<<4*1.25=5>>5<n>After buying the cookies, Josh has $8 - $5 = $<<8-5=3>>3<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input:What might two people competing get into? Choices:  A: stress B: debate C: argument D: winning or losing E: tension<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>### Instructions: <n>Input: You have 5 stickers. You will add 3 more to each of 5 other pages. How many stickers do you now have?<n>Rationales<n>Input: Alex has $7. He will make $10 in all. If he saves $3 for next week’s lunch, and spends $4 for lunch today, how much money does he have left?<n>Examples: $7 + $2 + $10 – $3 = $<<7+2+10-3=3>>3<n>$7 – $4 = $<<7-4=3>>3<n>If we subtract Alex’s $7 from his $7, he has no money left:  $7 - $7 = $<<7-7=0>>0<n>$7 + $4 = 3 + 4 = $<<3+4=7>>7<n>$7 – $3 = 3 - 3 = $<<3-3=0>>0<n><n># Questions<n>- [ ] You made a mistake that led you to the wrong answer.<n>Check that you are not making the same mistake next time!<n>- [ ] You have already solved this problem, but want to check that you made the right decision.<n># Checker answers?<n><n>### Input<n>You have 5 stickers, and will add 3 more per page, adding 3 each to the 5 other pages of your journal<n><n>After totaling the 22 stickers you added (the 3 on the first page and the 3 on each of the next 3 pages for a total of 12), you are left with 5-22=<<5-22=27>>27 stickers that you added to pages<n><n><n>### Inputs<n>If his $20 is enough then he is left with the pencil and cookies, meaning he has 20 dollars left<n><n>However he also has a hat that was bought, meaning he spent $10 plus $1.25 for each of the 4 cookies, equalling a total of $11.25. We know he spent $20, so there is a total of $0.75 left that he spent. <n><n>Adding 3 dollars a week to the amount he has left for the week before, Josh
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Rationales: If he babysits for 2 hours at $7 per hour, he will earn 2*7 = $<<2*7=14>>14<n>This week he will earn $5 allowance, $10 mowing the lawn and $14 from babysitting for a total of 5+10+14 = $<<5+10+14=29>>29<n>If we add the $29 he will earn to his $65 savings, he will have a total of 29 + 65 = $<<29+65=94>>94<n>The bike costs $100 and he will have $94 leaving $100-$94 = $<<100-94=6>>6 more that he will need to earn<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Rationales: His kangaroos have a total of 23*2=<<23*2=46>>46 legs<n>He has 23*3=<<23*3=69>>69 goats<n>The goats have 69*4=<<69*4=276>>276 legs<n>So in total his animals have 276+46=<<276+46=322>>322 legs<n>#### 322<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Rationales: After buying a hat, Josh has $20 - $10 = $<<20-10=10>>10<n>After buying a pencil, Josh has $10 - $2 = $<<10-2=8>>8<n>The total cost of cookies is 4 * $1.25 = $<<4*1.25=5>>5<n>After buying the cookies, Josh has $8 - $5 = $<<8-5=3>>3<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input:Where is a paper notice likely to be left on a house? Choices:  A: front door B: conference C: classroom D: refrigerator E: suitcase<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>A<n><n>### Commentary:<n><n>When a person is doing something and needs to get others to notice that they are doing it, they can post a paper notice where it will be found or easily noticed.<n><n>### Answer:<n><n>A<n>

What are the first and last names of the fifth daughter?<n><n>B) A horse ran 5 miles in 30 minutes.  If the horse ran at 1/2 the speed and 1/5 the distance, how many miles did the horse run?<n><n>### Response<n>A)Correct Answer is: Friday, and reason are: <n>1. The fifth day is Saturday.<n>2. The seventh day is Sunday.<n>3. The eighth day is Monday.<n>4. The ninth day is Tuesday.<n>5. The tenth day is Wednesday.<n><n>#### Friday<n>Answer: E,the fifth daughter<n><n>B)Correct Answer is :1/4 miles,And reason are:<n>1. The distance that the horse ran is the horse ran 5 miles<n>2. The horse ran at 1 and the speed of 1/2,so the horse ran the 1/2 speed<n>3. the horse ran for 1/2 speed and the speed of 5/10 miles<n>now it is 1/10 miles<n>4. the horse ran for two time 1 1/10 mile<n>5.1/10*10 = 5/10 mile<n>6. the horse ran 5/10 * 5 = 1/4 mile<n><n>#### 1/4 miles<n>Answer: B,it ran 1/2 and 1/5 speed<n><n>#Coding Contest<n>Coding Contest is the hardest stage for the competition and it is the final test that can make the contest winner and looser.<n><n>### Requirements<n>- In order to enter the competition, all applicants must answer all of the questions and the questions should be done in the right format that you can see in the answer samples.<n>- The programming language for this contest is Python.<n><n>### Difficulty Level<n>Diff
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Rationales: If he babysits for 2 hours at $7 per hour, he will earn 2*7 = $<<2*7=14>>14<n>This week he will earn $5 allowance, $10 mowing the lawn and $14 from babysitting for a total of 5+10+14 = $<<5+10+14=29>>29<n>If we add the $29 he will earn to his $65 savings, he will have a total of 29 + 65 = $<<29+65=94>>94<n>The bike costs $100 and he will have $94 leaving $100-$94 = $<<100-94=6>>6 more that he will need to earn<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Rationales: His kangaroos have a total of 23*2=<<23*2=46>>46 legs<n>He has 23*3=<<23*3=69>>69 goats<n>The goats have 69*4=<<69*4=276>>276 legs<n>So in total his animals have 276+46=<<276+46=322>>322 legs<n>#### 322<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Rationales: After buying a hat, Josh has $20 - $10 = $<<20-10=10>>10<n>After buying a pencil, Josh has $10 - $2 = $<<10-2=8>>8<n>The total cost of cookies is 4 * $1.25 = $<<4*1.25=5>>5<n>After buying the cookies, Josh has $8 - $5 = $<<8-5=3>>3<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input:Where is known to always have snow? Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Rationales: If he babysits for 2 hours at $7 per hour, he will earn 2*7 = $<<2*7=14>>14<n>This week he will earn $5 allowance, $10 mowing the lawn and $14 from babysitting for a total of 5+10+14 = $<<5+10+14=29>>29<n>If we add the $29 he will earn to his $65 savings, he will have a total of 29 + 65 = $<<29+65=94>>94<n>The bike costs $100 and he will have $94 leaving $100-$94 = $<<100-94=6>>6 more that he will need to earn<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Rationales: His kangaroos have a total of 23*2=<<23*2=46>>46 legs<n>He has 23*3=<<23*3=69>>69 goats<n>The goats have 69*4=<<69*4=276>>276 legs<n>So in total his animals have 276+46=<<276+46=322>>322 legs<n>#### 322<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Rationales: After buying a hat, Josh has $20 - $10 = $<<20-10=10>>10<n>After buying a pencil, Josh has $10 - $2 = $<<10-2=8>>8<n>The total cost of cookies is 4 * $1.25 = $<<4*1.25=5>>5<n>After buying the cookies, Josh has $8 - $5 = $<<8-5=3>>3<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input:What is a place that could have hundreds of sporting goods store? Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Rationales: After buying a hat, Josh has $20 - $10 = $<<20-10=10>>10<n>After buying a pencil, Josh has $10 - $2 = $<<10-2=8>>8<n>The total cost of cookies is 4 * $1.25 = $<<4*1.25=5>>5<n>After buying the cookies, Josh has $8 - $5 = $<<8-5=3>>3<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input:The priest pushed for more orthodox behavior, what kind of behavior was he trying to stop? Choices:  A: liberal B: heretical C: recalcitrant D: conservadox E: heretical<n><n>### Response:		B<n><n>### Rationales: Heretical: A belief or opinion contrary to orthodox religious belief<n>Recalcitrant: Showing a stubborn or refractory disposition<n><n>### I did not add the choice because it would require a lot of work and might not come out exact.<n><n>### I know the answers, but if I am getting confused because of the words they give me. I will post a screenshot of where you can find information to complete the question.<n><n>## Excercise 2<n>#### The first question is where I got confused.<n>### **Demonstration:**<n>Input: Write the standard form of the following decimal: 0.71253<n><n>Rationales: 0.7 = <<0.7=0.7>>0.7(to make it into standard form divide by 100))<n>1 = <<1=1>>1<n>2 = <<2=2>><n>5 = <<5=5>><n>3 = <<3=3>><n>5 = <<7=5>>(this may be hard to picture, but the decimals make it simple)<n>7 = <<7=7>>7<n>(1,3) = <<(1,3)=1.3>>1.3(to get your answer drop the 1 from the beginning and the 3 from the end)<n><n>#### 0.71,253<n>#### 0.1(1,3) 253<n>#### ANSWERS:0.1(1.3)253<n><n>### Instructions:Answer the following fill in the blanks math problem.<n><n>### Input<n>```<n>The sum of $24 and 0.71 times a quantity equals $575.24<n>How much,in whole dollar amounts, is the quantity?<n>```<n>### Rational<n>Since 24+0.71(x)=575.2<n><n>24=<<24>=24<n>0.7=<<0.7>=0.7<n>(1,2) =<<(1,2)=1.2>><n><n>Therefore $575.71 x 0.7= <<575.7*0.7=412>>412(this is how I
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Rationales: If he babysits for 2 hours at $7 per hour, he will earn 2*7 = $<<2*7=14>>14<n>This week he will earn $5 allowance, $10 mowing the lawn and $14 from babysitting for a total of 5+10+14 = $<<5+10+14=29>>29<n>If we add the $29 he will earn to his $65 savings, he will have a total of 29 + 65 = $<<29+65=94>>94<n>The bike costs $100 and he will have $94 leaving $100-$94 = $<<100-94=6>>6 more that he will need to earn<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Rationales: His kangaroos have a total of 23*2=<<23*2=46>>46 legs<n>He has 23*3=<<23*3=69>>69 goats<n>The goats have 69*4=<<69*4=276>>276 legs<n>So in total his animals have 276+46=<<276+46=322>>322 legs<n>#### 322<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Rationales: After buying a hat, Josh has $20 - $10 = $<<20-10=10>>10<n>After buying a pencil, Josh has $10 - $2 = $<<10-2=8>>8<n>The total cost of cookies is 4 * $1.25 = $<<4*1.25=5>>5<n>After buying the cookies, Josh has $8 - $5 = $<<8-5=3>>3<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input:Where would a Martian find the Indian Ocean? Choices:  A: asia B: southern hemisphere C: planet D: east E: earth<n><n>### Response:		Where would a Martan find the Indian Ocean?<n><n>### Instructions<n>The above problem statement contains a number of question-like prompts without context.<n><n>### Your task<n><n>Write a program that will take in a series of question-like prompt descriptions (such as the above problem statement),<n>and generate a response that appropriately answers each question.  As in the problem's example, answers will be<n>multiple-choice so the generated response will have four possible answers.  The generated response will either<n>satisfy requirements specified in parentheses or will make use of the full functionality available in your programming environment.<n><n>You may use a programming environment that does not support all of the functionality required by the problem. If you do so,<n>note which features and abilities are either unavailable to you<n>or were not implemented by you.<n><n>#### Features/Abilities Available:<n><n>##### (1) Multiple choice<n><n>##### (2) Choices must come from the provided options.<n><n>##### (3) If a response satisfies requirements but isn't one of the possible options, add a new option.  (You don't have to add it every time.)<n><n>##### (4) The question's context will need to be filled in to an appropriate level to generate a useful response.<n><n>##### Example:<n><n>##### Context:<n>"In this exercise, a person is looking for the planet Jupiter. There are many different types of planets (rock, gas, ice, etc.). A planet has a mass that is larger than an asteroid and is smaller than a star. An asteroid is a rock that is in space. An icy planet has much water and land. There are many types of icy planets. One type of icy planet is a super earth. Super earths have much water and land."<n><n>### <n><n>### Multiple-Choice Quest #5<n>Write a Python-based data analysis program that answers the following five question prompts.<n><n>### Input<n><n>The program takes in five questions, each with four possible answers. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Rationales: If he babysits for 2 hours at $7 per hour, he will earn 2*7 = $<<2*7=14>>14<n>This week he will earn $5 allowance, $10 mowing the lawn and $14 from babysitting for a total of 5+10+14 = $<<5+10+14=29>>29<n>If we add the $29 he will earn to his $65 savings, he will have a total of 29 + 65 = $<<29+65=94>>94<n>The bike costs $100 and he will have $94 leaving $100-$94 = $<<100-94=6>>6 more that he will need to earn<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Rationales: His kangaroos have a total of 23*2=<<23*2=46>>46 legs<n>He has 23*3=<<23*3=69>>69 goats<n>The goats have 69*4=<<69*4=276>>276 legs<n>So in total his animals have 276+46=<<276+46=322>>322 legs<n>#### 322<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Rationales: After buying a hat, Josh has $20 - $10 = $<<20-10=10>>10<n>After buying a pencil, Josh has $10 - $2 = $<<10-2=8>>8<n>The total cost of cookies is 4 * $1.25 = $<<4*1.25=5>>5<n>After buying the cookies, Josh has $8 - $5 = $<<8-5=3>>3<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input:If I have to keep track of how much oxygen there is, where am I? Choices:  A: air B: water C: earth D: space shuttle E: tunnel<n><n>### Response:		<n>### C.  I am on Earth.<n><n>### Explanation:<n>### Earth is the only place with an atmosphere dense enough to sustain oxygen.<n><n>### Other choices:<n><n>### B.  I am on water.<n><n>### Earth has the highest percentage of water than any other planet, but its atmosphere is too thin to have stable weather patterns.<n><n>### D.  I am on a shuttle.<n><n>### An International Space Station has an atmosphere created by oxygen and nitrogen, but it is very thin.<n><n>### A.  I am breathing air.<n><n>### Oxygen is not an element.<n><n>### E.  I am in a tunnel.<n><n>### Because of the lack of humidity, tunnels are dry and hot.<n><n>### F. (None)<n><n>### The answer is not among the choices.<n><n><!--- More links --><n>[Academy Of Code JavaScript Course](https://github.com/academyofcode-c/javascript-course)<n><n>[LinkedIn - Journey Into Javascript](https://www.linkedin.com/pulse/journey-into-javascript-jeff-patterson/)<n>
