How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Rationales: If he babysits for 2 hours at $7 per hour, he will earn 2*7 = $<<2*7=14>>14<n>This week he will earn $5 allowance, $10 mowing the lawn and $14 from babysitting for a total of 5+10+14 = $<<5+10+14=29>>29<n>If we add the $29 he will earn to his $65 savings, he will have a total of 29 + 65 = $<<29+65=94>>94<n>The bike costs $100 and he will have $94 leaving $100-$94 = $<<100-94=6>>6 more that he will need to earn<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Rationales: His kangaroos have a total of 23*2=<<23*2=46>>46 legs<n>He has 23*3=<<23*3=69>>69 goats<n>The goats have 69*4=<<69*4=276>>276 legs<n>So in total his animals have 276+46=<<276+46=322>>322 legs<n>#### 322<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Rationales: After buying a hat, Josh has $20 - $10 = $<<20-10=10>>10<n>After buying a pencil, Josh has $10 - $2 = $<<10-2=8>>8<n>The total cost of cookies is 4 * $1.25 = $<<4*1.25=5>>5<n>After buying the cookies, Josh has $8 - $5 = $<<8-5=3>>3<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input:What is made out of only one piece? Choices:  A: jigsaw puzzle B: chess game C: puzzle box D: jigsaw puzzel puxxle E: puxxle<n><n>### Response:		If the whole thing is made out of only 1 piece, then it would be a puzzle box.<n><n>#### Correct:<n>The correct statement is that a puzzle box is made out of only a one piece. <n><n>### Rationale:<n>The wording of the word problem is "made out of one piece" which means that it is something made up of just one thing, and then states the choice as a puzzle box.  If the entirety of the puzzle box is made up a just one piece then it would not be in any other category, as the other categories are each in two separate pieces.<n><n>#### Correct<n>The answer is correct, because the only thing that is a puzzle box is a puzzle box by definition.<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Rationales: If he babysits for 2 hours at $7 per hour, he will earn 2*7 = $<<2*7=14>>14<n>This week he will earn $5 allowance, $10 mowing the lawn and $14 from babysitting for a total of 5+10+14 = $<<5+10+14=29>>29<n>If we add the $29 he will earn to his $65 savings, he will have a total of 29 + 65 = $<<29+65=94>>94<n>The bike costs $100 and he will have $94 leaving $100-$94 = $<<100-94=6>>6 more that he will need to earn<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Rationales: His kangaroos have a total of 23*2=<<23*2=46>>46 legs<n>He has 23*3=<<23*3=69>>69 goats<n>The goats have 69*4=<<69*4=276>>276 legs<n>So in total his animals have 276+46=<<276+46=322>>322 legs<n>#### 322<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Rationales: After buying a hat, Josh has $20 - $10 = $<<20-10=10>>10<n>After buying a pencil, Josh has $10 - $2 = $<<10-2=8>>8<n>The total cost of cookies is 4 * $1.25 = $<<4*1.25=5>>5<n>After buying the cookies, Josh has $8 - $5 = $<<8-5=3>>3<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input:What happens to the conscience of someone who has been caught committing a murder? Choices:  A: jail time B: fear C: going to prison D: nothing E: feeling of guilt<n><n>### Response:		<n>#### C<n>Answer: C<n>

What gas do I buy?<n><n>### Demo:<n>#### half a gallon<n><n>Gas prices are always a pain.<n><n>#### half<n>#### full<n><n>Given half or a whole gallon of gas, we know you can only get 24 miles to the gallon (1 mile is $0.004 gallons), which means you can drive approximately  23.873 miles or 24 miles on a half gallon of gas or a gallon of gas.<n><n>#### full<n><n>#### half<n><n>We know from the question you can only buy half of a gallon of gas which means you can only travel 24 miles (because each mile costs $0.001 gallons).<n><n>#### half a galloon?<n><n>So if you only have half a gallon of gas in your car, you are limited to driving a maximum of 24 miles (each mile costing $0.002 gallons).<n><n>### Answer: A<n><n>Answers:<n><n>**Correct**: B<n><n>***Incorrect**: A, C<n><n>#### Answer: B<n><n>Answers are ordered by number of correct answers and then by number of incorrect answers and then alphabetically.<n>

His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Rationales: If he babysits for 2 hours at $7 per hour, he will earn 2*7 = $<<2*7=14>>14<n>This week he will earn $5 allowance, $10 mowing the lawn and $14 from babysitting for a total of 5+10+14 = $<<5+10+14=29>>29<n>If we add the $29 he will earn to his $65 savings, he will have a total of 29 + 65 = $<<29+65=94>>94<n>The bike costs $100 and he will have $94 leaving $100-$94 = $<<100-94=6>>6 more that he will need to earn<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Rationales: His kangaroos have a total of 23*2=<<23*2=46>>46 legs<n>He has 23*3=<<23*3=69>>69 goats<n>The goats have 69*4=<<69*4=276>>276 legs<n>So in total his animals have 276+46=<<276+46=322>>322 legs<n>#### 322<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Rationales: After buying a hat, Josh has $20 - $10 = $<<20-10=10>>10<n>After buying a pencil, Josh has $10 - $2 = $<<10-2=8>>8<n>The total cost of cookies is 4 * $1.25 = $<<4*1.25=5>>5<n>After buying the cookies, Josh has $8 - $5 = $<<8-5=3>>3<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input:Where could you find a fox hunting when not in a forest? Choices:  A: open meadow B: arctic tundra C: beach D: great outdoors E: england<n><n>### Response:		The correct response is A: open meadow, but B: arctic tunder is also correct.<n><n>### Explain why you got your response.<n><n>C: beach is wrong. The beach is on the coast of a body of water, thus not "open meadow"<n><n>D: great outdoors is incorrect. All of the other choices are locations on which one can hunt a fox. The fox has a "home habitat" of a forest and cannot be found in the "great outdoors", which is just a saying for hunting area.<n><n>E: England is incorrect. England is not a habitat, which should be a location where a fox lives.<n><n>Answer: A<n><n>### <n><n>### 15) 22 minutes<n><n>### [Amazon, 2012] Question 4:The graph below shows sales of 7 types of dog food over a 12-month period. <n>![](https://edtechsinsider.s3.eu-central-1.amazonaws.com/files/2019/09/B6752636-D527-4928-BECF-22E9B1E60081_image.png)<n><n>A:  The total sales of all of the dog foods combined is more than all of the other types of dog food combined?<n>B:  None of the types of dog foods are selling very well?<n>C:  The sales of Beefy Bites gradually increases over time?<n>D:  The sales of Peanut Butter increase over time until the end of the year when it drops down to almost nothing?<n>E:  The Doggie Delights never sold very many packages of dog food?<n>F:  The sales of Pure Fries are constantly in the top 2 selling types of dog food between January and June?<n>G:  The percentage of Chunky Cheese sold in packages of less than eight pounds stays the same between January and June? A: Charts<n>![](https://quizlet.com/67526087/a-charts/flashcards/index)<n><n>![](https://cdn.quizlet.com/-5a4de3fb3acd265
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Rationales: If he babysits for 2 hours at $7 per hour, he will earn 2*7 = $<<2*7=14>>14<n>This week he will earn $5 allowance, $10 mowing the lawn and $14 from babysitting for a total of 5+10+14 = $<<5+10+14=29>>29<n>If we add the $29 he will earn to his $65 savings, he will have a total of 29 + 65 = $<<29+65=94>>94<n>The bike costs $100 and he will have $94 leaving $100-$94 = $<<100-94=6>>6 more that he will need to earn<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Rationales: His kangaroos have a total of 23*2=<<23*2=46>>46 legs<n>He has 23*3=<<23*3=69>>69 goats<n>The goats have 69*4=<<69*4=276>>276 legs<n>So in total his animals have 276+46=<<276+46=322>>322 legs<n>#### 322<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Rationales: After buying a hat, Josh has $20 - $10 = $<<20-10=10>>10<n>After buying a pencil, Josh has $10 - $2 = $<<10-2=8>>8<n>The total cost of cookies is 4 * $1.25 = $<<4*1.25=5>>5<n>After buying the cookies, Josh has $8 - $5 = $<<8-5=3>>3<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input:What cuisine is joked about eating small dogs? What should the length of the table be?<n><n>### Demnstration:<n>You can make each piece of the table with a rectangular prism.  Let the width be "w" and the height be "h."  Length would be w+h.<n><n>### Answer: 20 + 30 = 50<n><n>###<n><n>## Task Description: <n>## Instructions to create a table with a given width and height for storing textbooks.<n>## Instructions:: You are hired to buit a table to store books. Choices:  A: nuclear power plant B: center C: basement D: main office E: bowel of the ship<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>#### (Rubric:30/30)<n>Rubric:3/3<n><n>#### (Task Scoring Grid)<n><n>### Instructions:<n><n>### Demostration <n><n>Input:Mikey is flying to Florida for summer camp.  His plane goes somewhere where their seasons are opposite.  When he’s at his summer camp he sleeps until midnight and wakes up at 7:00 AM.  He goes to bed at midnight if there’s daylight.  During daylight hours he stays busy with his camp activities.  What does he do when he is at home in wintertime?<n><n>Rationales:  Daytime is also referred to as morning and afternoon. At his winter home Mikey sleep at 7:0am and stays awake for 12 hours (7:0am-7:0pm) and then sleeps for 12 hours.<n><n>At his summer home he wakes up at 5:00 pm and goes to bed at 12:00 AM. This would allow him 12 hours (5:00pm-5:00am) to stay awake and sleep from 5:00am-5:00pm.<n>If he stays awake for 24 hours he needs to go to bed a half hour later at 7:30pm.<n>To wake up at midnight he would need to go to bed at midnight.<n><n>#### Midnight<n>Answer: Midnight  <n><n>#### Submitted: Midnight<n><n>### Instuctions<n><n>#### Write a two lines of code to print 24 as an octal number<n><n>### Demo:<n><n>#### Line #<n>1<n>Line #: 1<n>Line #<n><n>#### Explanation:<n>1. Choices:  A: sun B: sky C: candle D: house E: lamp<n><n>### Response:		A light source does not come from the sun because it is an object in space. Therefore, it cannot be sun. Next, a light source is not from the sky because the sky is an object in space that covers the whole entire atmosphere. Next, a light does not come from a candle because the candle is a type of artificial source of light.  A light source is not from a house because it is not an object in space.  Next, a light source does not come directly from a lamp.<n><n>![Exercise](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/44375106/113477336-9d203ac0-922e-11eb-9d86-48fb6bdf86c9.png)<n>

His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Rationales: If he babysits for 2 hours at $7 per hour, he will earn 2*7 = $<<2*7=14>>14<n>This week he will earn $5 allowance, $10 mowing the lawn and $14 from babysitting for a total of 5+10+14 = $<<5+10+14=29>>29<n>If we add the $29 he will earn to his $65 savings, he will have a total of 29 + 65 = $<<29+65=94>>94<n>The bike costs $100 and he will have $94 leaving $100-$94 = $<<100-94=6>>6 more that he will need to earn<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Rationales: His kangaroos have a total of 23*2=<<23*2=46>>46 legs<n>He has 23*3=<<23*3=69>>69 goats<n>The goats have 69*4=<<69*4=276>>276 legs<n>So in total his animals have 276+46=<<276+46=322>>322 legs<n>#### 322<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Rationales: After buying a hat, Josh has $20 - $10 = $<<20-10=10>>10<n>After buying a pencil, Josh has $10 - $2 = $<<10-2=8>>8<n>The total cost of cookies is 4 * $1.25 = $<<4*1.25=5>>5<n>After buying the cookies, Josh has $8 - $5 = $<<8-5=3>>3<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input:If you have trouble beginning work you're suffering from what? Choices:  A: sitting down B: excitement C: tiredness D: progress E: procrastination<n><n>### Response:		You're suffering from C) tiredness.  Excitement usually helps you begin work.  A) Sitting Down, B) Progress, and D)<n>Procrastination can cause you to have trouble beginning work.<n><n>### Output:<n>The user will receive an explanation, which they can follow or not. 
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100. He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Rationales: If he babysits for 2 hours at $7 per hour, he will earn 2*7 = $<<2*7=14>>14<n>This week he will earn $5 allowance, $10 mowing the lawn and $14 from babysitting for a total of 5+10+14 = $<<5+10+14=29>>29<n>If we add the $29 he will earn to his $65 savings, he will have a total of 29 + 65 = $<<29+65=94>>94<n>The bike costs $100 and he will have $94 leaving $100-$94 = $<<100-94=6>>6 more that he will need to earn<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs. Choices:  A: build family together B: fall in love C: make love D: complete E: distance themselves<n><n>### Response:		<n>Write a free-response response to the task.<n><n>#### Choice A:<n>The lover is likely to want to build family together: This is because the lover is likely to build a strong relationship and this could lead to building a family.<n><n>#### Choices B, C, D, E:<n>The lover will likely want to Fall In Love, Make Love, and Distance Themselves<n><n>#### Choice B:<n>The lover wants to Fall In Love<n><n>#### Choice C:<n>The lover make make love<n><n>#### Choice D:<n>The Lover will Complete<n><n>#### Choice E:<n>The lovers will Distance Themselmselves<n><n>#### Answer:<n>The lover are likely to want to Fall In Love and Make Love and Distance Themselve<n><n>### Instructions:Choose whether the sentence is true or false.<n><n>### Choice A:<n>There are 0.0022 miles in a millimeter.<n><n>### Rationale:<n>MM or mm stands for millimetre which is a unit of measurement of lengths, it is 1/1000th of a metre and it is a subunit of inch. A inch is a unit of measurement. A millimeter is equal to 1/<math>\displaystyle\frac{1}{\text{1000}}</math> of a meter which is 2.54 centimeters. 0.00022 miles <sup>(0.00003373575 miles)</sup> <sup>(0.402608 meters)</sup><n>0.402 x 0.22 = 0.52<n>### Rationale and Response:<n><n>Choice A is false, One millimetre is equal to 1000 Ｗ = 1/10 12 and one metre is equal to 25400 milimeters.  So 0.00 mm and 0.22 mm are not the same.<n><n>### Answer:<n>False<n><n>### Instrections:<n>Fill in the blank.<n><n>### Sentence:<n>The only numbers in the sequence 1,2,3,... are 1 and 2, but not _

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100. There is \$13 in your wallet and you want to split the bill evenly. His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Rationales: If he babysits for 2 hours at $7 per hour, he will earn 2*7 = $<<2*7=14>>14<n>This week he will earn $5 allowance, $10 mowing the lawn and $14 from babysitting for a total of 5+10+14 = $<<5+10+14=29>>29<n>If we add the $29 he will earn to his $65 savings, he will have a total of 29 + 65 = $<<29+65=94>>94<n>The bike costs $100 and he will have $94 leaving $100-$94 = $<<100-94=6>>6 more that he will need to earn<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Rationales: His kangaroos have a total of 23*2=<<23*2=46>>46 legs<n>He has 23*3=<<23*3=69>>69 goats<n>The goats have 69*4=<<69*4=276>>276 legs<n>So in total his animals have 276+46=<<276+46=322>>322 legs<n>#### 322<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Rationales: After buying a hat, Josh has $20 - $10 = $<<20-10=10>>10<n>After buying a pencil, Josh has $10 - $2 = $<<10-2=8>>8<n>The total cost of cookies is 4 * $1.25 = $<<4*1.25=5>>5<n>After buying the cookies, Josh has $8 - $5 = $<<8-5=3>>3<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input:The policemen wanted to clear the scene of the accident, so what did they do to traffic? Choices:  A: hurry along B: direct traffic C: help D: force open door E: corner thief<n><n>### Response:		<n>Demonstration:<n>Rationales: The policemen can prevent traffic from hurrying in a single direction, while forcing traffic to direct along a certain path, they can even stop someone from forcing their way in<n>#### 1<n>Answer: A<n><n>### Input:[Helen and Sally] had dinner at a very nice restaurant. Sally was too fat to fit her leg under the table so Helen held her leg. Helen then had to lean one way to reach an item on the table and then lean the other way to see her friend and so she swayed from side to side. How far did Helen sway? Choices: 1: 6 feet 2: 9 feet 3: 12 feet 4: 36 feet 5: cannot tell, the lady was not that fat at all!<n><n>### Demstration:<n>Ranking or Scoring:<n>### Rationales:<n>#### 4<n>Answer: 2<n><n>### Input:"I’m in a terrible mood!" cried Mary. "What happened?" asked her mother. Mary smiled. "I got to use the crayons!" she said. "We all use the crayons," said her mother. "And you want to be the only one to use the crayon sharpener?" asked her mother. "Well, OK," said Mary. "But I didn’t want to use it. I was going to share it with the other kids next time they asked, but they never asked!" said Mary. "They didn’t know it existed yet," her mother said. How many times did the other children ask for the crayon sharpner?<n><n>### Demostration:<n>Rank or Score, then rank or score:<n><n>#### 5<n>Answer: 2 or 3<n><n>## Solution <n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Rationales: If he babysits for 2 hours at $7 per hour, he will earn 2*7 = $<<2*7=14>>14<n>This week he will earn $5 allowance, $10 mowing the lawn and $14 from babysitting for a total of 5+10+14 = $<<5+10+14=29>>29<n>If we add the $29 he will earn to his $65 savings, he will have a total of 29 + 65 = $<<29+65=94>>94<n>The bike costs $100 and he will have $94 leaving $100-$94 = $<<100-94=6>>6 more that he will need to earn<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Rationales: His kangaroos have a total of 23*2=<<23*2=46>>46 legs<n>He has 23*3=<<23*3=69>>69 goats<n>The goats have 69*4=<<69*4=276>>276 legs<n>So in total his animals have 276+46=<<276+46=322>>322 legs<n>#### 322<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Rationales: After buying a hat, Josh has $20 - $10 = $<<20-10=10>>10<n>After buying a pencil, Josh has $10 - $2 = $<<10-2=8>>8<n>The total cost of cookies is 4 * $1.25 = $<<4*1.25=5>>5<n>After buying the cookies, Josh has $8 - $5 = $<<8-5=3>>3<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input:Where would you find performers on a platform in public? Choices:  A: arena B: building C: dock D: concert hall E: museum<n><n>### Response:		<n>Input:D - concert hall<n>Input:E - museum<n>Input:A - arena<n>Input:C - dock<n>Input:B - building<n><n>### Rationale:The question is referring to the platform as in a stage<n>#### A<n>Answer: <img src="https://s2.glbimg.com/0Wxm9H6k_377x2hZ46KoFQ_pKk=/fit-in/180x180/filters:no_upscale():/cdn-cgi/image/auto/w530/https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bc/Arena.jpg/180px-Arena.jpg"><n><n>### Rationales:<n>#### D<n>Answer: <img dir="auto" src="https://www.kidskonnect.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/10/Concert-Hall.jpg" alt="Concert Hall" width="180" height="180"><n><n>### 180<n>#### B<n>Answer: <img data-src-resize="600" src="https://encrypted-tbn0.gstatic.com/images?q=tbn:ANd9GcRg_o70MwZjyOvOvEtV4Kb_VGwfLtG1bw2n0G6wL7nA65xD4A&usqp=" alt="building" width="600" height="800"><n><n>## E<n>Answer: <img img-src="https://encrypted.google.com/search?q=gold+museum&source=lnms&tbm=isch&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjm05Ck1MDlAhXCnFQKHWj3C_gQ_AUICigB&biw=1772&bih=891" width="60x82" height="45"><n><n><n><n><n><n>

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100. Choices:  A: birthday party B: child's hand C: grocery store D: sky E: up in the<n><n>### Response:		Grocery Store<n><n>### Rationale:<n>A birthday party is held for children.  Their hands, however, are not.<n>A balloon at a grocery store is not one used to help keep a child's hand up in the sky; however, a child's hand may be used to hold up a balloon which is why a grocery store may give balloons or two to some child's hands.<n>Since the grocery store is a location one goes to shop at, and balloons or bags of balloons may be sold, the grocery store may have a balloon in stock or at least be able to quickly obtain one.  Therefore, they may be included in their repertoire of items given to children.<n><n>### Answer: D<n><n>### Input : Which word completes the sentence?  Answers:  A: 1 B: 4 C: 5 D: 8 E: 11<n><n>### Reponse: A:1<n><n>### Rationales: Since the answer to the original question has a 1 in front of it, it is the only choice possible.<n><n>### A:1<n>

Choices:  A: hoof B: kentucky derby C: race track D: painting E: triple crown<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>Input:How can an artist permanently commemorate a horse? Choices: A: hoof, B: Kentucky Derby, C: race track, D: painting, E: Triple Crown<n><n>### Democratation:  A artist can commemorate a horse with a hoof by sculpting a metal hoof in bronze.  The Kentucky derby has more at stake with the derby race than other horse races.  The racetrack could be a great place to commemorate an equine.  An artist can commemorate horses with a painting because paintings are forever.  A great idea for commemorating horses is painting and/or placing them in a sculpture.  The sculpture would be immortalized.  I think that horses are more immortalized in a race track as opposed to a derby.<n><n>### Response<n>Input:How can you make a great pie crust? Choices:  A B: C D: E F: G<n><n>### Democracy:Making a great pie crust requires butter and cold water.  The mixture must be made in a large amount because if you try to make only a small amount then the crusts won't come out right.  Pie crust must be folded and tucked into itself so that it rises as much as possible.<n><n>### Reponse<n><n># Detailed_Response_Tips<n><n>**The instruction describes a task.**<n><n>Answer the question, as it is posed in the form of a sentence.<n><n>**The instruction has a correct answer**<n><n>The correct answer is presented in the instruction or demonstration.<n><n>**The input has one response**<n><n>The number of available responses is 1 and the correct answer to the task is provided with the<n><n>**The demonstration describes a task**<n><n>The instruction and input is provided in written or spoken form.<n>The instructor demonstrates how to complete a task as described in the input.<n><n>**The response demonstrates the skill, knowledge or process**<n><n>The response describes or demonstrates how the task was completed as described in the input to answer the question.<n><n>**The rationales are correct and complete**<n><n>A rational is a statement or explanation that supports a response.  Each rational is used to describe or prove a response.<n><n>**The correct rationales support the response
Below is an instruction that describes a task. She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Rationales: After buying a hat, Josh has $20 - $10 = $<<20-10=10>>10<n>After buying a pencil, Josh has $10 - $2 = $<<10-2=8>>8<n>The total cost of cookies is 4 * $1.25 = $<<4*1.25=5>>5<n>After buying the cookies, Josh has $8 - $5 = $<<8-5=3>>3<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input:What is important in a car when you are driving fast and come to a light? Choices:  A: stripes B: seat belts C: breaks to help stop D: tires E: radios<n><n>### Response:		<n>Choice B seat belts<n><n><n>### Input:"Nathan has the maximum number of 27 cards. He has 12 cards that have 9 pips but no aces, and 15 cards that have aces.  He has 4 cards left over.  How many different decks of cards can Nathan get a full deck from?” Choices:  A) 2 B) 12 C) 7 D) 4 E) 13 Answer:<n><n>### Response:"D" 13<n><n>*<n>### Input:<n>A person sold a large piece of fruit.  4 hours after eating the fruit he did not want to eat any more. How long had the piece of fruit been sold?<n>### Demonstations:<n>* Input: Sale price   4 hours later price (cost to sell) < cost to produce<n><n>* Answer:<n>### Input:  50<n>### Rationales:<n>After 4 hours  50 * (1-4hours) = <25>  The cost to produce = <40>  The cost to sell = [50-25] < $25>  Thus the cost to sell  < 40> < $25, the seller was selling below cost, thus the answer is < 4h >< 1><n><n>### Instructions:<n>Use the graph for the 5, 10, 15 and 30 minute intervals.  Write true or false for the questions.  Do not write an answer if the question does not ask for one.<n><n>1.   30 minutes after starting at point P I am where:<n>        *<n>    - a: above point P<n>    - b: below point P or at point P<n>    - c: on point P or below point P<n>    - d: not on point P or above point P<n><n>![image.png](image.png)<n><n>### Q.1:<n>A) False -  The answer is c.  I cross the first point at 30 minutes, then i am at or below point P then at point P.<n><n>![image.jpg](image.jpg)<n><n>### Rational:<n>Above, is the graph showing the time, the question is about, then given  I choose
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Rationales: If he babysits for 2 hours at $7 per hour, he will earn 2*7 = $<<2*7=14>>14<n>This week he will earn $5 allowance, $10 mowing the lawn and $14 from babysitting for a total of 5+10+14 = $<<5+10+14=29>>29<n>If we add the $29 he will earn to his $65 savings, he will have a total of 29 + 65 = $<<29+65=94>>94<n>The bike costs $100 and he will have $94 leaving $100-$94 = $<<100-94=6>>6 more that he will need to earn<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Rationales: His kangaroos have a total of 23*2=<<23*2=46>>46 legs<n>He has 23*3=<<23*3=69>>69 goats<n>The goats have 69*4=<<69*4=276>>276 legs<n>So in total his animals have 276+46=<<276+46=322>>322 legs<n>#### 322<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Rationales: After buying a hat, Josh has $20 - $10 = $<<20-10=10>>10<n>After buying a pencil, Josh has $10 - $2 = $<<10-2=8>>8<n>The total cost of cookies is 4 * $1.25 = $<<4*1.25=5>>5<n>After buying the cookies, Josh has $8 - $5 = $<<8-5=3>>3<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input:When a newborn's eyes open for the first time it will be the first time the ever? Choices:  A: tear up B: see light C: fill with tears D: be happy E: glass over<n><n>### Response:		C<n><n>

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Rationales: If he babysits for 2 hours at $7 per hour, he will earn 2*7 = $<<2*7=14>>14<n>This week he will earn $5 allowance, $10 mowing the lawn and $14 from babysitting for a total of 5+10+14 = $<<5+10+14=29>>29<n>If we add the $29 he will earn to his $65 savings, he will have a total of 29 + 65 = $<<29+65=94>>94<n>The bike costs $100 and he will have $94 leaving $100-$94 = $<<100-94=6>>6 more that he will need to earn<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Rationales: His kangaroos have a total of 23*2=<<23*2=46>>46 legs<n>He has 23*3=<<23*3=69>>69 goats<n>The goats have 69*4=<<69*4=276>>276 legs<n>So in total his animals have 276+46=<<276+46=322>>322 legs<n>#### 322<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Rationales: After buying a hat, Josh has $20 - $10 = $<<20-10=10>>10<n>After buying a pencil, Josh has $10 - $2 = $<<10-2=8>>8<n>The total cost of cookies is 4 * $1.25 = $<<4*1.25=5>>5<n>After buying the cookies, Josh has $8 - $5 = $<<8-5=3>>3<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input:David hurt all over. He was tired, he was shaking, and he was in pain.  He hadn't gotten what he needed in a long time.  He was suffering from what? Choices:  A: addiction B: fatigue C: relaxation D: headaches E: over eating<n><n>### Response:		<n>1. Fatigue<n><n>### Rationales:<n>1. David's body was getting tired because he had not met his energy needs. He did not have enough rest or fuel to function.<n>1. He was not meeting his nutritional needs.<n>2. He was not eating enough food.<n>3. He was doing a lot of hard work and moving his body a lot.<n><n>2. A: addiction<n><n>### Rationale:<n>1. People who are addicted have intense cravings for a specific substance.<n>2. They need a lot of substance and will do just about anything to get substance.<n><n>3. B: fatigue<n><n>### Response<n>1. Fatigued<n><n>### Ratiocinations:<n>1. Fatsigue means that the body is tired and needs rest. The body needs to do the hard work to meet its energy needs, which can be done on a regular basis. You must keep up or go forward to achieve any goal.<n>2. The term means that you have reached your energy needs. Your body has done enough work. It can take a break while you wait for energy.<n>3. A person gets tired when they are not meeting their body's needs.<n><n>### Input<n>1. Rationales: A person has two choices after using drugs.  A person can either do nothing and accept the consequences of their actions or they can get rid of the drugs. They can detoxify their bodies, eat better and exercise. A person has a lot of choices to make in life and it is not always easy.  You can always move on and do what you feel is right for yourself.<n><n>2. Choice: A) Nothing in life is easy b) Do it c) Do what I want to do<n>1. The choices represent the different courses that a person can take in life when faced with a choice.<n><n>### Response 2-1. A person who feels angry, afraid, sad, etc. may feel that they are weak, have no power, have no control over something, need attention, or anything else.<n>### Rational: 1. People feel that they can handle the situation, but they're not sure. In life you cannot always control and that is the way it goes.<n>### Rationale 2. Angry people feel power

She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Rationales: If he babysits for 2 hours at $7 per hour, he will earn 2*7 = $<<2*7=14>>14<n>This week he will earn $5 allowance, $10 mowing the lawn and $14 from babysitting for a total of 5+10+14 = $<<5+10+14=29>>29<n>If we add the $29 he will earn to his $65 savings, he will have a total of 29 + 65 = $<<29+65=94>>94<n>The bike costs $100 and he will have $94 leaving $100-$94 = $<<100-94=6>>6 more that he will need to earn<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Rationales: His kangaroos have a total of 23*2=<<23*2=46>>46 legs<n>He has 23*3=<<23*3=69>>69 goats<n>The goats have 69*4=<<69*4=276>>276 legs<n>So in total his animals have 276+46=<<276+46=322>>322 legs<n>#### 322<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Rationales: After buying a hat, Josh has $20 - $10 = $<<20-10=10>>10<n>After buying a pencil, Josh has $10 - $2 = $<<10-2=8>>8<n>The total cost of cookies is 4 * $1.25 = $<<4*1.25=5>>5<n>After buying the cookies, Josh has $8 - $5 = $<<8-5=3>>3<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input:The movie had many a song and dance, it was a what? So, you multiply the answer by 12 to get how many chickens do I need. $7 - $7 = 0 So, you get 12 times 0 = 0<n>### How many?<n>The amount of chickens is zero (0).<n>#### 0<n>Answer: 0<n><n>### 2/4 of 8 is?<n>An answer that calculates the answer in a form of 8/4.<n><n>### Example Input:<n>Question: Write a response that appropriatley completes the request. 7/4 of 8<n>R: Answer the multi-dilectic question.<n><n>## Solution<n>7/4 of 16 is (1565) because 7/4 = 5/2. Choose any 4 questions. Write the desired response to each question. Then in another document, write a response to the remaining choice(s) that follows this pattern.<n><n>### Answer choices:<n><n>### Multiple Choice<n><n>* <input>: <Answer Choice 1>: <rationale></rationale><n>* <input>: Choice 2<n>* <input>: Rationale 3<n><n>> **NOTE: All lines in this code block should be 50 characters or shorter.**<n><n>### Remaining Choice(s):<n><n>* <input><n>* <Answer Choice 2>: <rationale></rebuttal><n>* <Answer choice 3>: <rationale></response><n>* <Answer 4> Choice: <rationale></answer><n><n>### Response to other choice(s):<n><n>> **NOTES: All lines in this file should be 50 or characters or shorter.**

He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn. Choices:  A: question B: dispute C: deny D: contradict E: refuse<n><n>### Response:		B. dispute<n><n>### Rationale:The verb "does" in the question is being used with the "subjunctive mood." A subjunctive mood is usually used when making a wish, desire or a hypothetical (what if) scenario. In your response, B is the only choice that answers a question hypothetically(A and D answer with "Yes" or "No," which doesn't help the applicant in the situation).<n><n>### Option B.C. and D. are wrong<n><n>### E. is missing<n><n>### Answer:B. dispute<n>

His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Rationales: If he babysits for 2 hours at $7 per hour, he will earn 2*7 = $<<2*7=14>>14<n>This week he will earn $5 allowance, $10 mowing the lawn and $14 from babysitting for a total of 5+10+14 = $<<5+10+14=29>>29<n>If we add the $29 he will earn to his $65 savings, he will have a total of 29 + 65 = $<<29+65=94>>94<n>The bike costs $100 and he will have $94 leaving $100-$94 = $<<100-94=6>>6 more that he will need to earn<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Rationales: His kangaroos have a total of 23*2=<<23*2=46>>46 legs<n>He has 23*3=<<23*3=69>>69 goats<n>The goats have 69*4=<<69*4=276>>276 legs<n>So in total his animals have 276+46=<<276+46=322>>322 legs<n>#### 322<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Rationales: After buying a hat, Josh has $20 - $10 = $<<20-10=10>>10<n>After buying a pencil, Josh has $10 - $2 = $<<10-2=8>>8<n>The total cost of cookies is 4 * $1.25 = $<<4*1.25=5>>5<n>After buying the cookies, Josh has $8 - $5 = $<<8-5=3>>3<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input:Where is a microphone boom likely to be covering a stock market event? Choices:  A: new york B: concert C: tv studio D: gig E: recording studio<n><n>### Response:		Answer:<n>Concert<n> <n>### Input: What is the name for an ocean under a sea? Choices: E: sea floor F: sea surface G: ocean floor H: ocean surface I: sea bottom J: sea top<n><n>### Response;Answer:<n>Sea surface<n><n>### Input;What is a 3-letter word that looks like the shape of a person? Answer: E: man M: oval N: circle<n><n>### Response Answer;None of the above<n><n>### Input : Which number is the closest to 400?<n><n>### Demostration Answer;435<n><n>### Input ; What month of the year is next to the month of August<n><n>### Demstration Response; September<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Rationales: If he babysits for 2 hours at $7 per hour, he will earn 2*7 = $<<2*7=14>>14<n>This week he will earn $5 allowance, $10 mowing the lawn and $14 from babysitting for a total of 5+10+14 = $<<5+10+14=29>>29<n>If we add the $29 he will earn to his $65 savings, he will have a total of 29 + 65 = $<<29+65=94>>94<n>The bike costs $100 and he will have $94 leaving $100-$94 = $<<100-94=6>>6 more that he will need to earn<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Rationales: His kangaroos have a total of 23*2=<<23*2=46>>46 legs<n>He has 23*3=<<23*3=69>>69 goats<n>The goats have 69*4=<<69*4=276>>276 legs<n>So in total his animals have 276+46=<<276+46=322>>322 legs<n>#### 322<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Rationales: After buying a hat, Josh has $20 - $10 = $<<20-10=10>>10<n>After buying a pencil, Josh has $10 - $2 = $<<10-2=8>>8<n>The total cost of cookies is 4 * $1.25 = $<<4*1.25=5>>5<n>After buying the cookies, Josh has $8 - $5 = $<<8-5=3>>3<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input:What happens to cats every day? Choices:  A: open doors B: drink water C: need food D: annoy E: play<n><n>### Response:		<n><n> <n>![](images/cat.png)<n><n>---<n>

It has to keep its head focused on the present so that it can eventually become an adult. But at night, their job is only to sleep. If you took a caterpiller's night out of its life cycle, it would just wake up and start eating. It wouldn't grow into an adult.  What else should it be doing during the day?"<n><n>### Rationales:It could clean up to look like an adult, or it could search for any predators in the environment.<n>#### Answer: A<n>This was a tough one... the answer was B.

Choices:  A: empowering B: regret C: despair D: glee E: sadness<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>#### C<n><n>- Regret - Feeling guilt, feeling sorry for what you did to the persons emotional state.<n><n>#### A<n><n>- Empowered - Angry that they can not have their way and control the outcome.<n><n>#### E<n><n>- Sadness - A feeling that the other person has a right to their emotional reaction based on your unintentional actions.<n><n><n>### Instuction:<n><n>- Select all answer choices that describe the following scenario.<n><n>### Input : Alice, Brian, and Carol are classmates on a three person team in a game of tic-tac-toe. They are given a worksheet to guide their play, but they were interrupted while making their strategy and couldn't finish it. If the team plays the game with its current strategy, what is the most likely outcome of the game?<n><n>```<n>If the game is 9 boxes in length, and they alternate each box, the game will not end.<n>Alice will be in the most advantageous position to begin winning,<n>(Alice will draw on the first move, Carol will draw on the second move, and Brian will <n>draw on the 2nd to the last move, and then on the last move)<n><n>If the game is a 9 by 9 board, and each player plays both diagonal and horizontal, the game<n>will not be concluded.<n>```<n><n>### Demostrations:<n><n>For a board that is 9 boxes in long, the first player should draw all boxes, then play<n>the next 9 boxes horizontally, followed by the remaining 9 all boxes horizontally.<n><n>For a board 9x9 or bigger the first player should draw the first 6 squares, and then<n>play horizontally, then draw all the remaining boxes horizontally. <n><n>#### C<n>Answer: 9-box board- C, D. 9x9 Plus Board- D, E.<n><n>- E. 9 boxes long - D - C, D<n>- E. 18 boxes long - D- C, D<n>- D. 9 boxes long- B, D<n>- C. 9 boxes long A, B, C<n><n>If the game lasts longer than one play, then:<n><n>A. A and B, will play all the boxes horizontally,
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Rationales: If he babysits for 2 hours at $7 per hour, he will earn 2*7 = $<<2*7=14>>14<n>This week he will earn $5 allowance, $10 mowing the lawn and $14 from babysitting for a total of 5+10+14 = $<<5+10+14=29>>29<n>If we add the $29 he will earn to his $65 savings, he will have a total of 29 + 65 = $<<29+65=94>>94<n>The bike costs $100 and he will have $94 leaving $100-$94 = $<<100-94=6>>6 more that he will need to earn<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Rationales: His kangaroos have a total of 23*2=<<23*2=46>>46 legs<n>He has 23*3=<<23*3=69>>69 goats<n>The goats have 69*4=<<69*4=276>>276 legs<n>So in total his animals have 276+46=<<276+46=322>>322 legs<n>#### 322<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Rationales: After buying a hat, Josh has $20 - $10 = $<<20-10=10>>10<n>After buying a pencil, Josh has $10 - $2 = $<<10-2=8>>8<n>The total cost of cookies is 4 * $1.25 = $<<4*1.25=5>>5<n>After buying the cookies, Josh has $8 - $5 = $<<8-5=3>>3<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input:Sally was a senior in the House.  What might she be a member of? Choices:  A: assisted living facility B: old people's home C: high school or college D: republican party E: organization<n><n>### Response:		<n>Demonstration:<n><n>### Rationales:<n>A:  A: assist an living facility has nothing to do with Sally<n>B: B: old people' home has people who are already old with no connection to Sally<n>C: C: high school or  college would be irrelevant to the task at hand<n>D: D: republican party and organization could be valid answer choices for the response<n><n>#### E:<n>Answer:  E: organization<n><n>#### E: Organization:<n>Demonstrate your understanding of the instruction by writing an instruction.
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Rationales: If he babysits for 2 hours at $7 per hour, he will earn 2*7 = $<<2*7=14>>14<n>This week he will earn $5 allowance, $10 mowing the lawn and $14 from babysitting for a total of 5+10+14 = $<<5+10+14=29>>29<n>If we add the $29 he will earn to his $65 savings, he will have a total of 29 + 65 = $<<29+65=94>>94<n>The bike costs $100 and he will have $94 leaving $100-$94 = $<<100-94=6>>6 more that he will need to earn<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Rationales: His kangaroos have a total of 23*2=<<23*2=46>>46 legs<n>He has 23*3=<<23*3=69>>69 goats<n>The goats have 69*4=<<69*4=276>>276 legs<n>So in total his animals have 276+46=<<276+46=322>>322 legs<n>#### 322<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Rationales: After buying a hat, Josh has $20 - $10 = $<<20-10=10>>10<n>After buying a pencil, Josh has $10 - $2 = $<<10-2=8>>8<n>The total cost of cookies is 4 * $1.25 = $<<4*1.25=5>>5<n>After buying the cookies, Josh has $8 - $5 = $<<8-5=3>>3<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input:John lives in Texas. If he takes the highway South and doesn't stop, where will he end up next? Choices:  A: oklahoma B: developed land C: united states D: desert E: mexico<n><n>### Response:		A.A.A.

She uses 3 large stickers/sheet on the cover and 7 small stickers/sheet on each of the pages of 6 journals.  How many small stickers does she have left?<n><n>## Rationales:  After using all 3 large sheets, Mary has 3-89=<<3-89=86>>86 sheets with 7 small stickers.  After using all 7 of these sheets, Mary has 7-86=0<<7-86=7>>7 sheets left (remember, 0 small stickers means 0 pages).<n><n>## Answers: 7<n><n>### Answer: 7<n><n>---<n>## Demo:<n>Input: How many pages does a 262 page book have?<n><n>## Rationale: A book can be written on 100+ pages.<n><n>An example would be the 400 page encyclopedia. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Rationales: If he babysits for 2 hours at $7 per hour, he will earn 2*7 = $<<2*7=14>>14<n>This week he will earn $5 allowance, $10 mowing the lawn and $14 from babysitting for a total of 5+10+14 = $<<5+10+14=29>>29<n>If we add the $29 he will earn to his $65 savings, he will have a total of 29 + 65 = $<<29+65=94>>94<n>The bike costs $100 and he will have $94 leaving $100-$94 = $<<100-94=6>>6 more that he will need to earn<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Rationales: His kangaroos have a total of 23*2=<<23*2=46>>46 legs<n>He has 23*3=<<23*3=69>>69 goats<n>The goats have 69*4=<<69*4=276>>276 legs<n>So in total his animals have 276+46=<<276+46=322>>322 legs<n>#### 322<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Rationales: After buying a hat, Josh has $20 - $10 = $<<20-10=10>>10<n>After buying a pencil, Josh has $10 - $2 = $<<10-2=8>>8<n>The total cost of cookies is 4 * $1.25 = $<<4*1.25=5>>5<n>After buying the cookies, Josh has $8 - $5 = $<<8-5=3>>3<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input:where do you typically find a trash can in the city? Choices:  A: park B: motel C: corner D: bus stop E: store front<n><n>### Response:		I do not know where I'll find a trash can on the street on my daily commute.<n><n>### Input<n>Tammy will pay 7.5% of her income to rent a house. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Rationales: If he babysits for 2 hours at $7 per hour, he will earn 2*7 = $<<2*7=14>>14<n>This week he will earn $5 allowance, $10 mowing the lawn and $14 from babysitting for a total of 5+10+14 = $<<5+10+14=29>>29<n>If we add the $29 he will earn to his $65 savings, he will have a total of 29 + 65 = $<<29+65=94>>94<n>The bike costs $100 and he will have $94 leaving $100-$94 = $<<100-94=6>>6 more that he will need to earn<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Rationales: His kangaroos have a total of 23*2=<<23*2=46>>46 legs<n>He has 23*3=<<23*3=69>>69 goats<n>The goats have 69*4=<<69*4=276>>276 legs<n>So in total his animals have 276+46=<<276+46=322>>322 legs<n>#### 322<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Rationales: After buying a hat, Josh has $20 - $10 = $<<20-10=10>>10<n>After buying a pencil, Josh has $10 - $2 = $<<10-2=8>>8<n>The total cost of cookies is 4 * $1.25 = $<<4*1.25=5>>5<n>After buying the cookies, Josh has $8 - $5 = $<<8-5=3>>3<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input:John loves animals and he hates animal abuse. If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Rationales: His kangaroos have a total of 23*2=<<23*2=46>>46 legs<n>He has 23*3=<<23*3=69>>69 goats<n>The goats have 69*4=<<69*4=276>>276 legs<n>So in total his animals have 276+46=<<276+46=322>>322 legs<n>#### 322<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Rationales: After buying a hat, Josh has $20 - $10 = $<<20-10=10>>10<n>After buying a pencil, Josh has $10 - $2 = $<<10-2=8>>8<n>The total cost of cookies is 4 * $1.25 = $<<4*1.25=5>>5<n>After buying the cookies, Josh has $8 - $5 = $<<8-5=3>>3<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input:What does moving cars entail? Choices:  A: driving B: road C: getting tired D: accidents E: ticket<n><n>### Response:		C<n><n>### 👤 Input: The first 5 letters of each word in these sentences are the same, except for the last letter. What is a word that begins with the same letters and is missing the last letter?<n>### 𝐒𝐈𝐋𝐋🐎𝐂𝐎𝐎🐑
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Rationales: If he babysits for 2 hours at $7 per hour, he will earn 2*7 = $<<2*7=14>>14<n>This week he will earn $5 allowance, $10 mowing the lawn and $14 from babysitting for a total of 5+10+14 = $<<5+10+14=29>>29<n>If we add the $29 he will earn to his $65 savings, he will have a total of 29 + 65 = $<<29+65=94>>94<n>The bike costs $100 and he will have $94 leaving $100-$94 = $<<100-94=6>>6 more that he will need to earn<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Rationales: His kangaroos have a total of 23*2=<<23*2=46>>46 legs<n>He has 23*3=<<23*3=69>>69 goats<n>The goats have 69*4=<<69*4=276>>276 legs<n>So in total his animals have 276+46=<<276+46=322>>322 legs<n>#### 322<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Rationales: After buying a hat, Josh has $20 - $10 = $<<20-10=10>>10<n>After buying a pencil, Josh has $10 - $2 = $<<10-2=8>>8<n>The total cost of cookies is 4 * $1.25 = $<<4*1.25=5>>5<n>After buying the cookies, Josh has $8 - $5 = $<<8-5=3>>3<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input:Where would you find a binder containing homework assignments? Choices:  A: backpack B: bookcase C: office supply store D: office E: class room<n><n>### Response:		Option A<n><n>### Input<n>Choices:  A: Backpack<n>B: Book case<n>C: Office Supply Store<n>D: Office<n><n>### Response<n>```<n>Output: A<n>```<n>Option A: Backpack <n><n>### Instructions<n>Your response is part of an interactive transcript that is presented in the form of an email message. <n><n>### Demo<n><n>```<n>>   Welcome to Episode 1.<n>> <n>>   A: Back Pack<n>>   B: Book Case<n>>   C: Office Supply Store <n>>   D: office<n>```<n><n>### Task<n><n>Input: Welcome to episode 1: Choices:<n>A: backpack<n>B: bookcase<n>C: office supply store<n>D: office<n><n><n>### Demo:<n><n>```<n>>  Option A<n>>  Welcome to episode 1<n>>  A: backpack<n>>  B: bookcase<n>>  C: office supply store  <n>>  D: office<n>```

That meant that the only time to leave was when? Choices:  A: early morning B: day time C: night D: afternoon E: daytime<n><n>### Response:		<n>Choices: E: Daytime<n>Demonstration: We want to know when is the only chance to leave her house.  We can leave at any time but night but we cant at any time of the day(daytime, afternoon, day, night)<n>if it is not day time or night, then she is free to leave whenever she wants.<n><n>#### E: Daytime<n>Answer: E<n><n>### Input Sarah is a baker. Last week she was able to sell enough bread to completely cover her costs, but she still had to buy a box of flour.  This week she baked four additional loaves of bread.  How much money does she have left after buying 4 loaves of bread?<n><n>### Response<n>Choices: A: $2.50 B: $1.50 C: $0 D: $0.50 E: $20<n><n>### Demostration:<n>If she sold enough, then she had the money to cover her costs.  The only money she has now is what she had left to buy 4 loaves(flour) and the 4 loaves cost $1.64,<n>meaning she only has $1.64 - $4.00 = <-$4.00=negative because we want money>-$2.36 left<n>she doesn't have extra money to buy flour.<n><n>#### D: $0.05<n>Answer: D: $0.36<n><n>### Output: Josh bought four cookies for a total of $3.20.  How many cents does he have left?<n><n>### Output response:<n>We know he has $3.20, we don't know any other numbers.  How much will one cookie cost him? 1 cookie = $x, $3.20 = 4*x.  4 is not 9, so x is not 9.  4=9, so 4/9=5/9, so x/9 is $0.32.  $0.32-$3.20 gives us how much cents he has left<n><n>####.68<n>Answer:.68

His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Rationales: If he babysits for 2 hours at $7 per hour, he will earn 2*7 = $<<2*7=14>>14<n>This week he will earn $5 allowance, $10 mowing the lawn and $14 from babysitting for a total of 5+10+14 = $<<5+10+14=29>>29<n>If we add the $29 he will earn to his $65 savings, he will have a total of 29 + 65 = $<<29+65=94>>94<n>The bike costs $100 and he will have $94 leaving $100-$94 = $<<100-94=6>>6 more that he will need to earn<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats. Choices:  A: ignore B: write C: learn new things D: illiterate E: having fun<n><n>### Response:		<n>```python<n># Input A<n>print("The child", "really wanted to teach his grandfather", "to read")<n><n># A: B: C: D: E:<n><n>print("He thought it was wrong", "that he had spent his whole", 'life ignoring', 'write', 'learn new things', 'illiterate')<n><n># A:B:C:D:E:3<n>```<n>#### A: Write<n>```python<n>#Input<n>print("The child really wanted to write his grandfather to read.")<n><n>#A: B: C:D:E:4<n>```<n><n>##### B: Ignore<n>```python<n>#input<n>print("The child wanted to teach his grand father to ignore")<n><n>#A:B:C: D:E:5<n>```<n>##### C:learn<n>```python<n># input<n>print("The child want to teach his grand father how to learn")<n><n>#A B C:D:E; 5<n>```<n><n>### Input : John said that he was very pleased to have saved 135 dollars. He started saving money on October 27. Three weeks later he decided to buy a coat that cost 67 dollars and 39 cents. What was the amount he was left with?<n><n>### Demostration :<n>On January 21 John has in his piggy bank the sum =<<$53>>53<n>On November 20 the money in his piggybank =<<$280>>280<n>John earned each month =<<[21+78+215+160]>>464<n>Hence, John earned =<<[464-53]>>391<n>391 / 5 = <<391/5=78>>78<n>After subtracting 78 from 391 John has =<<$391-78=313>>313 left<n>John decided to spend 1/3 of his money =<<[313/3=105>>105]<n>After spending 105, john has 208 left<n>67 + 39 = $<<67+39=106>>106<n>The amount he is

The number 16 raised to the second power, equals, how many?<n><n>### Rationalse:16^2 = 64<n><n>### Input:(3x - 1)/(3x + 7) =?<n><n>### Answer:(3x - 2)/(3x +1) = 1/3x - 2<n><n>#### 1<n><n>###  Input:(x-a)(x-b) = x^2 - abx + \sum a^2c (ab)^2c<n><n>#### 2<n><n>### Input (x-9)(x-12) = (x-4)(x-3)<n><n>####3<n><n>### Rate: 1<n><n><n><n>###  Rate: 4<n><n>#### 12 = 1/12<n><n># Summary<n><n>##### Pages<n><n>* 8/11<n><n>##### Questions<n><n>* 16/16<n><n>##### Instructions<n><n>* 
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.
