His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Rationales: If he babysits for 2 hours at $7 per hour, he will earn 2*7 = $<<2*7=14>>14<n>This week he will earn $5 allowance, $10 mowing the lawn and $14 from babysitting for a total of 5+10+14 = $<<5+10+14=29>>29<n>If we add the $29 he will earn to his $65 savings, he will have a total of 29 + 65 = $<<29+65=94>>94<n>The bike costs $100 and he will have $94 leaving $100-$94 = $<<100-94=6>>6 more that he will need to earn<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Rationales: His kangaroos have a total of 23*2=<<23*2=46>>46 legs<n>He has 23*3=<<23*3=69>>69 goats<n>The goats have 69*4=<<69*4=276>>276 legs<n>So in total his animals have 276+46=<<276+46=322>>322 legs<n>#### 322<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Rationales: After buying a hat, Josh has $20 - $10 = $<<20-10=10>>10<n>After buying a pencil, Josh has $10 - $2 = $<<10-2=8>>8<n>The total cost of cookies is 4 * $1.25 = $<<4*1.25=5>>5<n>After buying the cookies, Josh has $8 - $5 = $<<8-5=3>>3<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input:What preposition do you use if you want to combine two words? Choices:  A: article B: adjective C: interjection D: conjunction E: pronoun<n><n>### Response:		D<n>1. The prepositions article, adjective, interjection, conjunction, and pronoun were provided in this question.<n>2. Based on the context and definition of "preposition," articles, adjectives, interjections, and conjunctions can be used to link words or phrases in a sentence.<n>3. Pronouns are not used to combine two or more words.  The words "article" and "pronoun" were not provided in this question. <n>#### D<n>Answer: D<n><n>### Input<n>I use my bike to get to school. In the morning I ride it two miles and in the afternoon I ride it four miles. If I ride my bike twice as often in the night as in the morning, how many miles do I ride on an average day?<n>Rationales<n>I ride my bike two miles in the morning and again ride it four miles in the afternoon.<n>I ride it 6 miles in the both the morning and afternoon.<n>So I ride it 6 miles four times a day (twice in the morning, twice in the afternoon).<n><n>So<n>(6)/4 = Average = 1.5 miles<n><n>#### 1.5<n>Answer: 1.5<n><n>### Input :  I got 26 for my test. I passed every subject. I was the only one who was 100% right. If there were 22 kids in my class, how many got all right?<n>Rationales :<n>The question is talking about the entire class.<n>So, it was talking about how many students passed the class.<n>When you ask how many students passed the entire class, you should ask how many students got all correct.<n>However, the word "every" in the question could be confusing since it was referring to "subject" and was asking the total number of questions.<n><n>So, if the 22 kids answered 26 questions,<n>then 26 divided by 22 is equal to 1.21<n><n>However, since "100%" is referring to the total number of questions that were correct, 100% divided by 22 = 4.55<n><n>So, there is an error in the answer, but the answer is not 1.21.<n><n>#### 4.55 (the error should
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Rationales: If he babysits for 2 hours at $7 per hour, he will earn 2*7 = $<<2*7=14>>14<n>This week he will earn $5 allowance, $10 mowing the lawn and $14 from babysitting for a total of 5+10+14 = $<<5+10+14=29>>29<n>If we add the $29 he will earn to his $65 savings, he will have a total of 29 + 65 = $<<29+65=94>>94<n>The bike costs $100 and he will have $94 leaving $100-$94 = $<<100-94=6>>6 more that he will need to earn<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Rationales: His kangaroos have a total of 23*2=<<23*2=46>>46 legs<n>He has 23*3=<<23*3=69>>69 goats<n>The goats have 69*4=<<69*4=276>>276 legs<n>So in total his animals have 276+46=<<276+46=322>>322 legs<n>#### 322<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Rationales: After buying a hat, Josh has $20 - $10 = $<<20-10=10>>10<n>After buying a pencil, Josh has $10 - $2 = $<<10-2=8>>8<n>The total cost of cookies is 4 * $1.25 = $<<4*1.25=5>>5<n>After buying the cookies, Josh has $8 - $5 = $<<8-5=3>>3<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input:Where in your home would you store birth control pills near your toothpaste? He buys a juice that costs $1.01 every day but spends $1.02 on Tuesday.  Then, his mom give him an additional dollar every day to cover his Tuesday expense and he makes it up by returning to his $1.01 daily expense. How much did Josh’s Tuesday expense cost?<n><n>### Response<n><n>His Tuesday expense costs $1.02 – $1.01 = <<$1.02-1.01=0.01>>$0.01<n><n>### Instructions: Answer the following question in complete sentences.<n><n>### Dana has 5 apples and 3 oranges. How many total fruits can Dana make if she made 4 apples into apple pies and 2 oranges into orange pies?<n><n>### Demostration:<n>If Dana made 4 apples to apple pies and 6 total number of fruits<n><n>### Answer:<n>4 + 2 = 6<n><n>### Answers<n><n>### Instructor:  If there are 52 cards total in a deck of cards, and you remove a king and a queen, how many cards are left?<n><n>### Instinct:  If there are $52$ total cards in a deck of cards and you remove a $K$ and a $Q$, there are $49$ cards remaining.<n><n>### Solution:<n>There are 49 cards left.<n><n>### Explain answer:<n>There are $52$ cards in a deck and in the process of picking a king and queen, $2$ cards are removed.<n><n>So there are $ <<52-2>>49 cards remaining<n><n>### What would happen if you removed a $K$ and an $A$ from a deck?<n><n>- **Answer:** There would be $48$ remaining cards.<n><n>### What happens if you remove a $K$, a $A$, and a $10$?<n><n>- **Answer** : There would be $44$ remaining cards.<n>

Choices:  A: dissipate B: flown C: disintegrate D: fall apart E: penultimate<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>If a person has used the last of their money in some activity, then what has happened to their money afterward is to *fall apart*. Choice C indicates that the money has disintegrated or fallen apart. This is not feasible, if the money has already disintegrated, then there is nothing left to refer to, the sentence is incomplete. If a person spends the last of their money, the sentence would read, 'His money has flown for the last time' which is incorrect. Choice B can be used because the money flows and goes out. Choice E can be used because a person has lost the last of their savings.<n><n>### Input<n><n>Margaret has 2 dogs at home.  Dog Alpha has 4 legs, 3 teeth, 2 tails, and has a personality type of B.  At breakfast, Dog Beta has 4 legs, no teeth, 1 tail and will always be sad.<n>What animal species does Dog Alpha belong to?<n><n>### Response<n><n>The answer is a Dog. A dog is a mammal and therefore, the answer should be 'dog'.<n><n>### Input <n><n>Choose 2 out of the following answer choices:<n><n>* There are two dogs in the room.<n>* Everyone likes dogs.<n>* Dogs are not expensive pets.<n>* There are two puppies in the box.<n>* I love dogs.<n>* You are the king of dogs.<n>* A dog is a good pet to have around you.<n>* There are four dogs in this room. (Not an option)<n>* There are three dogs in this room.<n><n>Degree of certainty:<n><n>* Dog 1: There is a very high probability that dog 1 is not there.<n>* Dog 2: There is a very low probability that dog 2 is here.<n><n>#### 4) Dog 2, Dog 1<n><n>#### 5) Dog 2, 3<n><n>#### 6) Dog 2,4<n><n>### Input A: Answer the following multiple choice question<n><n>### Response A:<n>D is the answer because it is the only choice that mentions both dogs in the sentence, if you are referring to the dogs then they are not in the house and therefore, there is no dog left in the house.<n>

How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Rationales: If he babysits for 2 hours at $7 per hour, he will earn 2*7 = $<<2*7=14>>14<n>This week he will earn $5 allowance, $10 mowing the lawn and $14 from babysitting for a total of 5+10+14 = $<<5+10+14=29>>29<n>If we add the $29 he will earn to his $65 savings, he will have a total of 29 + 65 = $<<29+65=94>>94<n>The bike costs $100 and he will have $94 leaving $100-$94 = $<<100-94=6>>6 more that he will need to earn<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Rationales: His kangaroos have a total of 23*2=<<23*2=46>>46 legs<n>He has 23*3=<<23*3=69>>69 goats<n>The goats have 69*4=<<69*4=276>>276 legs<n>So in total his animals have 276+46=<<276+46=322>>322 legs<n>#### 322<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Rationales: After buying a hat, Josh has $20 - $10 = $<<20-10=10>>10<n>After buying a pencil, Josh has $10 - $2 = $<<10-2=8>>8<n>The total cost of cookies is 4 * $1.25 = $<<4*1.25=5>>5<n>After buying the cookies, Josh has $8 - $5 = $<<8-5=3>>3<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input:Where can you find a place to eat and places to buy items of many different kinds? Choices:  A: city B: downtown C: own house D: bar E: shopping center<n><n>### Response:		<n>The places where you can find a place to eat are A and downtown, which is part of the city. <n><n>For places to buy things, you can go to B and D. <n><n>#### Place A:  City : A  A: city<n><n>#### Place B: Downtown :  B  B   :  Downtown<n><n>#### Place C: Your House:  C  C : Your House<n><n><n>### Input : What does a 8 digit number with nines in between each consecutive digit mean? Choices: 1:97653221 2:976510121 3:9765000011 4:9765998800<n><n>### Response<n>> A 8 digit number with nine's in between each consecutive digit means 9765300011 in decimal notation.<n><n>#### 9765<n>300001 11<n>Answer: 9765 300000 11<n><n>### Input<n>The distance of a car going from point A to point B is 16 hours. This distance is double the distance of point B to point C, which is 85 miles away. What is the distance from point A to point C?<n><n>### Response <n>> Since the distance going from point A to B is 16 (h) hours.  To go this far it takes a total of 1 hour/mile to cover the 16 (m) miles.<n>It is the same number as the number of hours you had to drive B-C, which is 16 - 8 = 8 <n><n>The distance A-C is 6 hour/miles.<n><n>#### 6<n>8 6 ====> 6 hour/m
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Rationales: If he babysits for 2 hours at $7 per hour, he will earn 2*7 = $<<2*7=14>>14<n>This week he will earn $5 allowance, $10 mowing the lawn and $14 from babysitting for a total of 5+10+14 = $<<5+10+14=29>>29<n>If we add the $29 he will earn to his $65 savings, he will have a total of 29 + 65 = $<<29+65=94>>94<n>The bike costs $100 and he will have $94 leaving $100-$94 = $<<100-94=6>>6 more that he will need to earn<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Rationales: His kangaroos have a total of 23*2=<<23*2=46>>46 legs<n>He has 23*3=<<23*3=69>>69 goats<n>The goats have 69*4=<<69*4=276>>276 legs<n>So in total his animals have 276+46=<<276+46=322>>322 legs<n>#### 322<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Rationales: After buying a hat, Josh has $20 - $10 = $<<20-10=10>>10<n>After buying a pencil, Josh has $10 - $2 = $<<10-2=8>>8<n>The total cost of cookies is 4 * $1.25 = $<<4*1.25=5>>5<n>After buying the cookies, Josh has $8 - $5 = $<<8-5=3>>3<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input:If I recieve a letter from a friend over seas, why might I read it? Choices:  A: pudding B: get news C: strain D: answer E: though<n><n>### Response:		The pudding will taste bad if it is not read before it gets moldy (stale).<n><n><n>- You can get news from the world, if you do not read a letter from a friend who went over seas, you will not get the news. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Rationales: If he babysits for 2 hours at $7 per hour, he will earn 2*7 = $<<2*7=14>>14<n>This week he will earn $5 allowance, $10 mowing the lawn and $14 from babysitting for a total of 5+10+14 = $<<5+10+14=29>>29<n>If we add the $29 he will earn to his $65 savings, he will have a total of 29 + 65 = $<<29+65=94>>94<n>The bike costs $100 and he will have $94 leaving $100-$94 = $<<100-94=6>>6 more that he will need to earn<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Rationales: His kangaroos have a total of 23*2=<<23*2=46>>46 legs<n>He has 23*3=<<23*3=69>>69 goats<n>The goats have 69*4=<<69*4=276>>276 legs<n>So in total his animals have 276+46=<<276+46=322>>322 legs<n>#### 322<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Rationales: After buying a hat, Josh has $20 - $10 = $<<20-10=10>>10<n>After buying a pencil, Josh has $10 - $2 = $<<10-2=8>>8<n>The total cost of cookies is 4 * $1.25 = $<<4*1.25=5>>5<n>After buying the cookies, Josh has $8 - $5 = $<<8-5=3>>3<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input:Where would you see a performer at a gathering of you friends? Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Rationales: If he babysits for 2 hours at $7 per hour, he will earn 2*7 = $<<2*7=14>>14<n>This week he will earn $5 allowance, $10 mowing the lawn and $14 from babysitting for a total of 5+10+14 = $<<5+10+14=29>>29<n>If we add the $29 he will earn to his $65 savings, he will have a total of 29 + 65 = $<<29+65=94>>94<n>The bike costs $100 and he will have $94 leaving $100-$94 = $<<100-94=6>>6 more that he will need to earn<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Rationales: His kangaroos have a total of 23*2=<<23*2=46>>46 legs<n>He has 23*3=<<23*3=69>>69 goats<n>The goats have 69*4=<<69*4=276>>276 legs<n>So in total his animals have 276+46=<<276+46=322>>322 legs<n>#### 322<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Rationales: After buying a hat, Josh has $20 - $10 = $<<20-10=10>>10<n>After buying a pencil, Josh has $10 - $2 = $<<10-2=8>>8<n>The total cost of cookies is 4 * $1.25 = $<<4*1.25=5>>5<n>After buying the cookies, Josh has $8 - $5 = $<<8-5=3>>3<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input:What could you buy in a bookstore? Choices:  A: carpeting B: magazines C: strip mall D: city E: applesauce<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>Option A: Carpeting<n>Option B: Magazines<n>Option C: Strip Mall<n>Option D: City<n>Option E: Applesauce<n><n>Option D: City  <n>$39 for applesauce and $45 for a newspaper   <n>$39+45=$<<39+45=84>>84<n><n>Option D: Cities   <n>$7 for applesauce (1-apple)   <n>$1 for newspaper (2-newspapers)   <n>$7+1=$<<7+1=8>>8<n>#### 8<n>Answer: 8<n><n>Option C: Stripmall   <n>$29 for newspapers (2-newspaper)   <n>$7 for pencils (1-pencil)   <n>$29+7=$<<29+7=36>>36<n>#### 36<n>Answer: 36<n><n>#### What does the remainder represent?<n>R: the number of things left over  <n>O: original number  <n>N: new number<n><n>R: $7 (7-3=4, because 3+3 = 6)  <n>O: $39 (39-84=45)   <n>N: $36 (36-84=48)   <n>#### $7<n>Answer: $7<n><n>R: $45 (45-36=9)   <n>O: $36 (1-36=35)   <n>N:$4 (1-4=3, 1+3)   <n>#### $4<n>Answer: $4<n><n>R: $8 (8-3=5, 1+3+1)   <n>O: None   <n>N: $5 (2-2=3, +2)   <n>#### $5<n>Answer: $5<n><n>### Demostration:<n>The correct answer to the following multiple choice question is A.<n><n>What could you buy in the mall? Choose A: Carpeting. B: Magazines. C: Strip Mall. D: City.<n>Input: B<n>Rationales: 39-36=4

He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Rationales: After buying a hat, Josh has $20 - $10 = $<<20-10=10>>10<n>After buying a pencil, Josh has $10 - $2 = $<<10-2=8>>8<n>The total cost of cookies is 4 * $1.25 = $<<4*1.25=5>>5<n>After buying the cookies, Josh has $8 - $5 = $<<8-5=3>>3<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input:Some stores trick women to buy products, the sales make it seem like if you buy more you what? Choices:  A: get money B: pay money C: go shopping D: lose money E: save money<n><n>### Response:		<n>Input:You can buy three shirts for $5 at some stores.<n>You can buy two shirts for $4 at same stores<n>How much does a shirt cost at these stores and why?<n>Answer: $5 and $4 because there's no negative one there but $1.<n><n>### Input-<n>Input:You can either put a dollar in the bank to make interest on it for you or you can put money in your wallet that you have to work to make. Which option will let you hold on to your money longer?<n>Answer: put money in your wallets because it will be a whole bunch.<n><n>### The first step to solving an equation is multiplying both sides by the variable. <n>In the equation x+9x+6x=9, we multiply both sides by x.<n>On the right-hand side, we have 9x, so we multiply both sides by 9 to get the x term:<n>(x+9x+6)(9x) = 9 (9x + 81x + 36x) <n>= (9x)(9x + 8x + 6x)<n>=(9x*10)(1 x 9 + 1 x 8 + 1 x 6) <n>= 90x2 + 80x2 + 60x2<n><n>Simplify the expression to get the final result.<n><n>Input:In the equation x+10x=7x, add 10 to both sides to solve it algebraically.<n>Another option to solve the equation is to use FOIL.<n>The process is to find a property of the equation and do the operation suggested from the FOIL method.<n>FOIL means the four operations of:<n>First: Find the first term of the first row<n>In the equation 5a+3b=1a, the first term of the the first row would be 5a with the first variable of the equation which is A.<n>Next: Find the First term of the second row<n>Next to the first row is second row which is 3b. The First term of the second is 3b.<n>The term you need to look at the middle column first, then the first column, and last the last column.<n>The same goes for all the following steps.<n>Input:The process of
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Rationales: If he babysits for 2 hours at $7 per hour, he will earn 2*7 = $<<2*7=14>>14<n>This week he will earn $5 allowance, $10 mowing the lawn and $14 from babysitting for a total of 5+10+14 = $<<5+10+14=29>>29<n>If we add the $29 he will earn to his $65 savings, he will have a total of 29 + 65 = $<<29+65=94>>94<n>The bike costs $100 and he will have $94 leaving $100-$94 = $<<100-94=6>>6 more that he will need to earn<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Rationales: His kangaroos have a total of 23*2=<<23*2=46>>46 legs<n>He has 23*3=<<23*3=69>>69 goats<n>The goats have 69*4=<<69*4=276>>276 legs<n>So in total his animals have 276+46=<<276+46=322>>322 legs<n>#### 322<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Rationales: After buying a hat, Josh has $20 - $10 = $<<20-10=10>>10<n>After buying a pencil, Josh has $10 - $2 = $<<10-2=8>>8<n>The total cost of cookies is 4 * $1.25 = $<<4*1.25=5>>5<n>After buying the cookies, Josh has $8 - $5 = $<<8-5=3>>3<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input:What does god want people to do for money? Choices:  A: work in life B: speak to people C: everywhere D: sitting ideal E: care for people<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>### Rationales:<n><n>### Choices:<n>

C: You will use the most expensive item first. D: You will not use the cheapest item to complete the task.<n><n>### Response<n>##### C<n>### Instruc:<n><n>The statement "______" is best described by  the term ______. Choose your best answer A: The term describes the best possible choice between two options B: the term could be as easily used to describe the best possible option. C: You will not use a cheap item first. D: The most affordable will be used first.<n><n>##### A<n><n>### Rational:<n>-You must choose the best of two options therefore your best choice will be called the best.<n><n>### Ratios: <n><n>##### A 66<n><n>### Rationals:<n><n>-You must choose between 2 options the choice you chose will be called the best option.<n>

She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100. His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Rationales: If he babysits for 2 hours at $7 per hour, he will earn 2*7 = $<<2*7=14>>14<n>This week he will earn $5 allowance, $10 mowing the lawn and $14 from babysitting for a total of 5+10+14 = $<<5+10+14=29>>29<n>If we add the $29 he will earn to his $65 savings, he will have a total of 29 + 65 = $<<29+65=94>>94<n>The bike costs $100 and he will have $94 leaving $100-$94 = $<<100-94=6>>6 more that he will need to earn<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Rationales: His kangaroos have a total of 23*2=<<23*2=46>>46 legs<n>He has 23*3=<<23*3=69>>69 goats<n>The goats have 69*4=<<69*4=276>>276 legs<n>So in total his animals have 276+46=<<276+46=322>>322 legs<n>#### 322<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Rationales: After buying a hat, Josh has $20 - $10 = $<<20-10=10>>10<n>After buying a pencil, Josh has $10 - $2 = $<<10-2=8>>8<n>The total cost of cookies is 4 * $1.25 = $<<4*1.25=5>>5<n>After buying the cookies, Josh has $8 - $5 = $<<8-5=3>>3<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input:Stopping being married to one another was a costly task, the lawyers and their what were astronomical? Choices:  A: free time B: pleasure C: get divorced D: legal fees E: being lonely<n><n>### Response:		<n>#### C<n><n>### Rationales<n>#### C<n>Answer: C<n><n>### Response to the response:<n><n>I agree with your answer. My question was intended to lead the student to realize that the term "costly" meant "expensive" and that the choices "free time" or "pleasure" did not fit because being divorced was expensive and getting divorced is expensive (legal fees). The answer choice that was in my mind was a lawyer who charged high fees.<n><n>### Input<n>Molly spent the entire morning organizing her classroom into three separate learning centers. It took her twenty minutes to set up the reading center. How long did it take Molly to create the writing and math centers.<n><n>### Response<n><n>#### A<n><n>### Rationale<n>#### A<n>Answer: A<n><n>### Response for response:<n>I like your solution and think that it worked well.<n><n><n>### Reference:<n>https://www.khanacademy.org/math/cc-third-grade-math/addition-and-subtraction-within-30/addition-subtraction-strategies-within-3-sets/v/example-task-3-8<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Rationales: If he babysits for 2 hours at $7 per hour, he will earn 2*7 = $<<2*7=14>>14<n>This week he will earn $5 allowance, $10 mowing the lawn and $14 from babysitting for a total of 5+10+14 = $<<5+10+14=29>>29<n>If we add the $29 he will earn to his $65 savings, he will have a total of 29 + 65 = $<<29+65=94>>94<n>The bike costs $100 and he will have $94 leaving $100-$94 = $<<100-94=6>>6 more that he will need to earn<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Rationales: His kangaroos have a total of 23*2=<<23*2=46>>46 legs<n>He has 23*3=<<23*3=69>>69 goats<n>The goats have 69*4=<<69*4=276>>276 legs<n>So in total his animals have 276+46=<<276+46=322>>322 legs<n>#### 322<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Rationales: After buying a hat, Josh has $20 - $10 = $<<20-10=10>>10<n>After buying a pencil, Josh has $10 - $2 = $<<10-2=8>>8<n>The total cost of cookies is 4 * $1.25 = $<<4*1.25=5>>5<n>After buying the cookies, Josh has $8 - $5 = $<<8-5=3>>3<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input:What will happen if you are successful when committing suicide? Choices:  A: scars B: being born C: sorrow D: misery E: kill yourself<n><n>### Response:		<n>The only response that will change your score is: "D". But if you are successful in committing suicide, you will be killing yourself over and over again.<n><n>### Extra Credit:<n>##### Question 1:<n>```<n>Find out the sum of the following equation. You can use the variables in the above question to solve the equation.<n><n>(x+2)+(3x-2)+(3x)*x+(x)*(2-x)+(x)*(3x+(3x+2)+1)/2=x*x*x*x+x*x*x-(x+2)*(x+2)*(2-x)*(3x*(x+1)+1)/2<n><n>```<n><n>`x`+2+3x-2+   `(3x)*`x`+`(x)*`(2-x)`+`(x)*((3x+(3x-2)+1)/2)= x`*x`*x`+x`*x`-   `x`+2`+`((3x)`x`+x`*(3x+(3x)=   -`+`x+`(3x)<n><n>##### Question 2:<n><n>Find out the sum and multiplier of `(4x-7)-4*x+x*(7x-3)/2`.<n><n>(4x-7)-   (4x)+  x   *(7x-3)/=2<n><n>##### Questions 3:<n>## `x3-7x2+5x-7`<n><n>$$ 3(\frac{x(x-1)(x-2)}{6}) - 2 \cdot 7 - 5  $$<n><n>``x3-16x2+10x-8`<n><n>1.<n>> (3x-2)...<n><n>x-((x-2)/3)*3<n><n>2. `x^2+x+1`<n><n>   `(x+1)...` -> [<n><n>  > (x+1) +<n><n>  > (1+x)<n>    ] / /<n><n>  x + 1 + 1 + x + 1 / 2<n><n>  2. `2x`<n><n>    (2x)... = 2<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Rationales: If he babysits for 2 hours at $7 per hour, he will earn 2*7 = $<<2*7=14>>14<n>This week he will earn $5 allowance, $10 mowing the lawn and $14 from babysitting for a total of 5+10+14 = $<<5+10+14=29>>29<n>If we add the $29 he will earn to his $65 savings, he will have a total of 29 + 65 = $<<29+65=94>>94<n>The bike costs $100 and he will have $94 leaving $100-$94 = $<<100-94=6>>6 more that he will need to earn<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Rationales: His kangaroos have a total of 23*2=<<23*2=46>>46 legs<n>He has 23*3=<<23*3=69>>69 goats<n>The goats have 69*4=<<69*4=276>>276 legs<n>So in total his animals have 276+46=<<276+46=322>>322 legs<n>#### 322<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Rationales: After buying a hat, Josh has $20 - $10 = $<<20-10=10>>10<n>After buying a pencil, Josh has $10 - $2 = $<<10-2=8>>8<n>The total cost of cookies is 4 * $1.25 = $<<4*1.25=5>>5<n>After buying the cookies, Josh has $8 - $5 = $<<8-5=3>>3<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input:A school is most likely to be located in what sort of zone? Choices:  A: residential neighborhood B: community C: building D: prague E: every city<n><n>### Response:		A Residential neighborhood is most likely to be the location of a school.<n><n>### Explanations:The most likely zone for a school is a residential neighborhood.  Schools are designed to provide an area where kids can go to learn and be surrounded by people and things that they are familiar with.  The community would be too noisy for the students and the teachers.  Building and prague aren't even proper descriptions of a zone because they aren't zones like residential and community.<n><n>### Rationale:A Residential zone is the most likely area for a school.<n><n>#### 5<n>Answer: a<n><n>### Input:-Mary has a $100 voucher that she can to a clothing store. The store has items that can be bought for 3 times their sale price. How to she use her voucher to buy the greatest number of items?<n><n>### Demostration<n><n>$$<n>\begin{split}<n><n>\text{<n>100 dollars<n>} \equiv{ \dfrac{3}{100}} \times \text{ 3 times the sale price of items in store}<n>\\<n>\text{<n>\hspace{2cm}100 \text{ dollars and } 300 \text{ items}<n>}<n>\\<n>\textrm{<n>10000 dollars<n>} = \dfrac{\text{ 3333}}{ \text{100} \times 2 }<n>\\<n>$$<n>\end{split}<n><n>### Response<n><n>I would like to buy 3333 of things.<n><n>#### 7<n>Answer: 39060<n>

She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100. He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Rationales: If he babysits for 2 hours at $7 per hour, he will earn 2*7 = $<<2*7=14>>14<n>This week he will earn $5 allowance, $10 mowing the lawn and $14 from babysitting for a total of 5+10+14 = $<<5+10+14=29>>29<n>If we add the $29 he will earn to his $65 savings, he will have a total of 29 + 65 = $<<29+65=94>>94<n>The bike costs $100 and he will have $94 leaving $100-$94 = $<<100-94=6>>6 more that he will need to earn<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Rationales: His kangaroos have a total of 23*2=<<23*2=46>>46 legs<n>He has 23*3=<<23*3=69>>69 goats<n>The goats have 69*4=<<69*4=276>>276 legs<n>So in total his animals have 276+46=<<276+46=322>>322 legs<n>#### 322<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Rationales: After buying a hat, Josh has $20 - $10 = $<<20-10=10>>10<n>After buying a pencil, Josh has $10 - $2 = $<<10-2=8>>8<n>The total cost of cookies is 4 * $1.25 = $<<4*1.25=5>>5<n>After buying the cookies, Josh has $8 - $5 = $<<8-5=3>>3<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input:What happens to people when they do not have enough food? Choices:  A: eat fish B: they steal C: talk to each other D: write stories E: die of starvation<n><n>### Response:		Choices:  A is correct B is incorrect C is incorrect D is incorrect E is incorrect<n><n>### Rationales: Choices are not consistent with the situation.<n><n>### Answer:  All other choice are incorrect except E.<n><n>### What type of evidence justified your answer?  Write below if you provide sufficient reason.<n><n>### Input<n>I think that A: eat fish because it is the correct answer and i can see it<n><n>### Answer<n>I can see that E is the answer because it is out of the choices<n><n>### What information did you search to gather evidence like the information you shared above?  Write below what you searched or where you looked.  Write your answers on a separate page.<n>I searched google.com and i looked up the definition of starvation.<n><n>### In response to the prompt, write 5 statements that follow the sentence format P+S (predict/solve).<n>1.P:  I predict that I will eat my 1/4 cup of broccoli.<n><n>2.P:  I will solve that i will eat the broccoli.<n>3.P:  I won't eat my 1/2 cup of carrot.<n><n>4.P:I will solve eat half a carrot.<n><n>5.P:  I think i will eat my 1 piece of cheese.<n><n>### Do research on what kind of foods a pig eats.<n>[Golden Acorn<n><n>Lifeline Pig Food<n><n>Pig Grower Feed<n><n>Pig Growout<n><n>Pig Premium<n><n>Pig Purity<n><n>Pig Starter Feed<n><n>Porkers<n><n>Purina One Smartblend Large Breed<n><n>Purina Animal Nutrition<n><n>Smart Puppy<n><n>Wysong Pork-N-Beef]<n>### In response  to the prompt, write at least 5 sentences that follow the sentence format OP(objective, problem) (objective).<n>1. The first line has 5 syllables, the second line has 7 syllables and the third line has 5 syallables. Haikus can be fun and are a great way to show your creativity.<n><n>Each of you will contribute one haiku and together you will all create three haikus.<n><n>Choose three friends, then you and others will each write at least one line for each haiku.<n><n>If you are not working in a group, you may complete this task on your own.<n><n>#### A haiku<n>Answer: A haiku<n><n>### Instuctions:Answer the following sentence as a written response. <n>  Use appropriate punctuation and capitalization. <n>

If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Rationales: His kangaroos have a total of 23*2=<<23*2=46>>46 legs<n>He has 23*3=<<23*3=69>>69 goats<n>The goats have 69*4=<<69*4=276>>276 legs<n>So in total his animals have 276+46=<<276+46=322>>322 legs<n>#### 322<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Rationales: After buying a hat, Josh has $20 - $10 = $<<20-10=10>>10<n>After buying a pencil, Josh has $10 - $2 = $<<10-2=8>>8<n>The total cost of cookies is 4 * $1.25 = $<<4*1.25=5>>5<n>After buying the cookies, Josh has $8 - $5 = $<<8-5=3>>3<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input:Bob is in a dressing room.  He's putting on waterproof trunks and goggles.  What sort of facility is he most likely visiting? Choices:  A: swimming pool B: actors and actresses C: fancy restaurant. D: gym E: theatre<n><n>### Response:		<n>Input: Bob is in a dressing before entering the theatre.<n>Rationales: A: swimming pool: Want people to use the swimming pool.<n>B: actors/actresses: Need good performance to act good.<n>C: fancy restaurant: Must look presentable.<n>D: gym: Need to fit into tight clothes.<n>E: theatre: Want people to be dressed properly.<n>Choices: D: gym<n>Answer: D<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Rationales: If he babysits for 2 hours at $7 per hour, he will earn 2*7 = $<<2*7=14>>14<n>This week he will earn $5 allowance, $10 mowing the lawn and $14 from babysitting for a total of 5+10+14 = $<<5+10+14=29>>29<n>If we add the $29 he will earn to his $65 savings, he will have a total of 29 + 65 = $<<29+65=94>>94<n>The bike costs $100 and he will have $94 leaving $100-$94 = $<<100-94=6>>6 more that he will need to earn<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Rationales: His kangaroos have a total of 23*2=<<23*2=46>>46 legs<n>He has 23*3=<<23*3=69>>69 goats<n>The goats have 69*4=<<69*4=276>>276 legs<n>So in total his animals have 276+46=<<276+46=322>>322 legs<n>#### 322<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Rationales: After buying a hat, Josh has $20 - $10 = $<<20-10=10>>10<n>After buying a pencil, Josh has $10 - $2 = $<<10-2=8>>8<n>The total cost of cookies is 4 * $1.25 = $<<4*1.25=5>>5<n>After buying the cookies, Josh has $8 - $5 = $<<8-5=3>>3<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input:He was selling all his collector items even the rare plate, he had bought a lot at the what for the weekend? Choices:  A: supermarket B: kitchen cupboard C: table D: flea market E: dishwasher<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>Rationales: The letter "A" is the answer because the seller is selling all his collectors items even the rare plate that he bought.

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100. He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Rationales: If he babysits for 2 hours at $7 per hour, he will earn 2*7 = $<<2*7=14>>14<n>This week he will earn $5 allowance, $10 mowing the lawn and $14 from babysitting for a total of 5+10+14 = $<<5+10+14=29>>29<n>If we add the $29 he will earn to his $65 savings, he will have a total of 29 + 65 = $<<29+65=94>>94<n>The bike costs $100 and he will have $94 leaving $100-$94 = $<<100-94=6>>6 more that he will need to earn<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Rationales: His kangaroos have a total of 23*2=<<23*2=46>>46 legs<n>He has 23*3=<<23*3=69>>69 goats<n>The goats have 69*4=<<69*4=276>>276 legs<n>So in total his animals have 276+46=<<276+46=322>>322 legs<n>#### 322<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Rationales: After buying a hat, Josh has $20 - $10 = $<<20-10=10>>10<n>After buying a pencil, Josh has $10 - $2 = $<<10-2=8>>8<n>The total cost of cookies is 4 * $1.25 = $<<4*1.25=5>>5<n>After buying the cookies, Josh has $8 - $5 = $<<8-5=3>>3<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input:The artist knew that this was the peak of his fandom, so he decided it was time for cashing in by doing what? Choices:  A: countryside B: farming areas C: michigan D: texas E: north dakota<n><n>### Response:		Farming areas<n><n>### Explanation:Since Michigan is the only state that resembles a glove in shape, it must be the answer since the directions say "in shape" not the exact shape of a glove. <n><n>### Input:-8772987$ is 87729.987<n><n>### Rationale:<n>When the 4 was in the thousand spot, it was still a 4, so it should multiply like that.  Then after the decimal it is all ones so each spot just adds another one to make 0.987.<n><n>#### E<n><n>#### 5<n><n>### Examples:<n>**Practice:**<n>The table below shows that for one unit of time, 100 Joules of work were done for $1. How many units of energy are represented in the table?<n><n>Work     | Energy   <n>---  <n>$1 | Joules<n>**Rationales:**$Joules represents the amount of work done. Work*Energy=Power<n>Energy<n>Joules represents the energy used. Work*Eneregy=Power<n>**Explanation:**If  $\frac 10 = 0.01$, 100 J means $$100 \times \frac{0.01}{100} = 0.0001$$ Joules<n>If  $\frac 540 = 0.3571$<n>then 400 J means $$400 \times \frac{0.357}{ 400} = 14.6798$$ Joules<n><n>### Input:$ 3\frac{1}{5}$ $3.1$<n><n>### Expectation:<n>Remeber that fractions are a numerator divided a denominator so you take the numerator and divided it by the denominator.  So in this case 3/5 divided by 5/10 which means you take 3/5 and divide it by 5/1 or just 1.<n><n>You take 3/5 x 1 = 0.6 then multiply 0.6 x 5/100 which is just 3.<n><n>#### 0.2<n><n>##
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100. Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs. If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Rationales: His kangaroos have a total of 23*2=<<23*2=46>>46 legs<n>He has 23*3=<<23*3=69>>69 goats<n>The goats have 69*4=<<69*4=276>>276 legs<n>So in total his animals have 276+46=<<276+46=322>>322 legs<n>#### 322<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Rationales: After buying a hat, Josh has $20 - $10 = $<<20-10=10>>10<n>After buying a pencil, Josh has $10 - $2 = $<<10-2=8>>8<n>The total cost of cookies is 4 * $1.25 = $<<4*1.25=5>>5<n>After buying the cookies, Josh has $8 - $5 = $<<8-5=3>>3<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input:A person is alone in the woods and wounded, what should he do? Choices:  A: amount to nothing B: visit relatives C: charming D: doctor himself E: cross street<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>### Injury: If he needs a doctor, he will cross the street to get one.<n><n>### Response<n><n>### In the second example, write a response that contains ______.<n><n>### Response
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Rationales: If he babysits for 2 hours at $7 per hour, he will earn 2*7 = $<<2*7=14>>14<n>This week he will earn $5 allowance, $10 mowing the lawn and $14 from babysitting for a total of 5+10+14 = $<<5+10+14=29>>29<n>If we add the $29 he will earn to his $65 savings, he will have a total of 29 + 65 = $<<29+65=94>>94<n>The bike costs $100 and he will have $94 leaving $100-$94 = $<<100-94=6>>6 more that he will need to earn<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Rationales: His kangaroos have a total of 23*2=<<23*2=46>>46 legs<n>He has 23*3=<<23*3=69>>69 goats<n>The goats have 69*4=<<69*4=276>>276 legs<n>So in total his animals have 276+46=<<276+46=322>>322 legs<n>#### 322<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Rationales: After buying a hat, Josh has $20 - $10 = $<<20-10=10>>10<n>After buying a pencil, Josh has $10 - $2 = $<<10-2=8>>8<n>The total cost of cookies is 4 * $1.25 = $<<4*1.25=5>>5<n>After buying the cookies, Josh has $8 - $5 = $<<8-5=3>>3<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input:What  might john order at an indian resturant on top of the space needle? Choices:  A: large city B: seattle C: curry D: clothing E: reservation<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>### Rationales:We are looking for a larger or smaller region on the map, John would go for either Seattle or Clothing. For Curry and Reservation, you could say John went to the city or the restaurant. <n>### Response:C<n><n>### Rationale<n>This answer is more focused on the Indian resturant and not John's meal choice.  He was looking to spend an evening at the Indian resturant which is what the city is for.  <n>

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Rationales: After buying a hat, Josh has $20 - $10 = $<<20-10=10>>10<n>After buying a pencil, Josh has $10 - $2 = $<<10-2=8>>8<n>The total cost of cookies is 4 * $1.25 = $<<4*1.25=5>>5<n>After buying the cookies, Josh has $8 - $5 = $<<8-5=3>>3<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input:A person with children might have a lot of plastic things in what place? Choices:  A: cupboard B: cabinet C: own home D: everything E: garbage dump<n><n>### Response:		<n>#### D<n># Rationale:<n>### Input:Sometimes a person’s hand might come across what unexpected object while it’s in the pocket? Choice A: A snake. Choice B: A wad of gum. Choice C: A bug. Choice D = An unexpected object. Choice E = A key.<n><n>### Response<n>#### D<n># D<n>### 1)<n>#### 1<n># 1<n>### 2<n>#### 2<n># 2<n>### 3<n>#### 3
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Rationales: If he babysits for 2 hours at $7 per hour, he will earn 2*7 = $<<2*7=14>>14<n>This week he will earn $5 allowance, $10 mowing the lawn and $14 from babysitting for a total of 5+10+14 = $<<5+10+14=29>>29<n>If we add the $29 he will earn to his $65 savings, he will have a total of 29 + 65 = $<<29+65=94>>94<n>The bike costs $100 and he will have $94 leaving $100-$94 = $<<100-94=6>>6 more that he will need to earn<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Rationales: His kangaroos have a total of 23*2=<<23*2=46>>46 legs<n>He has 23*3=<<23*3=69>>69 goats<n>The goats have 69*4=<<69*4=276>>276 legs<n>So in total his animals have 276+46=<<276+46=322>>322 legs<n>#### 322<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Rationales: After buying a hat, Josh has $20 - $10 = $<<20-10=10>>10<n>After buying a pencil, Josh has $10 - $2 = $<<10-2=8>>8<n>The total cost of cookies is 4 * $1.25 = $<<4*1.25=5>>5<n>After buying the cookies, Josh has $8 - $5 = $<<8-5=3>>3<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input:A bride and groom are taking care of proposals, what is the likely ceremony? Choices:  A: efficiency B: getting work done C: marriage D: finishing up E: results<n><n>### Response:		<n>If a bride and groom take care of proposals they are likely to have a marriage.<n><n>### Input : When the snake goes into hibernation, how do his neighbors refer to his time period?<n><n>### Response : <n><n>If a snake goes into hiberation his neighbors will refer to hie time as hibernation.

How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100. How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Rationales: If he babysits for 2 hours at $7 per hour, he will earn 2*7 = $<<2*7=14>>14<n>This week he will earn $5 allowance, $10 mowing the lawn and $14 from babysitting for a total of 5+10+14 = $<<5+10+14=29>>29<n>If we add the $29 he will earn to his $65 savings, he will have a total of 29 + 65 = $<<29+65=94>>94<n>The bike costs $100 and he will have $94 leaving $100-$94 = $<<100-94=6>>6 more that he will need to earn<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats. Choices:  A: pocket B: shower C: chemist D: drug store E: shaving kit<n><n>### Response:		The shaving kit would be the correct answer because A, B, C, and D are incorrect and that leaves the shaving kit as the correct answer. You have to look at the phrase the shaving kit. If it has kit then it's not A or B. Then if you look at the phrase double edge shaver it would not be C or E. This leaves you with shower or drug store. Neither of those could be correct so that leaves shaving kit as correct. This is a 2 step process so you would have to go over A-D again and see if the answer would be A or D. Because shower A and shaving kit E can be eliminated you can go through the process again and the shaving kit becomes the answer.<n><n>#### 4 points<n><n>```md<n>Input: What would be the first thing to do?<n><n>Response: To make sure the answer can be found, we have to look over the choices.  In this case, Show up has a vowel/consonant at the start of the word. The other ones have either all vowels and all consonants or all consonants and all vowels, making the beginning consonant the correct answer.<n>```<n><n>### Instructions:<n>#### <n><n>#### Answer:<n><n>### Instroduction:<n>#### 42<n><n>#### <n>

Remember when working to be specific in your response.<n><n>*I have never eaten crab before*<n><n>### Which option completes the sentence correctly?<n><n>-I have never eaten {crab}.<n><n>-I have {never eaten} crab before.<n><n>-I have not eat {crab} before.<n><n>-It's {before} I've ever {eaten} crab.<n><n>#### 3<n><n>## Sentence:<n>My house is on {sale} at the moment.<n><n>### Which of the following must be added to the sentence to make it grammatically correct?<n><n>-I can't {find} your house on Google {sale}.<n><n>-I can find your house at this moment {sale}.<n>-I should put some of them on {sale}.<n>--I can't {go} and look {sale} for your house.<n><n>#### 4<n><n>## Sentence Error:<n>What a fun summer this is going to be!<n><n><n>### Correct the sentence by underlining the word(s) or phrase(s) that are not correct.<n><n>-It is so fun to enjoy the life.<n>--I’m looking forward to the next summer vacation.<n>-It is so hard to decide.<n>-I can’t wait for next summer.<n><n>#### 2<n><n>## Sentence Problem:<n>I will be ready when school starts this fall.<n><n>### Explain the error found in each sentence and how to revise it.<n><n>#### Part B<n><n>-To start working at Target, it is required that you should be 16+ years old at the time of employment.<n><n>#### Part C<n><n>-The first day of school is September 1st, 2016.<n><n><n><n><n><n>

If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Rationales: His kangaroos have a total of 23*2=<<23*2=46>>46 legs<n>He has 23*3=<<23*3=69>>69 goats<n>The goats have 69*4=<<69*4=276>>276 legs<n>So in total his animals have 276+46=<<276+46=322>>322 legs<n>#### 322<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Rationales: After buying a hat, Josh has $20 - $10 = $<<20-10=10>>10<n>After buying a pencil, Josh has $10 - $2 = $<<10-2=8>>8<n>The total cost of cookies is 4 * $1.25 = $<<4*1.25=5>>5<n>After buying the cookies, Josh has $8 - $5 = $<<8-5=3>>3<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input:The boy was too nervous to dance, so what was he doing progressively at the ball? Choices:  A: dance like crazy B: standing still C: wallflower D: stand still E: like dancing<n><n>### Response:		What was the boy doing on stage? A: standing still B: wallflower C: Like dancing D: Dancing E: standing still<n><n>#### C<n>Answer: C<n><n>### Input<n>Jake is the smartest and fastest student in Mr Jones math class. Jake is also the tallest student in his class. If he is 1.25 m taller than Mr Jones and 1.1m shorter than Mr Williams, how tall is Mr Jones?<n><n>### Response<n>Mr Jones is the tallest student in the class.<n>#### 1.25<n>Mr Jones is<n>Answer: 1.25
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Rationales: If he babysits for 2 hours at $7 per hour, he will earn 2*7 = $<<2*7=14>>14<n>This week he will earn $5 allowance, $10 mowing the lawn and $14 from babysitting for a total of 5+10+14 = $<<5+10+14=29>>29<n>If we add the $29 he will earn to his $65 savings, he will have a total of 29 + 65 = $<<29+65=94>>94<n>The bike costs $100 and he will have $94 leaving $100-$94 = $<<100-94=6>>6 more that he will need to earn<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Rationales: His kangaroos have a total of 23*2=<<23*2=46>>46 legs<n>He has 23*3=<<23*3=69>>69 goats<n>The goats have 69*4=<<69*4=276>>276 legs<n>So in total his animals have 276+46=<<276+46=322>>322 legs<n>#### 322<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Rationales: After buying a hat, Josh has $20 - $10 = $<<20-10=10>>10<n>After buying a pencil, Josh has $10 - $2 = $<<10-2=8>>8<n>The total cost of cookies is 4 * $1.25 = $<<4*1.25=5>>5<n>After buying the cookies, Josh has $8 - $5 = $<<8-5=3>>3<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input:What does someone living life fully feel? Choices:  A: joy B: valuable C: happiness D: early death E: adventurous<n><n>### Response:		<n>#### A<n>Answer: A<n><n>### Rationale:<n>Someone living life fully feels joy, not valuable or early death and not adventurous.<n><n>Answer with reference to how the question asks about "feel" and not what they are but how they "feel." We are asking about the emotion which a person would feel when being fully alive, therefore you would select answer (A) joy and not answer (D) early death.<n><n>### Question:<n>What would you miss the most if you could never again see the colors orange and blue and could only see colors green, blue, purple and yellow? Choices:  a: purple and blue b: green c: the sun d: orange<n><n>### Answer with reference to How many colours would you miss the most? (instead of all the options as provided in the question<n><n>#### A<n><n>Answer: B<n><n>### Rationales:<n>While you may wish that you could only see the colours, green, blue, purples and yellows, they all still represent color. The colour purple represents the colour you are asking about. Therefore, your option would be option B.<n><n>Answer with regard to how the question asks us to express what we would miss about colours and not what we would miss about being colour blind<n>

He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Rationales: If he babysits for 2 hours at $7 per hour, he will earn 2*7 = $<<2*7=14>>14<n>This week he will earn $5 allowance, $10 mowing the lawn and $14 from babysitting for a total of 5+10+14 = $<<5+10+14=29>>29<n>If we add the $29 he will earn to his $65 savings, he will have a total of 29 + 65 = $<<29+65=94>>94<n>The bike costs $100 and he will have $94 leaving $100-$94 = $<<100-94=6>>6 more that he will need to earn<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats. If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Rationales: His kangaroos have a total of 23*2=<<23*2=46>>46 legs<n>He has 23*3=<<23*3=69>>69 goats<n>The goats have 69*4=<<69*4=276>>276 legs<n>So in total his animals have 276+46=<<276+46=322>>322 legs<n>#### 322<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Rationales: After buying a hat, Josh has $20 - $10 = $<<20-10=10>>10<n>After buying a pencil, Josh has $10 - $2 = $<<10-2=8>>8<n>The total cost of cookies is 4 * $1.25 = $<<4*1.25=5>>5<n>After buying the cookies, Josh has $8 - $5 = $<<8-5=3>>3<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input:What would happen to you if you are not good at playing violin? Choices:  A: happiness B: relaxation C: create music D: sadness E: loud noises<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>### Choices:<n>A. A<n><n>### Rationales:<n>A. When you do something that you are poor at, you will feel unhappy. You will be stressed, so you will end up with emotions of sadness. You will feel relaxed when you are good at what you're doing. You will end up with emotional sensations that will induce you to make a sound to express yourself.<n><n>### B. B<n>B. You will feel relaxation when you are doing something that you're good at. You will feel relaxing sensation because you know you're doing well. You feel happy when you can express who you are as an artist by doing what you're good at, playing the violin. If you feel good about playing violin, you'll play violin easily.<n><n>### C. C<n>C. You will feel music when you're doing something you're good at and feel relaxed when you're not.<n><n>### D. D<n>D. If you're bad at violin, you're going to feel sad. You are going to feel like making noise because you're having pressure of not knowing how to play violin and frustrated by your own mistake. So you can't make a good music or performance when you have a pressure.<n><n>### E. E<n>E. When you're not good at violin, you would feel like creating loud noises and being sad if you try to make music because it is a pressure on you. If you feel sad, you'll be stressed and you'll make more loud noise to forget how sad you are.<n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100. He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Rationales: If he babysits for 2 hours at $7 per hour, he will earn 2*7 = $<<2*7=14>>14<n>This week he will earn $5 allowance, $10 mowing the lawn and $14 from babysitting for a total of 5+10+14 = $<<5+10+14=29>>29<n>If we add the $29 he will earn to his $65 savings, he will have a total of 29 + 65 = $<<29+65=94>>94<n>The bike costs $100 and he will have $94 leaving $100-$94 = $<<100-94=6>>6 more that he will need to earn<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.
