His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Rationales: If he babysits for 2 hours at $7 per hour, he will earn 2*7 = $<<2*7=14>>14<n>This week he will earn $5 allowance, $10 mowing the lawn and $14 from babysitting for a total of 5+10+14 = $<<5+10+14=29>>29<n>If we add the $29 he will earn to his $65 savings, he will have a total of 29 + 65 = $<<29+65=94>>94<n>The bike costs $100 and he will have $94 leaving $100-$94 = $<<100-94=6>>6 more that he will need to earn<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Rationales: His kangaroos have a total of 23*2=<<23*2=46>>46 legs<n>He has 23*3=<<23*3=69>>69 goats<n>The goats have 69*4=<<69*4=276>>276 legs<n>So in total his animals have 276+46=<<276+46=322>>322 legs<n>#### 322<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Rationales: After buying a hat, Josh has $20 - $10 = $<<20-10=10>>10<n>After buying a pencil, Josh has $10 - $2 = $<<10-2=8>>8<n>The total cost of cookies is 4 * $1.25 = $<<4*1.25=5>>5<n>After buying the cookies, Josh has $8 - $5 = $<<8-5=3>>3<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input:What animal produces milk? Choices:  A: supermarket B: pig C: cow D: refrigerator E: store<n><n>### Response:		<n>E<n><n>### Input<n>You have a bag full of 10 apples of different colors and 5 of every color.  If you eat a blue apple how many of each color do you have left?<n><n>### Rationale<n>We know that you have 5 of each color.  <n>After eating a blue apple it will no longer be included since we have already accounted for it.<n>We can simplify this to:<n><n>5 + (9 apples left) = 5 +??<n><n>5 / 5 = 1<n><n>5 + 1 = 6<n><n>### Answer<n>6<n><n>### Instructions:<n>#### 42<n>You need to calculate how many caterpillars will be left after they grow into butterflies.<n><n>### Answer:<n>302<n><n>### Input <n>#### 308<n>12 butterflies hatch and their combined weight is 3 pounds. What is the average weight of a butterfly?  <n><n>### Answer <n><n>2.5<n><n>#### 5<n>When the train pulled into the station, a man was waiting at the platform. When the train pulled out, he was still there. How could that be?<n><n>### Answer.<n><n>He left. he was at the train station, a train came into the train station so he was just there to watch a train come in, he was there earlier when the train pulled into the train station, and when the train pulled out he was still there... he left<n><n>### Input.<n><n>The butterfly had 5 legs and then another 7 legs were added by the other two butterflies that were there. Then another 14 were added. The pig still had 276 legs after the butterfly. When did the pig leave?<n><n>### Ans.<n>Butterfly left<n><n>#### 24<n>Two children have found an alligator in a swamp. They are both on the bank and the alligator is in the middle of the swamp looking up at the children. If each child cast a stone into the swamp, how many stones will land on the alligator? <n><n>### Ans.. a little over 2.5<n><n>### Input A:<n>#### 66<n>A 4-
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Rationales: If he babysits for 2 hours at $7 per hour, he will earn 2*7 = $<<2*7=14>>14<n>This week he will earn $5 allowance, $10 mowing the lawn and $14 from babysitting for a total of 5+10+14 = $<<5+10+14=29>>29<n>If we add the $29 he will earn to his $65 savings, he will have a total of 29 + 65 = $<<29+65=94>>94<n>The bike costs $100 and he will have $94 leaving $100-$94 = $<<100-94=6>>6 more that he will need to earn<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Rationales: His kangaroos have a total of 23*2=<<23*2=46>>46 legs<n>He has 23*3=<<23*3=69>>69 goats<n>The goats have 69*4=<<69*4=276>>276 legs<n>So in total his animals have 276+46=<<276+46=322>>322 legs<n>#### 322<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Rationales: After buying a hat, Josh has $20 - $10 = $<<20-10=10>>10<n>After buying a pencil, Josh has $10 - $2 = $<<10-2=8>>8<n>The total cost of cookies is 4 * $1.25 = $<<4*1.25=5>>5<n>After buying the cookies, Josh has $8 - $5 = $<<8-5=3>>3<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input:Society cannot exist without numbers. Choices:  A: band B: music room C: college D: university E: house<n><n>### Response:		<n>If a person buys an upright piano,<n>they usually need a room, so he can put it there.<n>If his piano doesn't have anywhere to go, he must move!<n>This should not be too hard to answer. Remember, you do not need an equal sign with equalities and does not need a colon (:) with conditionals. In other words, you do not need to separate every instruction into two lines.<n><n>#### 4<n>Answer: 1<n>Input: If 1+5=$3, then 3+8=$?<n>Input: If 2+4=$7, then 7+8=$?<n><n>### Instructions:<n>Input: If the number is greater than 100, then write "I like to eat".  If the number is less than 100 then write "I like ice cream".  Otherwise write "I like to run."<n><n>### Rationales:  If number is less than 20, then it is less than 1<n>If number is less than 40, then it is Less than 2 AND it is not bigger than 1<n>If it is not bigger than one but it is more than 100 it is not bigger than two<n>Otherwise number is between 0 and 9.<n>To get the answer out of this you will have to do something like this:<n><n>$$\begin{align}<n>  0 \leq n < 100 \\<n>  0 \leq x < 2 \\<n>-1\leq n \leq 9 \\<n>1 \leq x < 3 \\<n>\end{align}$$<n><n>and choose the most appropriate result as you see fit.<n><n>\$<n>\begin{align*}<n>0 + x=1 & \rightarrow & \text{"I like ice cream"} \\<n>0 < x=1 & \Rightarrow & \text{"I do not like to run."} \\<n>\end{array}<n>\Rightarrow \begin<n>\(n=\text{"I like to eat"}<n><n>\end{align*}<n><n>#### 3<n><n>#### 10<n><n># Task 4: <n>Create a "if" statement that describes the following statements.<n><n>Input 1: <n>If there are one or more odd numbers evenly divisible by one and two, I like to jog.

It's dark. Some stars are visible so I'd say that most of the beans are not visible. If all the beans were in the can at once, I would estimate that there are no beans visible.<n><n>### RATIONALES: Because the stars are visible in the sky, they are not blocking the sun. The fact that most of the beeans are not visible indicates that they are not in our line of sight and there isn't much to see out there. Because its dark, most of the light is blocked. You could turn off the lights in your room and see that there is not much light outside. Its not like there are thousands of stars lining every inch of space.<n><n>### Response:"If you throw a baseball 3 feet off of the wall, the ball will bounce straight back to you?"<n><n>The answer is: False.<n><n>If you throw the ball hard against a wall, it will still bounce back at the same distance. It won't go any further. You need to throw the ball hard enough for it to "catch" on the wall/door/something to bounce back at a larger angle.

He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Rationales: After buying a hat, Josh has $20 - $10 = $<<20-10=10>>10<n>After buying a pencil, Josh has $10 - $2 = $<<10-2=8>>8<n>The total cost of cookies is 4 * $1.25 = $<<4*1.25=5>>5<n>After buying the cookies, Josh has $8 - $5 = $<<8-5=3>>3<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input:The investigator considered the gun evidence, where did he send it? Choices:  A: drawer B: back to its owner C: police station D: crime scene E: holster<n><n>### Response:		B<n><n><n><n><n>### Input<n><n>The investigator considered the toothbrush evidence, what did he do with the handle?  Choices: A: returned it to its owner B: sent it to be analyzed C: sent it to the lab for fingerprinting D: put it in an evidence drawer<n><n>### Response<n><n>E<n><n><n><n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Rationales: If he babysits for 2 hours at $7 per hour, he will earn 2*7 = $<<2*7=14>>14<n>This week he will earn $5 allowance, $10 mowing the lawn and $14 from babysitting for a total of 5+10+14 = $<<5+10+14=29>>29<n>If we add the $29 he will earn to his $65 savings, he will have a total of 29 + 65 = $<<29+65=94>>94<n>The bike costs $100 and he will have $94 leaving $100-$94 = $<<100-94=6>>6 more that he will need to earn<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Rationales: His kangaroos have a total of 23*2=<<23*2=46>>46 legs<n>He has 23*3=<<23*3=69>>69 goats<n>The goats have 69*4=<<69*4=276>>276 legs<n>So in total his animals have 276+46=<<276+46=322>>322 legs<n>#### 322<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Rationales: After buying a hat, Josh has $20 - $10 = $<<20-10=10>>10<n>After buying a pencil, Josh has $10 - $2 = $<<10-2=8>>8<n>The total cost of cookies is 4 * $1.25 = $<<4*1.25=5>>5<n>After buying the cookies, Josh has $8 - $5 = $<<8-5=3>>3<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input:What do all rooms facing outside have? Choices:  A: square shape B: different sizes C: flowers D: doors and windows E: high walls<n><n>### Response:		All rooms facing outside have doors and windows.<n><n>### Rationales:All rooms facing outside are facing the outside and has doors and windows which faces outside.<n><n>### Input : Write a program that uses variables to calculate this area of a table.  You need to calculate the area of the table which is 5 and a half feet wide by 4 feet long. Use the following equation to accomplish this task:<n><n>Area_of_Table = 5.5 * 4<n><n>### Output : Your program should output the area of the table, which is 22 square feet.<n><n>Output: Area_of_table = 5.5 4 = 22.5 feet<n><n>### Rationale:<n><n>#### Area_of_Table=5.5 * 1<n><n>Area_of-Table=<5.5 * 2>22 feet<n><n>Output: Area of table = 5.5*4 = 22 square feet<n><n>### Input For Program:<n>Input: Mary likes to walk for a half hour for two days in a week. Choices:  A: problems B: offspring C: overpopulation D: larger family E: baby<n><n>### Response:		C<n>#### A<n>A1: The word "problems" refers to something that causes problems.<n><n>A2: "Invitro" in my note is not a problem but a choice.<n><n>A3: By using invitro for reproduction, women are forced to use hormonal treatment to prevent the fertilization of unwanted embryos.<n><n>A4: The treatment of the embryos would cost around $30,000 and after the implantation into a woman's womb, the embryo transfer can last for 20 years.<n><n>A5: The transfer of the egg from a donor to a recipient mother would increase the health risks to both mothers.<n><n>A6: The cost of invitro for reproduccion is around $30,300 per cycle.<n><n>#### B<n>B1: The word "offspring" refers to the children a person conceives.<n><n>B2: The word "baby" is commonly used to refer to an embryo.<n><n>B3: In contrast, invitro refers to a reproducion process using a donor egg and a recipient.<n><n>#### C<n>C1: The solution for overpopulation can be achieved using natural methods.<n><n>C2: The treatment of embryos is called invitro.<n><n>C3: The treatment of embriyos is $30,030 a cycle.<n><n>C4: The word "babies" refers to a young human.<n><n>C5: I was unable to find a definition for "larger family", but it is commonly understood to refer to having several children.<n><n>#### D<n>D1: The word "babiy" is commonly used to mention the child of human beings.<n><n>D2: Treatment of the embriyos is called invitr.<n><n>D3: The treatment of babies is $30,340 per cycle.<n>

How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Rationales: If he babysits for 2 hours at $7 per hour, he will earn 2*7 = $<<2*7=14>>14<n>This week he will earn $5 allowance, $10 mowing the lawn and $14 from babysitting for a total of 5+10+14 = $<<5+10+14=29>>29<n>If we add the $29 he will earn to his $65 savings, he will have a total of 29 + 65 = $<<29+65=94>>94<n>The bike costs $100 and he will have $94 leaving $100-$94 = $<<100-94=6>>6 more that he will need to earn<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Rationales: His kangaroos have a total of 23*2=<<23*2=46>>46 legs<n>He has 23*3=<<23*3=69>>69 goats<n>The goats have 69*4=<<69*4=276>>276 legs<n>So in total his animals have 276+46=<<276+46=322>>322 legs<n>#### 322<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Rationales: After buying a hat, Josh has $20 - $10 = $<<20-10=10>>10<n>After buying a pencil, Josh has $10 - $2 = $<<10-2=8>>8<n>The total cost of cookies is 4 * $1.25 = $<<4*1.25=5>>5<n>After buying the cookies, Josh has $8 - $5 = $<<8-5=3>>3<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input:The janitor got his pail out of where? Choices:  A: wishing well B: kitchen C: hardware store D: garage E: utility room<n><n>### Response:		<n>Choice B<n><n>**Explanation:** The janitor may have put the pail into the kitchen or the garage, but it's just as likely that he forgot where he put it.  <n><n>### Instructions:<n>A. Write a response that correctly completes the instruction.<n>B. Write a response that refutes the claim in the rationales.<n>C. Write a response that supports your claim with appropriate reasoning.<n>D. Write a response that presents an alternate claim using supporting reasoning.<n>E. Write a response in which you explain how each part of the task supports the claim.<n>F. Write a response that explains what is being requested and why it is being requested.<n>G. Write a response in how you would write the task and instructions differently.<n>H. Write a response that provides a possible problem or error with the instructions.<n><n>### Answer:<n>F<n><n>### Instuctions:<n>A. Explain where the pail that a janitor got his pails out of could be.<n>B. Rationales:  A pail could be in a wishing well or in a kitchen and a different pail could be in the garage.<n><n>#### F<n>Answer:<n>A. Explaining where the pail went:<n>Choices A-E:<n><n>* A: The janitor probably forgot where the pails were originally.<n><n>* B: The janitor may have dropped the pail on the floor, but it's more likely that he did that with the pails in the wishing well or the kitchen rather than a different pail that is in the garage.  <n>* C: The janitor may be able to use a different pail in the garage.   <n>* D: The janitor may need to buy a new pail at the garage.<n>* E: The janitor may not use the pail because it is not clean anymore.<n><n>C. Rationales: The janitor left his pails in the garage so he does not have to buy a new pails.<n><n>D. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Rationales: If he babysits for 2 hours at $7 per hour, he will earn 2*7 = $<<2*7=14>>14<n>This week he will earn $5 allowance, $10 mowing the lawn and $14 from babysitting for a total of 5+10+14 = $<<5+10+14=29>>29<n>If we add the $29 he will earn to his $65 savings, he will have a total of 29 + 65 = $<<29+65=94>>94<n>The bike costs $100 and he will have $94 leaving $100-$94 = $<<100-94=6>>6 more that he will need to earn<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Rationales: His kangaroos have a total of 23*2=<<23*2=46>>46 legs<n>He has 23*3=<<23*3=69>>69 goats<n>The goats have 69*4=<<69*4=276>>276 legs<n>So in total his animals have 276+46=<<276+46=322>>322 legs<n>#### 322<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Rationales: After buying a hat, Josh has $20 - $10 = $<<20-10=10>>10<n>After buying a pencil, Josh has $10 - $2 = $<<10-2=8>>8<n>The total cost of cookies is 4 * $1.25 = $<<4*1.25=5>>5<n>After buying the cookies, Josh has $8 - $5 = $<<8-5=3>>3<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input:Sally took her medicine and experienced strong side effects.  What did doctors say about the side effects? Choices:  A: great B: distinguished C: remarkable D: excellent E: peculiar<n><n>### Response:		Great<n><n><n>### Input<n>### Demonstraiton<n>### Rationales<n>### Answer<n><n>### Description:Write a response to the following prompt.<n>### The prompt is:<n>During his birthday party Ben requested to receive a large cupcake and a large jar of jelly for his party favor. Ben's party favor is equal to the difference between 1 more than the sum of his present bag and 3 times the sum of his present bottle and 2 less than the product of his present necklace and 4 less than the sum of his presents hat and 6. All Ben's presents were valued at dollar amounts. How much money exactly is Ben's party favor worth?<n>### Rational:The present in his bag and bottle is 86 and the bottle has 294 presents and the bag has 188 presents, 1 more than the bag or the bottle have 99, the party favor is 99-1+3+2-4-6-8= -10=99<n>### How to solve it with a diagram.<n>### The diagram starts in bag. it moves by adding value in the bag after receiving each present. There is no subtracting because the party favor is not present. There are 86 presents in the bag so the party favors value is 99 - 1 ( because bag already has 1 present) and bag will have  98. The present will move to the bottle and 99 will move to 99 + 3 = 102, 102 is more than 99 so it will move to 102 - 1 = 98. It will continue going through bag and bottle and by the time it gets to the next bottle, 5 presents will have been added to bag so it will move to  98 - 1 + 3 + 2 +6 = 102. Now when the party favor gets to bottle 2 it will move to  102 - 2 and then it will move to the bag and the party favorite will start with 98. When it gets to the second bag it will start with 99 + 1 = 100 and  100 - (2 less than bag) will equal 98

She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. Choices:  A: briefcase B: pocket C: friend's house D: office supply store E: classroom<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>### Demostration:If the pen costs $1.49 and you get $1.00 change, how much does the pen cost?<n><n>### Rationales:<n>The pen must cost less than $1.49 because the pen costs $1 and the change is $1.00.<n>Since the pen must cost more than $1.00 and cost less than $149 and the pen costs $149, this answer is not correct.<n>The pen must cost more than and the pen costs $2 because the pen costs $2.<n><n>#### 2<n>Answer: 2<n><n>### Instucton:What is 30 plus 5 times the square root of 105?<n><n>### Demstration:<n>Input:$30\times\sqrt{105} = $<<30\times\u001D105=1\:900>>1900<n><n>#### 1900<n>Answer: 1900

Ask students to provide a rationale to support their answer.<n><n><n>### Input<n>Amy has a large backpack full of school supplies. All of the supplies are inside her backpack. She has four pairs of shoes that require a total of 42 loops with a width of 8 loops. She has one scarf that needs 17 loops. She has 8 large socks that require 8 loops each. She has 6 pairs of smaller socks that each require 4 loops.  What is the maximum number of shoes she can wear without having to do any sewing to her items?<n>Rationales A backpack is similar to how school supplies would be used together.  Amy doesn't have any extra holes if she could fit four pairs on each sole; 4^17+4^20=4^37=<<4^37>>37<n>She also has 8 smaller socks that would each require 4 loops which is 8*4=<<8*4=32>>32<n>She would have 6 pairs of socks that together would use 6*4 = <<6*4=10>>11 and have 1 pair of shoes leftover to make 13 = <<13>>32<n><n>#### 32<n>Answer: 13<n><n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Rationales: If he babysits for 2 hours at $7 per hour, he will earn 2*7 = $<<2*7=14>>14<n>This week he will earn $5 allowance, $10 mowing the lawn and $14 from babysitting for a total of 5+10+14 = $<<5+10+14=29>>29<n>If we add the $29 he will earn to his $65 savings, he will have a total of 29 + 65 = $<<29+65=94>>94<n>The bike costs $100 and he will have $94 leaving $100-$94 = $<<100-94=6>>6 more that he will need to earn<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Rationales: His kangaroos have a total of 23*2=<<23*2=46>>46 legs<n>He has 23*3=<<23*3=69>>69 goats<n>The goats have 69*4=<<69*4=276>>276 legs<n>So in total his animals have 276+46=<<276+46=322>>322 legs<n>#### 322<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Rationales: After buying a hat, Josh has $20 - $10 = $<<20-10=10>>10<n>After buying a pencil, Josh has $10 - $2 = $<<10-2=8>>8<n>The total cost of cookies is 4 * $1.25 = $<<4*1.25=5>>5<n>After buying the cookies, Josh has $8 - $5 = $<<8-5=3>>3<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input:She was bad at dancing, so what basic skill did the instructor teach her? Choices:  A: euphoria B: rhythmic movement C: music D: moving body E: having fun<n><n>### Response:		D<n><n>### Input She took care of the pony,  gave it a name,  and did other things.  What other thing did she do? Choices: A: brush and feed her B: made sure she could talk C: play with her D: groom her E: clean the corral<n><n>### Response : C<n><n>### Input What can we tell about the pony’s name? Choices:  she named her pony “Bunny”  or “Barn” not “Barnie”  or “Barney” if they can’t know name<n><n>### Response A:  she named her horse Barny, or Barney<n><n><n>### Input You know your mom is your cousin because your mom had her, but you also know your sibling is your cousin too. Which of these facts best explain why that’s true? Choices:  your mom had your sibling too  A: Your mother has the same grandchildren and sisters as your sibling do.  B: Your sibling have the same grandfathers and cousins as your mother.  C: You are the child of your mother and your sibling is your mother’s child  D: Your mom is older than your sibling by one generation  E: You share the same paternal grandparents but the same grandmother’s.<n><n>### Response B<n><n>### Instructions:<n>You must use the information and your knowledge of punctuation marks to write the paragraph that follows the instructions. Add punctuation, as needed. Remember that it is important to check for errors.<n><n>### In the paragraph below, commas, periods, and question marks are not needed. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Rationales: If he babysits for 2 hours at $7 per hour, he will earn 2*7 = $<<2*7=14>>14<n>This week he will earn $5 allowance, $10 mowing the lawn and $14 from babysitting for a total of 5+10+14 = $<<5+10+14=29>>29<n>If we add the $29 he will earn to his $65 savings, he will have a total of 29 + 65 = $<<29+65=94>>94<n>The bike costs $100 and he will have $94 leaving $100-$94 = $<<100-94=6>>6 more that he will need to earn<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Rationales: His kangaroos have a total of 23*2=<<23*2=46>>46 legs<n>He has 23*3=<<23*3=69>>69 goats<n>The goats have 69*4=<<69*4=276>>276 legs<n>So in total his animals have 276+46=<<276+46=322>>322 legs<n>#### 322<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Rationales: After buying a hat, Josh has $20 - $10 = $<<20-10=10>>10<n>After buying a pencil, Josh has $10 - $2 = $<<10-2=8>>8<n>The total cost of cookies is 4 * $1.25 = $<<4*1.25=5>>5<n>After buying the cookies, Josh has $8 - $5 = $<<8-5=3>>3<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input:If a student was about to graduate, they would no longer be attending what? Choices:  A: library B: parties C: kindergarten class D: bar E: school<n><n>### Response:		A: library<n><n>## 2nd Task:<n><n>### Read carefully.<n><n>Instruction:Answer the following question correctly. Provide a brief rationale.<n><n>### Input:-5 -13 -2 = <<-5-13-2=-10>>-10<n><n>### Answer:-10<n><n>-10-13=<<-10-12=-2>>-2<n>Answer: -2<n><n>### Instructions:Answer the following question.<n><n>## Input: 50 + 2x + 4 = 100 Answer: 100<n><n>### Output: Input:80 x 20.6 + 15.8 +2.2 + 12 = 240.6 Output: 240.<n><n>###Input:-16 -8 -56 - 15 = -94 Output: -94<n><n>###Write your own solution.<n>Input: (-3)/(2x) -7 = 7 Output: 35<n>598=1300/8-1 Output: 860<n><n># 3rd Task: <n><n>### Instructios:Answer the following question correctl.<n><n>### Read the expression carefully, and provide a brief rationale to explain why the two answers are not the same.<n><n>7*9 + 6*6 + 10*5 + -3*(8 + 1) =<n><n>### Answer: 69<n><n>### Demostration:

His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Rationales: If he babysits for 2 hours at $7 per hour, he will earn 2*7 = $<<2*7=14>>14<n>This week he will earn $5 allowance, $10 mowing the lawn and $14 from babysitting for a total of 5+10+14 = $<<5+10+14=29>>29<n>If we add the $29 he will earn to his $65 savings, he will have a total of 29 + 65 = $<<29+65=94>>94<n>The bike costs $100 and he will have $94 leaving $100-$94 = $<<100-94=6>>6 more that he will need to earn<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Rationales: His kangaroos have a total of 23*2=<<23*2=46>>46 legs<n>He has 23*3=<<23*3=69>>69 goats<n>The goats have 69*4=<<69*4=276>>276 legs<n>So in total his animals have 276+46=<<276+46=322>>322 legs<n>#### 322<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Rationales: After buying a hat, Josh has $20 - $10 = $<<20-10=10>>10<n>After buying a pencil, Josh has $10 - $2 = $<<10-2=8>>8<n>The total cost of cookies is 4 * $1.25 = $<<4*1.25=5>>5<n>After buying the cookies, Josh has $8 - $5 = $<<8-5=3>>3<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input:Where may I view sharks in a clear tunnel? Choices:  A: south pacific B: sea world C: pacific ocean D: indian ocean E: gulf of mexico<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>Option A: A<n><n>### Answer:<n><n>#### 1<n>Answer: 1<n><n>### Input:(1): What do zebras have in common with pandas?<n><n>### Response:(1):  The have stripes or hair on their body.<n><n>### Answer:(1):<n><n>#### zebras have stripes<n><n>#### pandas have hair<n><n>#### 2<n><n>#### 2: The commonality<n><n>#### pandas and zebras both<n><n>#### 1 pandas and zebras<n><n>### Input (M):What do zebras have to common with pandas?<n>I believe that zebras have a commonality with pandas.<n><n>### Response (M):<n><n>Option A: B<n><n>### Answer (M):<n><n>#### A:  They have stripes.<n><n>#### B:  They are from Africa.<n><n>#### 2 pandas and zebras are<n><n>#### 2 zebras and pandas<n><n>### Input<n>During the Civil War, how many women traveled on the underground railroad?<n><n>### Rationales (2):<n><n>The answer to how many women travevelled on the underground railway is 40000<n><n>### Answer<n><n>#### 4000<n><n>#### 100002<n><n>################################################<n><n>### Instructions:Answer the following multiple-choice questions.<n><n>### Rationale:<n>**Option A:** This is the rationale part.<n>**Option B:** This is the answer to Option A.<n>**Option C:** The answer to Option B.<n>**Option D:** The answer to option C.<n>**Option E:** This is the final answer.<n><n>### Inputs:You have to drive from Chicago to Washington D.C. and it will take 52 hours if the distance is 999 miles. What is the speed of your car?<n><n>### Answer to Option A:<n>The answer to Option A is Option D.This happens because if the distance is 1 and the time is 52.If the distance is 1000 and the time is 1 it will take 1000/1 which is 1001 hours.In which case Option C will be the answer.
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Rationales: If he babysits for 2 hours at $7 per hour, he will earn 2*7 = $<<2*7=14>>14<n>This week he will earn $5 allowance, $10 mowing the lawn and $14 from babysitting for a total of 5+10+14 = $<<5+10+14=29>>29<n>If we add the $29 he will earn to his $65 savings, he will have a total of 29 + 65 = $<<29+65=94>>94<n>The bike costs $100 and he will have $94 leaving $100-$94 = $<<100-94=6>>6 more that he will need to earn<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Rationales: His kangaroos have a total of 23*2=<<23*2=46>>46 legs<n>He has 23*3=<<23*3=69>>69 goats<n>The goats have 69*4=<<69*4=276>>276 legs<n>So in total his animals have 276+46=<<276+46=322>>322 legs<n>#### 322<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Rationales: After buying a hat, Josh has $20 - $10 = $<<20-10=10>>10<n>After buying a pencil, Josh has $10 - $2 = $<<10-2=8>>8<n>The total cost of cookies is 4 * $1.25 = $<<4*1.25=5>>5<n>After buying the cookies, Josh has $8 - $5 = $<<8-5=3>>3<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input:Why would someone confess to committing murder? Choices:  A: guilty conscience B: fear C: go free D: problems E: find god<n><n>### Response:		<n>#### E<n>Input:Why would it be dangerous to get into an argument with a mad scientist? Choices: A: They might go crazy B: They might blow you up C: They may be a little crazy D: They may change you E: They might electrocute you<n><n>### Response<n>#### C<n>Input: When you're using a phonebook to find a phone number, the phonebook: ___ A: displays the name of the person you call if you dial 0 B: lists phone numbers separated by the number of the line C: tells you how to pronounce names you don't know D: is used to call people or to look up information E: is sometimes a phone<n><n>### Response :<n>#### D<n>Input: Which of these is the biggest number? How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Rationales: If he babysits for 2 hours at $7 per hour, he will earn 2*7 = $<<2*7=14>>14<n>This week he will earn $5 allowance, $10 mowing the lawn and $14 from babysitting for a total of 5+10+14 = $<<5+10+14=29>>29<n>If we add the $29 he will earn to his $65 savings, he will have a total of 29 + 65 = $<<29+65=94>>94<n>The bike costs $100 and he will have $94 leaving $100-$94 = $<<100-94=6>>6 more that he will need to earn<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Rationales: His kangaroos have a total of 23*2=<<23*2=46>>46 legs<n>He has 23*3=<<23*3=69>>69 goats<n>The goats have 69*4=<<69*4=276>>276 legs<n>So in total his animals have 276+46=<<276+46=322>>322 legs<n>#### 322<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Rationales: After buying a hat, Josh has $20 - $10 = $<<20-10=10>>10<n>After buying a pencil, Josh has $10 - $2 = $<<10-2=8>>8<n>The total cost of cookies is 4 * $1.25 = $<<4*1.25=5>>5<n>After buying the cookies, Josh has $8 - $5 = $<<8-5=3>>3<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input:What might the inability to learn cause? Choices:  A: intelligence B: education C: effectiveness D: distress E: a stupid<n><n>### Response:		Choice E: a stupid<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Rationales: If he babysits for 2 hours at $7 per hour, he will earn 2*7 = $<<2*7=14>>14<n>This week he will earn $5 allowance, $10 mowing the lawn and $14 from babysitting for a total of 5+10+14 = $<<5+10+14=29>>29<n>If we add the $29 he will earn to his $65 savings, he will have a total of 29 + 65 = $<<29+65=94>>94<n>The bike costs $100 and he will have $94 leaving $100-$94 = $<<100-94=6>>6 more that he will need to earn<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Rationales: His kangaroos have a total of 23*2=<<23*2=46>>46 legs<n>He has 23*3=<<23*3=69>>69 goats<n>The goats have 69*4=<<69*4=276>>276 legs<n>So in total his animals have 276+46=<<276+46=322>>322 legs<n>#### 322<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Rationales: After buying a hat, Josh has $20 - $10 = $<<20-10=10>>10<n>After buying a pencil, Josh has $10 - $2 = $<<10-2=8>>8<n>The total cost of cookies is 4 * $1.25 = $<<4*1.25=5>>5<n>After buying the cookies, Josh has $8 - $5 = $<<8-5=3>>3<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input:People were talking on the corner, who were they talking with? She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100. He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Rationales: If he babysits for 2 hours at $7 per hour, he will earn 2*7 = $<<2*7=14>>14<n>This week he will earn $5 allowance, $10 mowing the lawn and $14 from babysitting for a total of 5+10+14 = $<<5+10+14=29>>29<n>If we add the $29 he will earn to his $65 savings, he will have a total of 29 + 65 = $<<29+65=94>>94<n>The bike costs $100 and he will have $94 leaving $100-$94 = $<<100-94=6>>6 more that he will need to earn<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Rationales: After buying a hat, Josh has $20 - $10 = $<<20-10=10>>10<n>After buying a pencil, Josh has $10 - $2 = $<<10-2=8>>8<n>The total cost of cookies is 4 * $1.25 = $<<4*1.25=5>>5<n>After buying the cookies, Josh has $8 - $5 = $<<8-5=3>>3<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input:James wanted to stop competing. His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Rationales: If he babysits for 2 hours at $7 per hour, he will earn 2*7 = $<<2*7=14>>14<n>This week he will earn $5 allowance, $10 mowing the lawn and $14 from babysitting for a total of 5+10+14 = $<<5+10+14=29>>29<n>If we add the $29 he will earn to his $65 savings, he will have a total of 29 + 65 = $<<29+65=94>>94<n>The bike costs $100 and he will have $94 leaving $100-$94 = $<<100-94=6>>6 more that he will need to earn<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Rationales: His kangaroos have a total of 23*2=<<23*2=46>>46 legs<n>He has 23*3=<<23*3=69>>69 goats<n>The goats have 69*4=<<69*4=276>>276 legs<n>So in total his animals have 276+46=<<276+46=322>>322 legs<n>#### 322<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Rationales: After buying a hat, Josh has $20 - $10 = $<<20-10=10>>10<n>After buying a pencil, Josh has $10 - $2 = $<<10-2=8>>8<n>The total cost of cookies is 4 * $1.25 = $<<4*1.25=5>>5<n>After buying the cookies, Josh has $8 - $5 = $<<8-5=3>>3<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input:What should you do if your pens aren't work? Choices:  A: ink in B: caps C: ink cartridges D: take notes E: scribble<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>### Rationale:<n><n>### Answer<n><n>### Input<n><n>#### Recommendation:<n><n>#### 2<n>Answer: 2<n><n>### Input - Demo:<n><n>#### Output - Demo:<n><n>### <n><n>#### Input - Demo:<n>#### Output:<n><n>### Instructions<n><n>### Explanation:
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Rationales: If he babysits for 2 hours at $7 per hour, he will earn 2*7 = $<<2*7=14>>14<n>This week he will earn $5 allowance, $10 mowing the lawn and $14 from babysitting for a total of 5+10+14 = $<<5+10+14=29>>29<n>If we add the $29 he will earn to his $65 savings, he will have a total of 29 + 65 = $<<29+65=94>>94<n>The bike costs $100 and he will have $94 leaving $100-$94 = $<<100-94=6>>6 more that he will need to earn<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Rationales: His kangaroos have a total of 23*2=<<23*2=46>>46 legs<n>He has 23*3=<<23*3=69>>69 goats<n>The goats have 69*4=<<69*4=276>>276 legs<n>So in total his animals have 276+46=<<276+46=322>>322 legs<n>#### 322<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Rationales: After buying a hat, Josh has $20 - $10 = $<<20-10=10>>10<n>After buying a pencil, Josh has $10 - $2 = $<<10-2=8>>8<n>The total cost of cookies is 4 * $1.25 = $<<4*1.25=5>>5<n>After buying the cookies, Josh has $8 - $5 = $<<8-5=3>>3<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input:Where can you find a movie theater along with other stores in one placE? Choices:  A: downtown area B: urban area C: new york city D: shopping mall E: military base<n><n>### Response:		<n>C can be found in both the shopping mall and downtown area.<n><n>### Additional Instructions<n><n>#### How to interpret input-output pairs:<n><n>Input: In 2018 total U.S. exports amounted to approximately $2.1 trillion.<n>```<n>Rationales: *************<n><n>Output: The data represents the total amount of exports for the U.S. in 2018 at approximately $2.1 billion.<n>```<n><n>#### How to complete the request in response to input-output pairs:The graph below uses a scale of 1-10 to compare the 5 countries in order of GDP per capita.<n><n>### Input-output pairs:<n>```<n>Input:<n><n>Output:<n>```<n>#### How to respond to input-output pairs<n><n>The data represent the total exports for each of the 5 countries listed in the order of their GDP per capita in the table.<n>

She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100. She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100. He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Rationales: If he babysits for 2 hours at $7 per hour, he will earn 2*7 = $<<2*7=14>>14<n>This week he will earn $5 allowance, $10 mowing the lawn and $14 from babysitting for a total of 5+10+14 = $<<5+10+14=29>>29<n>If we add the $29 he will earn to his $65 savings, he will have a total of 29 + 65 = $<<29+65=94>>94<n>The bike costs $100 and he will have $94 leaving $100-$94 = $<<100-94=6>>6 more that he will need to earn<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Rationales: If he babysits for 2 hours at $7 per hour, he will earn 2*7 = $<<2*7=14>>14<n>This week he will earn $5 allowance, $10 mowing the lawn and $14 from babysitting for a total of 5+10+14 = $<<5+10+14=29>>29<n>If we add the $29 he will earn to his $65 savings, he will have a total of 29 + 65 = $<<29+65=94>>94<n>The bike costs $100 and he will have $94 leaving $100-$94 = $<<100-94=6>>6 more that he will need to earn<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Rationales: His kangaroos have a total of 23*2=<<23*2=46>>46 legs<n>He has 23*3=<<23*3=69>>69 goats<n>The goats have 69*4=<<69*4=276>>276 legs<n>So in total his animals have 276+46=<<276+46=322>>322 legs<n>#### 322<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Rationales: After buying a hat, Josh has $20 - $10 = $<<20-10=10>>10<n>After buying a pencil, Josh has $10 - $2 = $<<10-2=8>>8<n>The total cost of cookies is 4 * $1.25 = $<<4*1.25=5>>5<n>After buying the cookies, Josh has $8 - $5 = $<<8-5=3>>3<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input:The sanctions against the school were a punishing blow, and they seemed to what the efforts the school had made to change? Choices:  A: ignore B: enforce C: authoritarian D: yell at E: avoid<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>Incorrect<n>C)<n><n>Correct<n>B)<n><n>### Input::The book of Revelation contains visions of a new world.  These include a new temple and a new Jerusalem. Choices:  A) heaven B) hell C) space D) a new world E) the apocalypse<n><n>### Response<n><n>Incorrect<n>A)<n><n>Correct:<n>D)<n><n>### Instructions:<n>Input: The sanctions against the school will be a punishing blow for school efforts to change which seem to be ignored (a), enforced (b), authoritarian (c), yelled at (d), and avoided (e)?<n>Rationales: The sanctions will be a punishing (b) blow if ignored, enforced, authoritarian<n>If ignored, they (b) will be a punishing and if enforced they (b) will punish.<n>If authoritarian, they (c) will be an authoritarian (c) blow<n>If yelled at, they (d) will be a yelling (d) blow<n>If avoided, they (e) will be a blow to change (avoiding sanctions implies an effort to change)<n>If the changes are ignored (ignored efforts to change), they can be a punishing (punished) blow and will be ignored.<n>If the sanctions are enforced, they can be an authoritarian blow (authoritarian school sanctions)<n>If they are yelled at, they can be a blow to change.<n>If avoided, they can be a punishment for changes<n>The book of Revelations includes visions of a new (d) world.  These include (d) a temple (c) and (d) a new Jerusalem.<n>The book includes visions of a (d) new world (d) with a temple (c) that seems to be ignored (a).  This has (b) been an apocalypse (c) in the past.<n><n>#### 2<n>Answer:
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Rationales: If he babysits for 2 hours at $7 per hour, he will earn 2*7 = $<<2*7=14>>14<n>This week he will earn $5 allowance, $10 mowing the lawn and $14 from babysitting for a total of 5+10+14 = $<<5+10+14=29>>29<n>If we add the $29 he will earn to his $65 savings, he will have a total of 29 + 65 = $<<29+65=94>>94<n>The bike costs $100 and he will have $94 leaving $100-$94 = $<<100-94=6>>6 more that he will need to earn<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Rationales: His kangaroos have a total of 23*2=<<23*2=46>>46 legs<n>He has 23*3=<<23*3=69>>69 goats<n>The goats have 69*4=<<69*4=276>>276 legs<n>So in total his animals have 276+46=<<276+46=322>>322 legs<n>#### 322<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Rationales: After buying a hat, Josh has $20 - $10 = $<<20-10=10>>10<n>After buying a pencil, Josh has $10 - $2 = $<<10-2=8>>8<n>The total cost of cookies is 4 * $1.25 = $<<4*1.25=5>>5<n>After buying the cookies, Josh has $8 - $5 = $<<8-5=3>>3<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input:The fox walked from the city into the forest, what was it looking for? Choices:  A: pretty flowers. B: hen house C: natural habitat D: storybook E: dense forest<n><n>### Response:		<n>If it was the fox we would say it was looking for one or the other, but if it is a fox then we can be sure it is looking for a storybook :)<n><n>### Input<n>A student ate 5 burritos, 3 sandwiches and 2 quesadillas. Choices:  A: shirt pocket B: calligrapher's hand C: inkwell D: desk drawer E: blotter<n><n>### Response:		<n>A. Shirt pocket<n>B. Calligrapher's Hand<n>C. Inkwell<n>D. Desk Drawer<n><n>### Answer:<n>B. Calligramopher's Hand<n><n>### Instuction:<n>Answer the following multiple choice questions.<n><n>### Input1:<n>When you add a number of two-digit numbers together, the answer can be two digits long.  Can you explain why this works?<n><n>#### Explanation:<n>Two digit numbers can be added in groups.<n>Eg: 1+1= 2<n>2+4 = 6<n>3+6 = 9<n>5+2 = 7<n>5+3 = 8<n>6+2 = 8<n>7+1 = 8 etc.<n><n>### Response1:<n>Because we break the numbers into groups of two digits numbers, we get a answer.<n><n>####  Answer1:<n>A.<n>### Input2:<n>How many two-digit numbers can you make from the digits 0 to 4?<n><n>#### Explination:<n><n>We add 1 to the single digits to get a two digit number.<n><n>### Respons3:<n>2 4<n><n>####  Respons4:<n>C.<n>### Answer4:<n>A.<n><n>### Challenge Question:<n><n>Can you complete this puzzle?<n><n>Input: There is a small town.  The population of the town is the same as the number of dogs owned by the townspeople.  The population of this town is an odd number.  This is a problem because the town is required to send in an even number of dollars every week to the county to cover their share of county charges.  The mayor is worried about the town possibly having to pay a big fine because of their odd population number.  How can the mayor solve this problem?<n><n>#### Answer:<n><n>If everyone in town will buy a dog, the number will be even and the town will be able to send it out.<n><n>### Solution:<n><n>There are 2 dog owners in town. Therefore, there are $8-2=6$ numbers of dogs left to purchase for everyone else. Since we don't know how many dogs each person is buying, we can divide $6$ in $1+2+4+8$.

He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn. Choices:  A: state park B: bus depot C: garden D: gym E: rest area<n><n>### Response:		E<n><n>Input: John has $15<n>He pays $5 for a ticket to go to a baseball game with his brother.<n>How much money does he have left?<n><n>### Rationales:<n>If you subtract 5 dollars from $15, you're left with <<$5-15=10>>15.<n><n>Answer: $<<5-15=0>>0<n><n>### Direction: Read the following instructions carefully.<n>### Instruction A: Answer the following multiple choice question Choices: 1: A: 100 2: B: 150 3: C: 200 4: D: 3.735<n><n>### Instructions B:<n>Which part of the following response completes the prompt?<n><n>### C:<n><n>Choices: 1: (D, 2, 5 + 11 * 4 * 60)<n>1: $<<D,2,5+11*4*60>>402<n>2: (D, 0.3, 5 * 4 * 16)<n>1: $C: 0.3 * <<5*4*16>>64<n>2: (D, 9, 13 * 9)<n>1: $D: $<<13*9>>117<n>2: (D +, -, -, -)<n>2: $<<D+, -, -, +>>201<n>3: (D, 12, 50 * 4)<n>1: $>>D>720<n>2: ( D +1) 134<n>3: (D + 1/4)<n>$C: 134 * <<1/4>>25<n>4: (D + 4) 144<n>5: (D - 9) 129<n>6: (D * 15) 225<n>7: (D / 3)<n>$C : 225 / <<3>>7<n>8: (D - 2.4) 172<n>9: (D - 4.1 - 5)<n>$D: 5 * <<4.1>>4.1<n>1
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Rationales: After buying a hat, Josh has $20 - $10 = $<<20-10=10>>10<n>After buying a pencil, Josh has $10 - $2 = $<<10-2=8>>8<n>The total cost of cookies is 4 * $1.25 = $<<4*1.25=5>>5<n>After buying the cookies, Josh has $8 - $5 = $<<8-5=3>>3<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input:Sean was lying about the body, but he was very scared.  He constantly worried about what? Choices:  A: the reward money B: hurt feelings C: being found out D: problems E: trouble<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>#### A<n><n>Answer:<n>A<n><n>### Input<n><n>### If I use 3 apples to 2 oranges, how many of each fruit can I use to 16 ½ bananas?<n><n>### Response<n><n>#### C<n><n>Answer:<n>C<n><n>### Input <n>```<n>  - There is a total of 25 pounds of fish in the lake. <n>  - Fisherman A took 5 pounds of fish. When he took them away he left a total of 20 pounds of fish in the water. <n>  - 8 pounds of fish were taken away by fisherman B. When fisherman B took them away he left only 12 pounds of fish.<n>  - How much fish remained in the water when fisherman B took 8 pounds of fish?<n>```<n>### Response <n><n>#### A<n>  <n>- He left a total of 12 pounds of fih<n>- Fisherman B: He took 8 lbs of fish. When he finished and left, there 12 lbs left.<n><n>#### B<n><n>Answer:<n>B<n> <n>### Input<n>2 + 4<n><n>### Response 1<n><n>![](./read.jpg)<n><n>Response 2<n><n>https://imgur.com/gallery/9fOXfYP<n><n>### Input (Pen Pals)<n>```<n>Hi, my name is Kylie and I am 8 years old.<n><n>What is your name?<n><n>What is your favorite kind of animal?<n><n>My favorite kind of animals is a zebra and a crocodile because they are different.<n>Do you like animals too?<n><n>What is a day in your life like?<n><n>What do you like to do in your free time?<n>```<n>## Response<n><n>![](./penPalsResponse.png)<n><n>## Input (Food Chain)<n>```<n>There are 20 rabbits and 50 mice. An eagle needs to eat 3 rabbits a week.<n><n>How long will it take for the eagle to finish eating all the rabbits and the mice?<n>```<n><n>## Response<n><n>The response was to count the number of weeks.<n><n>Answer 1 was 10 weeks.<n><n>Answer2 was 1
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Rationales: If he babysits for 2 hours at $7 per hour, he will earn 2*7 = $<<2*7=14>>14<n>This week he will earn $5 allowance, $10 mowing the lawn and $14 from babysitting for a total of 5+10+14 = $<<5+10+14=29>>29<n>If we add the $29 he will earn to his $65 savings, he will have a total of 29 + 65 = $<<29+65=94>>94<n>The bike costs $100 and he will have $94 leaving $100-$94 = $<<100-94=6>>6 more that he will need to earn<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Rationales: His kangaroos have a total of 23*2=<<23*2=46>>46 legs<n>He has 23*3=<<23*3=69>>69 goats<n>The goats have 69*4=<<69*4=276>>276 legs<n>So in total his animals have 276+46=<<276+46=322>>322 legs<n>#### 322<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Rationales: After buying a hat, Josh has $20 - $10 = $<<20-10=10>>10<n>After buying a pencil, Josh has $10 - $2 = $<<10-2=8>>8<n>The total cost of cookies is 4 * $1.25 = $<<4*1.25=5>>5<n>After buying the cookies, Josh has $8 - $5 = $<<8-5=3>>3<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input:Joe suffered many consequences from stabbing a stranger to death.   Among them, the family of the victim did something to him. What was that? Choices:  A: knife wounds B: buy a gun C: bleeding D: jail time E: law suit<n><n>### Response:		<n>Input: Joe suffered many consequences from stabing a stranger to death...A: knife woundsB: buy a gunC: bleedingD: jail timeE: law suite<n><n>#### <n>Answer: <n><n>### Demostration:<n>Input: The man with the beans is 8 foot tall.  His pet is 1 foot tall.  How tall is his 13 foot tall dog?<n>Rationales:# The man is 8 ft tall<n># The man's pet is 1 ft tall<n># The dog's height is 1ft times 2=<<1ft*2=2ft>>2ft<n># The man'a dog is 13-2 or 11 ft tall<n>#### <n><n>### Question: <n><n>## Instruction:<n>Read the sentence that includes the error. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100. He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Rationales: If he babysits for 2 hours at $7 per hour, he will earn 2*7 = $<<2*7=14>>14<n>This week he will earn $5 allowance, $10 mowing the lawn and $14 from babysitting for a total of 5+10+14 = $<<5+10+14=29>>29<n>If we add the $29 he will earn to his $65 savings, he will have a total of 29 + 65 = $<<29+65=94>>94<n>The bike costs $100 and he will have $94 leaving $100-$94 = $<<100-94=6>>6 more that he will need to earn<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Rationales: If he babysits for 2 hours at $7 per hour, he will earn 2*7 = $<<2*7=14>>14<n>This week he will earn $5 allowance, $10 mowing the lawn and $14 from babysitting for a total of 5+10+14 = $<<5+10+14=29>>29<n>If we add the $29 he will earn to his $65 savings, he will have a total of 29 + 65 = $<<29+65=94>>94<n>The bike costs $100 and he will have $94 leaving $100-$94 = $<<100-94=6>>6 more that he will need to earn<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Rationales: His kangaroos have a total of 23*2=<<23*2=46>>46 legs<n>He has 23*3=<<23*3=69>>69 goats<n>The goats have 69*4=<<69*4=276>>276 legs<n>So in total his animals have 276+46=<<276+46=322>>322 legs<n>#### 322<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Rationales: After buying a hat, Josh has $20 - $10 = $<<20-10=10>>10<n>After buying a pencil, Josh has $10 - $2 = $<<10-2=8>>8<n>The total cost of cookies is 4 * $1.25 = $<<4*1.25=5>>5<n>After buying the cookies, Josh has $8 - $5 = $<<8-5=3>>3<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input:What is a person chatting with friends likely hoping to accomplish? Choices:  A: gathering of information B: communication C: feel relaxed D: kill boredom E: social bonding<n><n>### Response:		<n>Rationales:  Choices are mutually exclusive: {A,B,C,D,E}<n>Since the choices are mutually exclusive, you will need to count the number of times each choice occurs and subtract that from the total.<n>Ideally you should have a unique count for each answer, if this is the case you can just take the difference.<n>I will use {{A},{C},{E}}<n>#### 4<n>Answer: 6-2-5=<<6-2-5>>6-2-5<n><n>### Instructions:<n><n><img src="assets/img/instructions_0000-2.png"><p>Click on the number that indicates how many more triangles  than are in the original triangle.  (Hint: The solution is a <p><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Infinite_triangle">infinite triangle</a>.)</p><n><n>### Instructor’s Note:<n>This math-only task was not originally written for Cognitive Coaching but rather is used by the instructor as a pre-test for a math class.  Students’ responses, both correct and incorrect, are used together with in-class instruction to create an individual learning plan for students during the semester.<n><n>### Student Name:

He tells his client is to detect an intruder in a room.<n><n>### Response<n>Input:(the installation expert has a new Order to Install a brand  new motion detector and explains to the client what he uses this kind of sensor to detect : )<n>Rationales: Motion detectors are made to detect movement from a device.  We use this device to protect our houses from intruders.<n>If there is no movement from the device, there should not be any need to notify the police,  therefore, the police might not respond to a false alarm caused by such motion detectors.<n>#### 18<n>Answer: 18
