His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Rationales: If he babysits for 2 hours at $7 per hour, he will earn 2*7 = $<<2*7=14>>14<n>This week he will earn $5 allowance, $10 mowing the lawn and $14 from babysitting for a total of 5+10+14 = $<<5+10+14=29>>29<n>If we add the $29 he will earn to his $65 savings, he will have a total of 29 + 65 = $<<29+65=94>>94<n>The bike costs $100 and he will have $94 leaving $100-$94 = $<<100-94=6>>6 more that he will need to earn<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Rationales: His kangaroos have a total of 23*2=<<23*2=46>>46 legs<n>He has 23*3=<<23*3=69>>69 goats<n>The goats have 69*4=<<69*4=276>>276 legs<n>So in total his animals have 276+46=<<276+46=322>>322 legs<n>#### 322<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Rationales: After buying a hat, Josh has $20 - $10 = $<<20-10=10>>10<n>After buying a pencil, Josh has $10 - $2 = $<<10-2=8>>8<n>The total cost of cookies is 4 * $1.25 = $<<4*1.25=5>>5<n>After buying the cookies, Josh has $8 - $5 = $<<8-5=3>>3<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input:Where would you see some people doing jumping jacks? Choices:  A: military base B: opera C: water fountain D: bus stop E: church<n><n>### Response:		<n>#### C<n>Answer: C <n>B.J. Simmons <bjs@example.com><n><n>#### E<n>Answer: E<n><n>### Instructions:Answer the following multiple-choice question.<n><n>## Demonstration:Write a rational for the answer if needed.<n><n>Input: In order to keep her balance in her hula hooping, Jazmin must spin it at least 8 times in 23 seconds.<n>Rationales: She needs to keep the hula hoop off the ground for enough time to spin at least eight times.  Each rotation around the waist takes 4/3 sec. How many rotations does she need to make?<n>So, after x rotations Jazmin will need to have her hula hoop off of the ground so that it spins at least 8 times <n>In order to do this she needs 8/6 rotations to keep the hula going for the exact amount of time needed.<n><n>#### 8/6<n>Answer: 8/6<n><n>### Demostration 2:<n>Input: If a basketball player scores 9 free throws in a row without missing, the probability that he will finally miss during one of the last three free throws that he takes is<n><n>Rationales: the first 7 free throws,  a total of 6 are "successful" and there are 1 "free" so there is a 0% chance that the 6th free throw is unsuccessful after so many more successes<n><n>The probability for the 7th free throw is 0% because it has already met the conditions for all the other free throws<n>For instance if 7 successful free throws are "successful" then the 8th is also successful.<n><n>0% is a percentage so if we add the 7 successful free throws to the 8th % then we get 7*0% +8*0% = 0<n>That means the probability that a basketball player will miss a free throw in his 3rd to last free throw will be exactly 0.0%<n><n>Since the 8th free throw is unsuccesful the player can keep up the momentum. This means that the probability that he will miss the 9th free throw will be exactly the same as before.<n>(Therefore he is free to continue the same trend
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Rationales: If he babysits for 2 hours at $7 per hour, he will earn 2*7 = $<<2*7=14>>14<n>This week he will earn $5 allowance, $10 mowing the lawn and $14 from babysitting for a total of 5+10+14 = $<<5+10+14=29>>29<n>If we add the $29 he will earn to his $65 savings, he will have a total of 29 + 65 = $<<29+65=94>>94<n>The bike costs $100 and he will have $94 leaving $100-$94 = $<<100-94=6>>6 more that he will need to earn<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Rationales: His kangaroos have a total of 23*2=<<23*2=46>>46 legs<n>He has 23*3=<<23*3=69>>69 goats<n>The goats have 69*4=<<69*4=276>>276 legs<n>So in total his animals have 276+46=<<276+46=322>>322 legs<n>#### 322<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Rationales: After buying a hat, Josh has $20 - $10 = $<<20-10=10>>10<n>After buying a pencil, Josh has $10 - $2 = $<<10-2=8>>8<n>The total cost of cookies is 4 * $1.25 = $<<4*1.25=5>>5<n>After buying the cookies, Josh has $8 - $5 = $<<8-5=3>>3<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input:Where is there usually a fiddle playing? Choices:  A: music store B: dance hall C: orchestra D: symphony E: tennessee<n><n>### Response:		<n>Fiddle can be playing in a music store (B), a dance hall (A), symphony (D), tennessee (E), or an orchestra (C).<n><n>Answer: B<n><n>### Input : John bought his wife 1 dozen roses for Valentine's Day. How many roses does he get for his money? <n>A: 3 dozen Roses<n>B: 2 dozen Roses<n>C: 4 dozen Roses<n>D: 1 Dozen Roses<n><n>### Response : Answer: C
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Rationales: If he babysits for 2 hours at $7 per hour, he will earn 2*7 = $<<2*7=14>>14<n>This week he will earn $5 allowance, $10 mowing the lawn and $14 from babysitting for a total of 5+10+14 = $<<5+10+14=29>>29<n>If we add the $29 he will earn to his $65 savings, he will have a total of 29 + 65 = $<<29+65=94>>94<n>The bike costs $100 and he will have $94 leaving $100-$94 = $<<100-94=6>>6 more that he will need to earn<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Rationales: His kangaroos have a total of 23*2=<<23*2=46>>46 legs<n>He has 23*3=<<23*3=69>>69 goats<n>The goats have 69*4=<<69*4=276>>276 legs<n>So in total his animals have 276+46=<<276+46=322>>322 legs<n>#### 322<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Rationales: After buying a hat, Josh has $20 - $10 = $<<20-10=10>>10<n>After buying a pencil, Josh has $10 - $2 = $<<10-2=8>>8<n>The total cost of cookies is 4 * $1.25 = $<<4*1.25=5>>5<n>After buying the cookies, Josh has $8 - $5 = $<<8-5=3>>3<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input:What do drugs do? Choices:  A: damage B: cloud mind C: lower i.q D: cause illness E: cause accidents<n><n>### Response:		I found this problem difficult and chose to use google chrome in order to help me solve this problem.<n><n><n>### Answer:Answer= E   Drugs damage our organs or our brain.<n><n>### Citation:I citation from: https://sites.wesleyan.edu/wescomputerscience2020/wp-content/uploads/sites/443/2020/08/Syllabus.pdf<n>### References:(Kuhn et. al, 2020)

She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100. He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn. Choices:  A: hole B: television C: sporting goods store D: pool table E: sporting event<n><n>### Response:		I would see people in uniform playing at a sporting event.  A: hole: Where to put the ball on a golf course | B: television: watching tv showing people who wear a costume playing a sporting game | C: sporting goods: shopping for gear, glove, shinny pants, a ball etc. | D: pool table: game of pool | E: sporting event: watching sporting games being played |<n><n>### Input (Answer): The answer is option "E". Then I determined that we don't see people in a pool that are wearing a costume.<n><n>### Output (Input): If the "a" in "fruit salad" were capitalized, it would be "Fruit salad".<n><n>### Input(Output):<n>The apple is called “fruit”. For example "A is the first letter in the alphabet, its place in the alphabet is 1, so 1+1=2, so the first word in english has a value of 2." (repeat the process, and add up the total of the final, last digit)<n><n>### Output/(Input):<n>In this question, the first and last letter in the alphabet has a value of number 5, then the sum of the first and last letter's value is 5. so, 5+5=10, 10 takes away 5 and ends with 5, so the answer would be 5 because 5+5= 10 remove the number 10 and you have 5

Choices:  A: student union B: mall C: department store D: library E: town or city<n><n>### Response:		She needs to purchase a book from a bookshop, which can only be found at a library. We can assume that a library is a type of bookshop based on this instruction.<n><n>### Input :How can I go to the bookshop in my village while on holiday? Choices: 1: bus 2: taxi 3: plane 4: train 5: car<n><n>### Response :1 & 5 are the only transport options to travel to the village, which only offers transportation through trains or buses.<n><n>### Output: How long does it take if I take an express train? Answer: 25 minutes<n><n>### Explanation:Express trains travel the longest distances the fastest. They also have the highest speed limits and are only available in big cities.<n><n>### Question : Can I go home by taking a bus? Answer: yes, the bus service has been suspended due to the weather<n><n>### Explantation : Bus services can only be canceled in extreme weather conditions.<n><n>### Exlanation : Buses are the only public transportation services available in villages.<n><n>### What other methods are there of transport to use?<n><n>### Explantation : Bikes can also be used to access many villages and towns.<n><n>### How long does the bike take?<n><n>### Answer : Bikes take 30 minutes to travel the distance<n><n>### Why is a bike faster in distance than by foot?<n><n>### Bikes have been optimized by manufacturers to attain the most minimal drag<n><n>### Bicycles are lighter than humans.<n><n>### Bikers spend less time in motion so they attain higher efficiencies when transporting compared to walking.<n><n>### Conclusion<n><n>### A bicycle has been selected for use to access villages from the city. Its duration to cover the specific distance took 30 minutes as opposed to walking which would take approximately 45 minutes. If an express train had been in use at the time would have covered the distance within less than 15 minutes. Bikes, on the other hand, are ideal for use in short distances of less than 20 - 25 kilometers.

If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Rationales: His kangaroos have a total of 23*2=<<23*2=46>>46 legs<n>He has 23*3=<<23*3=69>>69 goats<n>The goats have 69*4=<<69*4=276>>276 legs<n>So in total his animals have 276+46=<<276+46=322>>322 legs<n>#### 322<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Rationales: After buying a hat, Josh has $20 - $10 = $<<20-10=10>>10<n>After buying a pencil, Josh has $10 - $2 = $<<10-2=8>>8<n>The total cost of cookies is 4 * $1.25 = $<<4*1.25=5>>5<n>After buying the cookies, Josh has $8 - $5 = $<<8-5=3>>3<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input:The man went to clown college, he had always want to run away with the what? Choices:  A: circus B: carnival C: surprise D: spoons E: party<n><n>### Response:		The man went to clowns college, he had always wanted to run away with the party.<n>The clue says that he went to the college with his choice of word for circus.  A is not the same as circus B is not the same as the circus and c is different again.  D is the same as clowns so that is already wrong.<n>C and D are close but D is the circus and D is Clowns.<n>That leaves circus and A, which A = party.<n><n>### Input (demonstration instruction 2):The farmer bought 800 acres of grassland. She sold 16 acres of it, and she got rid of 45 bales of straw. The remainder is only 23.5 acres. How many acres are left?<n><n>### Rationales: She bought 800-16-45 = 739 acres.<n><n>### Answer: 739<n><n>### Input : Write a number sentence that appropriately completes this statement.<n><n>### Rationale: Since you started from 800 acres minus 16 acres minus 45 bales it leaves 739 acres<n><n>### Answer : **739** acres of grass.<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Rationales: If he babysits for 2 hours at $7 per hour, he will earn 2*7 = $<<2*7=14>>14<n>This week he will earn $5 allowance, $10 mowing the lawn and $14 from babysitting for a total of 5+10+14 = $<<5+10+14=29>>29<n>If we add the $29 he will earn to his $65 savings, he will have a total of 29 + 65 = $<<29+65=94>>94<n>The bike costs $100 and he will have $94 leaving $100-$94 = $<<100-94=6>>6 more that he will need to earn<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Rationales: His kangaroos have a total of 23*2=<<23*2=46>>46 legs<n>He has 23*3=<<23*3=69>>69 goats<n>The goats have 69*4=<<69*4=276>>276 legs<n>So in total his animals have 276+46=<<276+46=322>>322 legs<n>#### 322<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Rationales: After buying a hat, Josh has $20 - $10 = $<<20-10=10>>10<n>After buying a pencil, Josh has $10 - $2 = $<<10-2=8>>8<n>The total cost of cookies is 4 * $1.25 = $<<4*1.25=5>>5<n>After buying the cookies, Josh has $8 - $5 = $<<8-5=3>>3<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input:He was receiving workman's compensation, he had tripped over a metal rod while building where? Choices:  A: factory B: construction site C: engine D: insides of skyscraper's walls E: shops<n><n>### Response:		D.<n><n><n><n><n><n>### Instructions:Rewrite the sentences below in the format of "He wants" followed by: "to buy a car" followed by "for his mother to find a job for him"<n><n>#### Instruction:He wants to buy a TV for his mother to find a new job for him<n><n>### Response<n><n>"He wants to buy a car for his mother."<n>#### Instructions:He wants her to have a dog to be a good mom<n><n>### Response <n><n>"He wants her to be a good mom."<n>#### Instruction:<n><n>### Solution: <n><n>#### Instruction:: <n><n>###Response<n>" He wants to eat a chocolate chip cookie for his brother to lose weights"<n><n>#### Instructions::<n><n>###Solution:<n>"He wants to eat a cheesecake for his brother to gain weights"<n><n>####Instructions:::<n><n>##Solution:<n>```<n>" He wants his parents to buy him a new video game for his little brother to have a new toy"<n>```<n><n><n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Rationales: If he babysits for 2 hours at $7 per hour, he will earn 2*7 = $<<2*7=14>>14<n>This week he will earn $5 allowance, $10 mowing the lawn and $14 from babysitting for a total of 5+10+14 = $<<5+10+14=29>>29<n>If we add the $29 he will earn to his $65 savings, he will have a total of 29 + 65 = $<<29+65=94>>94<n>The bike costs $100 and he will have $94 leaving $100-$94 = $<<100-94=6>>6 more that he will need to earn<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Rationales: His kangaroos have a total of 23*2=<<23*2=46>>46 legs<n>He has 23*3=<<23*3=69>>69 goats<n>The goats have 69*4=<<69*4=276>>276 legs<n>So in total his animals have 276+46=<<276+46=322>>322 legs<n>#### 322<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Rationales: After buying a hat, Josh has $20 - $10 = $<<20-10=10>>10<n>After buying a pencil, Josh has $10 - $2 = $<<10-2=8>>8<n>The total cost of cookies is 4 * $1.25 = $<<4*1.25=5>>5<n>After buying the cookies, Josh has $8 - $5 = $<<8-5=3>>3<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input:The student needed to  get some new pencils, where did he go? Choices:  A: store B: classroom C: backpack D: cabinet E: teacher<n><n>### Response:		Choice:  C -> classroom<n><n>### Input:"How many stars have you got?" she asked,  "5" he replied. How many has she got?  Choices:  A)4  B)3  C)5  D)6. Answer: D)6<n><n>### Response:"How many stars have I got", She said,   "5", I replied.<n><n>### Input1:There are 2 muffins left.  Mary takes 1.  How many muffins are left?<n>Input2: There are 7 apples left.  Mary takes half.  How many apples are left?<n><n>### Response1: 7 - 1 = 6<n><n>### Instructions:<n>Answer the following multiple choice questions.<n><n>#### Instruction:<n><n>### Input2: There are four apples left.   Mary takes half.   How many apples are lef?<n>#### Input:<n>Rationales:<n>- Mary's total consumption = 4-H(4/2)=7<n>- 2*H=1 so Mary consumes 7 apples.<n><n>#### Answer:<n><n>### Instuctions:<n>Use the following hints to answer the questions:<n><n>#### Input:<n>#### Instruction:There are 7 apples.  Each student can eat 3 apples.  Mary eats her 3 apples before everyone else does.  How many appes are left?<n>#### Rationales:<n>####<n>####<n><n>#### Input:There are  7 orange apples.  Each girl in a girl scout troop consumes six apples.  Six girls consume their apples at the same time.  If each of the remaining apples is eaten by a different scout with a different number of other apples eaten, is each scout eating a different number of apples or exactly the same number as the other scouts?<n>- The order of students eating the apples does not impact the answer:<n><n>#### <n>####<n>####<n>####<n>If your order is random and no one eats enough apples to get a full share, they end up with each eating 6 and thus they all would end up with different apples.<n>So it does not matter how the scouts eat them or in what order.<n>####<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Rationales: If he babysits for 2 hours at $7 per hour, he will earn 2*7 = $<<2*7=14>>14<n>This week he will earn $5 allowance, $10 mowing the lawn and $14 from babysitting for a total of 5+10+14 = $<<5+10+14=29>>29<n>If we add the $29 he will earn to his $65 savings, he will have a total of 29 + 65 = $<<29+65=94>>94<n>The bike costs $100 and he will have $94 leaving $100-$94 = $<<100-94=6>>6 more that he will need to earn<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats. Choices:  A: desk drawer B: desktop C: office D: wristwatch E: city hall<n><n>### Response:		<n>If the calculator is used regularly, then it is essential for the accountant to have one at his office so he can use it for his daily work.<n>Alternatively, he can own it for his personal use when not working and keep it on his desk at home.<n>Furthermore, one can argue to have both since the latter serves as a backup when the former is unusable.<n><n>#### B<n>Answer: B<n><n>### Input<n>Sarah goes to the store and buys six 500ml bottles of juice.  Each one costs 99 cents.  If Sarah’s total price is $58.40, how many bottles of juice does he drink in a week?<n><n>### Rationale<n>If total price is $50.40, and each bottle costs 99 cense each, then the number of bottles is 50.4/99 = <<50.4/1=5.04>>5.04<n><n>#### 5.04<n>Answer: 5.04

How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Rationales: If he babysits for 2 hours at $7 per hour, he will earn 2*7 = $<<2*7=14>>14<n>This week he will earn $5 allowance, $10 mowing the lawn and $14 from babysitting for a total of 5+10+14 = $<<5+10+14=29>>29<n>If we add the $29 he will earn to his $65 savings, he will have a total of 29 + 65 = $<<29+65=94>>94<n>The bike costs $100 and he will have $94 leaving $100-$94 = $<<100-94=6>>6 more that he will need to earn<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Rationales: His kangaroos have a total of 23*2=<<23*2=46>>46 legs<n>He has 23*3=<<23*3=69>>69 goats<n>The goats have 69*4=<<69*4=276>>276 legs<n>So in total his animals have 276+46=<<276+46=322>>322 legs<n>#### 322<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Rationales: After buying a hat, Josh has $20 - $10 = $<<20-10=10>>10<n>After buying a pencil, Josh has $10 - $2 = $<<10-2=8>>8<n>The total cost of cookies is 4 * $1.25 = $<<4*1.25=5>>5<n>After buying the cookies, Josh has $8 - $5 = $<<8-5=3>>3<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input:It was a great rest, she had never felt this much what in the morning? Choices:  A: active B: hunger C: in motion D: wakefulness E: lay down<n><n>### Response:		<n>### D<n><n>### Input It has 12 pages, 54 sentences, and 224 words. Choices:  A B C D E F G<n><n>### Response F<n><n><n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Rationales: If he babysits for 2 hours at $7 per hour, he will earn 2*7 = $<<2*7=14>>14<n>This week he will earn $5 allowance, $10 mowing the lawn and $14 from babysitting for a total of 5+10+14 = $<<5+10+14=29>>29<n>If we add the $29 he will earn to his $65 savings, he will have a total of 29 + 65 = $<<29+65=94>>94<n>The bike costs $100 and he will have $94 leaving $100-$94 = $<<100-94=6>>6 more that he will need to earn<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs. If you got A's on your other tests, write the sum of the grades you got.<n><n>### Rationales:I got 18 on the last test which is <<18>>18 on the last<n>test. I got A on my other tests so the next total will be <<18+A's on other tests>>total which will be <<18+(A+A+A)=36>>36<n>If I need to get 99 to get A, 99-36 will be <<99-36=63>>63<n>#### 63<n>Answer: 63<n><n>### Instructions:What is the sum of two whole numbers?<n><n>### Instroctions:<n><n>### Rationale:The whole numbers are: 1,2,3,4,5,etc<n><n>### Ratiu:0.5 is half (which is also called even)<n><n>### Ration for 2:2+0.5 = <<2+1/2=3>>3<n><n>### Ratian:1+1/2 = >>1+1/2=1+1/2>>1.5<n><n>### Answer:4<n><n>### Input for 3: 8 is the sum of a single digit and a double-digit number. What could they add to make it a triple-digit number? Choices: 1, 10, 100, 200,300<n><n>### Instuctions:<n>Instructions:<n>```<n>If you got 73% in math 2, you need to get 90% on this test to get an A. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Rationales: If he babysits for 2 hours at $7 per hour, he will earn 2*7 = $<<2*7=14>>14<n>This week he will earn $5 allowance, $10 mowing the lawn and $14 from babysitting for a total of 5+10+14 = $<<5+10+14=29>>29<n>If we add the $29 he will earn to his $65 savings, he will have a total of 29 + 65 = $<<29+65=94>>94<n>The bike costs $100 and he will have $94 leaving $100-$94 = $<<100-94=6>>6 more that he will need to earn<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Rationales: His kangaroos have a total of 23*2=<<23*2=46>>46 legs<n>He has 23*3=<<23*3=69>>69 goats<n>The goats have 69*4=<<69*4=276>>276 legs<n>So in total his animals have 276+46=<<276+46=322>>322 legs<n>#### 322<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Rationales: After buying a hat, Josh has $20 - $10 = $<<20-10=10>>10<n>After buying a pencil, Josh has $10 - $2 = $<<10-2=8>>8<n>The total cost of cookies is 4 * $1.25 = $<<4*1.25=5>>5<n>After buying the cookies, Josh has $8 - $5 = $<<8-5=3>>3<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input:The new play was the go to performance of the year, all the crowds would stand and what? How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100. He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Rationales: If he babysits for 2 hours at $7 per hour, he will earn 2*7 = $<<2*7=14>>14<n>This week he will earn $5 allowance, $10 mowing the lawn and $14 from babysitting for a total of 5+10+14 = $<<5+10+14=29>>29<n>If we add the $29 he will earn to his $65 savings, he will have a total of 29 + 65 = $<<29+65=94>>94<n>The bike costs $100 and he will have $94 leaving $100-$94 = $<<100-94=6>>6 more that he will need to earn<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats. If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Rationales: His kangaroos have a total of 23*2=<<23*2=46>>46 legs<n>He has 23*3=<<23*3=69>>69 goats<n>The goats have 69*4=<<69*4=276>>276 legs<n>So in total his animals have 276+46=<<276+46=322>>322 legs<n>#### 322<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Rationales: If he babysits for 2 hours at $7 per hour, he will earn 2*7 = $<<2*7=14>>14<n>This week he will earn $5 allowance, $10 mowing the lawn and $14 from babysitting for a total of 5+10+14 = $<<5+10+14=29>>29<n>If we add the $29 he will earn to his $65 savings, he will have a total of 29 + 65 = $<<29+65=94>>94<n>The bike costs $100 and he will have $94 leaving $100-$94 = $<<100-94=6>>6 more that he will need to earn<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Rationales: His kangaroos have a total of 23*2=<<23*2=46>>46 legs<n>He has 23*3=<<23*3=69>>69 goats<n>The goats have 69*4=<<69*4=276>>276 legs<n>So in total his animals have 276+46=<<276+46=322>>322 legs<n>#### 322<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Rationales: After buying a hat, Josh has $20 - $10 = $<<20-10=10>>10<n>After buying a pencil, Josh has $10 - $2 = $<<10-2=8>>8<n>The total cost of cookies is 4 * $1.25 = $<<4*1.25=5>>5<n>After buying the cookies, Josh has $8 - $5 = $<<8-5=3>>3<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input:Where would someone learn to play an upright piano? Choices:  A: music room B: music store C: music class D: medium E: house<n><n>### Response:		<n>- The correct answer is “A: music room.”<n><n>### Input<n>- A woman went to the bank to get some checks made and she has to put in her name and address on them. After she filled them out her bank assistant said she would keep them on file, so she doesn’t have to fill them in again. If the bank keeps her checks on file, do they need her name and address on each check? Choices: A: Yes B: No<n>Rationales: The bank keeps her checks on files and therefore, do not need name and address on each of her check.<n><n>- When she asked for cash, her assistant said that she has to fill out check before she’ll cash it. And she said she’s very sorry because you can’t do that. If they don’t want her to fill out the checks, why do they give them to her? Choices: A. Because she needs to give them her name and address B. To make sure the checks she gave them were good C. Her name and address are already printed on them D. Because she needs to fill her name and address on checks.<n>Rationales: Her assistant said she needs to give them name and address on each checks. The option A is correct.<n><n>- If you get change from a store, you’ve got to give them back the exact amount of money that they gave you. If you pay for a doll with a $10 bill, that’s $10 too much. You should give the store $10 dollars back in change. If the shopkeeper doesn’t want the extra change, what should you do? Choices: A) give it back to the cashier (not the other customer who gave you the money) B) make change for the cashier (don’t give the change back to the other customer) C) return the doll D) give the change to the shopkeeper E) write a check to the store If you pay for a toy with a $10 dollar bill, that’s too much. You should return the doll to the shopkeeper.
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Rationales: If he babysits for 2 hours at $7 per hour, he will earn 2*7 = $<<2*7=14>>14<n>This week he will earn $5 allowance, $10 mowing the lawn and $14 from babysitting for a total of 5+10+14 = $<<5+10+14=29>>29<n>If we add the $29 he will earn to his $65 savings, he will have a total of 29 + 65 = $<<29+65=94>>94<n>The bike costs $100 and he will have $94 leaving $100-$94 = $<<100-94=6>>6 more that he will need to earn<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Rationales: His kangaroos have a total of 23*2=<<23*2=46>>46 legs<n>He has 23*3=<<23*3=69>>69 goats<n>The goats have 69*4=<<69*4=276>>276 legs<n>So in total his animals have 276+46=<<276+46=322>>322 legs<n>#### 322<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Rationales: After buying a hat, Josh has $20 - $10 = $<<20-10=10>>10<n>After buying a pencil, Josh has $10 - $2 = $<<10-2=8>>8<n>The total cost of cookies is 4 * $1.25 = $<<4*1.25=5>>5<n>After buying the cookies, Josh has $8 - $5 = $<<8-5=3>>3<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input:Who is likely going in to a market? Choices:  A: stress B: food C: that you D: spending money E: walking<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>### Instructions:Answer the following multiple-choice question.<n>Input: If a person is stressed, they may also eat healthy foods.  A person who is happy is more likely going in to a grocery store than anyone who is stressing out or eating unhealthy foods.  Who is likely going in to the grocery store?<n>Rationales/Answer: Stressed out individuals are less likely shopping in the grocery store<n>I know I was stressing out to avoid the grocery<n><n>### Input<n>A: Stressed B: that person C: eat food D: walking E: stress<n>```Rationales/Answer<n>Stressed out individuals less likely to go on to the grocery <n>```<n><n>### Input A:<n>```B: That person```<n><n>### Response A:<n>```B```<n><n>### Instructors:<n>Answer the following multiple choice Questions.<n><n>### Input C:<n>```D: Spending Money```<n><n>### Rationales/Answer:<n>Stressed out individuals are less like going in to the grocey for the spending money<n>Grocery<n><n>### Answer:<n>D<n><n>```<n>-4<n>+10<n>+3<n>+1.5<n>-14 =0<n>+1<n>+27<n>+7<n>+5<n>+32<n>+2<n>+10<n><n>+13<n>+32<n>-11<n>-10<n>+2<n><n>+51<n>```<n>

So the answer is among. The probability of drawing a nickel is 675/799 = 0.8434. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Rationales: If he babysits for 2 hours at $7 per hour, he will earn 2*7 = $<<2*7=14>>14<n>This week he will earn $5 allowance, $10 mowing the lawn and $14 from babysitting for a total of 5+10+14 = $<<5+10+14=29>>29<n>If we add the $29 he will earn to his $65 savings, he will have a total of 29 + 65 = $<<29+65=94>>94<n>The bike costs $100 and he will have $94 leaving $100-$94 = $<<100-94=6>>6 more that he will need to earn<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Rationales: His kangaroos have a total of 23*2=<<23*2=46>>46 legs<n>He has 23*3=<<23*3=69>>69 goats<n>The goats have 69*4=<<69*4=276>>276 legs<n>So in total his animals have 276+46=<<276+46=322>>322 legs<n>#### 322<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Rationales: After buying a hat, Josh has $20 - $10 = $<<20-10=10>>10<n>After buying a pencil, Josh has $10 - $2 = $<<10-2=8>>8<n>The total cost of cookies is 4 * $1.25 = $<<4*1.25=5>>5<n>After buying the cookies, Josh has $8 - $5 = $<<8-5=3>>3<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input:An expressway can suffer from traffic, this traffic gets worse the closer you get to any what? Choices:  A: michigan B: map C: american city D: rest stops E: country<n><n>### Response:		D<n>

She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Rationales: If he babysits for 2 hours at $7 per hour, he will earn 2*7 = $<<2*7=14>>14<n>This week he will earn $5 allowance, $10 mowing the lawn and $14 from babysitting for a total of 5+10+14 = $<<5+10+14=29>>29<n>If we add the $29 he will earn to his $65 savings, he will have a total of 29 + 65 = $<<29+65=94>>94<n>The bike costs $100 and he will have $94 leaving $100-$94 = $<<100-94=6>>6 more that he will need to earn<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Rationales: His kangaroos have a total of 23*2=<<23*2=46>>46 legs<n>He has 23*3=<<23*3=69>>69 goats<n>The goats have 69*4=<<69*4=276>>276 legs<n>So in total his animals have 276+46=<<276+46=322>>322 legs<n>#### 322<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Rationales: After buying a hat, Josh has $20 - $10 = $<<20-10=10>>10<n>After buying a pencil, Josh has $10 - $2 = $<<10-2=8>>8<n>The total cost of cookies is 4 * $1.25 = $<<4*1.25=5>>5<n>After buying the cookies, Josh has $8 - $5 = $<<8-5=3>>3<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input:What can someone feeling happiness fall into? Choices:  A: lead to laughter B: love C: laughter D: smiles E: tears<n><n>### Response:		<n>* Input: Mary had 88 stickers.  She added 41 stickers to her journal page that she gave to Sarah. She used 7 stickers each on 6 other pages of the journal. How many stickes does Mary have left?<n>* Rationales: Mary had 82 stickers to start with.  She had 41 stickers left after she added them to her journal page that sh gave Sarah.  The total number of 7 stickers each she added to 6 other pages is 7*4 = <<7*4=28>>28<n>She had 82 - 28 = <<82-28=54>>54 stickers that she started with<n>#### 54<n>Answer: 54<n><n>### Input<n>* Demonstration:Jillian has five quarters, four dimes, and six pennies.<n>* Rationales<n>* Input: The number of the bus is 63.  The number of seats in the bus is 87.<n><n>#### 87<n>Answer: 87<n><n>### Input 2<n>* Demonstratin: A: lead to laugh B: love C: laugher D: smile<n><n>### Response<n><n>#### 66<n>Answer: 1<n><n>### Input3 3<n>* Demonstrations:<n><n>### Rationales 2<n><n>#### 126 2<n>Answer: I think we can use both<n><n>### Input4 4<n>* Demostrations: A: lead to love B: love C: lead to laugh D: smiles E...<n><n>### Rationels(4): <n>A: Mary had 84 stickers.  She had 8 large stickers and used seven stickers each on six other pages of her journal, then she used two small stickers on the front cover. How many stickers are left?<n>* A: <n>    I think what we are given is in steps. So after Mary has the 8 large stickers, if she had 84 stickeers left, then she had (8 + 6 + 2) - 8 = 60 stickers left. She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn. Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Rationales: After buying a hat, Josh has $20 - $10 = $<<20-10=10>>10<n>After buying a pencil, Josh has $10 - $2 = $<<10-2=8>>8<n>The total cost of cookies is 4 * $1.25 = $<<4*1.25=5>>5<n>After buying the cookies, Josh has $8 - $5 = $<<8-5=3>>3<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input:The people in class were instructed to brainstorm ideas, how would they use their minds for this? Choices:  A: shake hands B: control events C: talk to each other D: think creatively E: dress themselves<n><n>### Response:		<n>A) A-hands have two choices to move around to show how they can use their minds.<n>B) C-People can talk to each other to learn about each other.<n>C) D-People use their minds when thinking creatively.<n>E) People use their brain to think so they can think creatively.<n>#### C<n>Answer: C<n>### Instruction Complete the following task.<n><n>### Task: Use the following instructions to create a set of cards that includes one of each of the following: a card that is number 1; one that is number 4; one that is numbered 7; and one that is number 3.  If you like you can create a set of cards for each number in the sequence.<n><n>### Rationale: <n><n>The set is: \begin{code}<n>1<2<3<4<5<2 <4<3\end{code}<n><n>The first has only one two and three which are only one each.<n><n>The next 2 has the two and the 3.<n><n>The next <4<3> has the 4 and the 3 and the missing number 1 and 7<n><n>When we combine the first two we got the last <2<3> which has the 2 of the two then a <3 <3 <3.<n><n>#### A = 1<2<3\-<4<3> <2<3> <4<3> <3<n>Answer: A=1<2<3-<4<3><2<3> <1<2<3>\<n>### Input:Create a mathematical expression showing one of each of the given number in the sequence.  The example is 5<10 or 7<6.<n><n>### Response :<n>For the pattern that you have given there is three patterns.<n><n>The first 5, it has 5 and 0 and 5.  10 has 5 as its next higher and 5 as its next lower.<n><n>The second 7, there is 7<8 it has 7 and 1 and 0.  6 has 7 and 8 as its next higher and next lower.<n><n>And the third 7 as its next higher and lowest 5.  <n>#### A= 5<10; 5<10

Choices:  A: communicating with others B: hurt feelings C: dry mouth D: intimacy E: changing behavior<n><n>### Response:		A<n>Answer:A<n><n>### Input:"Hi, can I have a dollar please?" How much change does a 10-dollar bill have? Choices:  a: 10 cents b: less than a dime c: less than five dollars d: less than a quarter e: you don't have a 10- dollar bill<n><n>### Response:"Sure!  I'll show you:  Let me use a pen to represent 10 dollars. So, if this pen were exactly the same as 10 dollars, then I could give you exactly 100 cents.""Ok, we have a 10 dollar pen?" (Confused - "Oh, you don't have one!  I'm sorry - let me borrow one from my friends." (Writes a 1 on the pen with a pen). "Ok, now I have a 10 - I have 10 tens, meaning that I have exactly 100 cent.  "So, you'll take 10 and I'll keep 10 for me." The person takes 10 cents and keeps nine. "I'll take one. So I have 9 and I'll show you how much one is." (Throws the pen in the air). "How many?" (Confused - takes the pen and throws it on the table." "This many? -  OK." (counts the total on the pen), "I have 9 and one." (Counts: 9+1=10). "Ah, that's one! Cool!"<n><n>### Response""Ok!  Let me show you how to write a zero.  So, when I hold my finger here, (holding up the pen) it represents a zero.  It's the same as a pen, but I'm not holding any ink in it." (Flips paper so that the zero pen is upright)."Let me write 9 tens, meaning that I now have ninety cents. (Makes the zero). Then I'll show you a one. (Picks the pen back up and throws it back on the table". "Let me redo this, so that it looks like this:  We have zero, then 9, then zero, then one, then zero.

They've just watched a TV and accomplished nothing.<n><n>###<n><n>### Input:"A man walks into a psychiatric hospital and claims to be Napoleon, but it has to be a false claim because I am a psychiatrist and I know he isn't."<n><n>#1.This man can't be a psychiatric patient if he can walk into an hospital<n><n>The person who said that can not be at the psychiatric hospital since she or he isn't a psychiatrist, but the man can be a patient of another hospital. <n><n>###<n>### Input:A man walks into the office and tells his secretary, “I am the result of 100 years of careful human breeding. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Rationales: If he babysits for 2 hours at $7 per hour, he will earn 2*7 = $<<2*7=14>>14<n>This week he will earn $5 allowance, $10 mowing the lawn and $14 from babysitting for a total of 5+10+14 = $<<5+10+14=29>>29<n>If we add the $29 he will earn to his $65 savings, he will have a total of 29 + 65 = $<<29+65=94>>94<n>The bike costs $100 and he will have $94 leaving $100-$94 = $<<100-94=6>>6 more that he will need to earn<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Rationales: His kangaroos have a total of 23*2=<<23*2=46>>46 legs<n>He has 23*3=<<23*3=69>>69 goats<n>The goats have 69*4=<<69*4=276>>276 legs<n>So in total his animals have 276+46=<<276+46=322>>322 legs<n>#### 322<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Rationales: After buying a hat, Josh has $20 - $10 = $<<20-10=10>>10<n>After buying a pencil, Josh has $10 - $2 = $<<10-2=8>>8<n>The total cost of cookies is 4 * $1.25 = $<<4*1.25=5>>5<n>After buying the cookies, Josh has $8 - $5 = $<<8-5=3>>3<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input:In the middle of the day what will someone do because of being hungry? Choices:  A: cook dinner B: make bread C: eat in restaurant D: have lunch E: make bread<n><n>### Response:		C: eat at a restaurant<n><n>### Reason:In order to know choices which would be suitable for someone who would be hungry,<n>he/she could compare their body of the person if he\she would be hungry, because<n>hunger would be bad for body, than choose the choice to satisfy it, like food, eating in a restaurant.<n><n><n>

His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Rationales: If he babysits for 2 hours at $7 per hour, he will earn 2*7 = $<<2*7=14>>14<n>This week he will earn $5 allowance, $10 mowing the lawn and $14 from babysitting for a total of 5+10+14 = $<<5+10+14=29>>29<n>If we add the $29 he will earn to his $65 savings, he will have a total of 29 + 65 = $<<29+65=94>>94<n>The bike costs $100 and he will have $94 leaving $100-$94 = $<<100-94=6>>6 more that he will need to earn<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Rationales: His kangaroos have a total of 23*2=<<23*2=46>>46 legs<n>He has 23*3=<<23*3=69>>69 goats<n>The goats have 69*4=<<69*4=276>>276 legs<n>So in total his animals have 276+46=<<276+46=322>>322 legs<n>#### 322<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Rationales: After buying a hat, Josh has $20 - $10 = $<<20-10=10>>10<n>After buying a pencil, Josh has $10 - $2 = $<<10-2=8>>8<n>The total cost of cookies is 4 * $1.25 = $<<4*1.25=5>>5<n>After buying the cookies, Josh has $8 - $5 = $<<8-5=3>>3<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input:Where can peanut butter be stored? Choices:  A: wedding B: friend's house C: internet cafe D: movie E: restaurant<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>#### My Rational:<n><n>Because the answer is D and the choices are:  A, B, C, D, E<n>Choices that don't make any sense:  A, wedding-Because they were doing something quiet<n>And they weren't going to a wedding.<n>Choices that make no sense C, internet cafe-Because no one goes into Internet Cafes for a quiet evening<n><n>When we solve this equation we get:<n><n>The first part is:  D=movie<n><n>When we do our equation we get:<n>E - D = E + D - E - D = E + C - E + D - E<n><n>E + C = C + D + E = C + E + D<n><n>C + E + D = H<n><n>H = D + E<n><n>E + D = E<n><n>E + E = D<n><n>D=movie

Using operators, make the variable into a negative number.<n>Input:<n>Your variable = <<1000>>1000<n>To change the variable's value to -<<1000>>-1000<n><n>#### -1000<n>#1000 becomes:<n>-<<1000;>>-1001<n>Answer: -1000 (no need to format)<n><n>#Change variables in a for loop:<n>#Input:  variable = 1 + 5 + 5*3<n>#In the for loop, the variables are always changed <n>#to whatever they are in the loop, no matter what the previous value was<n><n>#Ask the user what x is:<n>#Input: x = 2<n><n>#Change the value of the loop variable to x:<n># 12<n><n>#Sum it all up:<n>#24<n><n>### Input<n><n>#You

If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Rationales: His kangaroos have a total of 23*2=<<23*2=46>>46 legs<n>He has 23*3=<<23*3=69>>69 goats<n>The goats have 69*4=<<69*4=276>>276 legs<n>So in total his animals have 276+46=<<276+46=322>>322 legs<n>#### 322<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Rationales: After buying a hat, Josh has $20 - $10 = $<<20-10=10>>10<n>After buying a pencil, Josh has $10 - $2 = $<<10-2=8>>8<n>The total cost of cookies is 4 * $1.25 = $<<4*1.25=5>>5<n>After buying the cookies, Josh has $8 - $5 = $<<8-5=3>>3<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input:The man wanted to take a bus, but all the chars were full of people doing what? Choices:  A: sitting down B: refusing C: saving money D: sit down E: go outdoors<n><n>### Response:		<n>The correct option would be "doing what" - D. When a char is full of passengers it means: Doing what the passengers (the people sitting on it) did is: "Sit Down"<n><n>### Input and Demonstration:The man wanted to know what did the elephant did after he swam the 9 yards and he asked her to check each answer.<n><n>### Response and Demonstration<n>The correct option is "bounced and hugged the man" that is the sequence in which he did<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Rationales: If he babysits for 2 hours at $7 per hour, he will earn 2*7 = $<<2*7=14>>14<n>This week he will earn $5 allowance, $10 mowing the lawn and $14 from babysitting for a total of 5+10+14 = $<<5+10+14=29>>29<n>If we add the $29 he will earn to his $65 savings, he will have a total of 29 + 65 = $<<29+65=94>>94<n>The bike costs $100 and he will have $94 leaving $100-$94 = $<<100-94=6>>6 more that he will need to earn<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Rationales: His kangaroos have a total of 23*2=<<23*2=46>>46 legs<n>He has 23*3=<<23*3=69>>69 goats<n>The goats have 69*4=<<69*4=276>>276 legs<n>So in total his animals have 276+46=<<276+46=322>>322 legs<n>#### 322<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Rationales: After buying a hat, Josh has $20 - $10 = $<<20-10=10>>10<n>After buying a pencil, Josh has $10 - $2 = $<<10-2=8>>8<n>The total cost of cookies is 4 * $1.25 = $<<4*1.25=5>>5<n>After buying the cookies, Josh has $8 - $5 = $<<8-5=3>>3<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input:Though nearby, an apple from an apple tree where would be an imported product to the USA? Choices:  A: ohio B: washington state C: alaska D: canada E: flowers<n><n>### Response:		<n>The apple from the apple tree would be counted as an import because it would come from Canada<n><n>### Rationales:<n>#### Canada<n>Answer: Canada<n><n>### Input (13)<n>#### 3<n>3. Though nearby, an apple from the apple tree where would be a domestic product to the USA?<n>Though the apple tree is still in the USA, it is an import from Alaska.<n><n>### Rationale:<n>#### 4<n>Answer: 3 <n>4. Though nearby, a banana fruit grown on a banana tree where would be a local product?<n>The banana flower grown on the banana tree would be domestic.<n><n>### Input<n>5. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Rationales: If he babysits for 2 hours at $7 per hour, he will earn 2*7 = $<<2*7=14>>14<n>This week he will earn $5 allowance, $10 mowing the lawn and $14 from babysitting for a total of 5+10+14 = $<<5+10+14=29>>29<n>If we add the $29 he will earn to his $65 savings, he will have a total of 29 + 65 = $<<29+65=94>>94<n>The bike costs $100 and he will have $94 leaving $100-$94 = $<<100-94=6>>6 more that he will need to earn<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Rationales: His kangaroos have a total of 23*2=<<23*2=46>>46 legs<n>He has 23*3=<<23*3=69>>69 goats<n>The goats have 69*4=<<69*4=276>>276 legs<n>So in total his animals have 276+46=<<276+46=322>>322 legs<n>#### 322<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Rationales: After buying a hat, Josh has $20 - $10 = $<<20-10=10>>10<n>After buying a pencil, Josh has $10 - $2 = $<<10-2=8>>8<n>The total cost of cookies is 4 * $1.25 = $<<4*1.25=5>>5<n>After buying the cookies, Josh has $8 - $5 = $<<8-5=3>>3<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input:If done correctly grooming pet's nails generally does not cause this? Choices:  A: training B: satisfaction C: injury D: beauty E: late<n><n>### Response:		Answers a: 3<n><n>#### A<n><n>### Input 2:<n>While grooming her pet, Alice found a wolf spider on her dog. Her dog Oscar also loves math.  Riley’s favorite number is pi and Oscar’s favorite number is 42.  Riley was at the zoo and saw a lion who had a rattle to keep her from getting hungry when he couldn’t get her to eat.  Her favorite zoo animal is a moose.  Oscar saw 18 peacock feathers.  How many animals (including 3 turtles, 4 lizards and 14 tortoise) are in the zoo?<n><n>#### Answer: 42<n><n>### Inputs and answer:<n>Another Animal Math Problem:  A group of scientists went to a cemetery to study the types and numbers of worms there.  They counted 1 mouse, 12 rats, 6 frogs, 1 dog, 4 goats, 2 cats, and 1 pig.  What was the total number of animals there?<n><n>#### Answer 106<n><n>### Input, operations and answer:<n>A third Animal Math Problem<n><n>A group of scientists went out to the desert to study what animals live there.  They counted:  39 gophers, 99 birds, 19 scorpions, and 26 cacti.  What was the average total number of animals of that were studied?<n><n>#### Answer was 139.203<n><n>### Instructors:Answer each question below completely by adding the number 400<n><n>```<n>1. 600+800<n>2. 700 + 900<n>3. 1000 + 400<n>4. 500 + 1000<n>5. 100 + 2000 + 3000 + 6000<n>6. 3235<n>```<n><n>### Instinct:How tall is the tallest stack of pennies?<n><n>1. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Rationales: If he babysits for 2 hours at $7 per hour, he will earn 2*7 = $<<2*7=14>>14<n>This week he will earn $5 allowance, $10 mowing the lawn and $14 from babysitting for a total of 5+10+14 = $<<5+10+14=29>>29<n>If we add the $29 he will earn to his $65 savings, he will have a total of 29 + 65 = $<<29+65=94>>94<n>The bike costs $100 and he will have $94 leaving $100-$94 = $<<100-94=6>>6 more that he will need to earn<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Rationales: His kangaroos have a total of 23*2=<<23*2=46>>46 legs<n>He has 23*3=<<23*3=69>>69 goats<n>The goats have 69*4=<<69*4=276>>276 legs<n>So in total his animals have 276+46=<<276+46=322>>322 legs<n>#### 322<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Rationales: After buying a hat, Josh has $20 - $10 = $<<20-10=10>>10<n>After buying a pencil, Josh has $10 - $2 = $<<10-2=8>>8<n>The total cost of cookies is 4 * $1.25 = $<<4*1.25=5>>5<n>After buying the cookies, Josh has $8 - $5 = $<<8-5=3>>3<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input:where do children play a game? Choices:  A: toy store B: bar C: casino D: table E: family room<n><n>### Response:		<n>Input: toy store:<n><n>### A: In 2016, the NBA’s Miami Heat had the most all-star selections in the Eastern Conference in both game’s All-Star teams, earning 9.5 percent between All-Stars Hassan Whiteside (first team), Goran Dragic (three-way tie for third) and Dwyane Wade (first team and third place for the 2016 Most Valuable Player). <n>### B: Playing for points<n>### C: There is a casino game that is popular among children called Craps that is played in the family room or at the bar.  While the game does not involve risking money, the betting and the excitement can be very addictive.  It can be found in most family-based casinos.<n>### D: In our local table tennis facility’s club tournaments, the under sixteen group plays in the family room. <n>### E: I like playing the "where do you play games" game at your house and the local family room is a favorite because there are tables for adults playing and other tables for young children. <n>### Input: 2016 was an important year for American women’s basketball, where the team beat Serbia 125-116 to win the first FIBA Women’s 3x3 World Cup. <n>### Response: 2017 is the first year that an expansion team in the WNBA has joined a city other than New York, Charlotte, Chicago, Dallas, Houston, Los Angeles, Phoenix, Sacramento, Seattle, San Antonio, Washington, D.C., or Atlanta. <n>### A: Women's basketball has always been popular and they have one of the most famous players since 2016.<n>### B: It has taken us less than an hour to make 260 cookies, after getting the ingredients and rolling out the dough. <n>### C: This is how he can go from starting in basketball and later switching to play football.<n>### D :I like sports and you played basketball I played football.<n>### E: A lot of people enjoy hockey too, where this was a tough game.<n>### Input: I'm not sure if you're all
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Rationales: If he babysits for 2 hours at $7 per hour, he will earn 2*7 = $<<2*7=14>>14<n>This week he will earn $5 allowance, $10 mowing the lawn and $14 from babysitting for a total of 5+10+14 = $<<5+10+14=29>>29<n>If we add the $29 he will earn to his $65 savings, he will have a total of 29 + 65 = $<<29+65=94>>94<n>The bike costs $100 and he will have $94 leaving $100-$94 = $<<100-94=6>>6 more that he will need to earn<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Rationales: His kangaroos have a total of 23*2=<<23*2=46>>46 legs<n>He has 23*3=<<23*3=69>>69 goats<n>The goats have 69*4=<<69*4=276>>276 legs<n>So in total his animals have 276+46=<<276+46=322>>322 legs<n>#### 322<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Rationales: After buying a hat, Josh has $20 - $10 = $<<20-10=10>>10<n>After buying a pencil, Josh has $10 - $2 = $<<10-2=8>>8<n>The total cost of cookies is 4 * $1.25 = $<<4*1.25=5>>5<n>After buying the cookies, Josh has $8 - $5 = $<<8-5=3>>3<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input:Blood isn't usually spilled during what sport that doesn't allow the use of hands? Choices:  A: soccer game B: capillaries C: ball D: animals E: person<n><n>### Response:		<n>A: soccer game<n>Rationales: Soccer is a sport that doesn't usually have much bloodshed or blood spilled.<n><n>### Input:"13 of a group were called out for tardies. The three that were called out first were called twice and the next three were called 3 times, and in the same order as the first 3. How many more students will be called out?"<n><n>### Response:"If you solve for x, you will find that x = 89.  89 is the number of students who will be called out. 89 is prime, so there could be no more students in the class than 89."<n><n>### Input:(Question from book):  If Jake and Jenny have a total of 19 toys and they each have 4 bags of toys.  Jake has 3 red toys and 4 blue toys, 2 red and 1 green and 1 blue. If Jenny has 4 red, 1 blue and 3 green, how many green toys does Jenny have?<n><n>### Response:(Question from book):14. She has more red then Jenny.  There are a total of 3 red + 4 blue = <<3+4=7>>7 in all. There are 6 green in total.<n><n>### Response "9. She has more red than Jenny.  There is no red in the question, but there is one red toy in Jake's. Jake has 14 green toys. 14 + 3= <<14+3=17>>17. There are 8 green in total."<n><n>### Response(From the book): 5. She has 4 more blue than Jake (3 to Jake + 4 = +(4)). The question is missing the numbers, but the book has 6 red + 3 blue and 4 green. (6 x 6-5 = 8 left over (7 to 1 7 to 2 7 to 3). 5 red + 4 blue (3 to Jake, 2 to Jenny, and 1 to Jake). (5 red + 3 blue = 9 which leaves 1, 9 + 8 left: 9 + 8 = 17).  5
