Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Rationales: If he babysits for 2 hours at $7 per hour, he will earn 2*7 = $<<2*7=14>>14<n>This week he will earn $5 allowance, $10 mowing the lawn and $14 from babysitting for a total of 5+10+14 = $<<5+10+14=29>>29<n>If we add the $29 he will earn to his $65 savings, he will have a total of 29 + 65 = $<<29+65=94>>94<n>The bike costs $100 and he will have $94 leaving $100-$94 = $<<100-94=6>>6 more that he will need to earn<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Rationales: His kangaroos have a total of 23*2=<<23*2=46>>46 legs<n>He has 23*3=<<23*3=69>>69 goats<n>The goats have 69*4=<<69*4=276>>276 legs<n>So in total his animals have 276+46=<<276+46=322>>322 legs<n>#### 322<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Rationales: After buying a hat, Josh has $20 - $10 = $<<20-10=10>>10<n>After buying a pencil, Josh has $10 - $2 = $<<10-2=8>>8<n>The total cost of cookies is 4 * $1.25 = $<<4*1.25=5>>5<n>After buying the cookies, Josh has $8 - $5 = $<<8-5=3>>3<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input:James is apply for a job that he really wants. It hurt my elbow 3 years ago. <n><n>If you play tennis often, and you're not using proper technique, the constant twisting and turning of the wrists can lead to tennis elbow. <n><n>The tissue around the elbow joint is thick. The muscles in the forearm, and particularly in the wrist, attach to the bone on the outer side of the elbow. These muscles control the movement of the wrist with the hand.<n><n>The muscles are attached to the bone with thick fibrous tissue, called the ___________, which is a major source of the pain.<n><n>These symptoms can be caused by a number of acute injuries, such as falling on your outstretched hand or by repetitive injuries caused by over use.<n>### In each of the following pairs, choose the lettered sentence that contains an error in grammar or usage. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Rationales: If he babysits for 2 hours at $7 per hour, he will earn 2*7 = $<<2*7=14>>14<n>This week he will earn $5 allowance, $10 mowing the lawn and $14 from babysitting for a total of 5+10+14 = $<<5+10+14=29>>29<n>If we add the $29 he will earn to his $65 savings, he will have a total of 29 + 65 = $<<29+65=94>>94<n>The bike costs $100 and he will have $94 leaving $100-$94 = $<<100-94=6>>6 more that he will need to earn<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Rationales: His kangaroos have a total of 23*2=<<23*2=46>>46 legs<n>He has 23*3=<<23*3=69>>69 goats<n>The goats have 69*4=<<69*4=276>>276 legs<n>So in total his animals have 276+46=<<276+46=322>>322 legs<n>#### 322<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Rationales: After buying a hat, Josh has $20 - $10 = $<<20-10=10>>10<n>After buying a pencil, Josh has $10 - $2 = $<<10-2=8>>8<n>The total cost of cookies is 4 * $1.25 = $<<4*1.25=5>>5<n>After buying the cookies, Josh has $8 - $5 = $<<8-5=3>>3<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input:The cabinets were imported from the south. John bought they because he knew that they would look good.  Where might they be installed? Choices:  A: kitchen B: pantry C: containing pots and pans D: in a flight E: mexico<n><n>### Response:		What is an adjective that describes how the kitchen and pantry would each be used?<n><n>### Answer: <n>Answer: <n><n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100. B) not applicable to louisiana. C) south carolina is not a landlocked state. D) south carolina has no southern states at its borders. How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Rationales: If he babysits for 2 hours at $7 per hour, he will earn 2*7 = $<<2*7=14>>14<n>This week he will earn $5 allowance, $10 mowing the lawn and $14 from babysitting for a total of 5+10+14 = $<<5+10+14=29>>29<n>If we add the $29 he will earn to his $65 savings, he will have a total of 29 + 65 = $<<29+65=94>>94<n>The bike costs $100 and he will have $94 leaving $100-$94 = $<<100-94=6>>6 more that he will need to earn<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats. If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Rationales: His kangaroos have a total of 23*2=<<23*2=46>>46 legs<n>He has 23*3=<<23*3=69>>69 goats<n>The goats have 69*4=<<69*4=276>>276 legs<n>So in total his animals have 276+46=<<276+46=322>>322 legs<n>#### 322<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Rationales: After buying a hat, Josh has $20 - $10 = $<<20-10=10>>10<n>After buying a pencil, Josh has $10 - $2 = $<<10-2=8>>8<n>The total cost of cookies is 4 * $1.25 = $<<4*1.25=5>>5<n>After buying the cookies, Josh has $8 - $5 = $<<8-5=3>>3<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input:Where would you get a contraceptive if you do not have one? Choices:  A: health center B: vagina C: emergency room D: drawer E: medicine cabinet<n><n>### Response:		<n>Health Center<n><n>#### ##<n>Answer:
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Rationales: If he babysits for 2 hours at $7 per hour, he will earn 2*7 = $<<2*7=14>>14<n>This week he will earn $5 allowance, $10 mowing the lawn and $14 from babysitting for a total of 5+10+14 = $<<5+10+14=29>>29<n>If we add the $29 he will earn to his $65 savings, he will have a total of 29 + 65 = $<<29+65=94>>94<n>The bike costs $100 and he will have $94 leaving $100-$94 = $<<100-94=6>>6 more that he will need to earn<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Rationales: His kangaroos have a total of 23*2=<<23*2=46>>46 legs<n>He has 23*3=<<23*3=69>>69 goats<n>The goats have 69*4=<<69*4=276>>276 legs<n>So in total his animals have 276+46=<<276+46=322>>322 legs<n>#### 322<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Rationales: After buying a hat, Josh has $20 - $10 = $<<20-10=10>>10<n>After buying a pencil, Josh has $10 - $2 = $<<10-2=8>>8<n>The total cost of cookies is 4 * $1.25 = $<<4*1.25=5>>5<n>After buying the cookies, Josh has $8 - $5 = $<<8-5=3>>3<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input:Sam found a giant hole in the plain.  What might this hole be called? Choices:  A: hill B: gorge C: sandplain D: cliff E: mountain<n><n>### Response:		Choices:  A:  hill B:  gorge C:  sandplain D:  cliff E:  mountain E: Mountain<n><n>### Instructions:<n><n>In each task, you will respond to one question and one prompt. You only need to respond to 1 question.<n>

She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100. The first time Greg goes to his left he is 1 yard away from the spot his love lost.  He is in the East and goes 1 yard left<n>    This time he is 1 yard to the left of his love<n>2. The second time Greg goes to his right he is -1 yards away from the spot his lost his love<n>3. The third time he goes back to his left, this time -2 yards<n>    The 3rd time Greg goes to his east<n>4. Choices:  A: do crossword puzzle B: see art C: give up D: grocery shop E: play chess<n><n>### Response:		Answer "do crossword puzzle"<n><n>### Detailed Explanation:<n>In this lesson, one method of helping you learn better is to create your own rules.  This was a method I used to help me learn some foreign languages, and it is a method used with babies too.  Rationales are what we use to understand our rules.  In the example with the stickers, she put rules in place and when she broke them, she had to follow through to resolve them.  Rationales allow us to explain how we came to an answer and also allow us to check if our answer is correct.<n><n>When Josh bought the first hat and pencil, he had the $20. When he bought four cookies, he would have had $8, but at the time he bought the four cookies he used up the last of his $8 so the way to think is he had $10 or $20 - $8 = $<<20$-8=12>>12 for the cookies.  If he split it between the four cookies he now had $3 for each cookie.  That means that by the end when the boredom set in, he only had $.75 for each cookie.  Therefore, since the cookies cost $.75 each, he would have none left.  In this answer, all the rationales are used to come to the answer of $0.75.<n><n>### Inputs: 1) Josh is at the grocery store buying groceries and can afford a certain amount. 2) An item is on sale for $.50 each and he wants to buy 8 of them. 3) He has $15 in his wallet. 4) He has $20 in grocery money. 5) He can get change for $2 bills. 6) There is not a person behind the counter to ask a question.  <n>Rationales: 1) Josh can not use two or fewer bills in a single purchase. 2) Josh can not use fractional change such as $.01.<n>1st Input: Josh can not spend his last of $5 because there are no more bills left<n>1st Input: You can not use fractional bills when buying one item<n>1st Input: There is not a dollar amount to give as change<n>2nd Input:

Choices:  A: expect to die B: believe in god C: stay in D: watch movies E: eat corn<n><n>### Response:		I think people like to watch movies.<n><n>### Rationales:<n>When the question says people expect to die they are using _____, which means to believe or assume.<n>The correct choice should reflect what is actually written in the question and not what you think they meant.<n>#### 4<n>Answer: 7<n><n>### Input<n><n>Grace bought 7 packs of rats.  Each pack weighs 2 pounds.  Which type of conversion should Grace use to find the total number of pounds in her rats?<n><n>### Dem/Rat/Excl: Converting Fractions to a decimal is used to find or calculate with a ration.<n><n>### Exp: Use the conversion in the above to solve this problem.<n><n>*7 packs of ratz * 2 pounds=21 pounds*21 pounds*7 packs of ratz=147 pounds<n>Grace should buy 5+147 pounds*7 = 137.5 more rats*a single pack weighing 2 pounds each to have a total of 923 pounds.<n><n>#### 4<n><n>Answer: 4<n><n>### InputWhether it is to watch a movie or have a nice walk outdoors many people ___________?<n><n>### Response 1: I think they like to think they know everyone they come into contact with.<n><n>### Response2: I think many people like to watch movi.<n><n>### Answer2: 2<n><n>### Instructions<n><n>### Task<n><n>* The task is to write a response to complete the sentences and phrases that are given.<n><n>* The responses should be as close as possible to the given sentence.<n><n>* The answers should be as correct and complete as possible without being repetitive.<n><n>* You should refer to the sentence to determine the response.<n><n>### Constructive Feedback<n><n>* You need to have a response that agrees with the original sentence.<n><n>* You need a response with a complete sentence that has a subject, verb and a predicate.<n><n>* The response should have a subject that agrees with the sentence.<n><n>* An antecedent, noun phrase or pronoun are also needed.<n><n>* The pronoun needs to refer to the subject.<n><n>* The predicate

He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Rationales: If he babysits for 2 hours at $7 per hour, he will earn 2*7 = $<<2*7=14>>14<n>This week he will earn $5 allowance, $10 mowing the lawn and $14 from babysitting for a total of 5+10+14 = $<<5+10+14=29>>29<n>If we add the $29 he will earn to his $65 savings, he will have a total of 29 + 65 = $<<29+65=94>>94<n>The bike costs $100 and he will have $94 leaving $100-$94 = $<<100-94=6>>6 more that he will need to earn<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Rationales: His kangaroos have a total of 23*2=<<23*2=46>>46 legs<n>He has 23*3=<<23*3=69>>69 goats<n>The goats have 69*4=<<69*4=276>>276 legs<n>So in total his animals have 276+46=<<276+46=322>>322 legs<n>#### 322<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Rationales: After buying a hat, Josh has $20 - $10 = $<<20-10=10>>10<n>After buying a pencil, Josh has $10 - $2 = $<<10-2=8>>8<n>The total cost of cookies is 4 * $1.25 = $<<4*1.25=5>>5<n>After buying the cookies, Josh has $8 - $5 = $<<8-5=3>>3<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input:Where can the legs of a stool be built? Choices:  A: jail B: internet cafe C: blacksmith's shop D: building E: bar<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>Answer: (D )  <n><n>#### 328<n>Answer: 3.28<n><n>#### 1.13<n>Answer: 1.13
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Rationales: If he babysits for 2 hours at $7 per hour, he will earn 2*7 = $<<2*7=14>>14<n>This week he will earn $5 allowance, $10 mowing the lawn and $14 from babysitting for a total of 5+10+14 = $<<5+10+14=29>>29<n>If we add the $29 he will earn to his $65 savings, he will have a total of 29 + 65 = $<<29+65=94>>94<n>The bike costs $100 and he will have $94 leaving $100-$94 = $<<100-94=6>>6 more that he will need to earn<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Rationales: After buying a hat, Josh has $20 - $10 = $<<20-10=10>>10<n>After buying a pencil, Josh has $10 - $2 = $<<10-2=8>>8<n>The total cost of cookies is 4 * $1.25 = $<<4*1.25=5>>5<n>After buying the cookies, Josh has $8 - $5 = $<<8-5=3>>3<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input:What are students trying to do? One very simple action is choosing not to drink soda because it’s not a good source of energy and nutrition. Also, consuming breakfast is very important to stay organized not only when doing school work but when having any daily activities. <n><n>#### <n>Students need to plan ahead of time. One technique is to get a planner.  A planner might assist students in keeping track of their daily schedule and any appointments.  Another option is to create to-do lists.  To-do lists can help remind students of things they need to do and ensure they don't overlook them. Finally, it's critical that students prioritize their work.  By tackling the most challenging duties first, they may accomplish their goals more regularly.<n><n>#### 	<n>Answer:<n>D<n>Students can also take time to work. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Rationales: If he babysits for 2 hours at $7 per hour, he will earn 2*7 = $<<2*7=14>>14<n>This week he will earn $5 allowance, $10 mowing the lawn and $14 from babysitting for a total of 5+10+14 = $<<5+10+14=29>>29<n>If we add the $29 he will earn to his $65 savings, he will have a total of 29 + 65 = $<<29+65=94>>94<n>The bike costs $100 and he will have $94 leaving $100-$94 = $<<100-94=6>>6 more that he will need to earn<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Rationales: His kangaroos have a total of 23*2=<<23*2=46>>46 legs<n>He has 23*3=<<23*3=69>>69 goats<n>The goats have 69*4=<<69*4=276>>276 legs<n>So in total his animals have 276+46=<<276+46=322>>322 legs<n>#### 322<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Rationales: After buying a hat, Josh has $20 - $10 = $<<20-10=10>>10<n>After buying a pencil, Josh has $10 - $2 = $<<10-2=8>>8<n>The total cost of cookies is 4 * $1.25 = $<<4*1.25=5>>5<n>After buying the cookies, Josh has $8 - $5 = $<<8-5=3>>3<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input:If I screw a chain ring onto something, what am I fixing? Choices:  A: necklace B: wall outlet fixture C: tool box D: computer E: motorcycle<n><n>### Response:		I screw it onto something. If it is screwed onto something, it is securely or tightly fastened. A necklace is made up of several pieces, each of which can be separated from the rest. If I screw the chain ring onto something that supports the necklace, I fasten it so it cannot be pulled apart. If I loose my dog's leash, I can tie the leash to a secure object so that my dog is unable to wander off. In both cases, I have fastened the chain ring securely onto something.A tool box can fall apart, as can a motorcycle chain ring. If I fix something with a chain ring, I ensure that it securely attaches to the object to which I am screwing it on. If the chain ring is broken, I am fixing one by fastening a new one in its place.<n><n>### Input (Continued): The answer I choose is the correct answer.<n><n>### Response (Continued): If I screw the necklace onto something, it is fastened together.<n>#### 3<n>A=<<A=1>>1<n>B=<<B=1>>1<n>C=<<C=1>>1<n>D=<<D=1>>1<n>E=<<E=1>>1<n>Answer: 3

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Rationales: If he babysits for 2 hours at $7 per hour, he will earn 2*7 = $<<2*7=14>>14<n>This week he will earn $5 allowance, $10 mowing the lawn and $14 from babysitting for a total of 5+10+14 = $<<5+10+14=29>>29<n>If we add the $29 he will earn to his $65 savings, he will have a total of 29 + 65 = $<<29+65=94>>94<n>The bike costs $100 and he will have $94 leaving $100-$94 = $<<100-94=6>>6 more that he will need to earn<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. Choices:  A: home team B: present C: at home D: come back E: charming<n><n>### Response:		home<n><n>#### charming<n><n>## Task:<n><n>### Instructions:Answer the following multiple choices question.<n>input: Billy's mother, Billy's father and Billy were in a room.<n><n>Billy's father was sitting on the chair.<n><n>Billy was on the chair and his mother was standing.<n><n>output: Billy's father was not on the chair.<n>Rationales:<n>input: Billy was on chair. output:  Billy's father was in the chair and Billy's mother was standing.<n>input: Billy was standing and his mother was on chair.<n><n>output:  Billy's mother was not on the chair., Billy's father was on the chair and Billy was standing.<n>input-output relation: output: chair <n> input: Billy was in the chair and his mother and father were standing.<n><n>output(in the same line): father and mother were not standing, Billy was standing and he was on the chair.<n>input: Billy and his parents were standing at the chair.<n><n>output(on different lines): father was in the chair; mother was standing; Billy was standing<n>input: Billy' s mother was sitting on the chair and Billy and his father were standing.<n>output: Billy' s mother and Billy's father were standing and Billy was sitting on the chair<n>input: Billy' father and his mother were in the chair and Billy was sitting and standing.<n>output:  Billy was not standing and Billy's mother and father were sitting <n><n><n>### Input-output relation: Output:  Billy' s mother was not on chair<n><n>### Response<n>A: input: Billy's father on the chair.<n>Output: Billy's father are in the chair<n>Rationale: If father is on the chair, Billy and his mother are standing<n><n>B: input: Billy on chair and his mother were not on chair. <n>Output: Billy' s mothers are in the chair<n><n>C:  input: Billy on chair, his mother were standing. <n>output: Billy' mother was not on chair.  mother and father were in the chair<n><n>D:  input: Billy was not on chair, mother were standing.  father were not in chair<n>Output:  Mother was in the chair, Billy was not standing.<n>```<n>Billy's mother was standing<n>Billy was on chair<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Rationales: If he babysits for 2 hours at $7 per hour, he will earn 2*7 = $<<2*7=14>>14<n>This week he will earn $5 allowance, $10 mowing the lawn and $14 from babysitting for a total of 5+10+14 = $<<5+10+14=29>>29<n>If we add the $29 he will earn to his $65 savings, he will have a total of 29 + 65 = $<<29+65=94>>94<n>The bike costs $100 and he will have $94 leaving $100-$94 = $<<100-94=6>>6 more that he will need to earn<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Rationales: His kangaroos have a total of 23*2=<<23*2=46>>46 legs<n>He has 23*3=<<23*3=69>>69 goats<n>The goats have 69*4=<<69*4=276>>276 legs<n>So in total his animals have 276+46=<<276+46=322>>322 legs<n>#### 322<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Rationales: After buying a hat, Josh has $20 - $10 = $<<20-10=10>>10<n>After buying a pencil, Josh has $10 - $2 = $<<10-2=8>>8<n>The total cost of cookies is 4 * $1.25 = $<<4*1.25=5>>5<n>After buying the cookies, Josh has $8 - $5 = $<<8-5=3>>3<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input:Where do most people keep magazines? How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Rationales: If he babysits for 2 hours at $7 per hour, he will earn 2*7 = $<<2*7=14>>14<n>This week he will earn $5 allowance, $10 mowing the lawn and $14 from babysitting for a total of 5+10+14 = $<<5+10+14=29>>29<n>If we add the $29 he will earn to his $65 savings, he will have a total of 29 + 65 = $<<29+65=94>>94<n>The bike costs $100 and he will have $94 leaving $100-$94 = $<<100-94=6>>6 more that he will need to earn<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Rationales: His kangaroos have a total of 23*2=<<23*2=46>>46 legs<n>He has 23*3=<<23*3=69>>69 goats<n>The goats have 69*4=<<69*4=276>>276 legs<n>So in total his animals have 276+46=<<276+46=322>>322 legs<n>#### 322<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Rationales: After buying a hat, Josh has $20 - $10 = $<<20-10=10>>10<n>After buying a pencil, Josh has $10 - $2 = $<<10-2=8>>8<n>The total cost of cookies is 4 * $1.25 = $<<4*1.25=5>>5<n>After buying the cookies, Josh has $8 - $5 = $<<8-5=3>>3<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input:How can buildings like the Empire State building be described? Choices:  A: small B: underground C: high D: huge E: tall<n><n>### Response:		<n>You are correct because: Empire State building is tall.  Empire State building is very high.   Empire State building is big.<n><n>### Choices:A: small B: undergrounC: high D: hugeE: tall<n><n>## Below is a command that describes a task.<n><n>### Command:The first task is to make a string. You should be able to use the string as a parameter to the other task.<n><n>## To complete the tasks, follow this instruction:<n><n>### Task1 - Make a string.<n><n>### Task2 - Create a variable and copy the string.<n><n>## # Below is a command that asks a question.<n><n>## # Response<n><n>## # Input:Create at least one expression with two operands. You may also need the variable to evaluate the expression.<n><n>## # For example, the following two expressions have both of the required elements:<n><n>## # 4 * x<n><n>## # 5 + yz<n><n>## # But the following do not:<n><n>## # "Hello"<n><n>## # 1<n><n>## # You can start building your expression in your own words.  After you have written something, you can save your work by pressing ENTER.  That automatically creates a new statement.  To add more statements, simply type them in.<n><n>## # When you have finished composing a question, create one final statement using the following:<n><n>## # Input + Expression + Output = Answer<n><n>## # Input is the expression you entered above, which includes one or more operations.<n><n>## # Expression includes both binary and unary operands, including the variable.<n><n>## # Output is the answer to the original expression.<n><n>### Input + Expression + Output<n><n>### Input is The first task is to make another variable, create another string and copy the string.  The second task is to evaluate the expression.  The third task is to apply the expression to the new variable while creating the output string.<n><n>## Input + Expression + Output - Response<n>#### 3<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Rationales: If he babysits for 2 hours at $7 per hour, he will earn 2*7 = $<<2*7=14>>14<n>This week he will earn $5 allowance, $10 mowing the lawn and $14 from babysitting for a total of 5+10+14 = $<<5+10+14=29>>29<n>If we add the $29 he will earn to his $65 savings, he will have a total of 29 + 65 = $<<29+65=94>>94<n>The bike costs $100 and he will have $94 leaving $100-$94 = $<<100-94=6>>6 more that he will need to earn<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Rationales: His kangaroos have a total of 23*2=<<23*2=46>>46 legs<n>He has 23*3=<<23*3=69>>69 goats<n>The goats have 69*4=<<69*4=276>>276 legs<n>So in total his animals have 276+46=<<276+46=322>>322 legs<n>#### 322<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Rationales: After buying a hat, Josh has $20 - $10 = $<<20-10=10>>10<n>After buying a pencil, Josh has $10 - $2 = $<<10-2=8>>8<n>The total cost of cookies is 4 * $1.25 = $<<4*1.25=5>>5<n>After buying the cookies, Josh has $8 - $5 = $<<8-5=3>>3<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input:John was stuck in his house. What is Dexter’s name?<n><n>### Demonication3:<n>Answer letter is the object of affection or love, especially when unrequited:<n><n>Letter B is spice for food:<n><n>Dex - ter, Dex = Dexter<n><n>Letter C is a male given name:<n><n>Dex = Dexter, Dex = D (D is Male given name)<n><n>Letter D is a common last name:<n><n>Deter = Dexter, (Letter D)<n><n>Letter E sounds similar to D:<n><n>Letter E has no pun.<n>#### D<n>Answer D<n><n>### Instructions: What is the best time for a group of 25 people to travel from one train station to another if each train holds 50 passengers, but only 40 seats, and a train must arrive at every station for a total of 10 stations?<n><n>### Rationales:<n>Letter E has only one word : E = Easy<n><n>Because travel can be easy:<n><n>If each train holds 5 people and can hold 50 passengers, this gives a total of 150:<n><n>5*50 = << 250 >><n><n>Letter F is a hard, 3

If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Rationales: His kangaroos have a total of 23*2=<<23*2=46>>46 legs<n>He has 23*3=<<23*3=69>>69 goats<n>The goats have 69*4=<<69*4=276>>276 legs<n>So in total his animals have 276+46=<<276+46=322>>322 legs<n>#### 322<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Rationales: After buying a hat, Josh has $20 - $10 = $<<20-10=10>>10<n>After buying a pencil, Josh has $10 - $2 = $<<10-2=8>>8<n>The total cost of cookies is 4 * $1.25 = $<<4*1.25=5>>5<n>After buying the cookies, Josh has $8 - $5 = $<<8-5=3>>3<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input:The gambler had been winning a lot, he wisely decided to what? Choices:  A: matchwinning B: cash in C: compete D: return E: celebrate<n><n>### Response:		Matchwinning<n><n>### Instructions:The gambler who has been winning a lot will wisely B, C D or E?<n><n>### Demostration:Input: The gambler had been a losing streak.She had been losing alot lately.She was lucky to see the dealer’s face. She wisely decided to end the game.So what did she do? Choices: 1:Match the winning Cards. 2: Compete over money. 3: Compete over time. 4: Return the money. 5: Celebrate her win.<n>Rationales: The gambler who had been a losing streaks, decided to end the game because she doesn't want to continue winning or losing.So that's where her response is "C:Compete over money."<n>```<n>----------------------------------------------------------<n>#### 3<n>Input:<n>The gambler who had a winning streak, wisely decided to.... Choices: 1. Match the winning cards. 2. Compete over money.<n>3. Compete over time.<n>4. Return the money.<n>5. Celebrate her wins!<n>Rationales:<n><n>The gambler had a winning streak.So she wisely decided to match the winning cards.<n>```<n>#### 3<n><n>## Input:<n>Kate had a total of 123 stickers. She gave 8 large stickers away on her family trip.  She used 7 stickers on each of 7 other pages of her journal in which she wrote about her trip.  How many stickers does she have left?<n><n><n>--------------<n><n>## Instruction<n><n>Rationales:  Total=<<123>>123-8*7=<<123-56>>67She had 67 left.<n><n>### Output:<n>Rationales: Kate had a total of 67 stickers left, but she only has 25 left.<n><n>--------------<n>## Instruction<n>Input: Sam bought a bike for $100. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Rationales: If he babysits for 2 hours at $7 per hour, he will earn 2*7 = $<<2*7=14>>14<n>This week he will earn $5 allowance, $10 mowing the lawn and $14 from babysitting for a total of 5+10+14 = $<<5+10+14=29>>29<n>If we add the $29 he will earn to his $65 savings, he will have a total of 29 + 65 = $<<29+65=94>>94<n>The bike costs $100 and he will have $94 leaving $100-$94 = $<<100-94=6>>6 more that he will need to earn<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Rationales: His kangaroos have a total of 23*2=<<23*2=46>>46 legs<n>He has 23*3=<<23*3=69>>69 goats<n>The goats have 69*4=<<69*4=276>>276 legs<n>So in total his animals have 276+46=<<276+46=322>>322 legs<n>#### 322<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Rationales: If he babysits for 2 hours at $7 per hour, he will earn 2*7 = $<<2*7=14>>14<n>This week he will earn $5 allowance, $10 mowing the lawn and $14 from babysitting for a total of 5+10+14 = $<<5+10+14=29>>29<n>If we add the $29 he will earn to his $65 savings, he will have a total of 29 + 65 = $<<29+65=94>>94<n>The bike costs $100 and he will have $94 leaving $100-$94 = $<<100-94=6>>6 more that he will need to earn<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Rationales: His kangaroos have a total of 23*2=<<23*2=46>>46 legs<n>He has 23*3=<<23*3=69>>69 goats<n>The goats have 69*4=<<69*4=276>>276 legs<n>So in total his animals have 276+46=<<276+46=322>>322 legs<n>#### 322<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Rationales: After buying a hat, Josh has $20 - $10 = $<<20-10=10>>10<n>After buying a pencil, Josh has $10 - $2 = $<<10-2=8>>8<n>The total cost of cookies is 4 * $1.25 = $<<4*1.25=5>>5<n>After buying the cookies, Josh has $8 - $5 = $<<8-5=3>>3<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input:A person writes a check to a clerk, where does the clerk put them? Choices:  A: cash register B: desk drawer C: pay envelope D: throw away E: box<n><n>### Response:		Answer the following multiple-choice question.<n>#### Question and Answer:<n>* A: cash register<n>* B: desk dra<n>* C: pay envelope<n>* D: throw away<n>* E: box<n><n>Answer: A<n><n>Input: A person writes a check to another person, where do they put it? Choices: A: in the mailbox B: in a pouch C: in an envelope D: in the trash E: on a table<n><n>Answer: A
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Rationales: If he babysits for 2 hours at $7 per hour, he will earn 2*7 = $<<2*7=14>>14<n>This week he will earn $5 allowance, $10 mowing the lawn and $14 from babysitting for a total of 5+10+14 = $<<5+10+14=29>>29<n>If we add the $29 he will earn to his $65 savings, he will have a total of 29 + 65 = $<<29+65=94>>94<n>The bike costs $100 and he will have $94 leaving $100-$94 = $<<100-94=6>>6 more that he will need to earn<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Rationales: His kangaroos have a total of 23*2=<<23*2=46>>46 legs<n>He has 23*3=<<23*3=69>>69 goats<n>The goats have 69*4=<<69*4=276>>276 legs<n>So in total his animals have 276+46=<<276+46=322>>322 legs<n>#### 322<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Rationales: After buying a hat, Josh has $20 - $10 = $<<20-10=10>>10<n>After buying a pencil, Josh has $10 - $2 = $<<10-2=8>>8<n>The total cost of cookies is 4 * $1.25 = $<<4*1.25=5>>5<n>After buying the cookies, Josh has $8 - $5 = $<<8-5=3>>3<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input:What is love when everyone keeps feeling it? Choices:  A: contagious B: wrong C: last forever D: painful E: blind<n><n>### Response:		B<n><n>### Instructions:Read the input and then respond correctly.<n>### Input: What is love when everyone keeps making it?  Choices: A: contagious  B: wrong  C: last forever  D: painful  E: blind<n><n>* You have to pay attention to the sentence carefully because the two question was a little bit different.<n><n>* You can check the options below to make sure that you responded correctly.<n><n>#### Answer:D<n><n>> A: contagious<n>> <n>> B: wrong<n>> <n>> C: last forever<n><n>Output from the above:<n><n>**Contagious:** Love is contagious. If you act loving, everyone around you will act loving. They'll do nice little things for you like leaving notes or flowers in your favorite places. It's like a contagion in a sense with your love being the virus.<n><n>**Wrong:** Love is wrong. Your heart isn't even on your sleeve. Even if you tell the truth and the truth hurts, you'll be seen as cruel and thought of as cold. People will only see the side of you that's hurt them, and with your heart off your sleeve there isn't much else that can be seen.<n><n>**Last Forever:** Love is forever. It will last forever, and it won't die. If someone tells you they love you, don't be scared by it, as it might not be true, or you might not have meant it when you said it. Don't be afraid to have feelings of love for someone when you are older either, because that doesn't necessarily make your feelings fake.<n><n>**Painful:** Love is painful. Love is so hard and heart-breaking that your heart will ache and feel like it will fall out at any moment. The pain may lessen over time, but it doesn't ever go away.<n><n>**Blind:** Love is blind. You'll love even the wrong people. You may not even notice your own shortcomings because you love unconditionally.<n><n>You have to pay attention to each question carefully when trying to answer these questions correctly.<n><n>### Reference:<n>- https://www.khanacademy.org/partner-contentp/money
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Rationales: If he babysits for 2 hours at $7 per hour, he will earn 2*7 = $<<2*7=14>>14<n>This week he will earn $5 allowance, $10 mowing the lawn and $14 from babysitting for a total of 5+10+14 = $<<5+10+14=29>>29<n>If we add the $29 he will earn to his $65 savings, he will have a total of 29 + 65 = $<<29+65=94>>94<n>The bike costs $100 and he will have $94 leaving $100-$94 = $<<100-94=6>>6 more that he will need to earn<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Rationales: His kangaroos have a total of 23*2=<<23*2=46>>46 legs<n>He has 23*3=<<23*3=69>>69 goats<n>The goats have 69*4=<<69*4=276>>276 legs<n>So in total his animals have 276+46=<<276+46=322>>322 legs<n>#### 322<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Rationales: After buying a hat, Josh has $20 - $10 = $<<20-10=10>>10<n>After buying a pencil, Josh has $10 - $2 = $<<10-2=8>>8<n>The total cost of cookies is 4 * $1.25 = $<<4*1.25=5>>5<n>After buying the cookies, Josh has $8 - $5 = $<<8-5=3>>3<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input:Billy bounced the ball off the wall.  There was a target on the wall for him to bounce against.  Where might he be? Choices:  A: pool table B: toy box C: playroom D: park E: closet<n><n>### Response:		<n>A.  pool table<n><n>### Input<n>Sam wants to see as many concerts as he possibly can.  Which concert will he see twice? Choices:  a concert that has 80 bands b concert that has 55 bands c concert that has 10 bands d concert that has 15 bands<n><n>### Response<n>a concert that has 88 bands.<n><n>### InputBilly’s mom gave him $8 and let him keep 20% of the money he earned. He sold his favorite baseball cards and lost 20% of his money. But he finally finished the week with $7.55. What is the value of the baseball cards? How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Rationales: If he babysits for 2 hours at $7 per hour, he will earn 2*7 = $<<2*7=14>>14<n>This week he will earn $5 allowance, $10 mowing the lawn and $14 from babysitting for a total of 5+10+14 = $<<5+10+14=29>>29<n>If we add the $29 he will earn to his $65 savings, he will have a total of 29 + 65 = $<<29+65=94>>94<n>The bike costs $100 and he will have $94 leaving $100-$94 = $<<100-94=6>>6 more that he will need to earn<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Rationales: His kangaroos have a total of 23*2=<<23*2=46>>46 legs<n>He has 23*3=<<23*3=69>>69 goats<n>The goats have 69*4=<<69*4=276>>276 legs<n>So in total his animals have 276+46=<<276+46=322>>322 legs<n>#### 322<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Rationales: After buying a hat, Josh has $20 - $10 = $<<20-10=10>>10<n>After buying a pencil, Josh has $10 - $2 = $<<10-2=8>>8<n>The total cost of cookies is 4 * $1.25 = $<<4*1.25=5>>5<n>After buying the cookies, Josh has $8 - $5 = $<<8-5=3>>3<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input:What would you normally expect a cat to say? Choices:  A: see king B: hello C: meow D: drink water E: live many years<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>### Input<n>Question: What is an animal that lives on land not in water?<n><n>### Response<n>A: dog or cow<n><n>### Input 2<n>Question: How many sticks does the stick man have left if he gave half away? 3+2=<<3+2=5>>5 sticks<n><n>### Input Response2<n>How does the answer make sense? It doesn't make cents. How many more would you get if you had more sticks? More<n><n>### Input3<n>Question: How many years does the cat live?<n><n>### InputResponse 3<n>2+1=<<2+1=3>>3<n><n>### Demostration<n>Input: What is an animal?<n>Rationales<n>A: A cat<n>#### 1<n>Answer: 3+2=2<n><n>### Instructions:<n>Answer the following multiple choice questions.<n><n><n>|A| What does the following word look like?<n><n>| 1|Aardvark<n>| 2|  Antelope<n>| 3|  Bear<n>| 4|  Bee<n>| 5|  Boat<n><n>|B|What kind of vehicle do you see in the following word?<n><n>| 6| A  Truck  <n>| 7| B Car<n>| 8| C Pick-up<n>| 9|D Van<n>| 10| E SUV<n><n>|C|How many legs do elephants have?<n><n>| 0| TWO<n>| 1| TWO HALF<n>| 2| THREE<n><n>### Answer: 8 8 08
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Rationales: If he babysits for 2 hours at $7 per hour, he will earn 2*7 = $<<2*7=14>>14<n>This week he will earn $5 allowance, $10 mowing the lawn and $14 from babysitting for a total of 5+10+14 = $<<5+10+14=29>>29<n>If we add the $29 he will earn to his $65 savings, he will have a total of 29 + 65 = $<<29+65=94>>94<n>The bike costs $100 and he will have $94 leaving $100-$94 = $<<100-94=6>>6 more that he will need to earn<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Rationales: His kangaroos have a total of 23*2=<<23*2=46>>46 legs<n>He has 23*3=<<23*3=69>>69 goats<n>The goats have 69*4=<<69*4=276>>276 legs<n>So in total his animals have 276+46=<<276+46=322>>322 legs<n>#### 322<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Rationales: After buying a hat, Josh has $20 - $10 = $<<20-10=10>>10<n>After buying a pencil, Josh has $10 - $2 = $<<10-2=8>>8<n>The total cost of cookies is 4 * $1.25 = $<<4*1.25=5>>5<n>After buying the cookies, Josh has $8 - $5 = $<<8-5=3>>3<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input:Where will a native lemur be found? Choices:  A: india B: hole C: cage D: habitat E: rain forest<n><n>### Response:		D<n>**Input:** <n><n>### Answer:<n><n>**A: india**<n><n>**B: hole**<n><n>**C: cage**<n><n>**D: habitat**<n><n>**E: rain forest**<n><n>**Answer:** D<n><n>### Input 2: <n><n>### Response 2:<n><n>### Input :<n><n>### Answer<n><n>**Answer 3:** D<n><n>**A:** E<n><n>**B:** C<n><n>**C:** B<n><n>**D:** A<n><n>**E:** This is a trap<n><n># Rational<n>- The rational explains why the method is true. It explains the procedure.<n>- The rationale makes a statement of the end result.<n>- The rationall tells of the procedures and why we do it.<n>- The rational describes the calculations and how they were calculated.<n>- The ratios shows how to make the steps<n>---<n>><n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Rationales: If he babysits for 2 hours at $7 per hour, he will earn 2*7 = $<<2*7=14>>14<n>This week he will earn $5 allowance, $10 mowing the lawn and $14 from babysitting for a total of 5+10+14 = $<<5+10+14=29>>29<n>If we add the $29 he will earn to his $65 savings, he will have a total of 29 + 65 = $<<29+65=94>>94<n>The bike costs $100 and he will have $94 leaving $100-$94 = $<<100-94=6>>6 more that he will need to earn<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Rationales: His kangaroos have a total of 23*2=<<23*2=46>>46 legs<n>He has 23*3=<<23*3=69>>69 goats<n>The goats have 69*4=<<69*4=276>>276 legs<n>So in total his animals have 276+46=<<276+46=322>>322 legs<n>#### 322<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Rationales: After buying a hat, Josh has $20 - $10 = $<<20-10=10>>10<n>After buying a pencil, Josh has $10 - $2 = $<<10-2=8>>8<n>The total cost of cookies is 4 * $1.25 = $<<4*1.25=5>>5<n>After buying the cookies, Josh has $8 - $5 = $<<8-5=3>>3<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input:Turkey is a nation in what part of the world? His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Rationales: If he babysits for 2 hours at $7 per hour, he will earn 2*7 = $<<2*7=14>>14<n>This week he will earn $5 allowance, $10 mowing the lawn and $14 from babysitting for a total of 5+10+14 = $<<5+10+14=29>>29<n>If we add the $29 he will earn to his $65 savings, he will have a total of 29 + 65 = $<<29+65=94>>94<n>The bike costs $100 and he will have $94 leaving $100-$94 = $<<100-94=6>>6 more that he will need to earn<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Rationales: His kangaroos have a total of 23*2=<<23*2=46>>46 legs<n>He has 23*3=<<23*3=69>>69 goats<n>The goats have 69*4=<<69*4=276>>276 legs<n>So in total his animals have 276+46=<<276+46=322>>322 legs<n>#### 322<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Rationales: After buying a hat, Josh has $20 - $10 = $<<20-10=10>>10<n>After buying a pencil, Josh has $10 - $2 = $<<10-2=8>>8<n>The total cost of cookies is 4 * $1.25 = $<<4*1.25=5>>5<n>After buying the cookies, Josh has $8 - $5 = $<<8-5=3>>3<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input:If people are vegetarian, what do they do more of? Choices:  A: believe in god B: sun themselves C: eat hamburgers D: gain wealth E: eat plants<n><n>### Response:		Choice C<n><n>Answer:<n>If people are vegetarian that means they eat plants.<n>Plants grow more in water.<n><n>So A,B,E don't make sense.<n>That leaves option c, which is the correct answer.<n><n>### Input<n>If people are vegetarians, what do They do more of? Choice A:  believe in god, choice B:  sun themselves, Choice  C: eat hamburger, choice  D: gain wealth, choice E:  eat plants.<n><n>Rationales:  Answer choices A,C,D are impossible:<n><n>C: If people are vegetarian, they eat plants. So plants grow more in water. There is no point in more watering or sunning one's plants if one follows a vegetarian schedule.<n><n>B: There is no point in sunning one's self more if one is a vegetarian.<n><n>A:  So if one is vegetarian (eats plants), there is no reason to want to believe in God, because there is nothing to worship.<n><n>D: Again, vegetarianism itself means that there is no need for more income.<n><n>E:  Answer choice E is the only answer where vegetarianism is relevant.<n><n>### Response<n>Choice D:  gain wealth<n><n>Answer:<n>Eating plants is what vegetarians do.<n>Therefore they need more income.<n><n>Answer choices C and D have the correct reasoning.<n><n>### If people are vegetarians what do they do more?<n><n>Rationales for Choice A:  Believe in God<n><n>Answer choice B:  Sun themselves<n><n>Answer choice E:  Eat plants.<n><n>Answer choice C: Eat hamburgers<n><n>Answer choice D: Gain wealth<n><n>### Choice A: Believe in god, choice B sunn themselves, choice  C: eat hamba burger, choice  D: Gain wealth, choice E: eat plants.<n><n>### Choices and rationales<n>A Believe in god<n>Think A is possible.<n><n>B Sun themselves<n>Is B possible or do people gain from sunning themselves when they are not vegetarian since you can gain wealth by sunning yourself and you can gain wealth by believing in god.<n><n>C Eat hamburg<n>C makes more sense because veget
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Rationales: If he babysits for 2 hours at $7 per hour, he will earn 2*7 = $<<2*7=14>>14<n>This week he will earn $5 allowance, $10 mowing the lawn and $14 from babysitting for a total of 5+10+14 = $<<5+10+14=29>>29<n>If we add the $29 he will earn to his $65 savings, he will have a total of 29 + 65 = $<<29+65=94>>94<n>The bike costs $100 and he will have $94 leaving $100-$94 = $<<100-94=6>>6 more that he will need to earn<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Rationales: His kangaroos have a total of 23*2=<<23*2=46>>46 legs<n>He has 23*3=<<23*3=69>>69 goats<n>The goats have 69*4=<<69*4=276>>276 legs<n>So in total his animals have 276+46=<<276+46=322>>322 legs<n>#### 322<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Rationales: After buying a hat, Josh has $20 - $10 = $<<20-10=10>>10<n>After buying a pencil, Josh has $10 - $2 = $<<10-2=8>>8<n>The total cost of cookies is 4 * $1.25 = $<<4*1.25=5>>5<n>After buying the cookies, Josh has $8 - $5 = $<<8-5=3>>3<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input:What do humans do when they want to reproduce? Choices:  A: eat ice cream B: have sex C: sit down D: make mistakes E: hear sounds<n><n>### Response:		<n>A. Incorrect choice!  This is an incorrect choice.   <n><n>### Demonsration:<n>Input: Jack bought 89 apples and he had 58 apples left.  He ate 10 apples after that.  He then lost 11 apples and gave 25 apples away. Which fraction is best to describe how many apples he had after that?<n>Rationales (The correct answer): If he started with 89 apples, he now has 89-58 = 31.  If he ate 10 then he now has 88-58 = 26.  If he lost 11 then he now has 26-11 = 15.  And if he gave away 25 apples then he now has 15-25= << -3>> -3.<n>In order to get the fraction, we use: << 88/31= RATIONAL/NOMINAL --> 2.75738 * 2.75962 --> 2.76000<n>Answer: 2.76<n><n>Input: Jill's father tells her he's going to get a new dog but it's going to cost him $125 for getting it. He is going to pay his credit card $50 a month if he waits to get the dog. He takes 6 months to pay it off so it will cost him $300.  Is it cheaper for Jill's father to wait than to buy it now?<n>Rationales(The correct answer): If we subtract the $125 credit card bill for month 1 from the $300 credit card bill for month number 12, we get $300 - $125 = <<300-125=175>>$. If we take that amount and calculate the monthly cost for 3 months, we would have $175 / 3 = $<<175/3=58>>$. Therefore Jill's father is better off to wait for that $58<n><n>Answer: Yes!<n><n>Input: Mary is working to save up enough money to buy a new iPhone 8. She's trying to earn $60 by

She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100. He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Rationales: If he babysits for 2 hours at $7 per hour, he will earn 2*7 = $<<2*7=14>>14<n>This week he will earn $5 allowance, $10 mowing the lawn and $14 from babysitting for a total of 5+10+14 = $<<5+10+14=29>>29<n>If we add the $29 he will earn to his $65 savings, he will have a total of 29 + 65 = $<<29+65=94>>94<n>The bike costs $100 and he will have $94 leaving $100-$94 = $<<100-94=6>>6 more that he will need to earn<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats. Choices:  A: injuries B: fatigue C: traffic jams D: tired E: accidents<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>### Rationales:Driving while distracted or distracted driving by definition means being inattentive and disregarding risks.  As a driver, you have to always stay attentive and alert.  Driving while being tired can affect how you react on the road. It can lead to you falling asleep behind the steering wheel.  Being inattentive is reckless driving and it can lead to many accidents.<n><n>#### A<n>Answer:A<n><n>## #9. <n>Write a response that appropriately responds to the question.<n><n>## #10.<n>Write a response that completes the task. How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Rationales: If he babysits for 2 hours at $7 per hour, he will earn 2*7 = $<<2*7=14>>14<n>This week he will earn $5 allowance, $10 mowing the lawn and $14 from babysitting for a total of 5+10+14 = $<<5+10+14=29>>29<n>If we add the $29 he will earn to his $65 savings, he will have a total of 29 + 65 = $<<29+65=94>>94<n>The bike costs $100 and he will have $94 leaving $100-$94 = $<<100-94=6>>6 more that he will need to earn<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Rationales: His kangaroos have a total of 23*2=<<23*2=46>>46 legs<n>He has 23*3=<<23*3=69>>69 goats<n>The goats have 69*4=<<69*4=276>>276 legs<n>So in total his animals have 276+46=<<276+46=322>>322 legs<n>#### 322<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Rationales: After buying a hat, Josh has $20 - $10 = $<<20-10=10>>10<n>After buying a pencil, Josh has $10 - $2 = $<<10-2=8>>8<n>The total cost of cookies is 4 * $1.25 = $<<4*1.25=5>>5<n>After buying the cookies, Josh has $8 - $5 = $<<8-5=3>>3<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input:The new kitten hadn't gotten used to what it was allowed to climb on in most rooms, so the owned kept the bedroom door what? Choices:  A: opened B: closed C: found at shower D: falling down E: locked<n><n>### Response:		<n>A: closed<n><n>C: falling down<n><n>E: locked<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Rationales: If he babysits for 2 hours at $7 per hour, he will earn 2*7 = $<<2*7=14>>14<n>This week he will earn $5 allowance, $10 mowing the lawn and $14 from babysitting for a total of 5+10+14 = $<<5+10+14=29>>29<n>If we add the $29 he will earn to his $65 savings, he will have a total of 29 + 65 = $<<29+65=94>>94<n>The bike costs $100 and he will have $94 leaving $100-$94 = $<<100-94=6>>6 more that he will need to earn<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Rationales: His kangaroos have a total of 23*2=<<23*2=46>>46 legs<n>He has 23*3=<<23*3=69>>69 goats<n>The goats have 69*4=<<69*4=276>>276 legs<n>So in total his animals have 276+46=<<276+46=322>>322 legs<n>#### 322<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Rationales: After buying a hat, Josh has $20 - $10 = $<<20-10=10>>10<n>After buying a pencil, Josh has $10 - $2 = $<<10-2=8>>8<n>The total cost of cookies is 4 * $1.25 = $<<4*1.25=5>>5<n>After buying the cookies, Josh has $8 - $5 = $<<8-5=3>>3<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input:Where do you keep a teakettle? Choices:  A: cupboard B: countertop C: water D: hardware department E: england<n><n>### Response:		If you were to go into a store, what is the first place you would go to find a teakettle?(B)<n><n>### Response/Question:How do teakettles work?(A)<n><n>### Demand:Answers:<n>Answer:If you were to go into A: Cupboard for a teakettle, then you would go to the B in the water section<n>#### Response: C countertop A:B<n>

Her budget was $55.  She also gave $1 each night to her younger sister.  After she had 11 items, she did not have enough money for the bread ($3.50). How much did she buy?<n>Rationales<n><n>Her budget was $55<n><n>After she bought 11 items, her budget was $55 - 11 = $ <<55-11=44>>45<n><n>After, she gave $1 each night  to her younger sister, she had $45 - 14 = $ <<45-14=31>>32<n><n>Because, she had 31 left in her purse, but she only had $3.50 for bread, she spent $3.50, she spent 10.50 more<n><n>So she bought 4 apples<n><n>#### 4 apples<n>Answer: 4 apples<n>

Choices:  A: footloose B: sailing C: fast D: tighten E: bind<n><n>### Response:		E<n>### Rationales<n>The wheel was loose and would have fallen of if they hadn't attached binding.<n><n>#### E<n>Answer: 💞E<n><n>### Input:"Let's get down to the last six-digit numbers you wrote," said the math teacher.  "You'd better go over your work again because I see an extra six on a couple of those answers."  "Oh, that's easy," said Dara.  "I figured it out this way.  If I wanted to find the area of the square that's four meters on a side, would I measure its perimeter or its height?"  "What do you mean?" asked the teacher.  "Well, it's about the same as if you take a square and break it into triangles," explained Dara.<n><n>### Response:"I was breaking up all of those numbers into smaller segments in order to come up with a formula for the overall answer."<n><n>### Rational<n><n><n>Dara realized she used a similar logic that she used to get the answer to the previous problem.<n><n>#### Rationales:<n>1. In the previous problem she used the height of the triangle (2) to get the bottom of triangle (2/3 in her expression to make the numbers easier to find).<n>2. Here she used the perimeter of the triangle (4) to the get the perimeter of the whole triangle (4+2+2)<n>3. Notice that instead of squaring the top of the triangle (4), she squared the bottom (2/3) because squaring a number in the denominant of the fraction will give the result of the whole fraction (2)<n>4. The area of a square is equal to the squared length * the length of the sides.<n>5. When we squared lengths of the sides of the triangle to 1, we got 4 to which she added the 2 which was the perimeter of each segment that makes up the whole triangle to get the final answer<n>6. This is what justifies why she took the perimeter of every triangle since each 2 and 2 and 2 in the denominant of 2, 1/3 and 1/6 are squared to get the lengths 4, 4 and 4.<n><n>#### R:<n><n>*R:*<n>Dara came with her own
